headline: S.E.C. BEGINS FORMAL INVESTIGATION OF NINE WEST
abstract: Nine West Group Inc says Securities and Exchange Commission has started formal investigation of company policies for recording revenue (S)

headline: German Insurers Address Lawsuit Over Policies Seized by Nazis
abstract: Germany's life insurance companies are seeking to distance themsleves from suit filed in New York seeking up to $1 billion in compensation for prewar policies confiscated from Jews; say they believe bulk of such cases in Germany were settled in 1950's; vow any outstanding claims will be processed quickly and not bureaucratically (M)

headline: Stuart Troup, 63, Ex-IHT Editor And Writer, Dies
abstract: PARIS—  Stuart Troup, 63, a versatile writer, critic and editor who worked for newspapers in the United States and Europe, died Wednesday in Valhalla, New York.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Cellnet Data Systems Inc., San Carlos, Calif., to Grey Advertising, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle advertising for the wireless communications network. Billings were estimated at $3 million.  * Zila Inc., Phoenix, to the Landmark Group Inc., Eatontown, N.J., to handle advertising and marketing for Oratest, an oral-cancer detection system, which is pending marketing approval from the Food and Drug Administration. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

headline: In Unusual Move, F.C.C. Chief Criticizes a Possible Deal
abstract: Federal Communications Commission Chmn Reed E Hundt, in unusual bid to scuttle merger between AT&T Corp and SBC Communications before it is even proposed, is expected to declare AT&T merger with regional Bell telephone company 'unthinkable' under antitrust laws; explains stand, interview; photo (M)

headline: PERKINS FAMILY RESTAURANTS' STOCK SLIDES 15 PERCENT
abstract: Shares of Perkins Family Restaurants LP fall more than 15 percent after Perkins, the restaurant chain, says it might eliminate its cash distribution because of Federal law requiring it to be taxed as a corporation starting next year (S)

headline: Lode of Brazilian Nationalism: A State Mine Goes Private
abstract: News analysis of unexpected court-ordered delay in Brazilian Government's sale of 45 percent of state-owned mining company, Vale do Rio Doce; Government expects to earn $5 billion in what is billed as largest privatization ever in South America, but plan is being fought with barrage of legal challenges, backed by popular protests (S)

headline: If at First You Don't Succeed, Turn to Netscape or Microsoft for Help
abstract: Profile of Voxware Inc, company typical of dozens of fledgling Internet start-ups that followed in footsteps of Netscape; Voxware's goal of translating human speech into digital language of computers and then decoding it for listening attracted $1 million investments, and its initial public offering raised $20 million; but company's promising start has yet to be translated into financial success; investors have retreated sharply from second-tier Internet start-ups, in part because of reconsideration of commercial outlook for Internet in general; whether Voxware thrives, or even survives, depends on how skillfully company executes its strategy and how quickly markets for telephony, conferencing and broadcasting on Internet develop; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Blair Urges New Way for Europe's Left
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair, on his third European excursion in two weeks, brashly counsels a gathering of continent's Socialist leaders in Sweden to discard dogma 'or die,' and tells Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Bonn that European Union is out of touch with its own people; addressing European Social Democratic Parties' Congress in Malmo, Blair declares 'Stay as we are and we fail'; Gallup Poll published in Daily Telegraph shows that Blair has approval rating of 82 percent, highest ever achieved by any British Prime Minister (M)

headline: ANALYST'S REPORT PUSHES ORACLE STOCK HIGHER
abstract: Stock of Oracle Corp rises in heavy trading after Goldman, Sachs & Co analyst Rick Sherlund speculates that company is on the verge of making an acquisition; stock rises $1.625, to $45.9375 (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: List of major articles in Business section

headline: Stock Trades: A Better Deal For Investors Isn't Simple
abstract: Market Place column on 'best execution,' benign concept that means that brokers must try to do their best to make sure that when customers buy a stock they pay lowest price available and when they sell a stock they get highest price; says no one seems to agree on exactly what 'best execution' entails, or exactly how to achieve it; holds that is not surprising, considering that there are millions of dollars at stake for investors, brokerage firms and stock exchanges; holds Congressional lawmakers, who commissioned report by Securities and Exchange on arcane ways of stock trading, were put up to it by New York Stock Exchange, which contends that practices by rival exchanges--Cincinnati and Boston--favor brokerage firms over their customers; SEC says it is not necessarily so (L)

headline: I.R.S. Criticized Harshly in Judge's Ruling
abstract: Federal Judge William P Downes awards $250,000 in punitive damages to Carole Ward whose family business, Kids Avenue clothing stores in Colorado Springs, Colo, was raided by armed Internal Revenue Service agents four weeks after Ward insulted IRS agent; revenue agents padlocked the stores and posted notices that some customers interpreted as evidence that Ward was drug smuggler; Downes found that IRS agent James Dolan was 'grossly negligent' and acted with 'reckless disregard' for the law, and that he made three false statements in sworn declaration; Downes also awards Ward $75,000 in actual damages plus lawyers' fees; IRS and Justice Department decline comment (L)

headline: Nerds Inc. Turns Typos Into On-Line Advertising
abstract: ''Tommy if you don't learn how to spell you are not going to get anywhere. . . .''    At the risk of making Mom really mad by contradicting her in public, it must be reported that poor spellers and bad typists can get somewhere, thanks to a new friend on the Internet.

headline: Writing Seems to Be on the Wall, But Tory Chief Chooses to Ignore It
abstract: Prime Min John Major is ignoring polls that show him running as much as 20 points behind his Labor Party opponent, Tony Blair, in Britain's May 1 election; is crisscrossing country trying to spur Conservative Party as he has in past; people say they are weary of 18 consecutive years of Tory rule and dismayed at corruption in party's parliamentary ranks (M)

headline: Wage Pressures Accompany Growth in Productivity
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports productivity of American businesses grew at annual pace of 2 percent in first quarter, best performance in more than three years; says hourly compensation at nonfarm businesses rose at annual pace of 4.7 percent, while unit labor costs edged up to rate of 2.7 percent; Federal Reserve survey of economic conditions finds fresh instances of rising wages during March and April even though overall 'upward wage pressures remained generally subdued'; second Federal Reserve report shows that consumers added to outstanding installment debt at 2 percent annual pace in March, smallest since September and les than one-quarter as fast as average of first two months of the year; map; table; graphs (L)

headline: As Flows to Mutual Funds Increase, So Do Cash Levels
abstract: Investment Company Institute reports that $15.7 billion flowed into stock funds in April, well above previous estimate of $13.5 billion and March total of $10.7 billion; bond funds took in $786 million, partly reversing previous month's net outflows of $2 billion; Dow Jones industrial average falls 27.05 points, to 7,330.18, while Standard & Poor's 500 index drops 3.13 points, to 844.08; Nasdaq composite index drops 7.14 points, to 1,403.04; table (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Tinkerbell Inc., Northvale, N.J., a subsidiary of Renaissance Cosmetics Inc., to Burkhardt & Hillman, New York, to handle the reintroduction of the company's cosmetics, toiletries and accessories for girls. There had been no previous agency. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

headline: EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
abstract: Equitable Companies says first-quarter earnings rose 57 percent; company earned $136 million, compared with $86.6 million in year-earlier period; table (S)

headline: Microsoft Took WebTV Risk, Despite Loss
abstract: Microsoft Corp decision to pay $425 million for WebTV Networks Inc, maker of set-top boxes that bring Internet to television sets, reflects calculated bet on making money from mass-market television audience as television becomes digital (S)

headline: New Refugee Crisis Builds in Zaire
abstract: New refugee crisis is unfolding as thousands of Rwandan refugees, who have braved harsh jungle for eight months to escape Zairian rebels, are now massed for exodus into neighboring Congo; Congo, fearing war will spill into its territory, is reluctant to admit refugees; international aid groups are ill prepared to help them; fears intensify as rebels take Mbandaka; over 50,000 refugees are clustered near town; massacres reportedly have begun; map (M)

headline: B.J.K.& E. Creates Health Care Unit
abstract: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has consolidated all of its health care marketing and communications divisions under new entity, called Bozell Wellness Worldwide in New York (S)

headline: Surfing for Satisfaction: Consumer Complaints Go on Line
abstract: Internet as new venue for disgruntled consumers to vent complaints discussed; photo of Catherine Stanton, who aired problem with Blockbuster Video and got redress; Internat can be powerful tool for circulating damaging or false information as well, raising questions about how First Amendment rights apply to Web (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department begins weekly reports on United States crops.

headline: ZIONS BANCORPORATION TO BUY SUN STATE CAPITAL
abstract: Zions Bancorporation agrees to buy Sun State Capital Corp for about $37 million, a move that strengthens its presence in Nevada (S)

headline: A Guilty Plea In Fraud Case
abstract: Edward A McKay, president of brokerage firms Buttonwood Securities Inc and Securities Planners Inc, pleads guilty to stealing $50,000 from client and agrees to cooperate with New York Attorney General's probe of A R Baron & Co; allegedly helped Baron manipulate price of certain securities and maintain its net capital position by pretending to buy large amounts of stock from Baron (S)

headline: Bonds Drop For a 2d Day; Job Data Cited
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities, with exception of shorter maturities, declined on bond markets on June 25 for second consecutive day; benchmark 30-year bond fell 17/32, to 98 2/32, to yield 6.78 percent; graphs (M)

headline: Kohl Insists on Start in 1999 Of Single European Currency
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany seeks to dispel fears in other governments that Germany's stubborn budget deficit could delay or derail start for single European currency; Kohl says he will stake his 'political existence' on punctual start in 1999; some economists interpret his remarks as sign that he is ready to back off from rigid fiscal requirements for taking part in single currency system, now that Germany is itself on brink of failing to meet euro entry standards (M)

headline: 16 Palestinians Marked for Death for Selling Land, Israelis Say
abstract: Haaretz, Israeli newspaper, says Israeli security forces have information that 16 Palestinians involved in selling land to Jews have been marked for death, including three land dealers already killed during past month (M)

headline: VOXWARE STOCK GAINS ON NEWS OF DEAL WITH MICROSOFT
abstract: Stock of Voxware Inc gains 22 percent after Microsoft Corp licenses its voice and audio compression technologies; terms undisclosed; stock gains 87.5 cents, to close at $4.875 (S)

headline: Publisher Builds Strategy on Diversification
abstract: International Data Group, producer of technology publications, plans series of public offerings of stock in company's businesses; Patrick McGovern, founder and chairman, is hoping that Wall Street will put substantial price on IDG's fastest-growing parts, thus increasing value of entire company; stock offerings are aimed at raising capital for new projects at various business units; company faces some serious challenges; growth in its largest business--technology publishing--has slowed as result of crush of new publications and competition from Internet; photo (M)

headline: Airlines Are Cracking Down on Delayed Departures
abstract: Airlines are pressing to improve on-time performance by putting new stress on taking off on time; are getting tough on late-arriving passengers; adhering closely to schedules gives airlines competitive edge and saves high cost of aiding passengers who miss connections because of delays; table; graphs; photo (L)

headline: In a further push into Latin America, DDB Needham is buying a stake in a Brazilian agency.
abstract: DDB Needham Worldwide to acquire majority stake in DM9 Publicidade, Brazilian advertising agency; will rename firm DM9 DDB; move reflects growing interest in Latin American market (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Apr. 11   Apr. 4   Apr. 12          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.4   7.7   7.3       Distillate production, daily   3.4   3.4   3.1       Gasoline stocks   199.7   196.0   202.5       Distillate stocks   101.0   98.4   89.4       Crude imports, daily   7.8   8.3   7.6       Product imports, daily   2.2   2.1   2.1       Crude stocks   311.4   308.4   300.0       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   93.6   94.3   91.6          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Cross Timbers Oil Co, Fort Worth oil and gas developer, acquires properties in Oklahoma, Kansas and Texas from Burlington Oil and Gas Co for $39.5 million (S)

headline: Union Pacific Resources Turns Hostile in Pennzoil Bid
abstract: Union Pacific Resources begins hostile $4 billion offer for Pennzoil Co, which rejected earlier friendly bid; merger would further petroleum industry consolidation; Pennzoil shares soar; Union Pacific chief executive Jack L Messman comments, interview; graph (M)

headline: Judge Says Canada Can Deport Suspect in Lethal Saudi Bombing
abstract: Canadian judge upholds deportation order against Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, Saudi terror suspect, opening way for US to question him about bombing of American military complex near Dhahran in 1996 in which 19 airmen died; backs findings by intelligence service that al-Sayegh was involved in attack; FBI Director Louis J Freeh says agency is interested in questioning al-Sayegh about bombing (M)

headline: AGOURON PHARMACEUTICALS TO ACQUIRE DRUG RESEARCHER
abstract: Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc agrees to buy Alanex Corp, privately held drug company, for about $63 million in stock (S)

headline: S.E.C. BEGINS FORMAL INVESTIGATION OF NINE WEST
abstract: Nine West Group Inc says Securities and Exchange Commission has started formal investigation of company policies for recording revenue (S)

headline: German Insurers Address Lawsuit Over Policies Seized by Nazis
abstract: Germany's life insurance companies are seeking to distance themsleves from suit filed in New York seeking up to $1 billion in compensation for prewar policies confiscated from Jews; say they believe bulk of such cases in Germany were settled in 1950's; vow any outstanding claims will be processed quickly and not bureaucratically (M)

headline: Stuart Troup, 63, Ex-IHT Editor And Writer, Dies
abstract: PARIS—  Stuart Troup, 63, a versatile writer, critic and editor who worked for newspapers in the United States and Europe, died Wednesday in Valhalla, New York.

Billings were estimated at $3 million.  * Zila Inc., Phoenix, to the Landmark Group Inc., Eatontown, N.J., to handle advertising and marketing for Oratest, an oral-cancer detection system, which is pending marketing approval from the Food and Drug Administration. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

abstract: Federal Communications Commission Chmn Reed E Hundt, in unusual bid to scuttle merger between AT&T Corp and SBC Communications before it is even proposed, is expected to declare AT&T merger with regional Bell telephone company 'unthinkable' under antitrust laws; explains stand, interview; photo (M)

abstract: Shares of Perkins Family Restaurants LP fall more than 15 percent after Perkins, the restaurant chain, says it might eliminate its cash distribution because of Federal law requiring it to be taxed as a corporation starting next year (S)

headline: Lode of Brazilian Nationalism: A State Mine Goes Private
abstract: News analysis of unexpected court-ordered delay in Brazilian Government's sale of 45 percent of state-owned mining company, Vale do Rio Doce; Government expects to earn $5 billion in what is billed as largest privatization ever in South America, but plan is being fought with barrage of legal challenges, backed by popular protests (S)

headline: If at First You Don't Succeed, Turn to Netscape or Microsoft for Help
abstract: Profile of Voxware Inc, company typical of dozens of fledgling Internet start-ups that followed in footsteps of Netscape; Voxware's goal of translating human speech into digital language of computers and then decoding it for listening attracted $1 million investments, and its initial public offering raised $20 million; but company's promising start has yet to be translated into financial success; investors have retreated sharply from second-tier Internet start-ups, in part because of reconsideration of commercial outlook for Internet in general; whether Voxware thrives, or even survives, depends on how skillfully company executes its strategy and how quickly markets for telephony, conferencing and broadcasting on Internet develop; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Blair Urges New Way for Europe's Left
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair, on his third European excursion in two weeks, brashly counsels a gathering of continent's Socialist leaders in Sweden to discard dogma 'or die,' and tells Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Bonn that European Union is out of touch with its own people; addressing European Social Democratic Parties' Congress in Malmo, Blair declares 'Stay as we are and we fail'; Gallup Poll published in Daily Telegraph shows that Blair has approval rating of 82 percent, highest ever achieved by any British Prime Minister (M)

headline: ANALYST'S REPORT PUSHES ORACLE STOCK HIGHER
abstract: Stock of Oracle Corp rises in heavy trading after Goldman, Sachs & Co analyst Rick Sherlund speculates that company is on the verge of making an acquisition; stock rises $1.625, to $45.9375 (S)

headline: Bozell Acquires Health Agency
abstract: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt acquires Mediphacs Inc, an advertising agency specializing in health care education services; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Disclosure Spurs Drop in Alkermes Shares
abstract: Shares in Alkermes Inc lose nearly a third of their value after company discloses that a study of its drug delivery agent in patients with brain tumors fails to meet its primary goal; Alkermes had developed technology called RMP-7 that was intended to allow drugs to selectively penetrate blood-brain barrier that normally protects brain from chemicals or pathogens (S)

headline: S.E.C. Narrows Prudential Case
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission closes investigations into activities of at least six former employees of Prudential Securities Inc because of statute of limitations established by court decision last year; probes, by SEC offices in Atlanta and Fort Worth, focused on serious supervisory lapses and fraudulent sales practices at Prudential's Dallas and Atlanta branch offices in 1980's and early 1990's (S)

headline: 2 Struggling Banks To Merge in Japan
abstract: Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, one of Japan's leading commercial banks, plans to buy rival Hokkaido Bank, which has market value of 6 billion yen ($496 million) (S)

headline: Deal to Create A Big Chain In Elder Care
abstract: Rapid consolidation of nursing home industry continues; Genesis Health Ventures Inc says it has agreed to buy Multicare Companies Inc for $1.06 billion in cash, creating one of biggest chains of homes and outpatient services for elderly in northern New Jersey, Boston area, Pennsylvania and West Virginia; deal, subject to regulatory approval, would create new company, Genesis Eldercare Acquisition Corp; in addition to nursing homes, combined company will provide day care centers, home health care and prescription drugs for nursing home patients; photo (M)

headline: CAPSTAR BROADCASTING TO COMBINE WITH GULFSTAR
abstract: Capstar Broadcasting Partners agrees to acquire sister radio-station company, Gulfstar Communications Inc; details undisclosed (S)

headline: Computing Giants Join Electronic Games Show
abstract: Computer giants Intel Corp and Microsoft Corp took key part in recent Electronic Entertainment Expo, Atlanta, trade show begun two years ago by video game companies; sought to promote personal computer as game platform and to impress potential partners and competitors; photo (M)

headline: Japan's View Of Rising Yen: Not to Worry
abstract: Japan's yen has strengthened against the dollar by almost 10 percent in last two weeks, moving from 126.70 yen to 115.60 yen to the dollar; dollar falls as low as 113.95 yen in trading on May 20; strengthening of yen is welcome by Japanese exporters and economists; Japan's economy has in many ways become more international than ever so that at certain levels, a weak yen hurts more than a stronger one; graph (L)

headline: Phoenix Building Is Sold
abstract: Viad Corp sells its 24-story headquarters in Phoenix, Ariz, for $73 million to a company that manages foreign reserves for Singapore (S)

headline: BANKBOSTON SELLS GANIS CREDIT TO UNIT OF DEUTSCHE BANK
abstract: Deutsche Financial Services, a unit of Deutsche Bank AG of Germany, acquires Gain Credit Corp for $30 million from BankBoston Corp (S)

headline: Palestinians Free Reporter Held for Week
abstract: Daoud Kuttab, a Palestinian journalist who was detained a week ago evidently because his broadcasts had angered Yasir Arafat, was released tonight by the Ramallah police. He said he was never interrogated, charged, or told why he was held.    ''I have no regrets for what I did, and I will continue doing what I did,'' Mr. Kuttab said as he left the Ramallah police station.

headline: Royal Caribbean Agrees To Acquire Celebrity Lines
abstract: Royal Caribbean International will to buy Celebrity Cruise Lines from Chandris Group and Overseas Shipholding Group Inc for $230 million in cash and some $270 million in stock and assume $800 million in debt (M)

headline: A Bank Swallows Another Brokerage Firm
abstract: BankAmerica Corp's acquisition of Robertson, Stephens & Co underlines current attraction that young entrepreneurial investment banks hold for big commercial banks, as brokerage and banking industries continue their rapid consolidation; table (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Frank Marinaro Jr. was named to the new position of president of Halo Strategic Planning, Hauppauge, N.Y., a division of Halo Group. He had been president of FMA, Dix Hills, N.Y., a consulting company, which closed.  * Janice Grossman, president for advertising and marketing at the K-III consumer magazine division of the K-III Communications Corp., New York, was named to handle additional duties for publications including American Baby and Modern Bride. She assumes those responsibilities from Judith Princz, vice president and group publisher, who left. Ms. Grossman was also promoted to executive vice president for the consumer magazine division, a new position.

headline: Finding success in television has become a nightmare for Dreamworks.
abstract: THOUGH the Dreamworks studio has yet to release its first movie, you could have found an especially scary title playing at the studio's headquarters in recent weeks. It was called ''A Nightmare on Television Row.''    In this installment, Freddie Krueger turned up to slash the schedule board listing the Dreamworks television productions. By the time it was over, the carnage was extensive:

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             May 9   May 2   May 10   1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   8.1   7.8   7.8       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.6   3.2       Gasoline stocks   197.1   190.5   203.0       Distillate stocks   96.5   97.6   90.6       Crude imports, daily   7.6   8.1   8.6       Product imports, daily   1.9   2.0   2.5       Crude stocks   322.6   315.7   299.7       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.6       Refinery utilization (%)   96.9   94.5   92.2          (Source: American Petroleum Institute)

headline: Rehearing Denied in Municipal-Bond Case
abstract: Federal Court of Appeals in Denver, Colo, has denied Justice Department petition to rehear case that overturned conviction of Robert Cochran, former municipal-bond executive with Stifel, Nicolaus & Co in Oklahoma City; decision could be serious blow to regulators' powers in municipal bond market; court denied Government's petition to rehear the case before full court (S)

headline: On-Line Shopper Challenges the On-Foot Variety
abstract: In some parts of the country, consumers can do their grocery shopping on-line through services offered by companies like Illinois-based Peapod. To see how the shopping experience of an on-line shopper compared with that of a traditional on-foot shopper, The New York Times set up a race against the clock. Here is the scenario: It's 10 A.M. and a long-lost friend calls. She will be in town tomorrow, and our shopper invites her and her husband to dinner. Our shoppers decides to serve vichyssoise with aoili and grilled salmon with asparagus, pea and lime potato salad.

headline: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN SHARES FALL ON EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: Stock of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc drops more than 13 percent after drug company says first-quarter earnings per share will fall 16 percent from level a year earlier; company also expects to report 6 percent drop in sales for the quarter ended March 31 (S)

headline: Work on Ziploc Shifts to BBDO
abstract: Dowbrands, unit of Dow Chemical Co, names BBDO Chicago to handle creative and media planning responsibilities for its Ziploc brand storage bags, which had been handled by Campbell Mithun Esty; billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million (S)

headline: Finally, Air France Reports Annual Profit
abstract: Air France Group posts its first annual profit in seven years in year ended March 31; company earned 394 million French francs ($67 million); concern's airline, which accounts for 90 percent of sales, made profit of 211 million francs; revenue rose 8.3 percent, to 42.7 billion francs (S)

headline: Radio Technology Fails To Win U.S. Acceptance
abstract: Radio Data Systems, 'smart' radios that can tune stations by format, interrupt cassette or regular programming for important announcements and print out data transmitted by stations, has not won acceptance in United States; failure comes despite early success in Europe and East Asia and strong push by Consumer Electronics Manufacturers Association and some of its members (M)

headline: NBC TO OFFER INTERNET SITE GEARED TO LOCAL STATIONS
abstract: NBC says it will offer its 215 television stations an Internet site that features telephone directories, restaurant and real estate listings and other services geared to local areas; Infoseek Inc will sell advertising for site (S)

headline: Stock Investor Enthusiasm Seen Ebbing
abstract: Investment Company Institute says preliminary figures show stock funds took in about $9.5 billion over all in March, down from $18.5 billion in February, a 49 percent drop; in comparison with March 1996, when a net $21.3 billion came in, contrast was even sharper, a fall of 55 percent; Dow Jones industrial average falls 23.79 points, to 6,540.05; since peaking at 7,085.16 on March 11, Dow has lost 545 points, or about 7.7 percent; for the year, index has gained 92 points, or about 1.4 percent (L)

headline: A Strong Debut Helps, as a New Chief Tackles Sony's Movie Problems
abstract: John Calley discusses his success so far in turning around troubled Sony Pictures Entertainment, interview; firm's two studios, Columbia Pictures and Tristar Pictures, have brought in combined $447 million at box office so far this year, record pace for film industry; graphs; photo (L)

headline: DAILEY PETROLEUM TO ACQUIRE TWO DRILLING CONCERNS
abstract: Dailey Petroleum Services Corp says it will acquire two closely held drilling services companies for total of $112.5 million in cash and assumed debt; companies are Air Drilling International Inc and Phoenix Drilling Services Inc (S)

headline: Voting Shows Croatia, in Effect, Annexed Bosnia Region
abstract: Croatia's presidential election is held on June 15; Pres Franjo Tudjman, 75, and seriously ill with cancer, appears to be headed toward landslide victory; map; photo (M)

headline: Allen & Gerritsen Wins Sybase Account
abstract: Sybase Inc names Allen & Gerritsen to handle creative portion of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million (S)

headline: Swiss, Irked by Critics, Ask 'Why Single Us Out?'
abstract: Truculent mood is building in Switzerland after months of being criticized about Swiss role in World War II, and it may turn nation against making amends for what Clinton Administration and others depict as Swiss complicity with Nazi Germany; increasingly, Swiss diplomats, commentators and general public bristle at what they see as double standard; many Swiss feel that critics, particularly United States, have unfairly singled out Switzerland for its shortcomings in period in which many other nations behaved ingloriously (M)

headline: Dollar Plunges Against Yen In Big Setback
abstract: Dollar plunges against Japanese yen, ending week with five percent loss in value, its biggest setback to date in its rally from record low just over two years ago; decline of American currency against yen also saps its strength against German mark and other European currencies (M)

headline: Free Minutes Fly as War of Wireless Phones Heats Up
abstract: New York's two leading cellular telephone carriers, Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile and AT&T Wireless, are running barrage of advertisements that promise from 200 to 1,000 free minutes of calling time in return for signing up for cellular service; third wireless competitor, Omnipoint Communications, may soon jump into market with its own introductory offer of free minutes; some industry experts see promotions as sure sign that long-predicted wireless telephone war is breaking out in New York market (L)

headline: Muslims Protest Turkish Curbs on Religion
abstract: Muslims stage demonstratuion in Istanbul against military-backed plan to restrict religious education in Turkey (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, is selling $900 million of debt securities in two parts. The first part is $400 million of notes due in 2007 through Salomon Brothers. The notes are priced at 99.792 to yield 7.63 percent. The second part is $500 million of debentures due in 2027 through Morgan Stanley & Co. The debentures are priced at 98.647 to yield 8.121 percent.    * Fannie Mae is selling $50 million of medium-term step-up notes due in 1999 through Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. The notes, which can be called on May 11, 1998, carry an interest rate of 6.32 percent. If the issue is not called, the coupon increases, or steps up, to 7.1 percent.

headline: Hong Kong's Government-to-Be Gives a Bit on Rights Cutbacks
abstract: Hong Kong's government-in-waiting, reacting to avalanche of local and international criticism of plans to roll back range of civil liberties, announces plans to slightly relax its proposals to curb public demonstrations and control political groups (M)

headline: Pricing the Convenience of A.T.M.'s
abstract: Donald G Ogilvie (American Bankers Assn) letter says ATM is example of marketplace that works, and customers are obviously willing to pay for convenience (S)

headline: Two States Investigate Film Company's On-Line Request for Investors
abstract: Officials in California and New York are investigating whether Destiny Pictures, fledgling film production company in Los Angeles, violated any securities regulations when it offered stock in a low-budget movie over the Internet; Daniel Reyes, company's Internet site director, says company has sent electronic-mail messages to all investors saying movie would not be made and that their $100 investments had not been processed (S)

headline: Nafta Environmental Lags May Delay Free Trade Expansion
abstract: Delay in study on environmental impact of North American Free Trade Agreement is weakening support Pres Clinton will need to win Congressional approval of wider Latin American trade accords; Mexico reportedly has raised strongest objections to planned independent study; denies trying to censor findings (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Lucent and Philips To Combine Phone-Making  Lucent Technologies and Philips Electronics have agreed to combine their telephone manufacturing operations into a joint venture with about $2.5 billion in annual revenue. The companies hope to create a global powerhouse in wireless telephones, the key growth area.    Lucent officials hope the venture will provide a strategy to revive the company's troubled consumer products business. And the deal addresses an important weakness in Philips's product line as that company focuses on consumer electronics. $(Page D2.$)

headline: Dow Adds 70, And in Week Soars by 4.7%
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average soars 70.57 points to close at 7,782.04 on June 13 (M)

headline: NOVELL PRESIDENT TO LEAVE AT END OF JUNE
abstract: Novell Inc says that Josephg A Marengi has resigned as president and chief operating officer, effective at end of June (S)þ

headline: An Effect, Not a Cause
abstract: Letter by Prof Joseph Santos on March 30 article by economist Edward Yardeni that opposed further rise in interest rates (S)

headline: McLuhan perferred form to content. So does the Internet -- to its sorrow.
abstract: Technology column notes World Wide Web is laden with sites devoted to wit and wisdom of Marshall McLuhan, godfather of new media; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TRAVELERS PROPERTY CASUALTY CORP., Hartford, a unit of Travelers Group Inc., agreed to buy back 6.6 million shares from four private investors for a total of $240.8 million.

headline: Student Passion in Korea: Now What's the Point?
abstract: South Korea's radical students, who are given credit for helping bring end to military dictatorship decade ago, have marginalized themselves to point that they hardly have voice in society; public disenchantment with radicals heightened recently after students reportedly admitted beating two men to death while interrogating them about accusations that they were police informants; photo (M)

headline: Editors Urge Limits on Input By Advertisers
abstract: American Society of Magazine Editors urges editors to resist influence from advertisers on editorial content; holds advertisers may see trend toward warning them about coming stories they might object to as invitation to pressure magazine to alter or kill article; stand reflects blurring of once-solid line between advertising and content (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  Earnings reports are expected from the Bank of New York, Boise Cascade, First Chicago NBD, General Motors, Intel and Nationsbank.    TUESDAY  Income tax day.  The Labor Department releases the Consumer Price Index for March. In February, prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent.  The Commerce Department reports on business inventories and sales for February.  Earnings reports are expected from Ameritech, Banc One, Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan, Citicorp, Merrill Lynch, Sprint and Texas Instruments.    WEDNESDAY  The Commerce Department reports on housing starts for March.  The Federal Reserve reports on industrial production and capacity utilization for March.  Earnings reports are expected from AMR, Apple Computer, BankAmerica, Colgate-Palmolive, Conrail, Ford Motor and Philip Morris.    THURSDAY  The Commerce Department reports on the trade deficit for February.  Earnings reports are expected from the Bank of Boston, Bell Atlantic, Digital Equipment, Microsoft, Reebok and Textron.    FRIDAY  The University of Michigan releases its April index of consumer sentiment.  Earnings reports are expected from Black & Decker, Hershey Foods and Tambrands.

headline: New Assignments For 2 Agencies
abstract: Cargill Inc, giant agricultural commodities company, names Miller Meester Advertising in Minneapolis to handle integrated marketing communications assignment aimed at large-farm customers; Daewoo Group names Ground Zero as its first agency to handle its Western regional account (S)

headline: 5 Years After Earth Summit, U.N. Seeks to Fill In Gaps
abstract: Environmental ministers from 53 countries will meetat UN on April 8 on setting new targetsasa fifth anniversary of Rio Earth Summit approaches; will attempt to fill some gaps left in emerging set of international environmental laws that have resulted from Rio summit (M)

headline: RUSSIA AGREES TO NATO PLAN PUSHED BY CLINTON TO ADMIT NATIONS FROM EASTERN BLOC
abstract: Russia reluctantly agreed today to the Clinton Administration's push to expand the NATO military alliance to include Moscow's former satellites in Central Europe.    The accord between NATO and Russia sets the terms under which the alliance is expected to admit Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and perhaps other Central and Eastern European nations left behind the Iron Curtain after the 1945 Yalta Pact.

headline: $900 Million Deal for Equipment Renter
abstract: North American subsidiary of Atlas Copco AB, a Swedish industrial machinery manufacturer, agrees to acquire Prime Service Inc, one of largest rental equipment companies in US, for $900 million in cash; deal is windfall for Investcorp International, London- and Bahrain-based investment bank that acquired Prime Service in December 1994 for $300 million and still controls about 74 percent of it, having sold 25 percent of company to public on Oct 31 at $23.50 a share (L)

headline: Former Executives Ordered to Pay Damages
abstract: Four former Stratton Oakmont Inc executives, including brokerage firm's former president, have been ordered by arbitration panel to pay total of $10.2 million in damages to California physician F Clark Gardner for use of misleading sales tactics; award is made by National Association of Securities Dealers; four executives deny wrongdoing; Stratton Oakmont is being liquidated (S)

headline: The offbeat film maker David Lynch directs a campaign for Unilever's home pregnancy test.
abstract: *Unilever enrolls film maker David Lynch to direct television advertising campaign for new home pregnancy test, Clear Blue Easy One Minute; commercials for test offer toned-down version of Lynch's notoriously offbeat trademark style, which incorporates dreamlike sequences and irrational events (Advertising column) (M)

headline: A potential arthritis drug could help Immunex rise even higher.
abstract: Outlook for investing in Immunex Corp discussed in light of bright prospects for Enbrel, firm's potential new drug for rheumatoid arthritis (M)

headline: Sun Microsystems Moves to Lowe
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc names Lowe & Partners/SMS to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $60 million to $70 million (S)

headline: Irish Go to the Polls To Choose Legislators
abstract: Irish vote for new Parliament, but they will probably not know until Sunday, if then, which parties will form a new government (S)

headline: Slovenia Discards the Yoke That Was Yugoslavia
abstract: Slovenia presses to add its name to list of former Communist countries whose applications for membership are being considered by NATO; has lifted itself out of morass gripping countries of former Yugoslavia, emerging as one of crucial demarcation points between new Western-oriented nations of post-cold-war Europe and those that seem destined to wallow for decades in political and economic disarray; decision by nine out of 16 NATO countries to back membership for Slovenia and Romania, despite US calls to limit entry to Hungary, Poland and Czech Republic, noted; map; photo (M)

headline: Tracking the Footprints on a Digital Trail
abstract: Chart describing how individuals leave electronic footprints everywhere they go and with everything they do; notes digital connections and surveillance cameras have become prime source of information for law enforcement agencies; says investigations of 1995 Oklahoma City bombing and of recent murder of Jonathan Levin are reminders of how easy it can be to pick up an electronic trail; drawings (M)

headline: Institutional Pharmacy Companies to Combine in Stock Swap
abstract: Capstone Pharmacy Services Inc agrees to buy pharmacy unit of Beverly Enterprises Inc for about $475 million in stock (M)

headline: Roseanne to Continue on TV But Is Expected to Leave ABC
abstract: Executives close to talks between Carsey-Werner Productions, which produces TV program Roseanne, and network programmers say that ABC has withdrawn from negotiations for a new show, which will not be named Roseanne and will amount to a spinoff; new show is all but certain and will find a home at a different network; new series may have no other surviving characters from current Roseanne program (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Automatic Data Proc  Blount Intl  Chemed  Crane  Ft Dearborn Inc Secs  Hormel Foods   Medusa

headline: Ruler Eyes Candidacy In Nigeria
abstract: Although new elections have been scheduled for next year, Nigeria is beginning to see strong signs that the military elite, which annulled the last elections four years ago, intends to hang on to power here indefinitely.     The officer who emerged in 1993 as Nigeria's leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, has allowed the impression to grow that he may resign from the military to run for President himself, and Nigeria's main political parties are falling over themselves to enlist him as their candidate.

headline: MCI Says Earnings Were Flat Despite Long-Distance Gains
abstract: MCI Communications Corp reports first-quarter net income of $295 million, same as year earlier; revenue rose 8.7 percent, to $4.9 billion from $4.5 billion; operating profit in long-distance operations rose 6.4 percent, to $653 million, while sales rose 8.2 percent, to $4.4 billion; table (M)

headline: Clinton's Choice: Press the Swiss, or Close Books
abstract: David E Sanger analysis contends that Clinton Administration must decide how hard to press Switzerland to return hundreds of millions of dollars in gold and art work that Nazis looted (M)

headline: 5 Airlines Extend Limits Of Alliances
abstract: United  Airlines, Lufthansa and three part ners  with considerable fanfare and a $25 million advertising budget -- announced today that they would expand individual agreements now linking their operations into a broad single alliance.    The group, which will be called the Star Alliance, also includes Air Canada, Scandinavian Airlines System, and Thai Airways International. Varig Airlines of Brazil plans to join in October, and negotiations are in an advanced stage with other potential partners, including British Midland and South African Airways.

headline: People
abstract: * John Nardone, director for media and research services at Modem Media, Westport, Conn., a unit of True North Communications, was named to the additional duties of managing director at Modem Media New York, formerly named Northern Lights Interactive. He succeeds John Adams, who resigned. Also, Sean Connolly, managing director at Northern Lights Interactive, Hong Kong, becomes managing director of the renamed Modem Media Hong Kong.

headline: INVESTORS PAY $48 MILLION FOR 4.5% OF AT HOME NETWORK
abstract: At Home Network says group of investors including Sun Microsystems and Motorola paid $48 million for about 4.5 percent of the closely held high-speed Internet-access service, giving company implied market capitalization of about $1.1 billion; other investors are Bay Networks and Canadian cable companies Rogers Communications and Shaw Communications (S)

headline: Retail Sales Down 0.3% Last Month
abstract: Commerce Department estimates shoppers spent three-tenths of 1 percent less in April than in March; says retail sales--unadjusted for inflation--were 4.9 percent higher than in April 1996, reaching estimated $212.2 billion; graph (L)

headline: SOUTHERN NATIONAL TO ACQUIRE VIRGINIA FIRST FINANCIAL
abstract: Southern National Corp agrees to acquire Virginia First Financial Corp for $148 million (S)

headline: More Pressure Seen on Big Banks To Acquire Securities Firms
abstract: Bankers Trust New York Corp's planned acquisition of Alex Brown & Sons is expected to increase already sharp pressure on Wall Street investment firms and commercial banks to insure that they offer what their customers need, and to acquire types of securities businesses they do not already have (M)

headline: Lufthansa Says Profit Will Meet Forecasts
abstract: Lufthansa AG says pretax profit will be about 700 million German marks, or $406 million, in 1996, in line with earlier forecasts (S)

headline: Germany Defends Pensions for SS Veterans
abstract: German Government acknowledges that war disability pensions are still being paid to members of Waffen SS units and even to war criminals, although official says possible way to exclude war criminals is being sought; defends record of payments to Jewish and non-Jewish victims of Nazis; American Jewish Congress has charged Germany with showing more sympathy toward war criminals than toward victims in Eastern and Central Europe, tens of thousands of whom have been denied compensation; Germany notes that former SS members and survivors can claim war-victim pensions on grounds of wartime injury (S)

headline: Michigan Professor Expected to Be Named to Fed
abstract: Pres Clinton is expected to name Edward M Gramlich, economist at University of Michigan, to fill one of two vacancies on Federal Reserve Board; no official announcement is expected immediately (M)

headline: Agency Association Names New Officers
abstract: American Assn of Advertising Agencies elects Ralph W Rydholm as 1997-98 chairman; Patrick J McGrath becomes vice chairman and Anthony L Bucci is elected secretary-treasurer (S)

headline: Big Sale Expected Of Italian Bank Shares
abstract: Cariplo SpA will sell shares to a partner in what is expected to be Italy's biggest banking acquisition (S)

headline: On the Campaign Trail in France, Scant Mention of Economic Pain
abstract: French leaders of conservative parties and of Socialist opposition agree that French voters do not want to endure more economic pain to meet requirements for common European currency in 1999; Pres Jacques Chirac had called election for new Parliament in hope of getting mandate to keep trimming welfare state and cut deficits; but Lionel Jospin of Socialist Party and Prime Min Alain Juppe of right, responding to public opinion, are soft-pedaling idea of sacrifice and instead promising to use euro and other economic tools to stimulate growth that is needed to lift France out of its double-digit unemployment; as result, no matter who wins, Chirac will have even harder time making further cutbacks in welfare state after elections than before; photos; chart (M)

headline: Rural Callers May Pay More in Deregulation
abstract: Federal Communications Commission is reviewing Depression-era Federal policy of giving disproportionate share of subsidies to small phone companies in rural areas to keep telephone service affordable in even farthest-flung corners of nation; FCC has already issued new rules stripping billions of dollars of subsidies from industry in attempt to turn it into free market; large local phone companies around US that serve both rural areas and urban areas brace for extensive redistribution of revenue that some say could jeopardize nation's tradition of universal phone service; some experts argue that wholesale deregulation could drive up cost of local service everywhere, if government wants to continue affordable phone service for secluded areas of nation; people in predominantly urban states, which are cheaper to serve, will wind up subsidizing people in rural states; photos; map; chart (L)

headline: Blair's Muted Helpmate: Look at Her Now!
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair's wife, high-powered London lawyer known professionally as Cherie Booth, returns to judicial post after serving as muted helpmate during election campaign; is first spouse of British Prime Minister to hold full-time job; photos (M)

headline: U.N. Report Accuses Zaire Rebels of Mass Killings
abstract: United Nations investigator Roberto Garreton tells organization's Human Rights Commission in Geneva that rebels in Zaire have killed hundreds of Hutu refugees and local civilians since beginning their insurgency last year (M)

headline: Judge Denies Request by Barney's to Offer a Breakup Fee
abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Judge James L Garrity Jr rejects request by Barney's Inc to offer $10 million in breakup fees to potential bidder for company; also says he will appoint mediator to oversee bidding (S)

headline: Biker Club House Blasted in Norway
abstract: Blast levels meeting house for Norwegian Bandidos motorcycle club, Drammen, Norway, killing at least one person and injuring several others; police say blast, from bomb or rocket, could signal intensification of Scandinavian biker war; probe Hell's Angels (S)

headline: Government Will Reserve Bills in Auction
abstract: Government takes steps to assure that Americans can get their fair share of Treasury bills at next auction; foreigners will be alllowed to buy no more than $3 billion of total of $12 billion in three- and six-month Treasury bills to be auctioned (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Drop Sharply As Labor Data Show Strength
abstract: Treasury prices fall sharply after March employment report shows brisk economic growth and rising labor costs (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CIRQUE CORP., Salt Lake City, named Thomas B. Quarton president and chief operating officer.    HYPERION SOFTWARE CORP., Stamford, Conn., said Peter F. DiGiammarino would step down as president and chief operating officer. Jim Perakis, chairman and chief executive, will resume day-to-day management of the company effective immediately, the company said.

headline: FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Roundup of recent events in mutual funds industry (L)ÿ

headline: Four Agencies Make Acquisitions Abroad
abstract: Addenda: Foote, Cone & Belding acquires majorty stake in AJL Publicidad C A in Caracas for undisclosed sum; Lowe & Partners Worldwide acquires substantial minority interest in SSPM (Sokoloff Samper Polar Mora) in Bogota for undisclosed sum; Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide will acquire Team-Mate Marketing Development & Services for $1.8 million plus possible additional payments; Caribiner International Inc acquires WCT Live Communication Ltd for $11.7 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Treasuries Rise on Fed Governor's Comments
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise; 30-year bond rises 3/32, to 99 5/32, to yield 6.69 percent (M)

headline: RAYTHEON AGREES TO DELAY OVER TEXAS INSTRUMENTS UNIT
abstract: Raytheon Co agrees to delay its $2.95 billion purchase of Texas Instruments Inc's military business until June 30 while companies resolve Federal antitrust concerns (S)

headline: FORD AND LENDER REVIEW MINORITY CHARGES
abstract: Ford Motor Co chairman Alex Trotman says Ford and Associates First Capital Corp, a consumer and commercial lending company 80.3 percent owned by Ford, are reviewing allegations that Associates took advantage of borrowers who were poorly educated or from low-income or minority groups; Trotman expresses strong doubt that any large-scale problem exists (S)

headline: NORTHERN TELECOM PLANS TO HIRE 5,000 WORKERS
abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd will hire 5,000 workers in Ottawa region in next four years to meet increased global demand for telecommunications products (S)ï

headline: Motorola Raises Stake in Czech Chip Maker
abstract: Motorola Inc increases its stake in Czech computer chip producer Tesla Sezam AS to 57 percent (S)

headline: VIACOM TO RAISE STAKE IN SPELLING ENTERTAINMENT TO 80%
abstract: Viacom will buy additional 5 percent of Spelling Entertainment Group for $27.6 million, raising stake to 80 percent (S)

headline: Dow Charges G.E. Hired Workers Privy To Its Secrets
abstract: Dow Chemical Co sues General Electric Co, accusing it of 'systematically and aggressively' hiring Dow employees privy to trade secrets, latest in series of moves by American companies to prevent important officials from going to work for competitors; lawsuit filed in state court in Pontiac, Detroit suburb, accuses General Electric of hiring 14 engineers and sales executives from Dow's plastics division over last two years and putting them to work at similar tasks; Michigan Circuit Court Chief Judge Edward Sosnick immediately grants temporary restraining order barring General Electric from using any trade secrets that it might have obtained from former Dow employees; restraining order also requires General Electric to return any Dow documents that it may have (L)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Frontier  Kimco Rlty  MBIA  Roc Communities

headline: Ireland's Hard-Pressed Premier Seeks National Election in June
abstract: Prime Min John Bruton of Ireland, whose integrity and Northern Ireland policy is under attack, will dissolve Parliament and call early elections in June (M)

headline: New Jersey Is Betting The Future On Wall St.
abstract: New Jersey last week sold $2.8 billion in state bonds--largest single long-term municipal financing in history--to buy stocks; Gov Christine Todd Whitman is sure those stocks will go up so fast that the state will come out ahead; graph (L)

headline: U.S. Reports High Vacancy Rate In Housing in Israeli Settlements
abstract: United States diplomats say quarter of homes in Jewish settlements on West Bank and half of those in Gaza Strip are empty, raising questions about Israel's stand that it expands settlement because of natural growth; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Jewish settlers dispute stand; US Consul Gen Edward Abington says expansion seems to be ideologically driven; photo (M)

headline: Nabisco Expands Ties With 2 Shops
abstract: Nabisco International, subsidiary of Nabisco Holdings Corp, expands its relationships with two of its roster shops, Foote Cone & Belding Worldwide and McCann-Erickson Worldwide (S)

headline: Top Soft-Drink Makers Raise Stakes in Brand War
abstract: Beverage wars among nation's top three soft-drink producers intensifies as Pepsico Inc says it will create new division for its $6.14 billion company-owned bottling operations to increase its competition; Coca-Cola Co confirms it is trying to banish Dr Pepper/Seven Up, nation's third-largest beverage company, from thousands of McDonald's restaurants; Coke and Dr Pepper have exchanged dueling letters over the issue, and legal action or a regulatory complaint is possible; Craig Jung is appointed to head new bottling division at Pepsico (L)

headline: Canada's Vote Focus: 'Jobs, Jobs, Jobs'
abstract: High unemployment and desire for job security are key issues in Canada's parliamentary elections; major parities are promising to cut unemployment, but lack convincing plan for creating jobs (M)

headline: Despite the uncertainties of looming Chinese rule, Hong Kong's hotels rush to update their rooms.
abstract: Hong Kong's hotels are racing to add technology to rooms, mostly to please business travelers, despite uncertainties of looming Chinese rule; European Union officially opens its skies to unfettered competition nearly 20 years after US deregulated its airlines; new airlines like Air Europa, Debonair, Easyjet, Ryannair and Virgin Group's Virgin Express already offer low-fare service; Zagat restaurant guide for Paris, France, is coming next March; Zagat will challenge ratings of Michelin (L)

headline: Burmese Project Tests Unocal Resolve
abstract: Unocal Corp, more than any other big American oil company, has staked its future on investments abroad, mainly in Asia, even as it disposes of its American refineries and gas stations; many oil companies, including Unocal, are finding that politics back home is new focus of risk; threat of unilateral economic sanctions, typically directed by US Government at governments accused of human rights violations, has become big enough to cast shadow over investment decisions; Unocal has placed its biggest bet so far in Myanmar, where it is part of international consortium that is investing $1.2 billion to develop Yadana natural gas field; and while field will not start operating until next year, Unocal's presence in Myanmar has already become case study in politics and pressures that are increasingly affecting energy industry; last month, Clinton Administration approved use of sanctions against Myanmar under legislation that Clinton signed last fall; tables; graphs; photos (L)

headline: DISNEY TO ACQUIRE TWO RADIO STATIONS FOR $105 MILLION
abstract: Evergreen Media Corp and Chancellor Broadcasting Co agrees to sell two radio stations to Walt Disney Co's ABC Radio unit for $105 million; stations are WDRQ-FM in Detroit and WJZW-FM in Washington (S)

headline: TRADING IN UNION CARBIDE GROWS ON SALE SPECULATION
abstract: Trading volume on Union Carbide Corp's options increases with speculation that company might be for sale (S)

headline: Europeans to Attach Terms To Boeing-McDonnell Deal
abstract: European Commission's top antitrust official, Karel Van Miert, calling Boeing Co's plan for buying McDonnell Douglas Corp 'totally unacceptable,' says letter will be sent within 10 days detailing conditions Boeing must meet to win European approval of the deal; Van Miert does not elaborate on what demands might be (M)

headline: RAYTHEON CO. (RTN, N)
abstract: Raytheon Co says earnings in first quarter fell 1.7 percent; net income fell to $183.4 million compared with $186.5 million a year earlier; revenue rose nearly 4 percent, to $2.9 billion from $2.79 billion; table (S)

headline: LESLIE'S POOLMART TAKEN PRIVATE IN $140 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Leslie's Poolmart Inc says it has been acquired by management in private transaction valued at $140 million (S)

headline: Israeli Labor Party Paves the Way for Replacing Peres as Its Leader
abstract: Israel's opposition Labor Party convention rejects Shimon Peres's continued leadership, refusing to create post of party president for him; vote is victory for rival, Ehud Barak; Peres vows to remain in public eye and work for peace with Arabs (M)

headline: California takes on the tobacco industry with a $22 million campaign to discourage smoking.
abstract: California unfurled its lastest attack on cigarette smoking last month, high-profile $22 million campaign that takes on new urgency in light of recently released study by state's Department of Health Services showing that smoking among California adults rose last year for first time in eight years; Asher/Gould Advertising created 16 radio and television ads; other ads will be developed by Valdes Zacky Associates, Imada Wong Communications and Carol H Williams Advertising; photo (L)

headline: Don't Alter Bankruptcy Laws
abstract: Comment by economist Mark Zandi urges Congress not to change bankruptcy laws, saying record number of filings is linked not to permissive rules but to sharp lowering of lending standards by creditors earlier in decade (S)

headline: Israel Plans To Construct 3,400 Homes For Arabs
abstract: Israeli Interior Ministry approves construction of 3,400 homes for Arabs in Sur Bahir, village in eastern Jerusalem that is near site of new Jewish neighborhood; map; Palestinian officials see ploy to deflect criticism (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Family Channel, Virginia Beach, Va., a cable television network owned by International Family Entertainment, to Sloan Group, New York, to handle trade advertising, which had been handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed.  * United States Mint, Washington, to Doner Direct, Baltimore, a unit of W. B. Doner & Co., to handle a new Franklin D. Roosevelt commemorative coin program to begin in May. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: State Dept. Set For Reshaping, Pleasing Helms
abstract: Pres Clinton approves plan to reorganize State Dept, decision that responds to longstanding demand by Sen Jesse Helms that has snarled foreign policy; plan, disclosed only after Helms finally agrees to allow Senate vote on chemical weapons ban, would consolidate Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and US Information Agency into State Dept over next two years; US Agency for International Development would remain distinct agency, but its director would come under direct authority of Secretary of State and some functions would be consolidated (M)

headline: Czar and Lenin Share Fate: Neither Can Rest in Peace
abstract: Remains of Lenin, father of Russian Revolution, still lie in state in mausoleum that dominates Red Square; remains of Czar Nicholas II, whose execution Lenin ordered in 1918, lie in Government pathology lab in city of Yekaterinburg; there is growing movement among liberal politicians and members of intelligentsia to bury Communism once and for all by interring Lenin in less conspicuous place; Pres Boris N Yeltsin recently suggested that referendum be held on issue; Russian Orthodox Church and other traditionalists want to bury Nicholas II and his family in Romanov family crypt in St Petersburg; formal plans to bury remains of royal family have been postponed at least twice; map; photo (M)

headline: Dutch Take 'Third Way' to Prosperity
abstract: Foreign economists, sociologists and union and political figures have visited Netherlands in weeks preceding meeting of European leaders that begins in Amsterdam on June 16; they seek to understand what has kept Netherlands so stable, prosperous and curiously without strikes; photo (M)

headline: J. Walter Thompson Shuffles Managers
abstract: New York and San Francisco offices of J Walter Thompson announce series of management changes; at New York office, Tod Seisser is named to oversee creative output, teaming up with J J Jordan as co-creative directors; at J Walter Thompson West, David Riemer is promoted to president, succeeding Steve Darland, who has stepped aside for 'important' undisclosed position; John Geoghegan is named to succeed Darland as general manager (S)

headline: Gates to Help Libraries Acquire Gear To Go on Line
abstract: William H Gates, co-founder of Microsoft Corp, is setting up Gates Library Foundation, which will spend $200 million over five years to bring new computers and Internet into public libraries; foundation will mainly aid libraries in low-income areas; move is Gates's largest charitable move to date; American Library Association head Elizabeth Martinez hails plan (M)

headline: Murdoch Gets Primestar Stake In Pact With His Cable Rivals
abstract: Rupert Murdoch is known as an entrepreneurial gambler, building his global media empire on one high-risk venture after another.    Yet by reaching a tentative agreement with his cable-television rivals to enter the satellite broadcasting business in America, Mr. Murdoch is showing his pragmatic side -- a willingness to cut his losses, following a series of setbacks.

headline: Rights Group Urges Kenya to Widen Freedoms Before Election
abstract: Amnesty International aide Pierre Sane, after fact-finding visit to Kenya, says elections will not be fair unless constitutional reforms are carried out and repressive public-order laws repealed; gives bleak account of human rights in Kenya; scores Pres Daniel arap Moi's Government for using colonial-era security laws to break up opposition rallies; urges Western nations to send human rights workers to monitor vote (M)

headline: ABBEY NATIONAL TO BUY CATER ALLEN HOLDINGS
abstract: Abbey National PLC, Britain's sixth-largest bank, says it will buy Cater Allen Holdings PLC for $317 million to increase its stock lending and British repurchase agreement business (S)

headline: Conseco Selects An Image Agency
abstract: Conseco Inc has named Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York as first agency to handle to corporate image and brandbuilding advertising; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: Keycorp to Sell 6 Branches
abstract: Keycorp plans to sell six branches in Ohio to LNB Bancorp and Lebanon Citizens National Bank, for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: ITT CORP. (ITT,N)
abstract: ITT Corp reports net income for first quarter was $80 million, up from $20 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose to $1.41 billion from $1.33 billion; table (S)

headline: Japanese Official Faults U.S. Procurement
abstract: Japanese Trade Minister, Shinji Sato, says he intends to point out to United States what he calls closed nature of Government procurement process in wake of US dumping accusation against NEC Corp of Japan; notes that US has urged Japanese Government to buy US-made supercomputers, but that US itself has not bought imported supercomputers (S)

headline: Central bankers and options traders weigh down gold's price.
abstract: Price of gold, which traditionally rises in response to economic jitters, has fallen 6.8 percent this year; factors include increased gold sales by central banks, threat of even more central bank sales and increasing options trading; graph (M)

headline: Chretien's Liberals, Pressing Austerity, Keep Slim Majority
abstract: Canadian voters return Prime Min Jean Chretien and Liberal Party to power, with slim parliamentary majority and weak mandate to continue fiscal austerity that has practically eliminated Federal deficit while cutting deeply into revered social programs; Liberals win at least 154 of 301 seats in new House of Commons, or barely enough to form second consecutive majority Government, and 20 fewer seats than 174 they previously controlled; results noted; major issues in election discussed; photo (M)

headline: Facing U.S. Boycott, Drugmaker Returns Pill Rights to Creator : Opponents Of Abortion Force Shift By Hoechst
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Concerned that its image might be tarnished by high-profile pressure from American anti-abortion groups, the German pharmaceutical company that makes the RU-486 abortion pill said Tuesday it was transferring its patent rights to a creator of the drug.

headline: KOHLBERG KRAVIS TO INVEST IN TEXAS GROCERY CHAIN
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co will invest $225 million in Randalls Food Markets, getting majority stake in closely held grocery store chain; Randalls operates 70 Randalls stores and 51 Tom Thumb stores (S)

headline: Arnell Group Gets 3 New Assignments
abstract: Arnell Group wins three new assignments; will handle brand duties for Limited Inc's Henri Bendel retail chain; will create trade advertising drive for Elle magazine; will develop worldwide brand identity program for Guggenheim Museum and its retail stores (S)

headline: China Issue for the Post-Deng Era
abstract: Analysis of return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule as victory marking start of new era for China under new generation of leaders; Hong Kong is first test in year of testing of new leaders, with leaders being judged by how they manage incorporation of free and vibrant Hong Kong society into body politic of Communist mainland; Pres Jiang Zemin, to succeed, will have to resist hard-liners and grant Hong Kong large measure of freedom; photo (M)

headline: Rebels Get a Warm Welcome in Zaire's Economic Heart
abstract: Rebel forces, led by Laurent Kabila, met little resistance from Government troops when they swept recently into Lubumbashi, Zaire, and got warm welcome from regional capital's 580,000 residents; residents, who have long resented Pres Mobutu Sese Seko for draining profits from region, are hoping for radical change under Kabila; life returns to normal on city streets; map; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HARRIS CORP., Melbourne, Fla., announced that its Lanier Worldwide Inc. unit had acquired Quorum Group Inc., a litigation services company based in Minneapolis, for $54 million.

headline: ANTHEM OFFERS $7 A SHARE FOR ACORDIA STAKE
abstract: Anthem Inc will pay $40 a share, or about $170 million, to acquire shares of Acordia Inc it does not already own (S)

headline: Dozens of Lively Tunes You Can Dance To
abstract: Comment on pop music scene in Brazil; photo of Netinho, who tops charts by combining rhythmic African beat with synthesizers and electric guitars (S)

headline: Who will pay the tobacco industry's huge bills? Smokers.
abstract: Peter Passell examines economics of $368 billion product liability settlement between cigarette manufacturers and states; says industry should be able to pass on nearly all of cost to consumers since tobacco consumption is not particularly sensitive to price; says while deal may spare millions of young Americans from addiction to nicotine, it will come at considerable cost to those unable to kick habit--disproportionate percentage of whom are poor; drawing (M)

headline: MACY'S TO PHASE OUT SALES OF ELECTRONIC ITEMS
abstract: Macy's plans to clear out electronic items to make room for clothing and bedding; Macy's says its electronic departments involve disproportionate investments of money, management time and other resources (S)

headline: Airline Alliance Picks Y.& R.
abstract: The Star Alliance, a joint venture marketing operation announced yesterday by five airlines, has named the New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising to create a worldwide campaign to introduce the partnership program. The campaign, with a budget of $25 million, begins this week with a gatefold print advertisement that opens to reveal an imaginary airplane bearing the logos of all five carriers: the UAL Corporation's United Airlines, Lufthansa, Air Canada, Thai Airways International and Scandinavian Airlines System.

headline: Investigators in Salinas Case Subpoena Records of a Texas Bank
abstract: Federal investigators, widening United States probe into possible money-laundering by Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of former Mexican Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari, reportedly probe movement of millions of dollars through Texas Commerce Bank; seek records of 1989 cash deposits in name of Margarita Nava Sanchez, made when she was Raul Salinas's girlfriend (M)

headline: Consumer Confidence Up for 4th Month
abstract: Conference Board reports its index of consumer confidence rose in June for fourth straight month, reaching 28-year high of 129.6, up from revised 127.9 in May (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: SUPREME COURT  Liberty for Cyberlibertines  In a sweeping endorsement of free speech in cyberspace, the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional a Federal law that was intended to protect minors by making it a crime to put ''indecent'' material on the Internet. The decision delighted a coalition of Internet users, the computer industry and civil liberties groups. In other decisions affecting business, the court gave Federal prosecutors and securities regulators a major victory, ruling that insider trading laws apply to people with confidential information even if they have no connection to the company involved. The court also struck down a landmark $1.3 billion class-action settlement for victims of asbestos exposure; upheld a New Deal-era Federal marketing program that requires agricultural companies to help pay for industrywide advertising, and denied prison guards employed by private companies the immunity from prisoner lawsuits enjoyed by guards on public payrolls.    THE MARKETS  Forget Stocks. Cut Velvet.  Stocks had a zigzag week that left traders' psyches as battered toward the end of the week as prices were on Monday, when they plunged 192 points on fear that the Japanese might sell United States Treasury securities. Tokyo hastily declared that remarks by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto had been misinterpreted, and the market climbed back up. By the end of the week, prices were back at last week's levels. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 108.79 at 7,687.72, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index was down 8.95 at 1,438.15. A much better investment, it seems, was made by Diana, Princess of Wales. At a packed Christie's auction in Manhattan, an off-the-shoulder, ink-blue dinner dress in which she danced at the White House with John Travolta sold for a record $222,500. Altogether the auction of 79 dresses owned by Diana raised $3.25 million for cancer and AIDS charities. The dresses originally cost about $5,000 each, so the gain was more than eightfold.

headline: Protecting Refugees: Nagging Problem at U.N.
abstract: As evidence accumulates in Zaire that significant numbers of Hutu refugees have been killed or abused by the rebel forces of Laurent Kabila, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees finds herself in a familiar trap:     While critics say the agency is not doing enough to safeguard refugees, the High Commissioner, Sadako Ogata, is repeatedly rebuffed when she calls for an international protection force.

headline: Clinton Flies To Mexico For Talks
abstract: Pres Clinton arrives in Mexico City on first state visit with members of Cabinet; will test Administration's policy of using praise rather than pressure to secure cooperation on variety of issues; Secretary of State Madeliene K Albright, Treasury Secretary Robert E Rubin and Attorney General Janet Reno and five other Cabinet members meet with Mexican counterparts for session of Bilateral Commission (M)

headline: Seat on Big Board Is Sold
abstract: Seat on New York Stock Exchange sells for $1.2 million, decrease of $85,000 from previous sale on Dec 30 (S)

headline: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM PLANS ACQUISITION OF ALAMCO
abstract: Columbia Gas System Inc., a natural-gas pipeline company, agreed yesterday to buy Alamco Inc. for about $83 million in cash and the assumption of about $18 million in debt. The deal, in which Columbia would pay $15.75 for each Alamco share, would enable Columbia to become the largest gas producer in the Appalachian Basin. Alamco, based in Clarksburg, W. Va., operates 1,200 oil and gas wells. Shares of Alamco rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $15.25, while Columbia Gas shares fell 87.5 cents, to $63.875. Columbia, based in Reston, Va., said its Columbia Natural Resources unit and Alamco together represent 13 percent of the gas produced in the Appalachian Basin.

headline: CORRECTIONS CORPORATION TO SELL 9 PRISONS
abstract: Corrections Corp of America agrees to sell nine of its correctional and detention centers to CCA Prison Realty Trust for $308 million; Corrections Corp manages prisons and detention centers for governmental agencies (S)

headline: U.N. Health Official, Opposed by U.S., Won't Seek Re-election
abstract: World Health Organization Dir Gen Hiroshi Nakajima, who has come under criticism in US, Europe and Africa, says he will not seek another term in office (M)

headline: Novartis is latest rival to accuse Schering-Plough of unfairly attacking its product.
abstract: For second time this year, Schering-Plough Corp has angered competitor over advertising that the rival says promotes Schering products by taking unfair shots at other brands; most recent case involves criticism of Schering's advertising for laxatives; Novartis Consumer Health, maker of Ex-Lax laxatives, is angered that Schering's health care unit ran full-page ad in two newspapers last week alerting consumers that Food and Drug Administration determined that 'some laxatives may cause cancer'; according to the ad, FDA recall of laxatives containing phenolphthalein 'would include most Ex-Lax products'; ad also notes that Schering's Correctol laxative does not contain phenolphthalein (L)

headline: Bank Profits Hit A Quarterly High
abstract: Survey by SNL Securities shows US commercial banks had net income of $14.1 billion in first quarter; results of 230 commercial banks covering 79 percent of industry assets surpassed record of $13.8 billion set in third quarter of 1995 (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             May 16   May 9   May 17          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   8.0   8.1   7.8       Distillate production, daily   3.6   3.5   3.3       Gasoline stocks   197.9   197.1   204.9       Distillate stocks   98.4   96.5   90.4       Crude imports, daily   7.8   7.6   7.8       Product imports, daily   1.9   1.9   1.7       Crude stocks   315.8   321.7   295.2       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.3       Refinery utilization (%)   97.6   96.9   92.2          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: MERFIN INTERNATIONAL URGES HOLDERS TO REJECT BID
abstract: Merfin International Inc urges shareholders to reject Buckeye Cellulose Corp's takeover offer worth $160 million (Canadian) (US)

headline: Broadcast Lobby Excels at the Washington Power Game
abstract: Broadcast industry has great power in Washington because it spends millions in campaign donations and on high-powered lobbyists and because its television stations determine how politicians are portrayed to their voters back home; in latest example of industry's influence, Government lent industry, free of charge, new space on public airwaves worth $7 billion to $15 billion, while other industries must buy air space at auction; critics are particularly upset that after this act of 'corporate welfare,' broadcast industry is resisting Pres Clinton's efforts to provide free 'public interest' television air time for political candidates; Edward O Fritts, president of National Assn of Broadcasters, has decried notion of federally required free air time for candidates as 'unconstitutional' and claimed that his industry is already faced with burdensome regulations (M)

headline: Hopes for Quick End to Age of Mobutu Are Fading Fast
abstract: It remains unclear whether Pres Mobutu Sese Seko, who is visiting Gabon, will return to Zaire in view of growing pressure for ailing leader to step down; photo (M)

headline: Ira Magaziner Argues for Minimal Internet Regulation
