abstract: Ira C Magaziner, who spent last 15 months studying Internet as head of White House task force, believes Internet community should be allowed to flourish free of most Government interference, and that industry self-regulation should take place of detailed Federal guidelines; Supreme Court recently came to same conclusion, striking down Communications Decency Act; Magaziner claims business conducted over Internet could be throttled by excessive Government intervention; Magaziner's study group concluded that Government involvement would be necessary in some areas, and that official oversight may be needed to protect against fraud and exploitation of children; it also accepted law enforcement's insistence on retaining some access to encrypted data, which computer industry almost unanimously opposes; photos (M)

headline: Jobless Claims Rise Unexpected 8,000
abstract: Labor Department reports number of Americans applying for state unemployment insurance rose surprising 8,000 for week ended June 14, to seasonally adjusted level of 347,000 (S)

headline: Late Rally Sends the Dow Above 7,300-Point Level
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 47.39 points, to 7,333.55; Nasdaq composite index rises 18.03 points, or 1.35 percent, to 1,353.58; table (L)

headline: BRISTOL-MYERS TO BUY MEXICAN FOOD-SUPPLEMENT MAKER
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co agrees to acquire Choco Milk from Procter & Gamble de Mexico SA de CV; financial terms undisclosed; Choco Milk is Mexico's leading milk-based nutritional supplement, which had 1996 sales of $50 million (S)

headline: Hearst Names a New Top Editor To Try to Turn Around Esquire
abstract: David Granger, third-ranking editor at GQ magazine, is named editor in chief of Esquire, replacing Edward Kosner (M)

headline: A Bad First Quarter for U.S. Stock Funds
abstract: Average mutual fund investing in American stocks had its worst performance in more than two years during first quarter of 1997, and funds specializing in US high-technology companies were particularly weak, losing average of more than 6 percent; tables; graphs (L)

headline: Scots' Payoff in Labor's Victory Is Likely to Be Own Parliament
abstract: Resounding Labor victory in British general election last month does more than sweep away Conservative Government that was seen by many Scots as indifferent, if not hostile, to Scotland's singular culture and special needs; it also turned an old dream of separate Scottish parliament into almost certain reality; many Scots argue that current political system, in which Scotland is answerable to national Parliament in London, puts them at disadvantage; this feeling is compounded by fact that in three successive elections Scots voted overwhelmingly for Labor Party, only to see Conservatives return to power in London; photo; map (M)

headline: Kia Motors Plant in Brazil
abstract: Kia Motors do Brasil, subsidiary of Kia Motors Corp of South Korea, says it will build $50 million plant to build Bongo brand light trucks in Brazil (S)

headline: Keep Banks Out of Corporate Claws
abstract: ONCE again Congress is being asked to approve legislation that would allow nonfinancial corporations to own and control commercial banks. If approved, this would eventually be harmful to all Americans because it would undermine the very essence of a democratic and competitive economy.   The proposal comes up about twice a decade. It last appeared in earnest during the Bush Administration, when it was part of a package to attempt a comprehensive reform of the financial system. Basically, the argument then was that banks were in difficulty and short of capital. Commercial enterprises would take over the banks, infuse new capital and thereby lift a potential burden from the backs of weary taxpayers, who were already reeling from the cost of the savings and loan bailout.

headline: Germany's Growth Put at 0.5% in Quarter
abstract: German Economics Ministry says that Germany's economy probably expanded about 0.5 percent in first quarter of this year from final quarter of 1996 (S)

headline: Less of a Grinch: Some Softening For the Image Of Greenspan
abstract: Economists and other students of Federal Reserve are starting to offer revisionist view of Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan, one that paints him as far more flexible in his approach to fighting inflation than his reputation--and his own public statements over the years--may suggest; over last year in particular, Greenspan has prodded Fed to consider whether sweeping changes like huge investments by businesses in technology might have given economy greater capacity for noninflationary growth than conventional theories might hold (M)

headline: Experimental Price Index Offers Glimpse of a Lower-Cost Future
abstract: Labor Department statisticians introduce experimental version of Consumer Price Index that could shrink inflation readings and thus save Government billions of dollars a year in payments to Social Security recipients and beneficiaries of other programs; if adopted in full, probably in 1999, experiment's methodology is estimated to reduce rise of price increase by about one-quarter of a point, compared with current method; measured by current method, inflation was 3.3 percent in 1996; graph (L)

headline: U.S. IS CONSIDERING CURBS ON MEXICANS TIED TO NARCOTICS
abstract: Clinton Administration quietly weighs proposals to impose economic sanctions on Mexico's biggest drug traffickers; proposals include freezing suspected traffickers American assets, barring their legitimate commercial ventures from doing business in United States and blocking their access to American banks; such sanctions are already in use against top Colombian cocaine producers and hundreds of their associates; opponents warn moves could damage Mexican economy, where traffickers are heavily invested (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Rise to New Highs In Broad but Quiet Rally  Stocks climbed to new highs in a broad rally. Technology and small-company stocks, in particular, posted strong gains, showing that they are catching up to the big names in the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500. The Dow reached its 20th high of the year in quiet trading, rising 87.78 points, or 1.2 percent, to 7,345.91.

headline: Honors
abstract: * Mary Lou Quinlan, president and chief executive of N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, a unit of the MacManus Group, was among eight women named to receive the 27th annual Matrix Awards, sponsored by New York Women in Communications.

headline: Terrorism's Worldwide Toll Was High in 1996, U.S. Report Says
abstract: State Dept report finds that international terrorist attacks killed 311 people worldwide last year, one of highest death tolls recorded; says nearly 200 of deaths were work of Tamil Tigers, separatist group in Sri Lanka; lists Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea, Sudan, Syria and Cuba as nations that sponsor such attacks; says only Iran was directly linked to any of terrorist bombings and killings last year (M)

headline: Adidas Says Profits Jumped 33% in Quarter
abstract: Adidas AG says profit climbed 33 percent in first quarter, to 169 million German marks ($97.5 million), from 127 million marks a year earlier; sales rose 42.5 percent, to 1.71 billion marks, from 1.2 billion marks a year earlier (S)

headline: A Champion of the Euro Finds That All Economics Is Local
abstract: German Finance Min Theo Waigel, who has done most to bludgeon and cajole rest of continent toward single currency on Germany's terms, finds himself, paradoxically, under mounting pressure to put Germany's own books in order so it will qualify to join single currency in January 1999; his effort has become act of budgetary high-wire maneuvering that most economists say looks uncertain (M)

headline: The Heir Is Clearly Apparent at Comcast
abstract: Interview with Ralph Roberts, 77-year-old founder and chairman of family-run Comcast Corp; he will soon turn over control of company to son Brian, who is president; photos; graph (M)

headline: As a Rebel's Path Ends, Hard Turf but Soft Hearts
abstract: Residents of Villa Maria del Triunfo, Peru, where slain Tupac Amaru leader Nestor Cerpa Cartolini was buried following commando raid that rescued hostages from Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima, express sympathy over his death and those of 13 other rebels killed during operation; photo (M)

headline: A Cosmetics Heir's Joint Venture Is Tainted by Ukrainian's Past
abstract: Cosmetics' heir Ronald Lauder's joint television venture in Ukraine with Vadim Rabinovich, self-made Ukrainian millionaire, raises eyebrows among Western diplomats and businessmen in both Washington and Kiev; Rabinovich spent nine years in Soviet prison for theft, and has been linked to suspected Russian criminal figure; there is also concern because their joint venture apparently received favored treatment from Ukrainian Govt; Western companies hoping to wedge their way into previously closed markets often find they must turn to local partners whose ties to govt are essential but whose backgrounds stir ripples; that can raise problems for publicly traded companies like Lauder's fledgling Central European Media Enterprises; such companies have legal obligation to disclose significant problems with their partners, particularly if they are to have management role; photo of Lauder (M)

headline: A Partly Alien Place Joins China Today
abstract: Hong Kong, which will revert to China after 156 years under British rule, is place unlike any on Chinese mainland; has free press and free markets that help fuel its growth; is place accustomed to its own mind, where people insist on controlling their own future; photos; maps (M)

headline: Chairman Reportedly Ousted at EMI Unit
abstract: Charles A Koppelman, chairman of EMI-North America, is ousted and is likely to be replaced by Ken Berry, president of EMI International (S)

headline: Pope, in Sarajevo, Calls for Forgiveness
abstract: Pope John Paul II celebrates Mass in Sarajevo, near graveyard full of Bosnian war victims; urges reconciliation and offers solace to Bosnia's dwindling Catholic population; city residents laud him for lending his moral authority to rebuilding effort; Pope meets separately with Bosnia's Orthodox Christian, Muslim and Jewish religious leaders; photos (M)

headline: Wealthy Texan Has Tough Talk For 2 Daughters
abstract: Harold C Simmons, Dallas investor, strikes back at two daughters who have challenged his control of billion-dollar fortune in lawsuit that threatens his control of at least four Big Board corporations; asserts that two daughters, Scheryle S Patigian and Andrea Swanson, can not handle any more money than the substantial amounts he has given them (M)

headline: C-Net Promotes a Novel Idea: The Internet Should Be Easy
abstract: C-Net Inc plans to offer new Internet service in partnership with phone companies, banks, brokerage firms, consumer products makers and personal computer vendors that will be free addition to what consumers already pay for access to Internet through some of these firms; service, Snap Online, will have features of competing on-line services, including news, chat and directions to thousands of Web sites; will provide space on its home page for partners to communicate directly with consumers and collect demographic data on them; will offer beginners tutorial on CD-ROM that will explain Internet in simple terms (M)

headline: The downside of Europe's one-size-fits all monetary policy.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene article questions wisdom of Europe's planned currency integration; doubts Germany's traditionally tight-fisted monetary policy should prevail in economically heterogenous Europe; drawing (M)

headline: Lacking Luster, U.S. Global Still Pans for Gold
abstract: US Global Investors, which manages $1.4 billion in assets in 15 mutual funds and whose fortunes have long been tied to gold market, remains optimistic over future financial prospects; became stuck with more than 300,000 shares of Bre-X Ltd, which went bankrupt in May; efforts to diversify away from gold have faltered, and company has lost some key executives; graph; photo (M)

headline: Mark Firms Against Dollar Amid Concerns About Euro
abstract: US dollar falls against most leading currencies as German mark strengthens on concern that European monetary union might not proceed as planned (M)

headline: When 'Celebrity' Consultants Sort Out the Dirty Laundry
abstract: Consumers Union president Rhoda H Karpatkin article expresses skepticism about companies turning to high-cost celebrities and lawyers to 'review' public complaints about working conditions or employment practices; suggests basic rules for research and reporting by celebrity consultants (M)

headline: Zaire General Calls for a 'Fight to Death' to Defend the Capital
abstract: Gen N'Zimbi Ngbale, head of Mobutu Sese Seko's Presidential Guard, urges his troops to fight to death to defend Kinshasa from rebels rapidly closing in on capital, radio speech; says reinforcements are being sent to defend Kiwit, last sizable city between rebel-held areas and capital; guard is composed mostly of soldiers from northern ethnic groups that see their fate as tied to Mobutu (M)

headline: CFM STOCK FALLS 21% ON NEWS OF INCREASED SPENDING
abstract: Stock of CFM Technologies Inc falls 21 percent after company says it will increase spending to develop new products; CFM makes cleaning equipment used in producing computer-memory chips and flat-panel displays (S)

headline: Unrest Erupts In Argentina Over Austerity
abstract: Violent protests over Government's economic reforms have erupted in major cities and towns throughtout Argentina in recent days; reforms have brought stability and high growth rates to nation once plagued by hyperinflation, but have also produced record unemployment as inefficient state industries were sold off and number of state employees drastically cut (M)

headline: A Question of Skills
abstract: Analysis of Viacom Inc chairman-chief executive Sumner M Redstone's executive skills in light of plunge in company's stock on news of overhaul of company's Blockbuster video business; photo (L)

headline: Boeing, Challenging Airbus, Seeks to Sell Planes to China
abstract: Boeing Co, matching proposal from its rival, Airbus Industrie, is seeking to sell China 100 aircraft valued at about $4 billion (M)

headline: Spain to Meet Economic Goals
abstract: Spain's Finance Ministry says Spain expects 3.2 percent annual growth through 2000, strong enough to maintain economic discipline demanded by European Union; ministry predicts inflation will grow at average of 2.3 percent and Government's deficit as percentage of gross domestic product will fall to 1.6 percent (S)

headline: It's One Rally After Another as the Mexican Vote Draws Near
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Mexico City residents pour into central plaza for mass demonstrations called by each of three main political parties, bringing city's first mayoral campaign of modern times to tumultous climax befome July 7 balloting; Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, leftist candidate who holds broad lead in opinion polls, congratulates Pres Ernesto Zedillo for working to set stage for fair elections; also warns that backers will defend their votes in event of electoral fraud they believed lost him vote in 1988 (M)

headline: Gates's Gift to Libraries
abstract: William H. Gates, the software entrepreneur sometimes criticized for being slow to give away his billions, is creating a foundation to spend $200 million to bring computers and the Internet into public libraries. It is the largest charitable effort by Mr. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft.   Business Day, page D1.

headline: France's Prime Minister Stumps, but Where's That Elan?
abstract: Prime Min Alain Juppe campaigns for re-election in France's Lorraine region; campaign stops are poorly attended; Pres Jacques Chirac plans statement to be published in regional newspapers to boost Juppe; responds to polls showing opposition parties are gaining (M)

headline: The Upside Of Employer Securities
abstract: Letter from J Michael Keeling and David L Wray on Mar 16 article about companies' offering their own stock in 401(k) plans (S)

headline: Stocks Bounce Back After a Big Selloff
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average flirted yesterday with a 10 percent decline from its recent peak before roaring back to close up about 60 points for the day.    Stocks had fallen sharply on Friday, and some investors were worried that if the Dow fell another 15 points, to 10 percent below the record it set on March 11, the bull market might be in serious jeopardy.

headline: COMCAST CORP. (CMCSK, NNM)
abstract: Comcast Corp reports larger-than-expected first-quarter loss; loss grew to $64.7 million from $34.6 million; revenue rose nearly 19 percent, to $1.13 billion from $950.7 million; table (S)

headline: Newspaper owners proselytize business sense to their reporters and editors.
abstract: Hard-pressed newspaper publishers around country are adopting campaigns aimed at getting their reporters and editors to accept cold facts about newspaper business these days; aim is to make news staff more aware of customer who is reading paper, the advertisers, and the community; Steve Geimann, president of Society of Professional Journalists, supports efforts to make news staff more aware of how business works in general, but he notes danger if business interests begin to impinge on news values; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Will Give Spanish Judge Documents for Pinochet Inquiry
abstract: US agrees to provide Government documents to Spanish Judge Manuel Garcia Castellon, who is investigating terrorism and human-rights violations in Chile during dictatorship of Gen Augusto Pinochet from 1973 to 1990 (M)

headline: A Weak Year For New Issues In Technology
abstract: Market Place: Record number of technology companies went public in 1995 and 1996 as investors clamored to own piece of what they hoped would be next Intel or Microsoft; but with many of last year's hot new issues faltering, the market for initial public offerings in high technology companies has tumbled; Securities Data Co says this year, new-issues market is down 35 percent from its pace last year, when record $49 billion was raised through 865 public offerings; graphs (L)

headline: Burnett Wins Print Competition
abstract: Leo Burnett Company's British agency wins top award at print portion of 44th International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France (Advertising column) (S)

headline: PHYSICIAN CORP. ASKS LENDERS FOR TIME TO PAY ITS LOANS
abstract: Physician Corp of America asks lenders for more time to review ways to pay its loans after Sierra Health Services Inc canceled plans on March 18 to buy the company and left it in default of $102 million in bank debt; Physician Corp says it had fourth-quarter loss of $182.6 million on revenue of $365.1 million (S)

headline: Congo Demonstration Ban
abstract: President Kabila banned political activity and demonstrations in Congo today, and an opposition leader called a protest march. Page A10.

headline: U.S. Trying To Smooth Mexico Path For Clinton
abstract: Top Clinton Administration aides have begun drive to assuage suspicions and rebuild ties with Mexico in advance of Pres Clinton's visit; respond to surge of mistrust and hostility toward United States; officials, including Drug Control Policy Office head Gen Barry McCaffrey, Immigration and Naturalization Service Comr Doris Meissner and Thomas F McLarty, special envoy for Americas, are making series of public appearances to assure ordinary Mexicans of Clinton's friendship (M)

headline: For Digital's Chief, A Last Grab for Glory
abstract: Profile of Digital Equipment Corp; pressure is mounting on chairman and chief executive Robert B Palmer to halt computer maker's slide from top corporate ranks; he has cut 59,000 of firm's 114,000 jobs since taking over in 1992 and posted billions of dollars in losses; Providence Capital Inc, investment firm known for aggressive drives against corporate management, has invited shareholders to June forum; graph; tables; photo (L)

headline: More Charges in APL Case
abstract: SEC identifies two more defendants in insider trading case involving deal for APL Ltd, shipping line; files complaint against Raymond Lum Kwan Sung, chairman of Lum Chun Holdings Inc, of Singapore, and Abdul Ismail of London, accusing them with using inside information to profit from Neptune Orient Lines Ltd's planned $825 million purchase of APL (S)

headline: Turks Say Bonn Is Encouraging Racist Attacks
abstract: Angered by recent attacks on Turks in Germany, Turkish and German officials are trading angry charges, straining their troubled friendship; Turkish Govt this week lists 17 such attacks since beginning of 1997, including one on Monday in Krefield in which Turkish woman and her two children were killed after arsonist set fire to their home; statement is followed by unusually sharp attacks on Germany by Turkish officials and news commentators; Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan contends attacks are result of 'anti-Muslim campaign' in Germany; German officials reject charges, and they seem at least partly vindicated when police in Krefeld arrest husband and father of arson victims, charging him with arson (M)

headline: P.&G. Posts 16% Increase In Earnings
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co says earnings rose 16 percent in fiscal third quarter; net income rose to $881 million from $760 million a year earlier; revenue rose 2.1 percent, to $8.77 billion, from $8.59 billion; sales volume grew 4 percent; table (M)

headline: S.& P. 500 Replacement
abstract: Shares of Countrywide Credit Industries gain 8 percent on news that company will be added to Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, replacing USLife Corp; S&P is replacing USLife because company is being acquired by American General Corp, which is also a component of S&P 500 (S)

headline: Thousands Go on Strike at Goodyear Plants
abstract: More than 12,000 members of United Steelworkers of America who work at Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co go on strike at nine plants, after failing to reach agreement on job security and wage and benefit issues; union and company break off talks; Goodyear is trying to keep its labor costs in line with those of big competitors, and union is reeling from loss of as many as 4,000 jobs last year (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Industrials Up 44.15, With Banking Issues Strong  Blue-chip stocks rallied, with the Dow industrials rising 44.15 points, to 6,783.02. The market overcame a selloff in Boeing to snap a three-session losing streak.    Interest-rate-sensitive stocks, such as those of banks, American Express and Travelers Group, which could suffer should inflation rise, were strong, showing that there is confidence in the market's prospects. $(Page D12.$)    Treasury prices rose, with the 30-year bond yield slipping to 7.11 percent from 7.14. $(D19.$)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * Fannie Mae is selling $200 million of medium-term notes due in 2002 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The notes are noncallable, carry an interest rate of 6.7 percent and are priced at par.    * Fannie Mae is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2004 through Merrill Lynch & Company. The notes have a one-time call on May 7, 1998, carry an interest rate of 7.22 percent and are priced at par.

headline: DASSAULT SYSTEMES IS ACQUIRING SOLIDWORKS
abstract: Dassault Systemes SA to acquire Solidworks Corp for stock valued at about $300 million (S)

headline: Magazine Executive Gets a New Post
abstract: Jack Kliger, one of three executive vice presidents at Conde Nast Publications, is leaving that post, effective June 2, to become executive vice president of Parade Publications; both are units of Advance Publications (S)

headline: Phone Companies' Earnings Meet Forecasts
abstract: Ameritech Corp tops analysts' forecasts with 12 percent earnings increase on 26 percent rise in sales in first quarter; GTE Corp says earnings rose 7.95 percent; Sprint Corp reports 6.1 percent decline in profits; Ameritech earned $536 million, up from $478 million in quarter a year earlier; sales rose 8.1 percent, to $3.86 billion from $3.57 billion; GTE says it earned $665 million, up from $616 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 6.7 percent, to $5.28 billion from $4.95 billion; Sprint earned $290 million, down from $309 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 7.4 percent, to $3.62 billion from $3.37 billion; tables (L)

headline: Laura Ashley Falls 28%; It Won't Meet Forecasts
abstract: Shares of Laura Ashley Holdings PLC plunge 28 percent after retailer warns that current-year profit will fail to meet expectations (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Hampel/Stefanides, New York, has resigned the account of the New York Restaurant Group, which the agency had handled since August 1995. The agency cited creative and philosophical differences. Billings on the account were estimated at $1 million to $1.5 million. The restaurants owned by the company include Smith & Wollensky and the Post House.

headline: Capitalism doesn't always take. Location, it seems, is destiny.
abstract: Economic Scene column on theory by Jeffrey Sachs, director of Institute for International Development at Harvard University, that geography, climate and resources play larger role in success of capitalist society than generally acknowledged; says while East Asia is doing splendidly, and former socialist countries of Eastern Europe have paused to regroup, Africa and Latin America are riddled with places where problems cannot be written off to failure to follow capitalist doctrine; holds Asian living standards will approach those in the West in next few decades; but tropics in general, and sub-Saharan Africa in particular, are not going to prosper economically anytime soon; drawing (L)

headline: KODAK IS TEST-MARKETING FILM FOR DISCOUNT MARKET
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co is test-marketing brand of discount film called Colorburst to compete with low-cost film brands; Kodak is selling film, which does not carry Kodak name, in five or fewer undisclosed markets in US; new film, which uses older-technology film emulsion, does not have same quality as Kodak's brand-name film (S)

headline: Haggar Moves Account To GSD& M in Austin
abstract: Haggar Clothing Co moves its advertising account without review to GSD&M unit of GGT Group in Austin, Tex, after three years at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco; billings estimated at $12.5 million (S)

headline: China Jails Audio and Movie Disk Pirates
abstract: Supreme People's Court of China, as part of nationwide crackdown on illegal copying of movies and music, announces heavy prison sentences in two prominent cases of copyright piracy; Pu Xinghua, former deputy general manager of Suzhou Baodie Compact Disk Company, is sentenced to 17 years in prison for pirating more than three million audio and video compact disks worth about $1.5 million; Wang Binyan, former chairman and general manager of Cailing Audio and Video Products in Guangzhou, is sentenced to four years for copying more than five million audio and video disks (L)

headline: Unfazed by Gingrich, China Agrees With Some of What He Said
abstract: Chinese Government indicates that it is essentially pleased with remarks by House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who said during recent visit to China that he accepted one-China policy but that US would defend Taiwan militarily if it was attacked (M)

headline: Accommodating the Tastes of Black Readers
abstract: Comment on South African book scene; sales are declining with emigration of thousands of white professionals to Canada and England, and publishers are trying to adjust to tastes of blacks with little money and no particular tradition of reading; photo (S)

headline: Treasury Securities' Prices Fall
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities fall; 30-year bond slides 13/32, to price of 96 10/32, and yield rises to 6.92 percent, from 6.89 percent on May 12 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SYNBIOTICS CORP., San Diego, a provider of animal health-care diagnostics and vaccines, will buy Rhone-Poulenc S.A.'s veterinary diagnostics unit for $14.98 million in cash and shares.    POST PROPERTIES INC., Atlanta, announced the sale of its 416-unit apartment complex in Pompano Beach, Fla., to Equity Residential Property Trust, Chicago, for $23.6 million.

headline: Attorneys General Defend Landmark Tobacco Pact
abstract: State attorneys general defend pact they reached with tobacco companies after nearly three months of talks as unprecedented leap forward on vital public health issue, meeting of their national association, Grand Teton National Park, Wyo; hold critics focus on minor flaws; negotiating team wins support from colleagues across party and regional lines (M)

headline: Hong Kong Still Carries Britannia's Indelible Mark
abstract: Hong Kong, being returned to China after 156 years of British colonial rule, carries Britain's mark in many ways, most obviously in use of English; British legacy includes both infrastructure and rule of law, legal system, parliamentary democracy and free press; chronology of events; photos (M)

headline: Short Positions on Nasdaq Rose 3.4% in Latest Month
abstract: Short-sellers became more active in recent weeks as the Nasdaq stock market rebounded from its recent decline, according to figures released yesterday.    Open positions of short sales on Nasdaq, or shares borrowed and sold but not yet repurchased, rose 3.4 percent, to 1.53 billion shares, in the most recent month from 1.48 billion shares in the previous month, the market reported.

headline: Monopolies Still Rule the Local Phone Markets
abstract: Study by Yankee Group, telecommunications research firm, shows sixteen months after Government opened $100 billion local phone market to competition, fewer than half of 1 percent of Americans receive their residential phone service from a competitor to the monopoly provider; finds most likely rivals to local monopolies--AT&T, MCI and other long-distance carriers--are entering residential market only grudgingly; report is sure to stoke anger of consumer advocates who argue the Telecommunications Act of 1996 has failed to deliver on its central promise of fostering competition in local phone business; Ameritech Corp reapplies to Federal Communications Commission for permission to offer long-distance service in Michigan; AT&T issues statement urging commission to rebuff Ameritech yet again because there is no discernible competition in Michigan (L)

headline: Killing Casts Focus on Abuse in Chile's Military
abstract: Mysterious death of military recruit Pedro Soto, 19, has raised storm of protest in Chile demanding end to mandatory military service; follows seven suicides by military recruits in last year and dozens of cases of physical and mental torture; Soto's family charges army failed to protect him from physical abuse that has long been part of miitary training; photo (M)

headline: CBS-TV Drags Down Westinghouse Results
abstract: Westinghouse Electric Corp reports net loss in first quarter and wider loss from continuing operations as poor performance of its CBS television unit more than offsets strong results at its radio network; net loss is put at $151 million, or 23 cents a share, and compares with net income year earlier of $181 million, or 41 cents a share; table (S)

headline: CHIEF OF WMX WOULD GIVE UP DUTIES FOR RIGHT SUCCESSOR
abstract: WMX Techologies says chairman Dean Buntrock is set to give up management duties in order to attract first-rate successor (S)

headline: A Low Price for Better Health Care
abstract: Viewpoint article by William a Mundell and Jack Friedman holds that the benefits of Federal Government investment in basic medical research are so great, and the costs so low, that an increase is justified in any budget picture (M)

headline: Sales Increase 18% At Roche Holding
abstract: Roche Holding AG says sales rose lower-than-expected 18 percent in first quarter; sales rose to 4.45 billion francs ($3.02 billion), from 3.79 bilion francs (S)

headline: Pope's Less Confrontational Tone Pleases Friends in Cracow
abstract: Pope John Paul II's less confrontational tone during recent visit to Polish homeland has pleased many old friends and colleagues, who felt he had been given bad advice by clerics during trip in 1991, when he adopted narrowly focused, combative tone about dangers of permissive society that struck false note (M)

headline: Sue Sumii, Writer, 95, Dies; Ally of Japan's Untouchables
abstract: Sue Sumii, human rights campaigner whose novel helped change attitudes toward Japan's 'untouchables,' dies at age 95; photo (M)

headline: A Reported Sighting of Pol Pot, in Custody
abstract: Gen Nhiek Bun Chhay, senior Cambodian general and adviser to First Prime Min Norodom Ranariddh, says he saw Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot at his headquarters in northern Cambodia, and that he is being held prisoner by his own soldiers; says he expects him to be handed over to Government soon; map; photo (M)

headline: Illegal Chinese Race to Get Toehold in Hong Kong
abstract: Hong Kong and Chinese authorities intensify efforts to keep many thousands of Chinese from trying to escape vast poverty of mainland for compact neon glitter of Hong Kong; fences at border are topped with razor wire and high-speed boats patrol harbor to thwart illegal immigrants trying to get into colony before it reverts to China, hoping that amnesty will be declared afterwards; photo; mainland Chinese are in general not allowed to move to Hong Kong, now or in future; most of illegals are trying to reunite families separated over years (S)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : City Dwellers Rush to Purchase A Piece of Nowhere in Nevada
abstract: For city dwellers tired of soot, smog and congestion, it seemed a dream: to own a square mile of land in the vast, empty expanses of Nevada, far from the madding crowd, in a place without squealing brakes or barking dogs or slamming doors, where at night, as one admirer put it, "the stars come all the way down to the ground.'

headline: Turkish Panel Links Killings To Authorities
abstract: Turkish Parliamentary commission, investigating charges that Government sponsored death squads and allowed gunmen to smuggle drugs and commit other crimes, recommends that two members of Parliament be stripped of immunity and brought to trial; says as Sedat Bucak, chief of pro-Government Kurdish militia and Mehmet Agar, former Interior Minister, may have been leaders of shadowy gang used by Government in recent years to assassinate perceived enemies of state (M)

headline: Chinese Unit Buys Hong Kong Bank Stake
abstract: China Resources Enterprises Ltd, investment arm of China's Foreign Trade Ministry, to buy 50 percent of Hong Kong Chinese Bank owned by its parent firm, China Resources Holdings Co, for $2 billion (Hong Kong) (US $258 million); will rename bank China Resources Bank (S)

headline: Ulster Talks Resume With Warning That Violence Can End Them
abstract: Stalled Northern Ireland peace talks resume, Belfast, amid renewed sectarian violence; George J Mitchell, who heads talks, warns all sides that continued violence and political instransigence could undermine effort; says new British Government of Prime Min Tony Blair gives talks new impetus (M)

headline: Hispanic Network And Seiko Sign Deal
abstract: CBS Telenoticias, a 24-hour Spanish-language news network, signs Seiko Corp as its 'official timekeeper'; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Scandals Mar Last Leg of Korean Leader's Term
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Young Sam approaches final leg of his term under cloud of suspicion and distrust stemming from accusation that he may have taken millions of dollars in illegal campaign funds and from widespread belief that one of sons took money in influence-peddling scheme; many South Koreans believe Kim, who followed series of military leaders, may have been involved in kind of scandals he so boldly staked reputation on uprooting (M)

headline: Airbus to Make Bigger Versions Of Large Jet
abstract: Airbus Industrie to build two larger versions of its biggest jet, A340; says A340-600 will carry 378 passengers in three seating classes; says A340-500 will be its longest-range plane, able to fly 8,300 nautical miles; Airbus managing director Jean Pierson charges Boeing Co's proposed purchase of McDonnell Douglas Corp is effort to force Airbus out of business, news conference (M)

headline: AMERICA ONLINE AND CUC SHOPPING SERVICE FORM VENTURE
abstract: America Online Inc and CUC International Inc are joining forces; under three-year agreement, America Online will receive $50 million in fees plus potential other payments from revenue-sharing arrangement; CUC is expected to generate more than a million annual memberships for America Online (S)

headline: House Defeats Effort to Punish China by Curbing Trade
abstract: House rejects, 259-173, attempt to punish China by ending its normal trading status with US; 173 votes registered by critics of China represent highest total since 1992; photo (M)

headline: REPUBLIC REPORTS BIG GAIN ON SALE OF ADT STOCK
abstract: Republic Industries says it sold 15 million shares of ADT Ltd for $412.5 million, making a 38 percent profit in little more than a month (S)

headline: Office Complaints: Voices in the Wilderness
abstract: Readers report their office complaints; drawing (M)

headline: Profit at Digital Equipment Fell 59% in Third Quarter
abstract: Digital Equipment Corp reports 59 percent drop in profits for its third quarter; company earned $51 million, compared with $124 million in quarter a year earlier; revenue declined slightly, to $3.31 billion from $3.62 billion; table (L)

headline: SUNBEAM EXPLORES TAKEOVER AND SALE OPTIONS
abstract: Sunbeam Corp is interviewing investment bankers to explore options, ranging from making hostile takeovers as big as $5 billion to selling company (S)

headline: Digital Pay TV In Germany Is Rough Going For Kirch Group
abstract: Germany's Kirsch Group has invested over $1 billion in year-old DF-1, digital pay-television service that has so far attracted only 40,000 customers; Kirch, which controls programming needed for such venture, has been unable to join with either Bertelsmann AG or Deutsche Telekom AG, which have key customer bases; Kirsch is hunting for new partners and capital and continues talks with both rivals (M)

headline: For Revolutionary Group, an All-Out Offensive Turns Into Disastrous Defeat
abstract: Violent end to Peru's hostage crisis leaves guerrilla group that carried out siege, Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, with most of its members either dead or in jail; seizing of Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima was desperate last-ditch gamble for Tupac Amaru, Peru's second-largest rebel group; photo (M)

headline: Australians Resist Facing Up to Legacy of Parting Aborigines From Families
abstract: Australian Government's Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, after an inquiry into Govt policy regarding Aborigines, sets off political firestorm by calling old policy of separating some Aborigine children from their families 'genocidal' and urging reparations and establishment of annual national day of apology; as many as 100,000 Aboriginal children were forcibly removed from their families between 1910 and early 1970's; at time program was considered to be in children's best interest, but it had another acknowledged purpose: to wipe out a people; photo; map (M)

headline: In Japan, Use of Dead Has the Living Uneasy
abstract: Japan is locked in debate over whether to legally define boundaries of death and allow organ transplants; issue is before Parliament, but it is so sensitive that lawmakers have decided--for first time in many years--to vote their consciences and not to issue any party positions; process of removing vital organs for transplants is more difficult to accomplish in Japan because it does not recognize brain death as death; there are two proposals to legalize organ transplants in Japan; one recognizes brain death as death; photo of Wakana Kume, 16-year-old who traveled to Australia two years ago to receive liver transplant from brain-dead patient (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Pitney Bowes  Total Sys Svcs

headline: Sears of Britain to Sell Its Mail Order Unit
abstract: Sears PLC of Britain will sell its Freemans mail order unit to Littlewoods Organization for 395 million pounds, or $664.2 million; it will also spin off its flagship department store unit to shareholders next year and sell part of its shoe business; company reports it had pretax profit of 68.1 million pounds in year ended Jan 31 (S)

headline: Bre-X: From Rags to Riches, Back to Rags
abstract: American and Indonesian companies that only a few months ago were fighting for the right to help Bre-X Minerals Ltd of Canada mine what had been touted as century's richest gold strike walk away from the project and leave Bre-X on its own to defend what is being called one of the scams of the century; Bre-X faces fallout from devastating report concluding that Indonesian mother lode at Busang was nothing but fabulous tale backed by false hopes and counterfeit data; finding is likely to wipe out whatever value is left in Bre-X's battered stock; photo (L)

headline: FORCENERGY OF MIAMI IS PLANNING AN EXPANSION
abstract: Forcenergy Inc will accquire Edisto Resources Corp and Convest Energy Corp for total of $172.1 million (S)

headline: KRAFT TO SELL CHEESE DISTRIBUTOR TO SCHRATTER FOODS
abstract: Kraft Foods agrees to sell its Anco Foods cheese distribution business to Schratter Foods, unit of Bongrain Group; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: The budget deficit problem will be back, with a vengeance.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Federal budget deal between Congress and Clinton Administration and forecast that Federal budget deficit will balloon after year 2002; says while accord should balance budget in 2002, there will be little time to savor triumph before Federal leaders are again choking on deficits; holds by 2020, when baby boomers have retired, big entitlements will account for 14 percent of Gross Domestic Product, and deficit will reach 7 percent of GDP; says by 2050 the deficit reaches 18 percent of GDP--meaning that unless policies change, Federal spending will be almost twice as large as revenues; holds while Washington leaders have put deficit to sleep, it is bound to come back rested and ready to wreck political havoc; drawing (L)

headline: As Mobutu Totters, France Ponders Options
abstract: France seems at loss in midst of rebellion that threatens to bring down Pres Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, one of its oldest allies; gains by rebels are seen as one of most serious setbacks in years for its policy in region (M)

headline: An Executive Shuffle in Nomura's Scandal
abstract: Japan's Nomura Securities Co, which has been tumbling from its heights because of scandal linking it to Japanese gangsters, announces that group of top executives will step down from their current positions; Nomura promotes Junichi Ujiie to take over as president; top ten executives, including president Masashi Suzuki, will relinquish their powers as voting members of the board, and five other directors will also step down (M)

headline: In French Race, Economy Will Sour the Victor's Future
abstract: Polls on eve of French parliamentary elections show that opposition Socialist Party, which has been out of power since 1993, is within reach of dramatic comeback that could put its leader, Lionel Jospin, in Prime Minister's office; that is not what Pres Jacques Chirac had in mind when, seeking mandate for deficit-cutting required to get France into common European currency in 1999, he called election year before end of legislative term; photo (M)

headline: 3 Companies Seek to End Phone Subsidy
abstract: AT&T, Bell Atlantic and Nynex make joint proposal to eliminate $2.5 billion in subsidies from industry while increasing local phone bills by 75 cents each month; proposal is attempt to settle raging debate within the industry about how much Government should reduce access charges that long-distance carriers pay to local phone companies (M)

headline: American Express Posts Profit Rise
abstract: American Express Co says earnings rose about 15 percent in first quarter; company earned $454 million compared with $396 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 6.5 percent, to $4.16 billion from $3.91 billion; operating expenses rose about 5.4 percent, to $3.52 billion from $3.34 billion last year; American Express Financial Advisers reports 21 percent rise in earnings, to $157 million, while total revenue rose 8.1 percent, to $1.08 billion; table (L)

headline: China Reports Sharp Decline In Inflation
abstract: Prime Min Li Peng of China says his nation's inflation rate fell to 3 percent in first quarter; many economists say it is remarkable that inflation fell so far at time when economy was expanding by 9.7 percent; they say figures might have been skewed somewhat by short-term factors like unusually strong harvest and overproduction of some goods; Li, at international business conference in Shanghai, predicts that economic growth will continue at annual rate of 8 percent over next three years and average 7 percent in decade that follows (M)

headline: I.B.M. to Introduce A New Product Line Of Data Storers
abstract: International Business Machines Corp to offer new line of data storage products that will give different types of computers using different operating system software access to data from single source; will not begin shipping key products until end of 1997 and sometime in 1998 (S)

headline: Antitrust Pact With Australia
abstract: US and Australia reach agreement to help each other uncover evidence of antitrust violations, a move intended to strengthen worldwide enforcement of price fixing and other anticompetitive activity; pact is first of what officials say will be series of agreements with major American trading partners (S)

headline: HUNT TO CUT WORK FORCE AND TRIM PRODUCT LINE
abstract: Hunt Manufacturing Co will lay off 15 percent of its staff and take charge of $14 million to $16 million in 1997 as it concentrates on most profitable segments of its office supply business; company plans to cut 300 jobs and trim variety of products it makes by 71 percent (S)

headline: Philip Morris To Pay Most Of First Bill
abstract: Industry aides say five tobacco companies involved in settlement will divide initial $10 billion payment under proposed $368.5 billion deal based on their stock market value, with largest firm, Philip Morris Cos, paying some $6.5 billion; subsequent annual payments, which will start at $8.5 billion and grow to $15 billion, will be divided based on each firm's share of United States cigarette market; Philip Morris Cos has about 50 percent share and RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp about 25 percent; RJR says its share of initial payment will be about $600 million; graph (M)

headline: Graduating With Honors And $100,000 in Debt
abstract: ON Thursday, Denis Gibbs will don cap and gown to receive a Bachelor of Arts degree from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Soon after he completes his four-year college journey, he will begin another long trip: paying off, over 10 years, a six-figure accumulation of loans.    Mr. Gibbs, 22, is hardly without resources. He is ambitious and smart, having made Phi Beta Kappa while majoring in international studies and German. And he has landed a job on Wall Street, at Smith Barney, where he will be paid a salary in the mid-$30,000 range, plus the potential for bonuses, to help evaluate the performance of the firm's divisions. He plans to begin work on July 7.

headline: Acorn Fund
abstract: Interview with Ralph Wanger, manager of Acorn Fund, which has had five-year annualized return of 19.61 percent, compared with average of 17.89 percent for small-company funds; photo; graph (M)

headline: Italian Coalition Faces Revolt on Plan to Send Troops to Albania
abstract: Italian Government is thrown into crisis as it scrambles to avert humiliating defeat in Parliament of Prime Min Romano Prodi's plan for Italian troops to lead multinational force to Albania (M)

headline: France Rejects G.E. of Britain
abstract: France rejects General Electric Company PLC of Britain as prime bidder for state's 58 percent stake in Thomson-CSF, citing national security interests (S)

headline: Europe Ruling Assured On British Air-American
abstract: European Commission will rule on planned trans-Atlantic alliance between British Airways PLC and American Airlines well before November (S)

headline: When the Policy Covers Only One Disease
abstract: Consumer groups widely critize cancer insurance; say consumers sometimes do no understand coverage limitations and can have difficult time collecting even when they do contract cancer; such insurance returns far fewer premium dollars to policyholders than standard health insurance; Aflac Inc, which spends heavily on lobbying to end New York ban on sale of such policies, defends insurance; graph; photo (L)/

headline: Hot Issue for Russia: Should It Return Nazi Plunder?
abstract: Fate of looted art and European and German historical papers seized by Soviet Army from Nazis at end of World War II is focus of hot debate in Russia; nationalists demand Russia keep material and European nations demand restitution; Pres Boris N Yeltsin, visiting Germany, suggests he will defy Parliament and make symbolic return of several items to Chancellor Helmut Kohl; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Team to Investigate Congo Massacre Reports
abstract: United Nations officials say that experts will go to Congo this week to investigate charges that troops loyal to Pres Laurent Kabila had massacred Hutu refugees (S)

headline: All Eyes on New British Leader at European Union Meeting
abstract: Britain's new Prime Minister, Tony Blair, dominates meeting of leaders of 15 European Union nations; Blair has promised to sweeten his country's sour relations with Continent, and has already reversed position of predecessor Conservative Government by agreeing to sign workplace-reform protocol called the Social Chapter; Blair says Europeans need to adjust their sights to needs of individual citizens rather than of bureaucracy (M)

headline: Swiss Resist Disclosing Any Mobutu Bank Funds
abstract: Swiss banking authorities resist pressure to disclose or freeze vast sums of money Zairian Pres Mobutu Sese Seko is believed to have looted from country and deposited in Swiss bank acounts; while estimates of Mobutu's fortune range well into billions of dollars, some officials say only small part may ultimately be traceable to bank accounts to which he can be linked; Swiss legislators across political spectrum have called for inquiry into how much Mobutu may have deposited in secret accounts, and rebel leader Laurent Kabila says he will demand accounting from Swiss once he takes power (M)

headline: F.T.C. Rejects Deal To Join Two Giants Of Office Supplies
abstract: FTC, acting over objections from some staff members, rejects proposed $4 billion merger of two office supply discounters, Staples Inc and Office Depot Inc; votes 4 to 1 seek a Federal court injunction against merger, which would have created office superstore chain with more than 1,000 stores and $10 billion in annual sales; William J Baer, director of FTC antitrust division, contends proposed deal is undisguised and illegal attempt to eliminate competition between two chains and would inevitably lead to higher prices for consumers (M)

headline: McLeodUSA and Consolidated To Merge in $400 Million Deal
abstract: McLeodUSA Inc says it will buy Consolidated Communications Inc for $400 million in cash and stock; boards of two companies have approved deal (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Central Vt Pub  York Intl

headline: Pricing the Convenience of A.T.M.'s
abstract: Rick Rofman letter on ATM charges in California

headline: Elf and Total Consider Buybacks of Stock
abstract: Elf Aquitaine SA and Total SA say they are considering buying back chunks of their own stock in next few years in move intended to increase returns to shareholders (S)

headline: Financial Merger Blocked in Norway
abstract: Shareholders of Storebrand block plans to create Norway's largest financial company through $1.8 billion stock swap with Christiania Bank (S)

headline: Debt Offerings Expected This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and the sale of a 10-year inflation-indexed note tomorrow.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.13 percent and a six-month bill was 5.30 percent. The inflation- indexed note was priced to yield 3.60 percent.

headline: Brazil's Mighty Mite Saves the Day for African Cassava Crop
abstract: Researchers have greatly increased crop yields of cassava, starchy root that is a staple food for 200 million Africans, by returniong to plant's Latin American origins to control a destructive pest; control program, which employs tiny mite from Brazil to feast on a cassava-munching cousin, has improved yields by about one-third in field trials over three years in West Africa; an entomologist says that higher yields mean greater economic security for poor farmers, for whom cassava often is crop of last resort, and might help African agriculture keep pace with soaring population growth (M)

headline: Sony retools its electronics brand for the digital age.
abstract: Sony Electronics is beginning new print advertising campaign that it hopes will humanize and popularize its brand and products in hotly competitive digital era; new campaign, with budget estimated at $5 million to $10 million, is by Lowe & Partners/SMS; photo (L)

headline: 2 Shops Merge In Toronto
abstract: Toronto office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications merges with another shop in Toronto, Bensimon-Byrne (S)

headline: Digital Equipment Reshuffles, Again, to Try to Lift Fortunes
abstract: Digital Equipment Corp announces new management structure, latest reshuffling in continuing struggle of chairman-chief executive Robert B Palmer to reverse computer maker's declining fortunes; Digital will combine sales and marketing of all its computers into single worldwide organizations headed by Bruce L Claflin; Harold D Copperman, current head of company's high-performance systems unit, will be in charge of new poducts division (M)

headline: Study Sees Holes in Internet Security Plan
abstract: Panel of computer scientists, in study coordinated by Center for Democracy and Technology, say Government's plans for unlocking data-scrambling software to pursue criminals and terrorists on the Internet could actually increase security risks and raise costs of on-line commerce (M)

headline: Daewoo Gets 40% Stake In Kazakstan Company
abstract: Kazakhstan Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr Pavlov says Daewoo Corp of South Korea has won 40 percent stake in state-owned national telecommunications company, Kazaktelecom, bidding total of $1.37 billion (S)

headline: Sober Speculation Amid the Partying About Hong Kong
abstract: Article on prospects for mutual funds that invest in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan in light of Britain's hand-over of Hong Kong to China; table (L)

headline: Snapple Account Leaves Foote, Cone
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago said on Friday that it had resigned the Snapple beverage account, with billings estimated at $40 million, citing a conflict with a longtime client, Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. But the Triarc Companies, which acquired Snapple from the Quaker Oats Company, said Foote, Cone had been dismissed.    Foote, Cone, a unit of True North Communications, said the conflict stemmed from Triarc's ownership of soft drinks like RC Cola; Foote, Cone handles Cadbury Schweppes soft drinks like Sunkist.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Apr. 18   Apr. 11   Apr. 19          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.7   7.4   7.3       Distillate production, daily   3.3   3.4   3.4       Gasoline stocks   194.6   196.5   203.5       Distillate stocks   96.3   101.0   88.4       Crude imports, daily   8.0   7.8   7.3       Product imports, daily   2.1   2.2   1.5       Crude stocks   312.8   311.4   297.6       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   93.5   93.6   91.9          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: New Strife Leads Netanyahu To Schedule a Visit to Clinton
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu schedules visit to Washington to meet Pres Clinton on April 7, as sense of crisis worsens in Middle East; two explosions in Gaza that Israel says are suicide bombing attempts and fatal shooting of two Palestinians in West Bank give fresh impetus to spiral of violence between Palestinians and Israelis; each explosion kills Palestinian; King Hussein of Jordan says crisis requires 'more active US role'; map (M)

headline: APL, Pacific Ship Power, Is to Be Sold to Singaporeans
abstract: APL Ltd agrees to be acquired by Neptune Orient Lines, a Singapore company, in deal valued at $825 million; combined operation will have 113 ships, with about 80 of them in container business (M)

headline: ALLSTATE CORP. (ALL,N)
abstract: Allstate Corp says earnings rose 81 percent in first quarter; net income rose to $767 million from $424 milion in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 4.7 percent, to $6.18 billion; table (S)

headline: Lazard Names New Top Team Post-Rohatyn
abstract: Steven Rattner is named deputy chief executive of Lazard Freres & Co, inheriting Felix G Rohatyn's job as firm's lead banker; Rattner is seen as executive most likely to succeed Michel A David-Weill, firm's chief executive and chairman; appointed vice chairmen are Kendrick R Wilson 3d, Damon Mezzacappa, Norman Eig and Herbert W Gullquist; Lazard also names Steven J Golub chief financial officer, and forms management committee of David-Weill, Rattner, four vice chairmen, Golub and Melvin L Heineman, firm's chief administrative officer; photo (L)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC STOCK SLIDES AS PROFIT LAG IS SEEN
abstract: Stock of Boston Scientific Corp plunges 24 percent after company warns that first-quarter profit will be behind estimates (S)

headline: Seoul Court Upholds Sentences on 2 Ex-Presidents
abstract: South Korean Supreme Court upholds lower court rulings sentencing former Pres Chun Doo Hwan to life in prison and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, to 17 years; Chun and Roh were convicted in Aug 1996 for their roles in 1979 coup that brought Chun to power, for crackdown next year in which hundreds of protesters were killed and for accepting bribes from businessmen (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Apr. 4   Mar. 28   Apr. 5          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.7   7.0   7.3       Distillate production, daily   3.4   3.3   3.1       Gasoline stocks   196.0   197.2   201.8       Distillate stocks   98.4   99.4   88.8       Crude imports, daily   8.3   8.0   6.8       Product imports, daily   2.1   1.6   1.5       Crude stocks   309.9   308.9   300.9       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   94.3   93.6   91.2          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: On-Line Stocks Fall as Reports of Deal Persist
abstract: Shares of America Online Inc and Compuserve Inc fall sharply in heavy trading as both companies decline to confirm reports that America Online is negotiating to buy Compuserve, its biggest rival; shares of America Online fall $4.125, to $44.25; Compuserve closes at $12, down $1.625; Compuserve is controlled by H&R Block Co (L)

headline: Two Charged With Perjury After Trading Lotus Options
abstract: New Jersey investors Robert S Kowalskie and Louis M Marino are first publicly identified targets in Federal investigation into possible insider trading in shares of Lotus Development Corp before it was bought by IBM in 1995; two men have been charged with lying in testimony given to Securities and Exchange Commission about their trading in options on Lotus stock; Kowalskie pleads not guilty; Marino pleaded guilty on May 7 to single count of perjury; he will be sentenced in September; graph (Market Place column) (L)

headline: In the Shadow of Scandal, U.S. Challenges a Suharto Project
abstract: Clinton Administration, in first direct challenge to financial empire of Pres Suharto of Indonesia, says that it will ask World Trade Orgn to rule against Indonesia's national car project, program run by Suharto's son that puts foreign companies at a disadvantage in country's potentially huge automobile market; challenge comes after months of unsuccessful negotiations with Indonesia that have been subject of extraordinary scrutiny in Washington because of campaign finance scandals; in Clinton's first term, Riady family of Indonesia, which is at center of investigations, repeatedly played intermediary role in effort to smooth relations between Suharto and White House (M)

headline: Harris Drury to Handle Celebrity Cruises
abstract: Celebrity Cruises Inc names Harris Drury Cohen to handle its advertising account, which had been previously handled by Korey, Kay & Partners; billings estimated at $15 million (S)

headline: BERLIN COURT SAYS TOP IRAN LEADERS ORDERED KILLINGS
abstract: German court concludes that highest levels of Iran's 'political leadership' ordered Sept 1992 killing of exiled Iranian Kurdish dissidents in Berlin; Judge Frithjof Kubsch rules that killing of four dissidents was orchestrated by secretive 'Committee for Special Operations' in Teheran; ruling reinforces Clinton Administration's assertions that Iran's Islamic rulers sponsor terrorism and fuels demands by US for Germany and other European allies to end their 'critical dialogue' with Iran; Kubsch's opinion does not identify top Iranian officials by name, but German prosecutors during trial accused Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and Pres Hashemi Rafsanjani of ordering and approving killings; Kazem Darabi and Abbas Rhayel, two of five men accused of involvement in killings, are given life sentences; one Iranian is acquitted and two others are given jail terms of between 5 and 11 years; German Foreign Ministry says it is recalling its Ambassador to Teheran and that four Iranian diplomats will be expelled (M)

headline: ZAIRIAN FOES MEET BUT FAIL TO AGREE ON END TO CRISIS
abstract: Zairian Pres Mobutu Sese Seko and rebel leader Laurent Kabila meet aboard South African warship in Congolese port of Pointe-Noire but fail to agree on terms of cease-fire for ending civil war; Mobutu says he will relinquish power as demanded by rebels, but only to transitional authority that would organize national elections; Kabila insists that power be handed over to him directly; vows to press ahead with military campaign; South African Pres Nelson Mandela, who brokered meeting, says both sides agreed to meet in six to eight days to resume discussions; stage appears set for rebel military takeover before second meeting can convene; photo; map (M)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY   None

headline: U.P.S. Pilots Vote to Authorize a Strike
abstract: Pilots for United Parcel Service of America Inc vote overwhelmingly to strike if agreement on wages is not reached with UPS; company recently asked National Mediation Board to release it from negotiations with Independent Pilots Association (S)

headline: Gold Surges as Audit Reveals Faked Indonesian Discovery
abstract: Gold prices surge in New York after report that audit found no gold worth mining at Indonesian site discovered by Bre-X Minerals Ltd of Canada (S)

headline: Computer Makers Challenge Broadcasters Over TV Format
abstract: Leaders of personal computer industry propose their vision of future of television, setting them on collision course with broadcast companies; executives from Compaq Computer Corp, Microsoft Corp and Intel Corp spell out technical format for digital televisions that Compaq and other personal computer makers plan to include as standard equipment in all personal computers sold in US starting in 1998--format incompatible with digital technology that broadcasters plan to use, National Association of Broadcasters' annual convention, Las Vegas, Nev (L)

headline: C. Martin Wilbur, 89, a Scholar Of Nationalists' Rise in China
abstract: Dr C Martin Wilbur, scholar of 20th-century Chinese history and politics, dies at age 89 (S)

headline: Politician With an Urge to Befriend Pakistan
abstract: Biographical sketch of Inder Kumar Gujral, India's new Prime Minister (Man In The News); photo (M)

headline: Korean Chief's Son Held on Graft Charges
abstract: Kim Hyun Chul, 38-year-old son of South Korean Pres Kim Young Sam, is arrested in connection with widening corruption scandal, raising questions about President's own role in affair; is charged with taking $3.6 million in bribes from businessmen who sought his influence to obtain Government contracts and licenses; is also accused of evading $1.5 million in taxes on payments he received from them; photo (M)

headline: DOW LOSES 157.11
abstract: Stock prices plunge for second consecutive session on March 31, fed by growing concerns over whether bull market can sustain itself after two years of double-digit returns; Dow Jones Industrial Average loses 157.11 points, or 2.33 percent, to close at 6,583.48; drop is biggest one-day decline since July 1996; two session decline of 297.22 points, or 4.3 percent, is biggest drop in percentage terms since index lost 4.63 percent over two days in August 1990, before current bull market began (M)

headline: Rocky going in stocks didn't faze fund investors in April.
abstract: Market Place: Investment Company Institute says mutual fund investors, apparently unfazed by stock market's rampant volatility in April, added $15.5 billion to equity funds last month; institute says estimated cash flows were 28 percent more than $10.5 billion taken in by stock funds in March (L)

headline: NFO Research Buys Prognostics
abstract: NFO Research Inc acquires Prognostics, a provider of customer satisfaction measurement for information technology companies, for 1.726 million shares of NFO stock worth about $30 million (S)

headline: GILLETTE PLANS TO CUT 1,700 JOBS IN RESTRUCTURING
abstract: Gillette Co plans to cut about 1,700 jobs as it eliminates duplicated operations after its acquisition of Duracell International Inc; Gillette took fourth-quarter charge of $283 million for expected restructuring costs and other expenses associated with Duracell acquisition (S)

headline: Fund Investors Warier on Technology
abstract: Market Place column tracks technology stocks; notes that technology mutual funds are taking in less cash than they used to when stock prices are rising, and are suffering larger outflows when prices fall; says this is indication that investors in these funds are much more nervous than they used to be; says their caution could make sector more vulnerable if bad news continues to arrive; graphs (M)

headline: A Grand Exit
abstract: Comment solicited on best parting shot for a resigning employee

headline: S.E.C. Cites Drug Researchers In Insider Trading Lawsuits
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission sues 13 people in first insider case to be brought against clinical drug researchers; commission contends that Milton Mutchnick, his wife, Renee, and a research assistant warned 10 friends, business associates and family members on April 25, 1994, that widely anticipated drug for treatment of hepatitis B had proved ineffective in clinical trials; 10 people then avoided losses of some $300,000 by immediately selling stock in Alpha I Biomedicals Inc, developer of the drug, and its primary licensee, Sciclone Pharmaceuticals Inc (M)

headline: WELLS FARGO STOCK DROPS AFTER BUFFETT REDUCES STAKE
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway Inc says it has sold 300,000 shares of Wells Fargo & Co, reducing its stake to 7.82 percent of outstanding stock; Wells Fargo's shares fall $14.125, to $265.50 a share (S)

headline: U.S. Incomes Accelerate, Led by Wages
abstract: Commerce Department says personal income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, while personal spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent; wages rose by $50 billion at annual rate, largest gain since April 1994; disposable income increased eight-tenths of 1 percent in February; savings rate rose to 5.5 percent from January's 5.1 percent, highest since a 5.6 percent rate last September; graph (M)

headline: Lehman Adds To Asian Staff
abstract: Lehman Brothers Inc hires 11 executives in Asia, including Sam Gu, Credit Suisse First Boston's chief representative in Beijing, as part of global push to improve businesses with high profit margins like investment banking (S)

headline: A Prophet's Gospel: Faith, Hope and Seed Money
abstract: Mariano Velarde, known as Brother Mike, 10 years ago founded evangelical movement in Philippines called El Shaddai; movement now has following estimated at five million; photo (M)

headline: Let's Give Parents An Extra Right to Vote
abstract: Article by Alexei Bayer on social, political and economic developments of past decades that have favored older Americans; says ingenious way to balance political power in aging society would be to extend the right to vote; says voting age should be lowered from 18 years old to encompass all Americans; asserts a legally designated parent or guardian of a minor should have the right to cast a vote on his or her behalf until age of 18; says parents make an array of economic and social decisions that affect their children's future; drawing (L)

headline: In Savage Theater of War, Soothing Music Is Back
abstract: Organizers hope to revive Baalbek Festival, casualty of Lebanon's civil war, as visitors begin returning to Baalbek to marvel at city's majestic Roman ruins; Hezbollah remains force in region and visitors must pass through countless checkpoints manned by Syrian soldiers and plainclothesmen; concert by cellist Mstislav Rostropovich will be festival highlight; map; photo (M)

headline: De Klerk Still Works the Crowds, but Few Listen
abstract: Interview with former South African Pres F W De Klerk, who comments on his efforts to transform his National Party, which governed nation for 46 years and formally imposed apartheid, into middle-of-the-road opposition to African National Congress that can draw voters of all races; photo (M)

headline: Donaldson Fund Buys a Company
abstract: Decision One Holdings Corp, largest computer maintenance company in North America, agrees to sell 85 percent of its shares to unit of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc for about $660 million (S)

headline: Apartheid-Era Defense Chief Defends Role in Ordering Raids on Neighboring Countries
abstract: Gen Magnus Malan, former South African Defense Minister, tells Truth and Reconciliation Commission that he ordered raids into neighboring nations that caused civilian deaths and set up army branch that became notorius for its brutality to dissidents; says he will not seek amnesty because acts were legal; says he volunteered to speak to commission to support soldiers; scores commission's failure to consider atrocities by anti-apartheid forces; photo (M)

headline: F.C.C. Is Ready To Ease Timing On Digital TV
abstract: Federal Communications Commission reaches general agreement on new rule that would require network television stations in nation's 10 largest broadcast markets to begin transmitting digital programming within two years; schedule represents compromise that would give broadcasters more time for transition than they would have had under initial proposal by FCC chairman Reed E Hundt (L)

headline: Grocery Chain's Bank Has 100,000 Patrons
abstract: J Sainsbury PLC, Britain's second-largest supermarket chain, signs up 100,000 customers for its new bank, more than it expected when it started venture in February; says that deposits at the bank, joint venture with Bank of Scotland PLC, has reached 100 million pounds ($163 million) and that bank is attracting 10,000 new customers a week (S)

headline: Small Investors and Big Money Taken by Tale of Jungle Gold
abstract: Dozens of stock mutual funds, with retirement savings of millions of Americans, are victims of once-in-a-generation fraud, involving gold-mining conglomerate Bre-X Minerals Ltd, that has rendered close to $500 million in investments worthless; many of country's biggest and smartest mutual funds advisers--including Fidelity Investments, American Express Financial Advisors, Invesco and US Global Investors--went far afield of typical discipline to invest in Bre-X; for many, Bre-X is likely to be long remembered as hard lesson about how some risks cannot be diversified away, even by most experienced professionals; Bre-X, which touted gold discovery in Busang area of Borneo as century's largest find, has admitted that area really contains insignificant amount of gold; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Kansas City Power and Light, Kansas City, Mo., to Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, to handle its integrated marketing account, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.    * Marks Brothers Jewelers, Chicago, to Barkley & Evergreen, Kansas City, Mo., for the jewelry retailer, whose account had been handled in-house. Billings have not been determined.

headline: EMI SHUTTING 2 NEW YORK-BASED RECORD LABELS
abstract: EMI Group will shut down two New York-based record labels, EMI Records and Enclave Records, and dismiss 140 employees; British company will take $191-million charge, as part of reorganization (S)

headline: In Modern Russia, a Fatal Medieval Witch Hunt
abstract: Superstition and witchcraft remain part of daily life for many Russians; one of Moscow's, and nation's, most popular television shows is straight, factual discussion of how sorcery and witchcraft can improve one's life; major national newspapers advertise services of clairvoyants, witches and warlocks every day; well-trained doctors at respected hospitals see nothing unusual in recommending that their patients take trip to a 'babka,' on old woman with power to heal; photo; map (L)

headline: Cisco Forms Technology Alliance With Alcatel of France
abstract: Alcatel Alsthom and Cisco Systems Inc form broad technology alliance to develop new communications gear to integrate telephone, data and video networks; Cisco seeks to link its networking technology with standard phone systems most people use to dial into Internet (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A More Reassuring Tone From the Fed Chairman  Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, unnerved many investors last December with an ominous rhetorical question, asking whether ''irrational exuberance has unduly escalated stock prices.''

headline: MEDICAL RESOURCES TO BUY U.S. DIAGNOSTIC
abstract: Medical Resources Inc agrees to buy US Diagnostic Inc for $212.5 million, combining two largest operators of medical-imaging centers in US (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.46   5.27        3-MO.
