headline: Hong Kong Democratic Party Faces Huge Question Mark: Its Future
abstract: Hong Kong's ruling Democratic Party faces its greatest challenge as return of British colony to Chinese rule on July 1 approaches; some politicians are scrambling to accommodate themselves to Beijing while others resolve to push limits of Chinese tolerance; photos of Democratic leader Martin Lee Chu-Ming and other leaders (M)

headline: Books vs. Computers: What About the Index?
abstract: Prof Ellen H Poisson letter comments on May 25 article on the debate over the use of books versus computers as information sources; holds most efficient search systems join the power of electronic retrieval with human subject indexing (S)

headline: NCR SET TO INTRODUCE SERIES OF PRODUCTS FOR INTERNET
abstract: NCR Corp is planning to introduce series of new Internet-related products on April 28 (S)

headline: Designer Protests Chrysler Ad Practice
abstract: Milton Glazer, prominent New York designer and illustrator, withdraws his name from Chrysler Corp's annual Innovation and Design Awards competition to protest Chrysler's policy of reviewing editorial content of magazines before buying space in them for its auto advertising; policy was described in Wall Street Journal article that detailed growing influence major advertisers exert over editorial content of magazines (S)

headline: Household International To Buy Transamerica Unit
abstract: Household International Inc agrees to buy Transamerica Corp's consumer finance business for $1.1 billion in cash, in move that will almost double Household's branch network (L)

headline: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING TO SELL AUTO PARTS NETWORK
abstract: Automatic Data Processing Inc agrees to sell auto parts trading network it acquired from Auto Info to settle Federal Trade Commission suit charging it illegally acquired firm to create monopoly in auto salvage industry (S)

headline: MONTEREY RESOURCES TO ACQUIRE MCFARLAND ENERGY
abstract: Monterey Resources Inc plans cash tender offer to buy McFarland Energy Inc for about $106 million (S)

headline: German G.D.P. Posts 0.4% Rise
abstract: German economy expanded more than expected in first quarter; gross domestic product increased four-tenths of 1 percent in first quarter from prior three months and 2.8 percent from a year ago (S)

headline: Lockheed Martin Planning Russia Venture
abstract: The Lockheed Martin Corporation plans to announce today that it is forming a joint venture with a Russian organization, Intersputnik, to offer satellite communications services, according to people familiar with the company's plans.    The company, to be called Lockheed Martin Intersputnik, intends to initially provide broadcast telecommunications to Eastern Europe, Africa, parts of Asia and the former Soviet Union. Eventually, it plans to offer direct-to-home video and audio.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.50   5.27        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.82   4.83   5.08        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.18   5.27        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.55   3.56   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.48   6.56   6.99        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.77   6.83   7.13        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.82   7.89   8.25        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.63   5.66   6.21          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Push for Royalties Threatens Use of Down Syndrome Test
abstract: Use of hormone test of pregnant women to determine risk of Down's syndrome, chromosomal birth defect, is in question as result of royalty demands by Dr Mark Bogart, who patented his research in 1989; Bogart's company, Biomedical Patent Management Corp, is now threatening lawsuits unless laboratories pay as much as $9 per test; experts in pre-natal testing are angered, fearing that millions of women may go without screening; legal experts predict court will invalidate patent, but geneticists fear high costs of litigation; Bogart did not, in fact, 'invent' anything, but, rather, took out patent on his observation of relationship between hormone HCG and incidence of Down's syndrome; his photo; graphs explaining test and its costs; Bogart filed application after University of San Diego, where he and colleagues worked, declined to patent discovery; test only came into widespread use after subsequent research established its accuracy as predictor (M)

headline: Machine Tool Orders Rose 9.3% in March
abstract: Orders for American-made machine tools jumped 9.3 percent in March from February, to estimated $721 million; increase is third rise in estimated orders in last four months; figures are from joint report from Assn for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors' Assn (S)

headline: Schering-Plough Net Rises 15% in Quarter
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp says earnings rose 15 percent in first quarter; net income rose 14.9 percent, to $375.3 million from $326.6 million; revenue rose 13 percent, to $1.07 billion from $950.1 million; Novartis AG says sales grew 22 percent in first quarter; Abbott Laboratories says sales rose 14 percent (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Personal Income May  New-Home Sales May    TUESDAY  Leading Indicators May  Construction Spending May

headline: The Velvet Fist of Fannie Mae
abstract: Profile of Federal National Mortgage Association, Government-created but shareholder-owned company that dominates nation's housing finance industry; cites chairman and chief executive James A Johnson's political links to Congress and executive branch; he rejects view that ties or political maneuvering allow firm to suppress debate over its Government sponsorship, interview; holds Fannie Mae has broad political support because it promotes low-cost home ownership; tables; graphs; photo (L)

headline: Ecuador's Interim President Says He Will Hold a Referendum
abstract: Fabian Alarcon, Ecuador's Interim President, pledges to hold referendum within 45 days to make his mandate legitimate; plan draws mixed reactions, even from his usual supporters (M)8

headline: Bereavement Travel: Why Not the Lowest Fare?
abstract: Janet R Trauner letter says airlines ought to offer lowest advance-purchase fares for bereavement travel (S)

headline: A City at Death's Door Turns the Doctors Away
abstract: Sumgait, Azerbaijan, was known as 'dead zone' in 1980's because wastes from chemical and metal plants killed 36 of 1,000 babies; United Nations office in Azerbaijan is irritated with delays in project that many foreign analysts call Sumgait's salvation--its transformation into 'special economic zone'; plan is to revitalize and clean up city simultaneously, using foreign capital; map; photo (M)

headline: A 2nd Pipeline, This One for Gas, Gains Support
abstract: State of Alaska, along with oil producers of North Slope--Exxon, Arco and British Petroleum--and an Alaskan subsidiary of transportation giant CSX are moving toward building another multibillion-dollar pipeline, this one to carry natural gas instead of oil; estimated $4 billion a year of liquefied gas--a byproduct of oil drilling in Prudhoe Bay--would be shipped across ocean to fuel expanding economies of Pacific Rim; aiming at same Asian market, oil companies have huge projects on drawing boards in Indonesia, Australia and elsewhere; photos; maps; charts (M))

headline: The Nervous Season: Beijing and a U.S. Prisoner
abstract: Hong Kong releases senior US immigration official Jerry Stuchiner from custody less than week before British colony reverts to Chinese rule; Stuchiner was arrested on corruption charges nearly year ago (M)

headline: Entrepreneur Seeks Break for Last-Minute Business Fliers
abstract: Entrepreneur Kevin P Mitchell, who has financial backing of blue-chip companies like Chrysler, Procter & Gamble and Black & Decker, expects to announce shortly an agreement with Frontier Airlines, Reno Air and possibly a third low-fare carrier that would guarantee them revenues for three years in return for starting service in cities sorely in need of airline competition; Mitchell is seeking a fare break for last-minute business flier; consortium that Mitchell runs--the Business Travel Contractors Corp--has also been negotiating with operators of corporate jets to start a kind of flying car pool; graphs; photo (L)

headline: WITH SALE IN QUESTION, POTOMAC ELECTRIC SHARES FALL
abstract: Shares of Potomac Electric Power Co fall after Baltimore Gas and Electric says $3.04-billion acquisition may fall through (S)

headline: With all the sound and fury over push technology, it must signify something.
abstract: IN the silicon world, as in many others, being contrary is almost as fashionable as being rich. So one of the best ways to gauge the value of a new technology is by the extent of the backlash it inspires.    The newbie-turned-villain of the moment is called push. Push is how media companies -- ''content providers'' in high-tech argot -- supposedly mean to deliver automatically bucketloads of information to every computer users' desktop, freeing the users to stop surfing the Internet in search of stuff to pull.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Delco Remy America Inc, maker of automotive parts, will shut down two plants in Mississippi next year, idling about 300 workers (S)

headline: Flying Home, but Not for Fun
abstract: Article on bereavement fares offered by major airlines compared with other discount fares; says discounts for bereavement often are not much and travelers can sometime get a cheaper fare on same airline; table; drawing (L)

headline: Trinet Buys 3 Buildings
abstract: Trinet Corporate Realty Trust Inc acquires three Silicon Valley, Calif, office buildings for $52.3 million (S)

headline: That knock at the door of the bull market party? Small caps.
abstract: Market Place column on bull market for small-capitalization stocks; says for about six weeks, small-cap stocks have been surging; informal survey of Wall Street strategists suggests that small caps should keep rallying as investors shop for small, undervalued companies (L)

headline: Spanish Company Is Expected To Drop Alliance With AT&T
abstract: Telefonica de Espana SA, Spain's telecommunications provider in Latin America, will leave AT&T Corp's global alliance; Telefonica is expected to join AT&T's rival--pending combination of MCI Communications Corp and British Telecommunications PLC (L)

headline: China Growth Slows a Bit, To 9.4% Pace
abstract: China reports economic growth rate of 9.4 percent in first quarter of year, down from 9.9 percent in previous three months, as companies reduce bloated inventories; consumer prices rose 5.2 percent (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows; Mistake Found in Report  The United States trade deficit narrowed 18 percent in February as exports and imports rose to new peaks, the Commerce Department said. The gap declined to $10.4 billion, from $12.7 billion in January.

headline: New Chairman at Comsat
abstract: Comsat Corp says C J Silas has resigned as chairman and director for health reasons; company names Edwin I Colodny to replace Silas (S)

headline: China Policy: Politics Rules
abstract: News analysis; Pres Clinton's new China policy is being attacked with new vigor on Capitol Hill, especially by Republicans who see another weapon to use against Democratic President; China is becoming, in heated language, touchstone in domestic partisan politics in way it has not been since early 1950's, when arguments raged over who lost China to Communists; on wide range of matters, Congress is showing distinct lack of faith in Administration's exercise of constructive engagement, and, as result, Clinton risks losing control of key area; annual debate over most-favored-nation trading status for China is expected to be loud and bitter; photo (M)

headline: Stoically, a Rival Tilts at Croatia's Leader
abstract: Vlado Gotovac, Croatian Pres Franjo Tudjman's chief rival in presidential elections, is attacked and knocked unconscious at campaign rally by man in army uniform; attack, before small crowd in Pula, leaves Gotovac hospitalized in Zagreb; photo (M)

headline: Who uses the Internet and how? We'll get back to you on that if someone figures it out.
abstract: Measuring World Wide Web use is key factor in establishing Internet as viable advertising medium; dozens of companies are competing to rate usership on Web just as A C Nielsen issues ratings of TV viewership; so many competing companies are pushing different approaches that many advertisers are holding back until there is standard way to compare how effective their ads are on various Web sites; drawing (M)

headline: Banks seem poised to buy their way into investment banking.
abstract: Market Place column on banking and financial companies that are poised to buy their way into investment banking; says Bankers Trust's plans for $1.7 billion takeover of Alex Brown Inc and Morgan Stanley's pending $10.2 billion acquisition of Dean Witter, Discover are attracting renewed attention for banks to acquisition route (L)

headline: I.B.M. Stock Soars Over Wealth of Good News
abstract: IBM raises dividend on its stock 14 percent, and its board authorizes management to buy back up to $3.5 billion worth of its own shares; shareholders approve previously announced 2-for-1 stock split; IBM's shares rise $8, closing at $158.375 (M)

headline: Grumble, Grumble
abstract: Why is the office so dingy? Why do only the managers get a parking space? Why does everyone have only 30 minutes for lunch? Although pay and benefits are often the biggest concerns for workers, sometimes the little, everyday things annoy them, too. Have you ever tried to change a stupid policy in your workplace? What were the results? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: A. R. Baron's Top Salesman Admits Guilt and Will Assist Inquiry
abstract: Roman Okin, star salesman at A R Baron & Co, brokerage house that cleared its trades through Bear Stearns Companies before collapsing amid customer and regulatory complaints last summer, enters guilty plea and agrees to cooperate with continuing criminal investigation of Baron; Okin pleads guilty to single count of enterprise corruption; was indicted May 13, along with Baron and 12 other former employees (L)

headline: Croatian Chief Re-elected by Wide Margin
abstract: Franjo Tudjman is re-elected as President of Croatia after election campaign that outside monitors condemned as fundamentally flawed (S)

headline: A Last-Ditch Policy in Zaire
abstract: As Bill Richardson, President Clinton's envoy, shuttled between foes in Zaire, American officials said their policy has come down to pushing President Mobutu Sese Seko to step down. Pages A14 and A15.

headline: SWISS FIND FUNDS THAT MAY BELONG TO NAZIS' VICTIMS
abstract: Swiss banks, faced with start of formal audits of their wartime accounts, have quietly told probers that they recently found hundreds of foreign accounts that may have belonged to Holocaust victims and thousands more dormant accounts opened by Swiss nationals, possibly for benefit of Holocaust victims; made disclosures to independent body set up by banks and headed by Paul A Volcker (M)

headline: Your Own Law Library (No Shelves Required)
abstract: Experts predict that huge data base of Federal and state case law will soon exist on line, searchable across jurisdictions; wealth of information already exists on Web that is of great help to generalists and professionals alike (M)

headline: Asians Are Alarmed as Beijing Objects to U.S. Forces in Region : China Tries to Be King of the Hill
abstract: SINGAPORE—  China has alarmed many Asian countries by saying publicly for the first time that it opposes the stationing of U.S. forces in the region.

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Cooperate to Seize 4 Terrorist Suspects
abstract: Israeli authorities say they have uncovered underground cell of militant Islamic group Hamas that bombed Tel Aviv cafe in March and kidnapped and killed Israeli soldier who has been missing since Sept; say two suspects were arrested by Israelis in West Bank and two others by Palestinian police (M)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * Associates Corp., Irving, Tex., is selling $300 million of notes due in 2001 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The notes are priced at 99.83 to yield 6.749 percent. The issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by both S.& P. and Duff & Phelps.    * Frontier Corp., Rochester, is selling $300 million of notes due in 2004 through Salomon Brothers Inc. and Lehman Brothers. The notes are priced at 99.966 to yield 7.257 percent. The issue is rated A3 by Moody's, A by S.& P. and A- by Duff & Phelps.

headline: A Fed Official's Romance Raises Issue of Conflict
abstract: John P LaWare, former Federal Reserve Board governor, is quoted in The Boston Globe questioning whether romantic relationship between E Gerald Corrigan, partner at Goldman, Sachs & Co who is former president of Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Cathy E Minehan, current president of Federal Resever Bank of Boston, might not be in best interest of the Federal Reserve; LaWare says 'I have the highest regard for their integrity, but the very fact of their relationship runs the risk of creating impressions that there may be conflicts of interest,' telephone interview; as one of nation's leading bond traders, Goldman, Sachs frequently invests its own capital in Government securities, effectively making bets on the Fed's monetary policy and the direction of interest rates; photos (L)

headline: What Can He Do If Banks Never Say No?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on the accounting alchemy that produces much of the profits at Champion Mortgage Co, company founded by Joseph P Goryeb that makes mortgage loans to people with blemished credit; notes that Goryeb will continue to run company and do its commercials after its acquisition by Keycorp (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS TO BUY BUMBLE BEE SEAFOODS
abstract: International Home Foods Inc says that it agreed to buy Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc for $163 million in cash; agreement is reached as Bumble Bee, nation's No. 2 tuna producer and subsidiary of Unicord Public Co of Thailand, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Federal Bankruptcy Court in San Diego (S)

headline: Daimler-Benz Plans To Expand Sales in Asia
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG, Germany's largest industrial company, plans to more than triple its sales in Asia as percentage of total sales; Daimler-Benz says sales rose 15 percent in first four months of 1997 to 36.3 billion marks ($21.4 billion) from 31.5 billion marks a year earlier (S)

headline: The Right Ingredients For Success in Hong Kong
abstract: Comment by Barbara Hackman Franklin on financial success in Hong Kong as Britain returns Hong Kong to China; holds every buiness leader and American company representative in Hong Kong is expecting 'business as usual'; says if China tries to make changes in way things are done in Hong Kong, we should watch for several things: interference in Hong Kong's financial affairs, changes in legal or court system, abrupt departure of highly respected civil servants, interference in free flow of financial information or suppression of of free press; drawing (L)

headline: Consumer Still the Big Spender
abstract: Analysis of American consumer's exuberant spending habits in last six months sees buying as main reason for best performance by national economy in nine years; says consumer spending grew at annual rate of 4.9 percent from September through March; reasons why Americans have been so free with their money discussed; graph (L)

headline: Offerings Expected This Week Of Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Action Performance Cos., Tempe, Ariz., 1.9 million shares. Montgomery Securities.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  Heads of state meet at the United Nations to discuss environmental issues; President Fidel Castro of Cuba is to attend and meet with American business executives all week.  The Agriculture Department releases its weekly report on crop conditions.    TUESDAY  The Conference Board releases its consumer confidence index for June.  Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.

headline: Tending Your Money Where You Make It
abstract: Employee Access Accounts are being set up for employees by many corporations to help them in simplyfying financial planning; service has been offered for past 20 years at banks, brokerage firms, mutual fund companies and others; one-stop account opened by financial services consultant Eliza L Moore at Andersen Consulting described; photo (M)

headline: Sony and Fuji TV Join In Murdoch Venture
abstract: Sony Corp and Japanese broadcaster Fuji Television Network Inc say they will become partners in Japan Sky Broadcasting Co, headed by Rupert Murdoch; Sony, Fuji, News Corp and Japanese media company Softbank will each own 20 to 25 percent of J Sky B after sale; Murdoch is also negotiating to make Walt Disney Co a partner in the venture (S)

headline: Italian Silk Industry Upset By a New U.S. Trade Law
abstract: Companies in Como, Italy, that produce 90 percent of Europe's silk exports are in conflict with United States over import legislation enacted last year by Congress; if bill is strictly enforced, much of Italian silk would have to be marked 'Made in China' to reflect fact that raw silk comes from China, then is shipped to Italy for finishing, dyeing and printing; law was enacted to prevent growing business of goods shipped through third countries, practice that undermines American economy and hurts American textile workers because it allows dealers to skirt quotas on textiles from low-wage countries (M)

headline: Broken Hill Says Its Loss Widened
abstract: Broken Hill Proprietary Company's fourth-quarter net loss balloons to $712 million (Australian), or $535 million (US), after company cuts value of its copper and steel assets (S)

headline: Fear of Contagion Sets Off Heavy Losses In Europe and Asia : Markets Fall Worldwide, Alarmed by Wall Street
abstract: LONDON—  World stock markets racked up some of their worst losses in months Tuesday, shedding billions of dollars in share value, as equities plummeted in response to two days of heavy losses on Wall Street.

headline: For Now, Earnings Gap Has Stopped Widening
abstract: Wages at low end are rising significantly faster than the inflation rate--faster, in percentage terms, than pay of middle-class Americans; low-wage workers are in great demand despite their lack of skill; in tight labor market, those who employ unskilled laborers are being forced to lift bottom of the pay scale; increase in minimum wage, first since 1991, has also raised wages of low-paid workers; higher wages are helping to draw into labor force more black women, older men, immigrants, teen-agers and Hispanic Americans; big unknown is whether wage gains at the low end will continue long enough to make meaningful difference for millions of Americans struggling to make ends meet, or whether raises will be washed away in next wave of economic distress; graphs; charts; photos (L)

headline: CLINTON TO PRESS ISRAELIS TO ASSIST THE PALESTINIANS
abstract: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met with King Hussein of Jordan here to discuss eroding confidence in the Middle East peace effort, President Clinton prepared today to push Mr. Netanyahu to make good on his promises to improve the lives of Palestinians.     Mr. Clinton and Mr. Netanyahu will meet in Washington on Monday in a hastily arranged effort to stem  the rising distrust between Palestinians and Israelis and to bring stability to the region. One proposal is to construct new Arab housing in East Jerusalem. Nearly three weeks of demonstrations and violence have followed the Israeli decision -- despite American opposition -- to build new Jewish housing in mostly Arab East Jerusalem, at a place the Palestinians call Jabal Abu Ghneim and the Israelis, Har Homa.

headline: Signs of Gold in Latin America's Blue Chips
abstract: Outlook for investing in Latin American blue chip stocks that trade in United States as American depository receipts discussed; such stocks are often relatively inexpensive, even though they come from one of world's hottest economic regions; table; photo (M)

headline: GREEN STREET STOCK REPURCHASE PLAN IS APPROVED
abstract: Green Street Financial Corp receives approval from Office of Thrift Supervision to buy back up to 5 percent of its common stock (S)

headline: With Pomp and Circumstance, Hong Kong Legislature Fades Into the Sunset
abstract: Hong Kong's Legislative Council, territory's first fully elected legislature, ends final session of hectic lawmaking and political speechmaking; will be replaced by China-appointed legislature; photo (M)

headline: Listening to Shareholders
abstract: Letter by Sarah Lawrence College president Alice Stone Ilchman on May 18 article about defeat of shareholder proposals to change structure of Tri-Continental fund, in which she is outside director; says majority of shareholders are being heard, and safely steered in investment they understand (S)

headline: An Arbitration Albatross
abstract: Madelaine and Theodore G Eppenstein comment on plight of investors who lose money to unscrupulous stockbrokers and are limited to arbitration proceedings conducted by industry tribunals; Supreme Court ruling ten years ago, with SEC blessing, locked courthouse doors to such investors by granting brokerage industry's wish that customer claims be limited to arbitrations (S)

headline: Turkish Leader, His Coalition Crumbling, Will Call Elections
abstract: After 11 months in office as modern Turkey's first Islamist leader, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan acknowledged today that his coalition Government was crumbling and said he would call for new elections.    ''We decided that for Turkey to continue its economic success, an early election would be necessary,'' Mr. Erbakan said at a news conference in Ankara, the capital.

headline: Divorcing Central Banks and Politics: Independence Helps in Inflation Fight
abstract: Analysis of Britain's newly-elected Labor Government's granting control over interest rates to Bank of England, the central bank; says in granting more independence to central bank, new British Government is late entrant in a trend that has seen nations give increasing autonomy to their central banks, distancing monetary policy from direct political control; holds the practice has spread across the globe in response to demand from investors in financial markets for proof the governments will remain committed to inflation-fighting; photo (L)

headline: Daunting Math for Those Tax Breaks
abstract: Some of tax breaks proposed by Pres Clinton, and their possible fates in Congress, discussed (S)

headline: A. Everette MacIntyre, 96; Served on F.T.C.
abstract: A Everette MacIntyre, who served on Federal Trade Commission for 12 years, dies at age 96 (M)

headline: Awards Presented For Fragrance Ads
abstract: Fragrance Foundation presents annual Fifi Awards for best fragrance advertising campaigns; Ralph Lauren Fragrances and its agency, Carlson & Partners, wins best national print and television campaign for women's fragrances, for Ralph Lauren Polo Sport Women; Ground Zero wins best national print and television campaign for men's fragrance, for Michael Jordan Cologne (S)

headline: Congo Opposition Leader, Detained Overnight, Is Freed
abstract: Congo's leading opposition politician, Etienne Tshisekedi, is released after night of detention that sets off scattered disturbances throughout Kinshasa and seems to indicate period of heightened confrontation between new Government and opposition parties, whose public meetings have been banned; Tshisekedi urges his supporters to 'battle all kinds of dictatorship'; photo of demonstrators (M)

headline: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC TO GET $50 MILLION FOR TIMBER TRACT
abstract: Louisiana-Pacific Corp agrees to sell 38,000 acres of timberland in Northern California to privately held Sierra-Pacific Industries for $50 million; timberland is in northeast part of Sacramento Valley (S)

headline: U.S.-Mexico Wrangle: Closeness Breeds Friction
abstract: News analysis: Mexicans continue to feel vulnerable to US power and still deeply distrust Washington's intentions; recent unintentional political gaffes suggest that even when two Governments want to get along, turbulence is normal state of relations; peculiar logic of marriage of geography of convenience between both countries seems to be that closer relationship gets, more tensions arise (M)

headline: Some Odd Assumptions on Capital Gains
abstract: Analysis of US House Ways and Means Committee chairman Repr Bill Archer's proposed tax bill that calls for cut in capital gains tax; says proposal to cut top rate on capital gains to 20 percent from 28 percent, effective for sales made on May 7 or later, is expected to provoke rush of stock selling, enough so that Government will take in $1.7 billion more during current fiscal year, ending Sept 30, and $6.3 billion more in next fiscal year, than it would have without the changes; holds by fiscal year 2001, revenue estimate numbers assume that lower rates will be costing Government $3.6 billion in comparison with current tax law; finds some of the assumptions for later years questionable; photo (L)

headline: Ruling Could Jeopardize Class-Action Settlements
abstract: Legal experts say Supreme Court decision tossing out $1.3 billion settlement in asbestos case could jeopardize recent settlements of huge class-action lawsuits involving smokers, industrial workers and consumers and derail new legal strategy in which some companies have tried to use settlements to insulate themselves from future damages, including claims by people who have not yet been harmed by work hazards or products; say ruling, barring use of global settlements to resolve product liability claims, could upset asbestos industry's $1.5 billion settlement, and set back Liggett Group's efforts to settle huge anti-tobacco lawsuit outside framework of much broader deal being considered in Washington; ruling might offer grounds to overturn settlement involving sales practices by Prudential Insurance Co of America (M)

headline: F.C.C. Waives Foreign Ownership Rules For Nextwave Telecom
abstract: Federal Communications Commission will allow Nextwave Telecom Inc, which is trying to build national network for wireless communications, to keep its foreign investors and try to raise more money overseas (S)

headline: The Free and the Florid Among Screen Savers
abstract: Advice on World Wide Web sites offering computer screen saver designs; list; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Trader to Get Account Access
abstract: Panel of National Association of Securities Dealers orders Kidder, Peabody & Co to release additional $1 million to Joseph Jett from his account to cover Jett's legal fees and expenses; Kidder, now defunct, dismissed Jett in April 1994 and froze about $5 million he had in an account at the firm, after accusing him of falsely inflating firm's profits by $350 million (S)

headline: LOCKHEED MARTIN SAYS IT WILL SELL STAKE IN 10 BUSINESSES
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp to sell controlling stake in 10 aerospace and military communications businesses to investment group led by Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc; transaction is valued at $525 million (S)

headline: Near Zaire, 'America's 911' Stands By
abstract: US troops of 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit are poised in Brazzaville, Congo, to rescue Americans in neighboring Zaire if country's civil war spills into capital of Kinshasa; photo (M)

headline: Taiwan Lifts Ban On Exports of Pork
abstract: Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade says Taiwan has lifted ban on exports of pork and pork-related products, which was imposed on March 20 after outbreak of epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease (S)

headline: A Toy With a Present, And Maybe Even a Future
abstract: Tamagotchi cyber-pet toys that have been huge seller in Japan may have been successfully transplanted to United States, with FAO Schwarz's flagship store on Fifth Avenue, NYC, reporting that its initial 10,000-unit order was sold out, scarcely 24 hours after Bandai Co toy went on sale (M)

headline: Nation's Trade Deficit Rose 7.8% in April
abstract: Commerce Department reports nation's foreign trade deficit rose 7.8 percent in April, calling new attention to trade tensions with Japan and China as Pres Clinton and other world leaders gather for summit meeting in Denver; tensions with Japan over trade had eased in 1995 and first half of 1996; they returned in recent months as Japanese started pouring out exports again to rev up Japanese economy; Pres Clinton is expected to bring up trade frictions with Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan; America's deficit with Japan increased 5.1 percent in April, to $4.8 billion; trade gap with China jumped 33.3 percent in April, to $3.5 billion; graphs (M)

headline: 37-Month Sentence For Ex-Bank Trader
abstract: Victor Gomez, former trader for Chemical Banking Corp, has been sentenced to 37 months in prison for concealing $66 million trading loss amassed from failed bets on Mexican peso; Federal District Judge Michael Mukasey says Gomez will not have to pay criminal fine because he does not have the money (S)

headline: Equity and Debt Offerings Expected This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Wearing the Crown, If Only for Two Weeks
abstract: On the Job column quotes experiences of workers who ran their offices while the boss was on vacation (S)

headline: Chinese Officials Replace Top Securities Regulator
abstract: China has replaced its top securities regulator, stock exchange officials and traders said today, prompting speculation that the Government will crack down further on the country's surging stock markets.    The regulator, Zhou Daojiong, was asked to resign as chairman of the Securities Regulatory Commission and will be succeeded temporarily by Zhou Zhengqing, now chairman of the Cabinet's securities committee, a senior official in the Stock Exchange Executive Council, who asked not to be identified, said. The securities committee oversees the regulatory commission.

headline: France Starts Divided Rule With Jospin As Premier
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac appoints Socialist Party leader Lionel Jospin new Prime Minister following victory by Socialists in Parliamentary elections; move establishes potentially difficult cohabitation of left and right as France tries to arrest economic decline and define its place in Europe's project for single currency; charts (M)

headline: Continental Ponders Consolidated Account
abstract: Continental Airlines Inc has placed its worldwide advertising account in review and is considering consolidation; account, with billings estimated at $50 million, is handled by more than 10 agencies (S)

headline: Rival Railroads Agree on Conrail's Assets
abstract: CSX Corp and Norfolk Southern Corp announce agreement that details how two companies would split assets of Conrail; CSX and Norfolk Southern will jointly pay $115 cash a share, or $10.2 billion, for Conrail; two rival railroads will then divide Conrail, with CSX paying $4.3 billion for 42 percent of assets and Norfolk Southern paying $5.9 billion for remaining 58 percent; map (L)

headline: Treasury to Sell Notes and Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and auctions of two- and five-year notes tomorrow and Wednesday, respectively.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.14 percent and a six-month bill was 5.38 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.42 percent, and the five-year note, 6.72 percent.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * The Lloyd Northover Citigate division of Citigate Group, London, formed an alliance with Bass Yager & Associates, an identity and design agency in Los Angeles. Bass Yager will continue as an independent shop under the name Bass Yager Citigate.  * The Rogge Effler & Partners unit of Dentsu Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., changed its name to Colby, Effler & Partners.  * Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, Boston, changed its name to Ingalls. The agency company's subsidiaries will now be known as Ingalls Advertising, Ingalls One to One Marketing, Ingalls Public Relations, Ingalls Recruitment Advertising, Ingalls Design and Ingalls Interactive.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   New-Car Sales April     TUESDAY   Factory Orders March

headline: UROHEALTH SYSTEMS TO PURCHASE IMAGYN MEDICAL
abstract: Urohealth Systems Inc agrees to buy Imagyn Medical Inc for $73 million in stock to expand its line of products used for minimally invasive gynecological surgery (S)

headline: Ex-Rebels Adrift in an Angola Without a War
abstract: Thousands of former Angolan soldiers on both sides of country's 20-year civil war remain threat to country's recovery; find transition to peace difficult and are likely to take up banditry, which is far more lucrative and closer to kind of life to which they become accustomed; map; photo (M)

headline: MCCAWS, EXERCISING OPTION, TO RAISE NEXTEL HOLDING
abstract: Nextel Communications Inc, digital-communications concern backed by cellular-phone pioneer Craig O McCaw, says that McCaw family will exercise option to buy 15 million Nextel common shares on July 28 at $15.50 apiece, or $232.5 million (S)

headline: Far Out in Front in British Polls, Labor Party Still Runs Scared
abstract: British Labor party's campaign to end 18 years of Conservative rule enters final week with party leaders determined to prevent replay of five years ago, when Labor's commanding lead evaporated in last few days; Tony Blair avoids any hint of triumphal manner; polls give Labor 20-point lead (S)

headline: Dow Jones Markets Names New Officers
abstract: Dow Jones & Co names Gregory E Smith and Debra Isenberg senior vice presidents of its troubled Dow Jones Markets (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.00   5.82   5.28        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.29   5.09   4.97        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.54   5.29   5.13        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.59   3.56   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.67   6.71   6.85        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.91   6.95   7.05        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.98   8.00   8.17        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.88   5.89   6.17          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Swiss to Seize Funds In Salinas Accounts
abstract: Swiss prosecutors have concluded that drug traffickers paid the brother of Mexico's ex-President tens of millions of dollars to protect narcotics shipments (a charge he denies), and the Swiss are preparing to seize the money. The findings have significant implications for Citibank and  other banks that helped the Mexican, Raul Salinas de Gortari, channel money to Swiss accounts.    Article, page A3.

headline: Compuserve Concedes It's in Acquisition Talks
abstract: Compuserve Corp, struggling provider of second-largest computer on-line service, acknowledges that takeover reports are at least partly true, saying in statement that it is in talks to be acquired; Compuserve and H&R Block, which owns 80 percent of on-line provider, decline to disclose suitor's identity or any other details of negotiations; analysts say America Online Inc is likely suitor (L)

headline: Bell Partners' Next Hurdle Is Credibility Size of Deal for Nynex
abstract: Industry experts say Bell Atlantic and Nynex, having won battle for regulatory approval of their $22 billion merger, will find it comparatively easy to meld their operations and turn combined firm into East Coast's dominant telecommunications provider; consumer advocates and other critics score Justice Department's failure to put any curbs on market power of vast new company (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Midwest Utility Merger Back to Drawing Board  A Federal regulatory agency told two utilities in the upper Midwest, Wisconsin Energy and Northern States Power, that it would withhold approval of their merger agreement as it is now structured, saying that it would give them too much dominance over the electricity market in their regions.    But the regulators said the utilities could draw up a plan to sell some of their generating plants and then resubmit the merger for consideration. $(Page D2.$)

headline: 2d Saudi Held by Canada Cleared in Bombing
abstract: Canada says Fahad Shereri, held as terrorist since his arrest at Ottawa airport in Dec, is no longer suspect in June bombing of American military barracks in Saudi Arabia; seeks to deport him as national security threat; he seeks asylum, holding he left Saudi Arabia to escape arrest for nonviolent opposition to Government (M)

headline: E-Mail: Lean, Mean And Making Its Mark
abstract: Comment by Alan Robbins on growing number of typographical and spelling errors he is encountering in electronic-mail messages he receives; drawing (L)

headline: One Farm's Stock Plan Gives Its Migrant Workers a Stake
abstract: McKay Nursery Co, which hires Mexican migrant workers to sustain its operations in southeastern Wisconsin, has veered far from norm in agriculture, quietly evolving into employee-owned enterprise in which many workers not only play increasingly influential role, but annually receive chunks of stock; has been lauded by Pres Clinton and Business Enterprise Trust, California foundation that honors businesses that combine financial success with social vision; even though McKay's hourly wages are $6 per hour for new migrants, or below $7.50 average in Great Lakes region, its workers have other benefits and advancement opportunities that keep far more than 90 percent returning year after year; eligible migrants receive annual bonuses equal to 20 percent to 25 percent of wages in stock or cash--or at least $2,000 for lowest paid worker; company president Griff Mason comments; photo; charts and graphs on migrant farm workers, crops harvested by farm workers and average hourly wages (L)

headline: Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank May Face Punishment
abstract: Japan's Ministry of Finance may suspend Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd from its list of banks and brokerage firms that can underwrite Government bond issues and bid at Government bond auctions; decision will be made if prosecutors file charges in connection with bank's illicit lending to racketeer Ryuichi Koike (S)

headline: Herbert Hoover Jr., 79, Company Head
abstract: Herbert W Hoover Jr, former chairman of vacuum cleaner company founded by his grandfather, dies at age 79; company is now owned by Maytag (S)

headline: Penske Buys Control of a Motor Speedway
abstract: Penske Motorsports Inc acquires about 70 percent interest in North Carolina Motor Speedway in exchange of stock (S)

headline: A Blue-Collar Mirror
abstract: Comment on Britain's favorite television program Eastenders, BBC soap opera set in London's gritty East End; photo (S)

headline: Ball Makers Pitch to the Heavy Hitter in Every Hacker
abstract: Golf equipment manufacturers are offering balls in exotic new materials, such as tungsten and titanium, to attract affluent golfers who are willing to pay almost anything to improve their games; Dr Tony M Pisacano, playing at Westchester County Club, concedes point; Peter McDonald, instructor there, says ego and marketing are responsible for fact that club's best-selling ball is Titleist that is covered with balata and costs about twice as much as ordinary ball; photos; sales graph (M)

headline: Trade Data Confirmed: $10.4 Billion February Gap
abstract: Commerce Dept releases corrected figures confirming that US trade deficit declined to $10.4 billion in February, narrower than initially estimated; chart; graph (S)

headline: ST. LAURENT PAPERBOARD TO BUY CHESAPEAKE ASSETS
abstract: St Laurent Paperboard Inc agrees to buy paper mill, four plants and other assets from Chesapeake Corp for about $508 million (S)

headline: Elliott Quits Agency He Helped Start
abstract: Tim Elliott leaves Doig, Elliott, Schur Inc, agency he helped start, to join Foote, Cone & Belding (S)

headline: What computer quandary at century's end? With a creative clock, 2000 can be read as 1980, or '72.
abstract: Harvey Alter patents method to enable computer programs that omit first two digits of year to sort year 2000 dates after 20th century dates; method involves subtracting set number of years from all dates in data files; Robert E Evans patents belt-like device that enables golfer to drag bag of clubs behind him, so that arms do not get fatigued; House has approved bill calling for several changes in patent system, including requiring that patent applications from companies be published 18 months after submission; bill contains Rep Marcy Kaptur amendment that exempts small businesses, independent inventors and universities from 18-month requirement (M)

headline: South Asian Summit Talks End With Hope for Enhanced Trade
abstract: A summit meeting of the seven Asian nations that share the subcontinent ended here today with what their leaders acknowledged was a wake-up call to themselves and to the 1.3 billion people they represent.     The leaders acknowledged that their failure to curb hostilities that have troubled the region for 50 years has cost all of their countries dearly in lost trade and other ties, with results that have contributed heavily to the poverty that, according to official figures in the countries involved, entraps at least 500 million people.

headline: A new magazine reviewing commercial Internet sites may prove to be ahead of the curve.
abstract: New magazine called Internet Shopper provides critical commentary on content, appearance and customer service of World Wide Web sites it chooses to review, even marking its favorites with litle logo (M)

headline: 2 Agencies Split Video Account
abstract: Midway Home Entertainment Inc names DDB Needham Dallas and McCann-Erickson Southwest to handle its video game account, which had been handled Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago since 1994; billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million (S)

headline: 2 NEW INTRANET PRODUCTS JOINING I.B.M. SOFTWARE ROSTER
abstract: IBM announces new entry-level software aimed at helping small businesses or corporate departments establish internal computer networks, or intranets; two new products will be sold by IBM's Lotus Development unit; new products are called Lotus Go and Domino Mail (S)

headline: Unisource and Partners Move to Cut Costs
abstract: Unisource NV says its three European partners will merge their international telecommunications operations, to cut costs and ease loss of Spain's Telefonica de Espana as a partner; Unisource consists of dominant Dutch, Swedish and Swiss telephone companies (S)

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange
abstract: SEC is investigating whether units of Philadelphia Stock Exchange shortchanged some investors in violation of Federal law; reportedly finds serious deficiencies at Philadelphia Depository Trust Company and Stock Clearing Corp of Philadelphia; exchange president Nicholas A Giordano says there was no fraud and problems have been remedied (S)

headline: Why a 'Fund of Funds' May Prove a Heavy Burden
abstract: Investors faced with picking from among 8,000 stock and bond funds on market can choose a 'fund of funds,' investments that own shares in other mutual funds; says advantage is their simplicity, diversification and access; says disadvantage is that they generally lack good returns; drawing; chart (M)

headline: Chirac's Gamble: Rebuff Could Turn Into Humiliation
abstract: News analysis: Pres Jacques Chirac took a deeply personal gamble in dissolving the French Parliament a month ago and calling early parliamentary elections; results of the first round of elections, with a weak showing by Chirac's center-right coalition, constitutes a stinging rebuke to a President; if, as appears quite possible, the left wrests a parliamentary majority in the second round of voting on June 1, France would find itself facing potentially crippling political divisions at a decisive period; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO., Palo Alto, Calif., signed a $300 million three-year contract to sell its patient-monitoring and resuscitation products to the 1,800 member hospitals of Premier Inc. Premier was created from the merger last year of American Healthcare Systems Inc., Sunhealth Alliance Inc. and Premier Health Alliance Inc.

headline: $122 MILLION VENTURE FORMED FOR SALVESEN WAREHOUSES
abstract: Hunt Financial Corp and Security Capital Industrial Trust of Denver form new corp, CS International LLC, to acquire North American refrigerated operations of Christian Salvesen Inc, British food distributor, for $122.4 million (S)

headline: Former CBS President Quits Troubled Tele-TV Venture
abstract: Howard Stringer resigns as chairman of Tele-TV; Tele-TV also announces that it is laying off 100 employees, half of its work force; Sandy Grushow, who had been president and chief program executive, resigned in January; Tele-TB is joint venture formed in 1994 by Bell Atlantic Corp, Nynex Corp and Pacific Telesis Group (M)

headline: Fairfax Shares Rise On Takeover Rumors
abstract: Shares of John Fairfax Holdings Ltd, newspaper publisher, rise amid speculation that Australian Government will relax media ownership laws, allowing Australia's richest man, Kerry Packer, to buy it (S)

headline: ELF ENDS BRITISH MERGER TALKS WITH CHEVRON
abstract: Elf Aquitaine SA breaks off talks with Chevron Corp to merge refining and service station business in Britain with that of Chevron's Gulf Oil (GB) (S)

headline: Staying Level-Headed About Level-Payment Plans
abstract: Selling used car through a consignment dealer is an unconventional and widely overlooked route for getting higher price than a trade-in and saving time and trouble of selling it oneself; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: AAMES FINANCIAL CORP., Los Angeles, said it had promoted its chief operating officer, Cary Thompson, to chief executive and named vice chairman Neil Kornswiet president to replace its chairman, Gary Judis, in those posts.    BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, named Bruce Van Saun executive vice president and chief financial officer. Mr. Van Saun was a managing director and chief financial officer of Deutsche Bank North America since 1994. He will be responsible for corporate finance, strategic and tax planning and will report to the president and chief executive, Thomas Renyi.

headline: Brazil Awards Big Mining Stake To Group Bidding $3.13 Billion
abstract: Privatization of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, Brazilian state-owned mining giant, proceeds, with group financed by Nationsbank Corp emerging as winning bidder; Nationsbank provides $1.1 billion loan for the purchase, which is led by Brazilian steelmaker Companhia Siderurgica Nacional; group is taking 41.73 percent stake in the company for $3.13 billion; privatization is largest sale of state asset in Latin America (M)

headline: . . . But Computers Are Clearly the Future
abstract: Jack McGarvey article, citing computer proficiency of his middle school students, recommends investing in technology stocks (M)

headline: An Internet Address Is Sold for $150,000
abstract: New high price for high-profile Internet address is set when an address--business.com--is sold for $150,000 to undisclosed company in Texas; Internet address is sold by Business Systems International of London (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * In-N-Out Burgers, Irvine, Calif., to McCann-Erickson Los Angeles, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its account, which had been handled by Weller, O'Sullivan, Zuckerman & Lightcap, Los Angeles. Billings have not been determined.

headline: Strong Selloff Pushes Dow Down 139.67
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average plunges 139.67 points, or 1.93 percent, to 7,085.65, and other major indexes also tumble; chairmen of Congress's tax-writing committees say any capital-gains tax cut approved this year would apply to sales made on or after May 7; analysts had said they expected spurt of selling once start date was announced because many investors have been holding off in hopes that budget compromise would include such a tax cut; table (L)

headline: Goldman Director Named to Treasury
abstract: Pres Clinton nominates Gary Gensler, managing director at Goldman, Sachs Group LP, to be Assistant Treasury Secretary for financial markets (S)

headline: Bre-X Files For Bankruptcy
abstract: Bre-X Minerals Ltd is granted protection from creditors by Alberta, Canada, court as it oversees liquidation of the company, which was described this week as having perpetrated biggest mining fraud in history; Bre-X says its chief geologist John Felderhof has left the company (S)

headline: LG&E Energy Agrees to Buy Rival Utility In Kentucky
abstract: LG&E Energy Corp, Louisville, Ky, utility that has campaigned for deregulation, announces agreement to buy another Kentucky utility, KU Energy Corp, for $1.5 billion in stock; LG&E chairman Roger W Hale says merger creates one of largest low-cost energy holding companies in the country (L)

headline: From Clinton to Lott, a Last-Minute Letter
abstract: Text of Pres Clinton's letter to Sen Trent Lott addressing concerns about provisions of Chemical Weapons Convention (S)

headline: At Morton, Much More Than a Dash of Cash
abstract: Profile of Morton International Inc, which as produced famous table salt since its founding in Chicago in 1848; company is now far more diverse, selling glues for food packages and other specialty chemicals, which now account for about two-thirds of corporate profits; photo; graph of recent stock performance; company is cash-rich cost-cutter that is divesting itself of products unrelated to its major lines (M) y

headline: Is Recovery in Store for FPA Shares?
abstract: Article on prospects for shares of FPA Medical Management; graph (L)

headline: Tele-Communications Abandons Plan to Spin Off 3 Units
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc says it will not spin off Liberty Media Corp and two other businesses because it could not obtain favorable tax ruling from Internal Revenue Service; other two companies are Tele-Communications International, and the company that holds Liberty's 9 percent stake in Time Warner Inc; decision by Tele-Communications comes after company is unable to meet IRS request concerning shares of its late chairman, Bob Magness, who controlled large block of TCI shares (M)

headline: For Stock Values, a Yardstick With a Difference
abstract: Price-earnings ratio, which compares stock price with company's profits per share, may be most common measure for finding low-priced deals in market; some investors turn to lesser-known instrument: price-sales ratio; this measure compares stock price with company's sales per share, revealing how many invested dollars are needed to buy one dollar of revenue; average price-sales ratio for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is 1.60; value seekers typically focus on companies with low-priced stocks--those with ratio of less than 1; photo; chart (M)

headline: Federal Reserve Allowing Rates To Hold Steady
abstract: Federal Reserve Open Market Committee votes to leave interest rates unchanged, betting economy is slowing enough to avert resurgence of inflation; decision sends stock prices surging (M)

headline: A British magazine stirs up a fuss over medical emergencies on United States airlines.
abstract: London's New Scientist magazine is stirring up a fuss with article in current issue declaring that more airline passengers are dying from heart attacks and other medical emergencies on US carriers than in plane crashes; magazine cites Federal Aviation Administration figures released in February showing that there are about 14,000 medical emergencies each year on major US airlines; magazine reports estimated 350 passengers die each year aboard US carriers, compared with average of 118 passengers a year who have died in air crashes in this country since 1978; there are still some summer and fall bargain air fares for travelers who missed out on earlier sales, but they must be purchased no later than June 16; some bargains noted; passengers using T F Green Airport in Warwick, RI, which serves nearby Providence, can now avail themselves of in-flight meals; Aviation Consumer Action Project survey shows most airline companion fares, in which one passenger buys round-trip ticket at full fare and companion travels free on same flight, are a bargain (L)

headline: Mexican Steel Venture Set
abstract: Grupo Acerero del Norte SA forms $30 million joint venture with Eisenwerk Sulzau-Werfen R & E Weinberger AG of Austria; venture, based in Mexico, will maker rollers, which are used in production of steel plate (S)

headline: Israeli Court Ruling Opposes Closing of Street on Sabbath
abstract: Israeli Supreme Court, reviving issue that led to violent confrontations last summer between strictly observant Jews and other residents of Jerusalem, rules street through religious neighborhood should remain open on Sabbath until Transport Minister finds ways to accomodate few nonreligious residents; city's increasingly assertive ultra-Orthodox population is expected to resume efforts to block street on Saturdays (M)

headline: Mobutu's Nemesis Keeps His Plans to Himself
abstract: Interview with Laurent Kabila, Zairian rebel leader who is adept at giving voice to the discontent of his countrymen but is less forthcoming about his own past as a left-wing revolutionary and his plans for Zaire's future; he insists he has abandoned Marxism and favors multiparty democracy, but his recent ctions hint otherwise; photos (M)

headline: TCI to Buy Newspaper Owner in Utah
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc plans to acquire Kearns-Tribune Co, owner of The Salt Lake Tribune, Utah's largest newspaper, for $627 million in stock; transaction would give TCI a platform from which to experiment with electronic publishing; deal is also aimed at solidifying John C Malone's control of TCI; separate agreement between Malone, TCI chairman, and Kearns would allow Malone to increase his voting control of TCI, which is now 16.9 percent, by swapping his class A shares, which carry one vote each, for class B shares owned by Kearns; class B shares have 10 votes each; Kearns-Tribune also owns 6.6 million shares of Liberty Media, which is TCI's programming arm (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Apr. 25   Apr. 18   Apr. 26          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.7   7.7   7.6       Distillate production, daily   3.3   3.3   3.4       Gasoline stocks   194.2   194.6   203.8       Distillate stocks   94.9   96.3   88.6       Crude imports, daily   8.0   8.0   8.1       Product imports, daily   2.2   2.1   1.8       Crude stocks   314.7   312.8   297.1       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   93.5   93.5   92.7          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Zaire's Decay Slows Return of Refugees
abstract: Efforts by UN to repatriate thousands of Rwandan Hutu refugees, driven deep into Zaire by rebel forces, have been measurably slowed by decades-old decay of Zaire's transportation system; logistical nightmare faced by relief workers in evacuation of refugees from Kisangani, Zaire, to Rwanda--distance of 450 miles--described; map; photos (M)

headline: Pivotal Force at CBS Expands His Spectrum to TV
abstract: Profile of Mel Karmazin, who has been given control of CBS network's 14 television stations; management shuffle at CBS prompted resignation of Peter A Lund, chief exec of CBS; photo (M)

headline: HOME DEPOT SPLITS STOCK AND INCREASES DIVIDEND
abstract: Home Depot Inc will split its stock 3 for 2 and increase its quarterly dividend by 25 percent, to 5 cents on post-split basis; names president and chief operating officer Arthur M Blank to additional post of chief executive, succeeding Bernard Marcus, who remains chairman (S)

headline: Bursting the bubble at the Bubble Factory, another tale from Hollywood.
abstract: Severing of ties between Bubble Factory, two-year-old production firm, and Universal Pictures offers rare glimpse into Hollywood practices; Seagram Co apparently gave unusually lucrative deal to Sidney J Sheinberg, Bubble Factory founder and former MCA Inc president, in effort to keep film maker Steven Spielberg at MCA's Universal unit; Sheinberg's close ties to Spielberg noted; Bubble Factory films have not been financially successful; photos (M)

headline: Mobutu's Son Lingers, Reportedly Settling Scores
abstract: Capt Kongulu Mobutu, son of ousted Zairian Pres Mobutu Sese Seko who was officer in Presidential Guard, reportedly sought to rally other guardsmen in last-ditch effort to stave off rebel capture of capital of Kinshasa and to avenge his father's defeat; reportedly plotted to punish those he felt abandoned President, from moment he learned of father's decision to give up power; he is believed to have played role in assassination of Defense Minister, Gen Mahele Lioko; photo (M)

headline: French Child-Porn Dragnet Is Criticized After Suicides
abstract: French Justice Min Elisabeth Guigou voices concern that police may have gone too far in nationwide sweep of pedophiles after four of accused committed suicide; approximately 800 persons were detained, but only 24 remain under arrest; human rights groups charge some of defendants' rights were violated (M)

headline: Two Agencies Make Promotions
abstract: TBWA Chiat/Day names Bob Kuperman, president and chief executive of Venice, Calif, office to new post of president and chief executive of TBWA Chiat/Day's North American operations; at Venice office, Steve Goldman and John Truscott are promoted to assume responsibilities from Kuperman in new posts of joint managing directors; Leo Burnett USA names Cheryl R Berman, executive vice president and deputy creative office, chief creative officer; Berman assumes responsibilities from Michael Conrad, who was promoted earlier this month to chief creative officer of parent, the Leo Burnett Co (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of week's events affecting financial and economic sectors; photos; graph (S)

headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS INC. (SBC,N)
abstract: SBC Communications Inc says that rainstorms in Northern California and expenses for new ventures weakened first-quarter profits, first report combining its results with Pacific Telesis Group, which it acquired on April 1; merged company reports 3.5 percent decline in pro forma net income to $857 million, or 94 cents a share, from $888 million, or 96 cents share, in quarter year earlier; table (S)

headline: Profiting as a business-to-business middleman on the Internet is tricky.
abstract: Technology column on lessons to be learned from bankruptcy filing of Nets Inc, company that sought to deploy Internet to streamline corporate procurement process; says playing middleman role on Internet is tricky, because essence of Internet is that it enables people and businesses to connect directly; says early opportunities for Internet market makers are going to be defined narrowly in specific industry sectors as opposed to across-the-board manufacturers' mall formula of Nets (M)

headline: Pearle Vision Names New Agency
abstract: Pearle Vision Inc has named McCann-Erickson New York to handle its advertising and marketing account, with billings estimated at $25 million; account had been handled by GSD&M (S)

headline: CVS Starts Review Of Broadcast Account
abstract: CVS Corp places in review broadcast creative portion of its advertising account; account had been handled by Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: China's Army Is Ready For a Display of Force
abstract: Thousands of Chinese troops will enter Hong Kong by land, sea and air on July 1, six hours after end of British rule, in decisive display of China's sovereignty over what had been British colony for 156 years (M)

headline: Regulatory Hurdles in an AT&T Deal With SBC
abstract: If last week's premature disclosure of merger talks between the AT&T Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. was an attempt to float a trial balloon, it is fair to say the balloon got shot out of the sky.    Lawyers, lawmakers and lobbyists were almost unanimous in predicting that such a deal would never pass regulatory muster. Harold H. Greene, the Federal judge who issued the landmark ruling that broke up AT&T's Bell System in 1984, said in an interview, ''I don't think there is a great deal of competition in either local or long distance, which should be a prerequisite for recombining the Bell System empire.''

headline: Compaq Computer Agrees to Buy Maker of Networking Products
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp agrees to buy Microcom Inc for $280 million in cash, latest move in rapid consolidation of computer networking industry (M)

headline: Erring on the side of fighting inflation at the expense of jobs.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan has kept economy on even keel since recession of 1990-91, but he has not really established that Fed has found golden mean between stable prices and economic growth; says no one knows whether 'nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment' is 5.5 percent or 4.5 percent, so decisions about target implicitly have as much to do with how one weighs consequences of erring on side of slow growth against costs of inflation; drawing (M)

headline: Prodigy in China
abstract: Prodigy Inc becomes first Government-approved foreign Internet provider in China, which closely controls access to global computer network (S)

headline: Investment Banks Shut in Thailand
abstract: Thailand shuts some of biggest investment banks and orders them taken over under rescue effort that could cost up to $11.9 billion (S)

headline: No Joe Camel? Here is an imagined world if Big Tobacco is faced with new Federal Regulations
abstract: Advertising column suggests some quick and easy fixes that would bring cigarette advertising in line with tighter Federal regulations that can be expected as result of current negotiations between tobacco industry and Government; drawings (M)

headline: Give Workers Respect, And Longer Vacations
abstract: Anthony Steventon letter wonders that American workers do not demand and receive more generous vacation time and shorter work weeks that are commonplace in Europe (S)

headline: Home Shopping Seen in Deals For 50% Stake In Ticketmaster
abstract: Home Shopping Network agrees to acquire 47.5 percent stake in Ticketmaster held by Paul G Allen, co-founder of Microsoft Corp, for $210 million in Home Shopping stock; Home Shopping Network also plans to buy additional 2.5 percent of Ticketmaster on the open market, allowing it to consolidate Ticketmaster's profits; acquisition is expected to bolster both companies' ability to offer home-shopping services while cutting costs (L)

headline: 58% Gain in Quarterly Profit Is Reported by Times Company
abstract: The New York Times Co reports that net income for first quarter rose more than 58 percent; attributes gain to higher advertising revenues and declining newsprint prices; company earned $51.8 million, compared with $32.7 million in quarter a year earlier; revenue rose more than 10 percent, to $692.5 million; operating profit of newspaper group rose to $100 million, from $61.1 million a year earlier, as revenue for group rose to $621 million from $565.4 million; table (M)

headline: Operating Profit Up 25% At Munich-Based Bank
abstract: Bayerische Landesbank Girozentrale, Germany's sixth-largest bank, says that its operating profit in first quarter rose 25 percent, led by commission income; operating profit rises to $233 million (S)

headline: ITT CONSIDERING SALE OF STAKE IN ITALIAN HOTEL CONCERN
abstract: ITT Corp weighs sale of part of 70 percent stake in Ciga SpA, Italian luxury hotel chain, as well as sales of individual Ciga hotels (S)

headline: Kodak Assigns Executive to Hong Kong
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co says it will send Carl F Kohrt, executive vice president and assistant chief operating officer, to Hong Kong to oversee its Asian business and further Kodak's efforts to become a global company (S)

headline: Hewlett Net Falls Below Estimates
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co reports second-quarter earnings that fall below Wall Street analysts' estimates; for quarter ended April 30, company had earnings of $784 million, up 8.4 percent from $723 million in year-earlier period; revenues rose 4.7 percent, to $10.3 billion, from $9.9 billion in last year's second quarter; table (L)

headline: Puncturing Czech Economic Miracle
abstract: Czech Republic's Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus, after insisting that his country is model for quick transition from Communism to capitalism, has been forced to admit mistakes, administer some medicine and reshuffle his Government; Czech Republic faces decline in economic output this year, in contrast to growth estimated at 6 percent in neighborhing Poland; Klaus has introduced second austerity package in a month, freezing wages and cutting Government spending; photo (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.32   5.14        3-MO. headline: Corrections
abstract: An article on March 16 about investing in Four Seasons Hotels misstated the number of hotels managed by the company worldwide. It is 38, not 39. The article also referred incorrectly to the relationship between the company shares that trade in Canada and those that trade in the United States. The shares are exchangeable.     The article also misstated the role of Isadore Sharp, the company's chairman,in starting the company. He was the founder, not a co-founder.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: E.I. DU PONT DE NEMOURS & CO., Wilmington, Del., the chemicals and plastic giant, said its directors had voted to increase its quarterly dividend by 11 percent, to 63 cents a share, while its stockholders had approved a 2-for-1 stock split.

headline: PACIFICARE SHARES SLIDE ON FORECAST OF EARNINGS
abstract: Pacificare Health Systems Inc forecasts that its second-quarter earnings will be just 30 cents to 45 cents a share, sending managed-care company's shares tumbling for second time this week (S)

headline: Data Showing Little Inflation Lift Bonds
abstract: US Treasury bond prices rise, sending yields plunging to their lowest levels in a month; price of 30-year benchmark bond jumps 1 17/32 points, to 95 19/32; yield drops to 6.98 percent, from 7.11 percent; graph (L)

headline: Outlook for Big Crops Sends Soybeans and Corn Tumbling
abstract: Soybeans and corn for delivery after this year's harvest sink after Government says plantings in US this spring could be largest since 1980's; cotton prices fall (M)

headline: Asking a Lawyer to Lift Tobacco's Haze
abstract: Interview with Calvert D Crary, managing director of securities firm of Auerbach, Pollak & Richardson and litigation analyst, on how regulation, not litigation, is cigarette industry's biggest problem and why investing in tobacco is risky; photo (L)

headline: Privatized German Farms Liable for Communists' Debt
abstract: Germany's highest court rules that farmers have to pay back $6 billion in debt that old collective farms in former East Germany ran up during Communist era; debts are likely to weigh on about 2,000 former collective farms, which were converted after Germany's reunification in 1990 into for-profit companies, for at least next 10 years; ruling further angers farmers because German Government has already forgiven billions of marks in debt owed by bankrupt state-owned factories and has pumped billions more into trying to rebuild them from ground up (L)

headline: Bonds Lower In Advance Of Price Data
abstract: US Treasury securities are flat; 30-year bond's price slips 2/32, to 93 12/32, pushing its yield up to 7.17 percent, from 7.16 percent on April 11; graph (L)

headline: Paper Tests May Die, but Graphite Will Scribble On
abstract: Trend toward computerized testing does not faze Dixon Ticonderoga Company in Heathrow, Florida, nation's de facto pencil-making capital; company chief executive Gino N Pala does not believe pencils will become extinct, noting that sales of trusty Number 2 are expected to rise five percent this year; graph (S)

headline: C.I.A. Plotted Killing of 58 In Guatemala
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency, plotting to overthrow the Guatemalan Government in the early 1950's, drew up a ''disposal list'' of at least 58 key leaders, and it trained assassins to kill them, newly declassified documents show.    The coup, code-named Operation Success, toppled the freely elected President of Guatemala, Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, and installed the first of a series of right-wing leaders friendly to the United States.

TREAS. BILLS   4.87   4.98   5.03        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.20   5.23   5.12        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.60   3.61   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.73   6.79   6.78        30-YR. TREAS.
