headline: The 800-pound gorilla among advertisers, the auto industry, gained a little more weight in 1996.
abstract: Competitive Media Reporting says auto makers, traditionally nation's largest advertisers, nailed down industry's premier position even more securely in 1996 by raising their ad spending 9.4 percent over 1995; reports auto industry as a whole spent $11.6 billion on advertising, or more than 17 percent of $66.7 billion that nation's advertisers spent; General Motors Corp spent $1.61 bilion; Chrysler Corp, number 4, spent $1.07 billion, while Ford Motor Co, number 5, spent $843 million; sandwiched between car makers were Procter & Gamble and Philip Morris, respectively number 2 and number 3; other rankings noted (L)

headline: Lane Timmons, 81, Former Envoy to Haiti
abstract: Benson Ellison Lane Timmons 3d, former Ambassador to Haiti, dies at age 81 (S)

headline: Fire Kills Pilgrims at Tent Camp in Mecca
abstract: Fire swept through a crowded encampment yesterday outside Mecca, Saudi Arabia, where some two million Muslim pilgrims had gathered for one of Islam's holiest rituals. As many as 300 people were killed, witnesses said.    Hours after the blaze had been contained, Saudi officials put the death toll at 217, with more than 1,290 people injured.

headline: Guinness and Grand Met in $22 Billion Deal
abstract: Grand Metropolitan PLC and Guinness PLC, faced with steady decline in major liquor consumption in their traditional markets, agree to merger valued at about $22.27 billion; together, companies own some of best known brands of Scotch, vodka and gin, along with famed Guinness stout; companies are confident that efficiencies resulting from combination, including eliminating 2,000 jobs, will lift sales and profits; merger will create new company, GMG Brands, which will also absorb Grand Met's huge food operations including more than 9,000 Burger King restaurants, Green Giant vegetables, Haagen-Dazs ice cream and Pillsbury; Grand Met shareholders will wind up with controlling 52.7 percent of shares in new company; Guinness chairman Tony Greener and Grand Met chairman George Bull comment; photo (L)

headline: King of Pop Faces U.S. Market With Subdued Promotion Effort
abstract: Epic Records has released pop star Michael Jackson's latest recording with little fanfare in United States, where recording is selling poorly; has shifted promotional focus overseas, where Jackson is much more popular; photo (M)

headline: Fed Rate Rise On March 25 Was Backed By Full Panel
abstract: Minutes of Federal Open Market Committee meeting show Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in raising overnight bank lending rate on March 25, though they decided to take more relaxed stance toward inflation in the interim (M)

headline: Lilly Cuts Distribution Unit's Book Value by $2.4 Billion
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co, admitting it overpaid for PCS, drug distribution and managed care business it bought in 1994, cuts book value of unit by $2.4 billion and will report loss in current quarter and for 1997; Lilly and other big drug makers have fared poorly in their purchases of pharmacy benefit managers, which have been warned by Federal Trade Commission not to favor parent firms' drugs (M)

headline: Miller Withdraws MTV Beer Ads
abstract: The Miller Brewing Company has withdrawn commercials for its beer brands from the MTV cable television network after a similar step by Miller's primary competitor, the Anheuser-Busch Companies.    ''We felt that this move would help insure Miller's intentions regarding its media buying practices,'' Susan Henderson, a spokeswoman for Miller in Milwaukee, said yesterday in confirming a report this week in Advertising Age. Miller, owned by the Philip Morris Companies, has not run spots on MTV since February, she added; Anheuser-Busch stopped its MTV ads in September.

headline: The Khmer Rouge Implosion
abstract: Seth Mydans analysis contends that violent self-destruction of Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge leadership appears to mark end of civil war that has riven Cambodia in one form or another for 30 years; maintains that divisions tha ttore group apart appear to be connected with political cold war within Cambodia's Government that could erupt into new violence; map (M)

headline: As Rebels Gain in Zaire, Mobutu Declares Emergency and Imposes Military Rule
abstract: Zaire Pres Mobutu Sese Seko declares state of emergency throughout country, replacing civilian officials with military administrators; move, which will give Mobutu nominal control over only five of Zaire's eight provinces, comes as civilian opposition to his authority continues to grow and armed rebellion appears poised to make new gains in countryside; map (M)

headline: A Licensing Deal By 2 Drug Makers
abstract: Cocensys Inc, biotechnology company, agrees to license its new anti-anxiety drug to Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, a division of American Home Products Corp, for combination of fees and payments worth as much as $59 million (S)

headline: G.E. Posts 10.5% Profit Gain, In Line With Analyst Forecasts
abstract: General Electric Co says earnings rose 10.5 percent in first quarter; net income rose to $1.68 billion in quarter from $1.52 billion a year earlier; revenue rose 17.9 percent, to $20.2 billion from $17.1 billion; table (S)

headline: A.I.G. Chairman Names Son President
abstract: Maurice R Greenberg, chairman of American International Group Inc, names his son, Evan G, president and chief operating officer (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Worries About Fed Persist, And Stocks Are Mixed  Stock prices were mixed as investors continued to worry about the possibility of higher interest rates, even though the Federal Reserve voted to leave them unchanged earlier this week.    Banks, among the companies most sensitive to rising rates, fell. The Dow industrials slid 12.77 points, to 7,290.69. But many computer-related issues rose, and the Nasdaq was up 9.87 points, to 1,373.75. $(Page D10.$)

headline: Phone Company to Move
abstract: Midcom Communications will move its headquarters to Southfield, Mich, from Seattle; move will affect about 130 employees (S)

headline: 2 Units Split on New Leadership
abstract: Andersen Worldwide, consulting and accounting firm, is beset by internal conflict, as partners fail for second time to elect new chief executive; there is tension and mistrust between two sides of Andersen Worldwide; reflecting company's roots, 1,700 auditing and tax partners at Arthur Andersen outnumber the 1,000 partners at Andersen Consulting, and partners from auditing side likewise holds two-thirds of seats on company's 27-member board; but consulting partners bring in more revenue per partner and generally resent sharing those profits with the accountants; photos of Jim Wadia, Arthur Andersen's managing partner in Britain, and George T Shaheen, managing partner for Andersen Consulting; graphs (L)

headline: J. Rembrandt George, Creator Of Idea of Taxi Ads, Dies at 73
abstract: J Rembrandt George, advertising executive who was instrumental in introducing elongated, pyramid-like plasticized billboards that sit on top of New York City's taxicabs, died on May 23 at age 73; photo (M)

headline: Jospin Takes Office and Talks With Communists on Cabinet
abstract: Socialist leader Lionel Jospin becomes French Prime Minister, replacing Alain Juppe; holds talks with Communists on their terms for joining new left-wing Government; Juppe sets special meeting to choose Gaullist party leader; photo (M)

headline: This Panel on the Media, The Media Want to Stop
abstract: Press freedom groups, concerned that United Nations might be drawn into renewed campaign for worldwide regulation of news media, are lobbying against efforts to convene world conference on communications gaps between developed nations and third world (M)

headline: Albright Chides Balkan Chiefs On Flouting of Peace Accord
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright meets with Croatian Pres Franjo Tudjman in Zagreb and Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade and lectures them about their failure to comply with Dayton peace accords; warns both leaders that their countries could face stronger penalties if they do not turn over people indicted on war crimes charges and allow refugees to return to their homes (M)

headline: Of All That He Sells, He Sells Himself Best
abstract: Profile of and interview with Richard Branson, indefatigable promoter of his own many ventures, which now include financial company, Virgin Direct; funds have so far handled $1.3 billion, much of which comes from small investors; Branson himself says he avoids stock market because he believes he can do better by plowing his own money back into Virgin empire, now encompassing more than 200 companies with annual sales of about $2.5 billion; enterprises of 46-year-old high-school dropout recounted; table; photos; Sunday Times list showing Branson as fifth-wealthiest Briton, excluding royal family (L)

headline: Follow the Bouncing Return
abstract: Roundup of mutual fund news; American Heritage, top-performing mutual fund in first quarter, was worst performer last year; manager Heiko Thieme comments on fund's volatility; Vanguard Group offers booklet that examines past market tumbles and advises investors how to prepare for one; graphs (M)

headline: Rebels Force 80,000 Hutu to Flee to Jungle
abstract: UN officials accuse Zairian rebels of trying to drive Hutu refugees to slow death in jungle; aid workers report 80,000 refugees have disappeared from camps; map (S)

headline: Goodby, Silverstein Wins 24 Clios
abstract: For the third consecutive year, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors at the Clio Awards ceremonies, winning the most awards.    At the 38th annual awards presentations, held last night and Tuesday in New York, Goodby, Silverstein, part of Omnicom Group, won 24 Clios: 1 gold, 10 silver and 13 bronze. Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston followed with 12 Clios: 2  gold, 2 silver, 7 bronzes and the Grand Clio for a national television campaign created for the financial services division of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company. Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., won 10 Clios: 6 silver and 4 bronze.

headline: Swedbank Says Profits Increased by 9%
abstract: Swedbank AB says first-quarter operating profit rose 9 percent; profit rose to 1.315 billion kronor ($171 million) from 1.202 billion in first quarter of 1996 (S)

headline: Promoting books via TV commercials and movie trailers has become affordable.
abstract: Publishers are using television commercials and movie trailers to promote books; advanced computer technology has cut cost of producing commercials and cable channels now offer targeted, inexpensive advertising opportunities; publishers time movie trailers for best-selling authors to movies based on their books; photo (M)

headline: RIVAL TOPS SELECT MEDICAL'S BID FOR HOSPITAL COMPANY
abstract: Shares of Transitional Hospitals Corp rise 42 percent after company says unidentified potential bidder offered on May 4 to pay it $15 a share, topping bid of $14.55 a share that it had accepted earlier from Select Medical Corp (S)

headline: Little Inflation Seen, And Markets Rally
abstract: Fears that inflation is building up were eased somewhat after the Government reported that consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in March.     The bond and stock markets, which have been troubled by the prospect of greater inflation and higher interest rates, rallied on the report. Bond prices gained, pushing their yields down to where they were a week ago. The Dow Jones industrial average surged 135.26 points, or 2.1 percent -- its second-largest point gain in history, although much less significant in percentage terms.

headline: Where the Street Meets the Strip
abstract: Money Show, series of investment seminars around nation sponsored by Charles and Kim Githler, successfully attracts small investors; majority of participants prefer to manage own investments; bullish and bearish views of investment gurus featured at Las Vegas seminar discussed; tables; photo (L)

headline: Pope Renews Call for Poles to Get Rid of Abortion-Rights Law
abstract: Pope John Paul II, celebrating outdoor Mass, Kalisz, Poland, urges Polish Catholics to join fight against abortion, key issue in forthcoming Polish parliamentary elections (M)

headline: Additional Share Offer For Machines Bull
abstract: Compagnie des Machines Bull SA, France's biggest computer maker, will offer further 1.46 million shares to individual investors after its initial sale of 1.62 million shares is 21 times oversubscribed (S)

headline: Closing the Book on Poor Performers
abstract: Fund Watch column notes that trustees of Steadman funds are proposing to merge their offerings and then convert it to closed-end fund; funds have done poorly and lost shareholders millions of dollars during their existence (M)

headline: Pacificorp Is Said to Reach Deal to Buy British Utility
abstract: Pacificorp reaches oral agreement to acquire Energy Group PLC for $6 billion in cash and is selling its telecommunications subsidiary, Pacific Telecom, for $1.5 billion to help pay for Energy Group acquisition; identity of buyer of Pacific Telecom is not disclosed (L)

headline: Hanson Electrical Sold For $219.8 Million
abstract: Hanson PLC sells its electrical equipment business to Cinven for $203.5 million in cash and $16.3 million loan note that pays 5 percent interest and is due in 2006 (S)

headline: AMERICAN GREETINGS SAYS IT IS STILL INTERESTED IN RIVAL
abstract: American Greetings Corp chief executive Morry Weiss says his company remains interested in buying rival, Gibson Greetings Inc, a year after its acquisition bid failed; Gibson's president-chief executive Frank O'Connell declines comment (S)

headline: Cat Hair Finds Way Into Courtroom in Canadian Murder Trial
abstract: Jury on Prince Edward Island, Canada, finds Douglas Beamish guilty of murdering his former girlfriend, Shirley A Duguay; main evidence against him comes from DNA of family cat; forensic scientists say case is first in which animal DNA has been introduced in court (M)

headline: Mexico Cracks Down on Long Tradition of Dirty Politics
abstract: Mexico City police raid factory mass-producing videotapes portraying leftist party's candidate for mayor, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, as violent radical, and his aides say that tapes are part of dirty tricks campaign to hurt party in national elections (M)

headline: Renewed Violence Strikes Ulster As Talks Are About to Resume
abstract: The police said today that the Irish Republican Army threatened new violence this weekend in the Roman Catholic area of Poleglass in West Belfast.    In a separate incident, the police said, an off-duty policeman was beaten to death early this morning by Protestant men outside a bar in the Protestant town of Ballymoney, north of Belfast.

headline: Big Industrial Nations Warn Dollar Rise Must Be Halted
abstract: Finance ministers and central bankers of seven leading industrial nations strongly hint they would intervene in currency markets, if necessary, to halt dollar's rise against Japanese yen and keep Japan's trade surpluses in check, Group of Seven meeting, Washington; warning is first to directly link decision on how high to let dollar rise to concern about Japanese trade imbalances with United States and others (M)

headline: Insurer Is Said To Near a Deal For Scudder
abstract: Zurich Insurance Group is close to acquiring Scudder, Stevens & Clark, money management firm, for estimated $1.5 billion; big Swiss insurance company would be trying to broaden its asset management expertise and provide complement to its Zurich Kemper Investments subsidiary that would bolster that unit's performance (L)

headline: Stocks Surge As Dow Leaps 173.38 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 173.38 points, or 2.6 percent, to close at 6,833.59; Dow point rise is largest since Oct 21, 1987; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rises 14.24 points, or 1.87 percent, to 774.61; Nasdaq composite index gains 8.79, closing at 1,212.74; table (L)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : Nostalgia Fuels the Craze In Baby Boomers' Discards
abstract: The castoffs of Baby Boomers' youth are fetching big prices in flea markets, garage sales, art galleries and, yes, junk shops.

headline: Dollar Falters Against Yen After Reaching 4 1/2-Year High
abstract: US dollar falls for first time in a week, tumbling from four-and-a-year high against Japanese yen, after three senior Japanese officials suggest that Japan might sell dollars to halt its rally (M)

headline: PERU TROOPS RESCUE HOSTAGES; REBELS SLAIN AS STANDOFF ENDS
abstract: Peruvian troops storm Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima and rescue scores of captives from Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement guerrillas who had held them hostage for four months; Pres Alberto K Fujimori says all but one of 72 hostages were rescued and 14 of rebels were killed, including leader, Nestor Cerpa Cartolini; hostage who died was Supreme Court Justice Carlos Giusti Acuna; Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan says his country was not informed in advance of attack; Fujimori had agreed to consult Japanese before taking any military action; map; photos (M)

headline: What Will Follow 7 Years Of Riches?
abstract: Market Watch column speculates about outlook for technology stocks (S)

headline: Niche Magazines on Maladies Take a Peppier and Glossier Route
abstract: Recent trend in magazine publishing is to put glossy, for-profit spin on concept of how reader and his loved ones can cope with a particular malady; such information was once controlled by low-budget, nuts-and-bolts informational material put out by foundations; now, new breed of magazines--for people with AIDS, or arthritis, or physical disabilities--carries articles on foreign travel and glamorous interiors, alongside profiles of disease survivors; such magazines find that attracting advertisers, other than pharmaceutical companies, can be tough sell; photos (M)

headline: Motorola Sidelines Device Providing Live N.B.A. Scores
abstract: Four months after winning a groundbreaking lawsuit establishing its right to broadcast second-by-second National Basketball Association game scores over its pager network, Motorola Inc. is showing little interest in the electronic device at the heart of the legal debate.    Sportstrax, a $99 pager-like gadget that provides live scores and other game data from Major League Baseball and the National Basketball Association, is ''no longer being actively promoted as a product,'' said Joe Mulvey, general manager at Motorola.

headline: Industrial Output Up by 1.9% in Germany
abstract: Germany's Economic Ministry reports industrial output rose seasonally adjusted 1.9 percent in February over Janaury; February's output was up 2.1 percent compared with year earlier; Bundesbank leaves key interest rates unchanged at its fortnightly meeting as had been expected (S)

headline: Indonesian Governing Party Wins Yet Another Landslide
abstract: Indonesia's ruling Golkar party, first voted into office in 1971, wins its fifth straight victory in May 29 parliamentary elections; with 64 percent of votes counted, Golkar party of Pres Suharto has received 74 percent of total; voting is largely peaceful despite violent campaign in which over 200 people were killed; photo (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: List of upcoming market reports

headline: Korean Lust After Cures Is a Threat To Species
abstract: Craving for traditional Chinese medicines is fueled in South Korea by increasing wealth; poses threat to bears, other rare and endangered species (M)

headline: ENERGY CONSULTANTS ANNOUNCE $65 MILLION MERGER DEAL
abstract: Metzler Group Inc agrees to buy Resource Management International Inc for about $65 million in stock (S)

headline: Factions Weigh In on Hong Kong Under Chinese Rule
abstract: World Wide Web sites about Hong Kong offer variety of views about what will happen after sovereignty shifts to Beijing on June 30 (M)

headline: Murdoch Gets Some Bad News In Dispute With Time Warner
abstract: Rupert Murdoch loses round in his bitter feud with Time Warner when Federal Judge Jack B Weinstein dismisses two claims by Murdoch's News Corp that Time Warner had fraudulently backed out of deal to carry Fox News Channel on its New York City cable system; Weinstein rules that News Corp had no reason to presume that oral assurances from Time Warner's senior execs were same as an ironclad agreement to carry Fox channel (M)

headline: MOBUTU GIVES UP, LEAVING KINSHASA AND CEDING POWER
abstract: Mobutu Sese Seko ends 32 year of rule over Zaire, slipping out of Kinshasa as Laurent Kabila's rebels approach capital; Mobutu gives up angrily after generals warn they cannot defend city; generals reportedly try to make contact with rebels for peaceful takeover that would avoid fighting or pillaging; Mobutu's top general is reported killed by diehard officers; prime minister takes refuge in French Embassy; maps showing rebel advance since last December (M)

headline: Reno Air Suing Northwest Over Fare Cuts
abstract: Reno Air Inc has sued Northwest Airlines Corp for reportedly cutting air fares to force Reno Air out of Minneapolis-St Paul market four years ago (S)

headline: Link to Brother's Fund-Raising Seen in Suspension by Broker
abstract: Suspension of Robert B Maloney as Smith Barney Inc's New England regional director stems from question about money he helped to raise for Congressional election campaigns for his brother, Repr James H Maloney; James Maloney, Democrat of Connecticut, in November defeated Gary A Franks, incumbent Republican, to win election to House, after failed Congressional bid in 1994 (M)

headline: Once Again, Africa Deals With a Crisis on Its Own
abstract: Ouster of Pres Mobuto Sese Seko by rebels in Congo and Nigerian-led West African intervention to reverse military coup against elected Government in Sierra Leone signal new determination by many African countries to take command of own regional affairs; analysts say countries have been moving with unaccustomed forcefulness to settle problems that threaten regional stability, ushering in what Clinton Administration official calls post-post-colonial era; photo (M)

headline: $10.9 MILLION INVESTMENT AT TRUCK PLANT IS PLANNED
abstract: General Motors Corp will invest $10.9 million in equipment at its truck plant in Flint, Mich, and move 1,000 managers to new metal-fabricating division headquarters in city by year 2000 (S)

headline: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES TO ADD HIGHLANDS GAS
abstract: Union Pacific Resources Group Inc agrees to acquire Highlands Gas Corp for about $180 million (S)

headline: Khmer Rouge Said to Execute A Top Aide on Pol Pot's Order
abstract: Pol Pot, ailing founder of movement responsible for deaths of more than million Cambodians in 1970's, orders execution of a top lieutenant, 67-year-old Son sen, then fees his jungle hideout on a stretcher; report suggests that 20 years after Khmer Rouge seized power and turned Cambodia into a killing ground, core of its leadership it itself disintegrating in violence; First Prime Min Prince Norodom Ranariddh says that gunmen, acting on orders of Pol Pot, killed Son Sen, his wife and

headline: TECHNITROL TO SELL MEASUREMENT DEVICE UNIT TO AMETEK
abstract: Ametek Inc plans to acquire Technitrol Inc's test and measurement products business for $34 million in cash (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence June

headline: I.R.A. May Have Planted A Land Mine in Belfast
abstract: Police in Belfast say Irish Republican Army planned attack on police patrol using land mine but abandoned it because there were civilians in area (S)

headline: Sinn Fein Candidate Is Elected to a Seat in the Irish Parliament
abstract: Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, wins seat in Irish Parliament for first time in 16 years; Caoimhghin O'Caolain will be first member of his party to take seat since Ireland won independence from Britain in 1922 (M)

headline: Can a Top Designer Overcome a Spendthrift Reputation?
abstract: No one seems to agree on the exact line in the budget where the principals of Donna Karan International Inc. will wield the knife. Perhaps it will be the trips to Africa and the Far East in search of design-inspiring objets d'art. Or the victim could be a few thousand yards of cashmere.    But the one thing on which Wall Street analysts, fashion denizens and steaming-mad investors concur: Donna Karan, the chief executive of the company that bears her name, spends too much money. And her spending has cost investors their shirts.

headline: LUCENT DEAL WITH BELL ATLANTIC WORTH UP TO $1 BILLION
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc says Bell Atlantic Corp agreed to buy as much as $1 billion of phone equipment over five years as part of lawsuit settlement; on March 13, Bell Atlantic agreed to buy more Lucent equipment in exchange for dropping suit that accused AT&T Corp, parent of Lucent, of blocking transmission of caller-identification information over its phone network (S)

headline: Facing the Rubicon, Italy's Separatists Start to Test the Water
abstract: Eight men who stormed bell tower in Venice, Italy, on May 9 in support of secession for northern Italy appear to have put into action program of region's small but boisterous separatist movement at time when it was losing ground, even among few ordinary northerners who supported it (M)

headline: To Sell Stock or Not: A Guide to the Budget Vigil
abstract: Article on major areas expected to be in tax bill, with some of issues that could arise as lawmakers strive to keep down total cost to Government; topics discussed include changes in capital gains tax, individual retirement accounts, estate taxes, tax credit for parents who have children and education provisions; graph (L)

headline: Government Issues Flat In a Light Day
abstract: US Government securities are relatively flat in light trading; 30-year bond slips 6/32, to price of 96 11/32, and yield rises to 6.92 percent, from 6.90 percent on May 16; graph (L)

headline: Royal and Sun Alliance Acquiring Italian Insurer
abstract: Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group, a British insurer, agrees to buy Prudential Corp's Vita Group, an Italian life insurer, for about $73.5 million (S)

headline: Island Tenants Triumph: They're the Lairds Now
abstract: Sixty-eight residents of beautiful Isle of Eigg, Scotland, celebrate their successful campaign to raise $2.5 million so that they can buy their island from its German landlord and guarantee their right to stay; Maggie Fyffe, secretary of new Isle of Eigg Heritage Trust, which will take over ownership on June 12, comments; photo; map (M)

headline: Early Gains In Treasuries Fail to Hold
abstract: Treasury prices are little changed, with early gains on back of strong dollar evaporating by afternoon; price of 30-year Treasury bond slips 1/32, to 94 5/32 (M)

headline: Grossman's Files For Chapter 11
abstract: Grossman's Inc, building-supply retailer, files for bankruptcy protection from its creditors; company also reaches arrangement worth up to $50 million with GDI Co, affiliate of Jeld-Wen Inc, a major Grossman's supplier (S)

headline: Stage Set for Appellate Ruling on Class-Action Suits vs. Companies
abstract: Federal District Judge Fern Smith, citing 1995 law aimed at blocking frivolous securities suits, dismisses lawsuit contending officials of Silicon Graphics defrauded investors; dismissal is expected to lead to first appellate court ruling on just how far that law goes in inhibiting class-action suits; William Lerach, partner in law firm of Milberg, Weiss, Bershad, Hynes & Lerach, which represented plaintiffs in the case, says ruling will be appealed; Bruce Vanyo, partner in law firm of Wilson, Sonsini, Goodrich & Rosati, which represented Silicon Graphics, praises ruling; ruling deals with issues raised by Private Securities Reform Act of 1995 (L)

headline: Calpers Draws A Blueprint for Its Concept of An Ideal Board
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System (Calpers) releases blueprint describing what it thinks are basic requirements for structure of corporate boards; suggests that independent directors make up majority of board, that boards appoint director to balance power of chief excecutive who is also chairman, and that directors receive only cash or stock as compensation, but no extra benefits like retirement plans; Calpers releases criteria but its own board stops short of approving list because of disagreement over two suggestions: that directors be no longer considered independent after 10 years on board, and that no more than 10 percent of board's directors be older than 70; Calpers is nation's largest and most prominent player in shareholder-rights movement, so its principles of corporate governance are certain to get attention of corporate America (M)

headline: Saudi in Alliance to Develop Planet Hollywood Restaurants
abstract: Planet Hollywood International Inc forms alliance with Prince Walid bin Talal; Saudi prince will develop 34 Planet Hollywood restaurants in 23 countries in Middle East and Europe (M)

headline: How the Senators Voted on Treaty
abstract: Roll-call in Senate's 74-26 vote approving Chemical Weapons Convention

headline: How Airplane Tanks Powered Hot Rods : AMERICAN TOPICS
abstract: A visitor to Utah's Bonneville salt flats, scene of countless land speed records, might even today see one of the stranger vestiges of World War II: odd-looking, tear-drop-shaped aluminum hot rods made of war-surplus airplane parts.

headline: Japanese Insurer Is Ordered Closed
abstract: Japan's Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka orders Nissan Mutual Life Insurance Co to halt its operations, first time Japanese life insurer has been ordered closed since World War II; Mitsuzuka says failure of company is result of poor asset management, resulting in losses on its investments; adds policyholders will be fully protected (S)

headline: Only Real Surprise on 'Ellen' Was Lineup of Advertisers
abstract: Only real surprise on 'coming out' story line for ABC-TV series Ellen was lineup of advertisers during the show; most notable was abundance of spots plugging coming motion pictures and dearth of fast-food, beverage and car advertisements, which usually fill prime time (L)

headline: On a Web tour of the world, you can skip tourist traps and sample the local flavor.
abstract: Edward Rothstein Technology column notes that nearly every country has site on World Wide Web, each with its own prejudice, perspective and style, often providing unusual image of country itself; main emphasis is on tourism, business and trade, and scientific research; photo (M)

headline: Nine West Faces Problems on Two Fronts
abstract: Market Place column on Nine West Group's accounting problems that has resulted in Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry and its investor relations problem with several institutional investors and securities lawyers (L)

headline: A Family Feuds In Texas Over 2 Trust Funds
abstract: Several family members have challenged Harold C Simmons's command of billion-dollar fortune he has amassed as corporate raider and executive; in court filing in Dallas, Tex, last month, Simmons's daughters Scheryle S Patigian and Andrea Swanson said trusts that Simmons set up for them have been used for his personal gain; they also say that Simmons, one of nation's largest Republican donors, pressured them into making what Patigian calls 'illegitimate and illegal' campaign contributions from the trusts; in court documents, Simmons has denied his family's accustions; Simmons achieved notoriety in 1980's for takeover raids on corporations, including NL Industries, Valhi Inc, Keystone Consolidated Industries and Tremont Corp; Simmons is head of Contran Corp; photo (L)

headline: The Internet as Commerce: Who Pays, Under What Rules?
abstract: Analysis: Internet is becoming mainstream medium of communications and commerce, raising questions about who will determine commercial rules of the road on global web of computer networks; current disputes are about assigning 'domain names,' or suffixes like '.com' in Internet addresses, and 'peering,' in which Internet service companies exchange electronic-mail messages with each other free; there are also host of thorny business and public policy issues lying ahead; two trends appear inevitable: Federal Government will become increasingly involved in affairs of Internet, and there will be shakeout in business of supplying Internet access, with big, well-financed corporations more and more supplying businesses and households with links to Internet (M)

headline: Higher Price Cements Samsung's Deal With AST
abstract: Samsung Electronics Co agrees to acquire 51 percent of AST Research Inc that it does not already own for about $170 million (M)

headline: Pharmacia Moves 2 New Brands
abstract: Accounts of two pharmaceutical brands being acquired by Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc from units of Johnson & Johnson have been awarded to W B Doner & Co; Doner is named to handle Micatin line of antifungal products, which had been handled by McCann-Erickson Worldwide; Doner is awarded Pediacare line of cough and cold products, which had been handled by Susan Spindler Advertising (S)

headline: Airline to Pay $1.4 Billion For 67 Jets
abstract: American Eagle, American Airlines affiliate, will buy 42 regional jets from Embraer of Brazil and 25 from Bombardier Inc of Canada in contracts valued at $1.4 billion; order is biggest at Paris Air Show, trade event usually dominated by makers of large jets; shows strength of market for smaller regional jets, with 50 to 70 seats (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Japanese stocks trade lower in Japan on June 20; Nikkei index closes down 122.31 points at 20,385.54 (S)

headline: Scripps to Buy Harte-Hanks Media Assets
abstract: E W Scripps Co agrees to acquire newspaper and broadcasting properties of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc for between $605 million and $775 million; deal involves six Texas newspapers--The Corpus Christi Caller-Times, The Abilene Reporter-News, The Wichita Falls Times Record News, The San Angelo Standard-Times, The Plano Star Courier and Anderson Independent-Mail in South Carolina--along with television stations KENS-TV and radio station KENS-AM, both in San Antonio, Tex (L)

headline: Iraqis Laugh Again and Lather Up
abstract: Rations received by the people of Baghdad this month, more than five months after Iraqi oil began to flow again under United Nations supervision, were more bountiful than at any time since the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991; however, the oil-for-food plan that has begun to sweeten life will expire on June 9, and it is not clear whether it will be renewed; map; photo (Baghdad Journal) (M)

headline: Governor Weld Asked to Take Mexican Post
abstract: White House confirms Pres Clinton has offered post of Ambassador to Mexico to Massachusetts Gov William Weld, Republican; Weld tells reporters at annual White House correspondents' dinner he will accept job (S)

headline: German Bank Merger Is Under Consideration
abstract: Bankgesellschaft Berlin A.G. said yesterday that it had begun talks to acquire Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, which could lead to the creation of one of Germany's biggest banks. The banks' combined assets at the end of last year were 567 billion marks ($332 billion), about two-thirds the size of Deutsche Bank, Europe's largest bank.

headline: ING Is Negotiating to Buy Remainder of Dillon, Read
abstract: ING Group NV, Dutch financial services giant, is in talks to acquire 75 percent of Dillon, Read & Co it does not already own, as yet another venerable Wall Street firm becomes a target for foreign and domestic banks (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.70   5.28        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.06   5.08   4.99        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.29   5.33   5.10        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.59   3.61   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.73   6.74   6.84        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Monitor Radio Operation to End
abstract: Church of Christ, Scientist has put most of its broadcast operations up for sale and will end Monitor Radio, its money-losing news and public affairs broadcast arm, this summer (S)

headline: Palestinian Held by U.S. Now Faces Legal Limbo
abstract: Israeli decision to suspend bid for extradition of alleged terrorist Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, puts Hamas leader in legal limbo in United States; Federal court is expected to return him to custody of Immigration and Naturalization Service, which detained him at New York airport in July 1995 and must now weigh whether to deport him as terrorist and where to send him (M)

headline: Inflation Data Help to Lift Bond Prices
abstract: Prices for US Treasury securities rebound from early losses; price of 30-year bond rises 8/32, to 94 16/32; yield falls to 7.07 percent, from 7.09 percent on March 31; graph (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DOW CHEMICAL CO., Midland, Mich., said its polyurethane unit, Dow Polyurethanes, had agreed to buy Eastman Chemical Co.'s thanol polyols business for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Israeli Premier Survives Vote Of Confidence In Parliament
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu survives no-confidence vote in Parliament; he postpones plans to announce reshuffled Cabinet when Ariel Sharon, who was to take over powerful Finance Ministry, demands that he retain key parts of his current portfolio and be included in shaping strategy for negotiating with Palestinians (M)

headline: In a Modest Nod to Peace, Croats Reopen Bosnia Bridge
abstract: As Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright presided, the Government of Croatia reopened a bridge linking its territory to the northern Bosnian town of Brcko today, an important, if largely symbolic, step to comply with the 1995 Dayton peace accords.    The reopening of the bridge, which spans the Sava River at the site of some of the war's most intense fighting, came as Ms. Albright took a whirlwind tour through Bosnia today that included two stops in the Bosnian Serb republic, the Serbian enclave within Bosnia.

headline: Product Shift Is Credited as Earnings Rise 14% at Xerox
abstract: Xerox Corp says earnings rose 14 percent in first quarter; net income increased to $270 million from $237 million in year-earlier period; revenue grew 2.3 percent, to $4.02 billion from $3.93 billion; table (M)

headline: Iraq Plans Flights to Saudi Border Despite Ban
abstract: Iraq, in new sign of defiance, says it will send helicopters to Saudi border to pick up returning Muslim pilgrims from Mecca, despite ban on flights in area; seems intent on exposing reluctance of world powers to enforce harsh restrictions imposed in days leading up to Persian Gulf War in 1991; its defiance of ban on April 9, when it sent planeload of pilgrim to Saudi Arabia, noted; US, which enforces ban with allies, has urged Iraq to reconsider; says its warplanes will not shoot down civilian helicopters (M)

headline: How Peruvian Hostage Crisis Became Trip Into the Surreal
abstract: Special report, 126 Days, recounts ordeal of hostages who were held for four months at Japanese embassy residence in Lima by Tupac Amaru guerrillas; saga began last December 17, as several hundred prominent Peruvians and foreigners gathered for annual birthday celebration for Emperor Akihito; 14 masked men and women, led by Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, blasted their way into compound; scores of prisoners were released gradually over next few weeks and sporadic talks took place; photos; ordeal ended when Pres Alberto Fujimori ordered commando assault; one hostage and two soldiers were killed, along with all 14 guerrillas (L)

headline: Zairian Rebel And His Plan Puzzle West
abstract: Victorious Zairian rebel leader Laurent Kabila was, until start of rebel drive to oust Pres Mobutu Sese Seko seven months ago, obscure leader with history of starting Quixotic Marxist revolts that fell apart; he names himself new President of country, renamed Democratic Republic of the Congo, in initial declaration, but makes no mention of plans to hold elections; leaves unanswered question of how he will structure government, or whether any opposition politicians will play role; he urges residents of capital of Kinshasa to remain calm; says troops will not tolerate acts of vengeance against officials of former government; orders government employees to remain at posts and await further instructions (M)

headline: Fugitive Mexican Prosecutor Is Arrested in Spain
abstract: Authorities in Spain arrest Pablo Chapa Bezanilla, former top prosecutor in Mexico who disappeared after he was dismissed last December amid charges of evidence tampering; Mexico will seek extradition; Chapa is charged with conspiring to plant body on ranch belonging to Raul Salinas de Gortari, former President's brother, to frame him for in political assassinations in 1994 (S)

headline: Starts of Housing Up 2.6%, But Key Category Is Weak
abstract: Construction of single-family houses was weak last month, providing another sign of economic slowing; another survey finds that consumer confidence remains strong; Commerce Dept reports that housing starts over all rose 2.6 percent inn April, to annual rate of 1,473 million; graph (M)

headline: Russia and NATO: No Accord Yet on Military Goal
abstract: Senior US and NATO officials warn that difficult military issues concerning Russia are still unresolved and could delay signing of agreement, despite Pres Boris Yeltsin's optimistic statement; even name of document is uncertain, with Russian wanting more fundamental word than 'charter'; main outstanding issues revolve around Russia's effort to limit NATO forces on soil of new members, while NATO alllies do not want to create second-class members (S)

headline: Disney Sights Set On Japan Project
abstract: Walt Disney Co is negotiating to buy stake in Japan Sky Broadcasting Co, satellite broadcaster owned by News Corp, which is headed by Rupert Murdoch, and Softbank Corp of Japan (S)

headline: WACHOVIA TO BUY VIRGINIA BANK FOR $542 MILLION
abstract: Wachovia Corp, making its long-awaited expansion into Virginia, agrees to acquire Jefferson Bankshares Inc for $542 million in stock (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMF Group Inc says its American Bowling Centers unit has completed its acquisition of American Recreation Centers Inc for about $70 million (S)

headline: Fabege Shares Soar On Takeover Offer
abstract: Fabege AB's shares soar after it receives cash takeover offer of $286 million from Naeckebro AB (S)

headline: Turkish Generals Raise Pressure on Premier
abstract: Turkey's military leaders step up their pressure on Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan's Islamic Government; Gen Fevzi Turkeri, chief of military intelligence, says political Islam is working closely with Iran and other Islamic countries against Turkey (M)

headline: EXPONENTIAL SAYS DEFECT TO DELAY CHIP PRODUCTION
abstract: Exponential Technology Inc, closely held computer chip maker partly owned by Apple Computer Inc and UMAX Data Systems, says design defect will delay production of its highest-speed chips; company had planned to ship the chips in July (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: MORGAN GRENFELL CAPITAL MANAGEMENT, New York, named Joan Binstock executive vice president, and to the newly created position of chief operating officer.    FOX BROADCASTING CO., Beverly Hills, Calif., a unit of the News Corporation, named Stephen Weinheimer  senior vice president of promotion production. He will report to George Greenberg, executive vice president for marketing.    MTV NETWORKS, New York, a unit of Viacom Inc., named Matt Farber senior vice president for program enterprises; he will also be the general manager of M2, a new 24-hour music network from MTV.

headline: SBC Planning Charges Up to $2.3 Billion
abstract: SBC Communications Inc says it will take charges of up to $2.3 billion in connection with its acquisition of Pacific Telesis Group; merger is first between two regional Bell operating companies and will create second-largest United States phone company behind AT&T Corp (M)

headline: TWO HIGH-LEVEL EXECUTIVES RESIGN AT SILICON GRAPHICS
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc says its chief financial officer, Stanley J Meresman, and Michael Ramsey, senior vice president, have resigned as company restructures; William Kelly will take over Meresman's duties until replacement is found; David Orton will assume Ramsey's duties (S)

headline: Award Puffs Up Magazines' Profiles but Not Their Ad Sales
abstract: National Magazine Awards Ellies, most highly coveted honors in prize-strewn magazine business, are craved by editors, ignored by general public and dismissed by advertisers; prizes, administered by American Society of Magazine Editors, seek to spur quality in reporting, design and other areas; yield remarkably few benefits, commercial or otherwise; photo; graph; table (M)

headline: India and Pakistan Plan Kashmir Talks
abstract: India and Pakistan pledge new effort to reconciole diffreences over disputed territory of Kashmir, issue that more than any other has made enemies of both countries for past 50 years; Foreign Secretaries of both countries, following three days of talks in Islamabad, will make Kashmir issue for separate discussions within broader negotiations aimed achieving detente; photo (M)

headline: Fed Official's Speech Raises Anxiety as Bond Prices Fall
abstract: Prices of US Government securities decline; 30-year bond falls 17/32, to price of 93 27/32; yield rises to 7.13 percent, from 7.08 percent on April 23; graphs (L)

headline: Agencies Win Best of Show
abstract: Best of Show honors are awarded at 30th annual American Advertising Awards ceremony to Wieden & Kennedy in television category, and to Hunt Adkins in print category; awards are sponsored by American Advertising Federation (S)

headline: Gains Posted By Treasuries As Fed Buys
abstract: Treasury securities prices rise; 30-year bond rises 13/32, to 99 8/32, to yield 6.68 percent; graph (M)

headline: WITH MOBUTU OUT, ZAIRE REBEL CHIEF CLAIMS PRESIDENCY
abstract: Victorious rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, declares himself President of Democratic Republic of the Congo, formerly Zaire, as his forces enter capital of Kinshasa; suspends Zairian Constitution; pledges to form national salvation Government within three days, and create constituent assembly within two months; crowds on streets of capital mob rebel troops in celebration; their arrival in Kinshasa is marked by confusion and infighting among remaining elements of Zairian Army; Gen Mahele Lioko, Defense Minister, is assassinated by member of own force during efforts to ease rebels' entry into capital; Prime Minister, Gen Likulia Bolongo, seeks protection in French Embassy, as other Government officials flee across Congo River; Mobutu and family reportedly arrive in Rabat, Morocco; photos; map (M)

headline: A Go-Between Helps Muslims and Christians Interpret One Another
abstract: Interview with Murad Hofmann, former German Ambassador who converted to Islam from Roman Catholicism 17 years ago and who has taken up new calling of trying to explain Christians and Muslims to each other; lives in Istanbul, Turkey, but travels far afield; says he is trying to build bridges between communities (M)

headline: Founding Fathers, With Different Spirits of Independence
abstract: Off the Shelf review of corporate autobiographies Ben & Jerry's Double-Dip: Lead With Your Values and Make Money, Too, by Ben Cohen & Jerry Greenfield, and Bloomberg by Bloomberg by Mike Bloomberg with Matthew Winkler; cover photos (S)

headline: Stock Prices Set Records For 4th Straight Session
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs 36.56 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to record high of 7,575.83; Standard & Poor's 500 Index rises 4.30, to 869.57, its 24th record this year; Nasdaq composite index rises 6.16 points to 1,407.85; table (L)

headline: Past as Prologue: Blair Faults Britain in Irish Potato Blight
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair expresses regret over Britain's role in potato famine that devastated Ireland in mid-19th century, but stops short of making full apology; speaks, in letter to organizers of event commemmorating famine's 150th anniversary, of deep scars caused by famine that left 1.5 million dead of starvation or famine-related disease; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Prices for Wheat Slip Again As Rain Aids European Crop
abstract: Wheat prices fall for third time in four trading sessions as rains replenish dry wheat fields in Europe, easing concern that drought will damage crops there (M)û

headline: Irish President Favored for U.N. Rights Post
abstract: Pres Mary Robinson of Ireland is leading candidate for position of United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (S)

headline: ITT Industries Names Doremus
abstract: ITT Industries names Doremus & Co as first advertising agency to handle corporate communications; billings estimated at $10 million to $12 million (S)

headline: Daiwa and Nikko Both Post Losses
abstract: Daiwa Securities Co and Nikko Securities Co of Japan both post net losses for fiscal year ending March 31 as result of providing aid to financially troubled affiliated companies; Daiwa reports that its parent company loss totaled 84.02 billion yen ($666 million) in fiscal year; Nikko reports net loss for parent company of 113.6 billion yen ($902 million) (S)

headline: CIENA SHARES HIT A 52-WEEK HIGH AS NET CLIMBS
abstract: Shares of Ciena Corp hit 52-week high after company, telecommunications equipment concern, reports second-quarter earnings that exceed expectations; reports pro-forma earnings of $27.6 million, or 26 cents a share, on revenue of $86.7 million, compared with loss of $2.7 million, or 3 cents a share, on no revenue in year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: Dow Jones Forms Alliance With Microsoft
abstract: Dow Jones & Co forms technology and marketing alliance with Microsoft Corp as part of its effort to revive Telerate, its faltering financial data division that was recently named Dow Jones Markets; under agreement, Dow Jones will use Microsoft's operating systems, data base programs and other software to create system that will allow its customers to trade, exchange messages and view historical and up-to-the-minute financial information on personal computers (M)

headline: Albright Outlines Moves to 'Renew Momentum' in Bosnia
abstract: Sec Madeleine Albright reiterates that US remains deeply committed to establishing stable, multi-ethnic state in Bosnia; remarks before Congress and at The New York Times call on all sides to keep promises made in Dayton peace accords (S)

headline: In Japan's Rebound, Exporters May Be the Stars
abstract: American investors would take close look at some of Japan's corporate giants, particularly the exporters; at home in Japan, these companies operate in an economy that is finally looking up after seven-year recession; for dollar-based investors, the yen makes exporters look particularly attractive; Japan's economy is strengthening but yen's relative weakness makes country's exports low-priced; prospects for Japanese exporters, Sony Corp, Ito-Yokado Co, Canon Inc and Fuji Photo Film Co, discussed; table; photo (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Average Up for Week, Bolstered by Bond Rally  Stocks ended a seesaw week on the up side, as a rally in bonds lifted bank shares and a sharp drop in the dollar bolstered exporters.

headline: Offering by Hartford Life
abstract: Hartford Life Inc sells 23 million common shares for $28.25 apiece, or $649 million, in an initial public offering of stock (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Avnet  BRE Pptys    TUESDAY   Century Tel Ent  Dames & Moore  Enova  Firstbank P R  Inland Stl Inds  Ipalco Enterprises  Unicom  Westvaco

headline: India Coalition Picks a Premier To End Crisis
abstract: India's coalition Government names Foreign Min Inder K Gujral as prime minister, ending three weeks of political turmoil; Gujral, 77, is surprise choice; sets cleaning up political corruption, easing Hindu-Muslim strains and attacking poverty as priorities; downfall of Prime Min H D Deve Gowda reviewed; photo (M)

headline: Radio Stations Are Sold
abstract: Evergreen Media Corp agrees to sell three radio stations to Douglas Broadcasting/Personal Achievement Radio for $18 million; Evergreen is selling WZHF-AM and WBZS-AM in Washington and KDFC-AM in San Francisco; sale is part of Evergreen's divestiture of eight stations, move required for its planned acquisition of Chancellor Broadcasting Corp and 10 radio stations from Viacom Inc (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   How to play foreign stocks without a broker -- or a broker's fees. By Carol Marie Cropper.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6/   Many funds charge for active management yet deliver index-like returns from being spread so thin. Not Oakmark Select, a smart-looking newcomer that sticks with just a few good ideas. By Virginia Munger Kahn.    SPENDING IT /Page 8/   Cancer insurance, not allowed in some places, is getting a boost from deregulation. But consumer groups say you may well be better off without the coverage. By Carol Marie Cropper.    VOICES /Page 12/   The ticking time bomb lurking in A.T.M. cards. By Richard E. Anderson.

headline: Stocks Decline Then Rebound in Tokyo
abstract: Japan's Nikkei stock average falls as much as 1.76 percent before closing down 133.81 points from March 31, at 17,869.59, or down 0.74 percent on Tuesday, April 1 (S)

headline: Computer Associates Presents Dilbert
abstract: Popular comic strip Dilbert is being featured in advertisements running in Wall Street Journal; Computer Associates International Inc is using comic, created by Scott Adams, with its portrayals of innocent employees caught between dimwitted superiors and malicious human-resource managers; ads feature comics that are high-technology oriented (S)

headline: AMR's First-Quarter Profits Are Better Than Expected
abstract: AMR Corp, parent of American Airlines, earned $152 million in its first quarter, down 3 percent from $157 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose almost 3 percent, to $4.43 billion from $4.31 billion; results easily surpass Wall Street expectations (M)

headline: CABLETRON IS ACQUIRING A STAKE IN IPSILON NETWORKS
abstract: Cabletron Systems Inc, computer networking company, is paying $20 million for unspecified stake in closely held Ipsilon Networks Inc, a start-up company in that business (S)

headline: New Horizons in Ecuador, but Paralysis Sets In Early
abstract: New government of interim Ecuadorean Pres Fabian Alarcon appears paralyzed; has not put together economic plan, merely slowing former Pres Abdala Bucaram's unpopular program; Alarcon, former Congress president, has essentially led Congressional takeover of presidency, extending to executive branch Congress's own fragmentation and weakness; critics charge he does little beyond maneuvering to extend his term; Congress, which presented self as crusading agent of popular will, is increasingly implicated in corruption scandals involving Bucaram (M)

headline: VOTERS IN FRANCE, REBUFFING CHIRAC, SWING TO THE LEFT
abstract: French vote heavily for leftist opposition and protest parties, in stinging rebuff to Pres Jacques Chirac's call to renew huge conservative majority in legislature for five more years; Chirac called vote year early to try to win mandate for deficit-cutting policies he says are necessary for France to join common European currency in 1999; but national outpouring of protest has been so powerful that there is chance of Socialist-led leftist majority in Parliament; Prime Min Alain Juppe, who is deeply unpopular, urges supporters to mobilize this week to turn result around in runoff; photos (M)

headline: ADVANTA TO STOP OFFERING SPECIAL CREDIT CARD
abstract: Advanta Corp agrees to stop marketing credit card that gave customers rewards in American Express Co program after settling lawsuits with Visa USA and Mastercard International (S)

headline: Tokyo House Passes Bill Bolstering U.S. Bases
abstract: Lower house of Japanese parliament overwhelmingly approves bill to allow Japan to continue providing land for US bases, which would put bases on stronger legal footing; officials hope passage will set good tone for Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto's visit to Washington; Okinawan landowners are refusing to renew leases, but Government may now be able to seize land used for bases (S)

headline: On This Flight, the Cargo Wore Sandals and Shorts
abstract: David J Morrow article on his experiences as passenger testing out UPS Airlines's new charter service, which uses cargo planes converted into passenger jets on weekends; drawing (M)

headline: Whitbread to Sell 13 Hotels to Regal
abstract: Whitbread PLC will sell 13 hotels to Regal Hotel Group for 64.5 million pounds ($104.8 million) (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: THE BUDGET  We Did It! The Sun's Up!  One can easily imagine today's politicians working through the night, brows furrowed amid clacking fax machines, searching for a way to make the sun rise. When the sun burst upon the scene, there they'd be, cheering and slapping backs. Last week, sure enough, White House and Congressional negotiators trumpeted that they'd solved a ''problem'' that many economists deny is even a problem -- the Federal deficit. The fine points are still being worked out, but there'll be trims in Social Security increases and some tax cuts. More to the point, though, the Federal budget -- while all this fuss was going on -- was moving quietly toward balancing itself, courtesy of a mighty economy.     STOCK MARKET  A 'Correction' Corrected  A few weeks ago, the stock market seemed headed for its long-awaited collapse. It was just taking a little breather, though -- or ''correction,'' in the standard euphemism. On Tuesday, in the latest surge, the Dow leaped 179 points, and the next day it ventured above 7,000 again. Even when word came out on Friday that unemployment had sunk to 4.9 percent -- a 23-year low -- the market kept barreling ahead. Wall Street, you see, doesn't like the job picture to be too good: maintaining the right economic balance is deemed more important than shorter unemployment lines. But there were fewer-than-expected jobs added, so -- by the Wall Street formula -- all was well.     CANAL STREET  Suez Bargains! Today Only!  Look at a globe. When the world's land masses paused in their migratory dance, they left a convoluted inkblot indeed for travelers by sea. Some journeys were straight shots, while others -- from, say, the Red Sea to the Mediterranean -- were maddeningly circuitous. But humanity outwitted the mischievous gods of plate tectonics by building the great canals -- first the Suez, then the Panama. Problem solved, it seemed -- and a solution that left those who run the canals with the ultimate monopolies. But a round-trip ticket through the Suez Canal can run more than $500,000, and it's not even deep enough for some of today's mammoth tankers. So ships are finding alternatives, like sending oil through a pipeline or even taking the long way around to beat the toll. While 22,500 ships passed through the canal in 1982, only 15,000 did so in 1996 -- the fewest in two decades. So, yes, the mighty Suez Canal has joined the discounting craze, slashing prices and offering special deals.     AIR TRAVEL  Enter the Frequent Complainer  A mere instant ago, geologically speaking, it took months to traverse this great nation. Now, astoundingly, you can be transported within hours, sipping a drink and watching a movie all the while. But does humankind cry out its undying gratitude for the miracle of flight? You've got to be kidding. Today's air travelers are so spoiled that the slightest delay or irritant might set them off. One passenger, denied an extra sandwich, punched a flight attendant. Another, asked to wait at the gate, punched a pilot. They curse, they spit, they hurl food trays or suitcases. Passenger behavior, in fact, has become so disruptive that last week the Air Line Pilots Association organized a meeting in Washington, called the International Conference on Disruptive Airline Passengers, to figure out what to do. (Some ideas: more oxygen, less liquor.)    PROMOTIONS  A Rebel's Unlikely Cause  When it comes to marketing icons, there's an unmistakable difference between being dead and being alive. Suppose, for instance, that Fidel Castro had died a fiery rebel's death a generation ago. Today, instead of seeing him as an unending threat to our cozy capitalist existence, we might have Fidel toothpaste, Fidel baseball bats, and, of course, Fidel cigars. If you doubt it, consider Mr. Castro's pal Che Guevara: he's long dead -- for precisely 30 years, in fact, long enough to become a nice, safe, romantic myth. Long enough, in fact, to become a brand name: in a ski promotion, on a CD jacket, on a limited-edition Swatch watch, not to mention five biographies and six movies. And the site of his execution in Bolivia is a tourist spot. A rebel with a strange cause indeed.     MAYORAL ECONOMICS  Staten Island, on the House  Normally, death and taxes can count on some company: rising prices. The best things may stay free, but everything else goes up and up and up. Except, for some reason, the Staten Island Ferry. It costs all of 50 cents to ride now -- rock-bottom cheap when you think of it. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani decided that even that was too much, and starting on July 4, the ride's free. The move coincides with the end of the extra fare for transferring from bus to subway, and the Mayor says it all fits his goal of not penalizing the outer boroughs -- Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx as well as Staten Island. But he possibly also recalled that he has a lot of political support at the south end of that ferry ride.    5TH AND 57TH  Center of a Certain World  Fifth Avenue retailers, especially those near 57th Street, often act as if they're at the center of the world. Do you want to gaze at $1,500 dress shirts? You have an appointment, naturally. How much is that trinket at Tiffany's? Uh, well, never mind. But it's not an illusion. In a sense, this is the center of the world -- in the real estate sense. For the third consecutive year, according to a recent survey, the stretch of Fifth from 49th to 57th ranked as the world's richest retail strip, with annual rents averaging $575 a square foot. You want to open a modest little 30-by-40 shop? It'll cost you nearly $2,000 -- every single day. And second place? Not far -- just around the corner, on 57th. And fourth? Around the next corner, on Madison Avenue. Only Tokyo's Ginza district, in third place, joined this elite Manhattan crowd.    PUBLIC SAFETY  Clamping Down on Brookhaven  A nonprofit organization called Associated Universities was planning a series of events to mark the anniversary of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, which it operated for all of its 50 years. If there's a party, though, the group will miss it. Last week, the Energy Department, the lab's owner, dismissed the organization, saying it had consistently put research ahead of environmental safety. That's hard to argue with, considering the radioactive tritium that has reportedly contaminated the groundwater for miles around. There will be no trade-off between research and public health, Energy Secretary Federico F. Pena vowed. ''Confusion and mismanagement'' at the lab, he said, ''is unacceptable, inexcusable and flat-out wrong.''     BROKERAGE FIRMS  What, Indeed, Is in a Name?  Would you buy a used stock from a firm called Kennedy, Mathews, Landis, Healy & Pecora? Of course you would. The name reeks of respectability. One can almost see the ornately framed turn-of-the-century portraits staring down reassuringly from walnut-paneled walls. But again, alas, things are not what they seem. Those names weren't exactly pulled from thin air -- they were the five original S.E.C. commissioners. But none of them had the slightest connection with the firm. And if you did buy stock from the firm, you might have regretted it. Kennedy, Mathews, which specialized in penny stocks, faced various disciplinary actions, neglected to pay its fines, and last week was officially expelled by Nasdaq.

headline: Mega-Merger In Italy Dies As Marzotto Withdraws
abstract: ROME—  In a development that could mark a shift in Italian capitalism and the erosion of power of Italy's leading financial player, the Marzotto clothing group has abruptly pulled out of a merger that would have created a $5 billion-a-year European fashion powerhouse.

headline: F.C.C. Phone Plan to Hurt, Businesses Say
abstract: Some business telephone companies say they could come out as big losers as Federal Communications Commission puts finishing touches on sweeping plan to deregulate telephone industry; under terms of plan circulating at FCC, businesses would be charged additional $1 to $2 a month in flat monthly charges for each phone line, over $6 a line they pay now; long-distance carriers would be charged flat rate of up to $4.50 for each business line by local phone companies (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Dana L. Fields, vice president and group publisher for Rolling Stone and US magazines, New York, owned by Wenner Media Inc., was named to the new post of group publisher for all Wenner Media titles, assuming added responsibility for Men's Journal magazine. Kevin C. O'Malley, vice president and associate publisher at Rolling Stone, was named publisher of Men's Journal, succeeding Mark E. MacDonald, who left. Jeffrey S. Ahl, advertising director at Rolling Stone, succeeds Mr. O'Malley as associate publisher; Jack Rotherham, Eastern advertising director, succeeds Mr. Ahl as advertising director.

headline: Chief of United Paramount Network Is Quitting
abstract: Lucie Salhany, chief executive of United Paramount Network, has decided not to renew her contract this fall as head of fledgling television network; Salhany says she will remain at her post until replacement is found and will be involved in setting network's schedule (M)

headline: MEDIATOR APPOINTED TO HELP BARNEY'S SORT OUT FUTURE
abstract: A mediator was appointed yesterday to help Barney's Inc. attract an investor and resolve its dispute with its former partner, the Isetan Company. Judge James L. Garrity Jr. of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan appointed Raymond L. Shapiro as the mediator after denying Barney's request on Friday to offer a potential bidder $10 million in breakup fees and expenses. A breakup fee is given when a party makes an offer that is accepted but then is later outbid. Mr. Shapiro will try to help Barney's, which operates 13 specialty stores, secure an acceptable investment bid and resolve its rent dispute with Isetan, a Japanese retailer that financed Barney's three biggest stores.

headline: In Indonesia, Megawati Warns of Poor's 'Rage'
abstract: JAKARTA—  Excluded by the government from Indonesia's legislative elections scheduled for Thursday, Megawati Sukarnoputri spends much of her time in a suburban house with a large tropical garden where caged doves coo contentedly.

headline: European Merger Runs Aground
abstract: Framatome, French nuclear reactor maker, says planned merger with GEC Alsthom is unlikely to succeed; merger fails after General Electric of Britain refuses to accept French Government's condition that it hold less than 50 percent of new company (S)

headline: Sales at Penney Declined 3.7%
abstract: J C Penney Co says sales at its stores open at least a year fell 3.7 percent in March; total sales for five weeks ended on April 5 rose 36.5 percent, to $2.54 billion, from $1.86 billion in same period last year (S)

headline: Simpler, Maybe, But Is It Useful?
abstract: Letter by Gerald Shirley on April 13 article by Peter Schuck and Ian Ayres on car buying made simpler (S)é

headline: Technology Stocks Surge, But Others Sag
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average loses 20.87 points to close at 6,812.72; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks loses 0.97 point, to 773.64; Nasdaq composite index gains 14.40 points, or 1.19 percent, to 1,227.14; table (L)

headline: HEXCEL TO ACQUIRE U.S. OPERATIONS OF FIBERITE
abstract: Hexcel Corp agrees to acquire most of US operations of Fiberite Inc for about $300 million (S)

headline: Pakistan Acts To Cut Power Of President
abstract: Pakistani Prime Min Nawaz Sharif wins parliamentary approval to eliminate power of country's appointed President to dismiss elected governments and to appoint armed forces chiefs; says repeal of presidential powers has been approved by Pres Farooq Leghari (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about the growth of the Cablevision Systems Corporation misstated the ITT Corporation's profit on the sale of its 50 percent stake in Madison Square Garden to Cablevision. It was $290 million, not $125 million.

headline: Nigerians Fire on Rebels Who Seized Sierra Leone
abstract: West African force led by Nigeria goes on offensive to put down eight-day-old military coup in Sierra Leone, sending ships, planes and troops into action against rebel targets in capital of Freetown; map (M)

headline: Glaxo Shares Climb On News of Drug Trials
abstract: Glaxo Wellcome PLC's shares climb after it reports 'extremely encouraging' results from tests of new hepatitis B drug that analysts say could generate annual sales of $486 million (S)ï

headline: Ellis Benjamin Gardner Jr., 77; Helped Update U.S. Shipbuilding
abstract: Ellis Benjamin Gardner Jr, retired transportation executive who helped modernize American shipbuilding in 1960's, dies at age 77 (M)

headline: Spanish Martyr Is First Gypsy Beatified by Catholic Church
abstract: Pope John Paul II beatifies Ceferino Jimenez Malla, illiterate Spanish horse-trader, who was executed by firing squad during Spanish Civil War, making him first Gypsy ever beatified by Church; beatifies four others, including Marian Encarnacion Rosal, 19th-century Guatemalan nun, Revs Enrico Rebuschini and Gaetano Catanose, Italian priests, and Florentino Asensio Barroso, Italian Bishop; photos (M)

headline: American Trade Deficit Decreased 18% in February
abstract: Commerce Department says US trade deficit narrowed by 18 percent in February, though not as much as expected, as both exports and imports rose to new peaks; trade gap declined to $10.4 billion in February from $12.7 billion in January; economists expected deficit to fall to $10.1 billion; $10.4 billion figure is provided only after Commerce Department says it made mistake in reporting trade deficit in the morning; it was first given as $11.6 billion, but figure was discovered to have been overstated by $1.2 billion because of miscount of oil imports; though deficit with China shrank to $3.4 billion from $3.7 billion, it is running 37 percent higher so far this year; deficit with Japan, largely unchanged at $4.3 billion, is still 11 percent above level a year earlier (L)

headline: BBDO Wins Ad Age Awards
abstract: BBDO Worldwide wins most awards in 1996 persentation of Best Awards for advertising excellence sponsored by Advertising Age (S)

headline: Settlement Set In Futures Case
abstract: Merrill Lynch Futures Inc, Mitsubishi Corp and Country Hedging, St Paul, Minn, brokerage firm are fined total of $415,000 to settle Government charges that they engaged in illegal sales on wheat futures contracts (S)

headline: Japanese Take Back Mansion, Ending Hostage Saga
abstract: Peru Pres Alberto Fujimori turns over burned-out residence of Japanese Ambassador to Japanese Foreign Min Yukihiko Ikeda, formally ending long hostage ordeal; denies that Tupac Amaru guerrillas were executed during commando rescue of hostages; Amb Morihisha Aoki appears in wheelchair, weak from weight loss during long captivity (S)

headline: U.S. BEER MAKER RAISES STAKE IN MEXICAN BREWER
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies raises its stake in Mexican beer brewer Grupo Modelo SA to a controlling 50.2 percent, buying another 13.25 percent of company for $550 million (S)
