headline: As Red River Crests, Manitoba Holds Its Breath
abstract: Winnipeg, Manitoba, and surrounding towns brace for flooding from Red River as it flows north, after devastating Grand Forks, North Dakota; 24,000 Canadians have had to leave homes; permanent ring dikes built around towns like Emerson, on North Dakota border, have kept communities dry, albeit isolated; photo; map (S)

headline: 163 Workers Let Go After Loss at Casino
abstract: Casino Magic Corp dismisses 163 people at its recently opened casino in Bossier City, La, after posting $700,000 loss in first quarter (S)

headline: Guatemala Digs Up Army's Secret Cemeteries
abstract: Archeologists and anthropologists unearth remains of victims of Guatemala's civil war in secret Army cemetery; scientists working in San Andres Sajcabaja are excavating a well from which 35 skeletons, some still enveloped in remnants of shirts or blue jeans, have already been recovered; more than 100,000 people were killed during 36-year conflict in Guatemala, which ended with signing of United Nations-sponsored peace last December; another 40,000 disappeared and are presumed dead; there are reportedly many clandestine Army cemeteries across country; findings reviewed; photos (L)

headline: Internet Changing How Research Centers Work
abstract: Experts in fields as diverse as politics, economics, the environment, law and business are choosing Internet as most efficient forum for policy research; Internet gives everyone opportunity to contribute their thoughts without leaving their desks; long-distance collaboration has been organic part of Internet since it began in academic and Government circles in 1980's, but now it is being used as tool for research centers to reorganize policy discussions, build agreements among specialists and reach out for new voices and new perspectives; drawing (M)

headline: CABLEVISION SYSTEMS PLANNING TO SELL MAINE UNITS
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp says it will sell its cable television systems in Maine for about $78 million in cash as part of its strategy to focus on certain geographic areas and reduce debt; reaches agreement with Frontiervision Partners LP for sale of systems in Bangor and Lewiston (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: OLSTEN CORP.,  Melville, N.Y., said it had acquired 70 percent of Sogica S.A. of Paris., to expand into the temporary-employment markets in France and Spain.     JUST FOR FEET INC.,  Pelham, Ala., a sports store operator, acquired Imperial Sports. of Flint, Mich., a sneaker and apparel retailer, for $25 million in cash and stock, and the assumption of about $9 million in debt.     NORANDA FOREST INC.,  Toronto, a forest products company, sold its paper mill in Thorold, Ontario, to Gallaher Thorold Paper Co. for undisclosed terms.     TIFFANY & CO. New York, the jeweler and specialty retailer, increased its quarterly cash dividend to 7 cents a share from 5 cents, payable July 10 to shareholders of record on June 20.

headline: Boeing Profit Climbs, but Stock Falls
abstract: Boeing Co says first-quarter earnings more than tripled from year ago, but results fall short of investors' expectations and prompts 6.5 percent drop in Boeing shares; Boeing earned $377 million, up from $119 million in quarter a year earlier; sales jumped 70 percent, to $7.3 billion, from $4.3 billion a year earlier; Boeing shares close at $95.375, down $6.625; table (L)

headline: In Denver for Economic Talks, Clinton Calls for Freer Trade
abstract: Pres Clinton chides critics of his free-trade policies and calls on Congress to give him greater flexibility in negotiating trade agreements with Latin American countries; he urges Congress not to revoke China's trading privileges with US in vote on its most favored nation status; photo (M)

headline: Worries Over the Euro Elbow Other Issues Aside
abstract: Increasing likelihood that European Union will go ahead on schedule with bold plan to start a common currency in 1999 has made it defining issue of domestic politics across 15-nation group; euro, as new money will be called, has become obsession not only of British election campaign, but also in France; chart shows budget deficits as percentage of gross national product at end of 1996 for Germany, France, Spain, Britain and Italy; to qualify for joining in common currency, each country must lower its deficit to 3 percent or less of GNP by end of this year; euro is to begin replacing existing currencies in 2002 (M)

headline: Burmese Officials Return Fugitive in U.S. Heroin Case to Thailand
abstract: Burmese officials return Li Yung Chung, chief suspect in biggest heroin seizure in US history, to Thailand, where he jumped bail earlier in year; he is wanted in connection with seizure of 1,070 pounds of heroin in Hayward, Calif (M)

headline: Petroleum Is Lower on Doubts On OPEC's Production Curbs
abstract: Crude oil futures prices declined on June 26, amid skepticism that OPEC would keep its promise to curb production; crude for August delivery drops 43 cents, to close at $19.09 per barrel; gasoline for July delivery lost 0.18 cents, to 56.79 cents per gallon; heating oil for July fell 0.97 cent, to 52.02 cents per gallon (S)

headline: Continental Set to Begin Exclusive Pact With Boeing
abstract: Continental Airlines is expected to announce that it will buy 35 wide-body jets in exclusive arrangement with Boeing Co; order is worth more than $3 billion (M)

headline: Pepsico Bottling Operation In South Africa Is Closed
abstract: Pepsico Inc franchise bottler in South Africa, New Age Beverages, cedes country's $1 billion beverage market to Pepsi's archrival, Coca-Cola Co; Pepsico announces that bottler had filed for voluntary liquidation in Johannesburg court and that company had already ceased operations; Pepsi spokesman asserts that Coke's 'stranglehold' in South Africa 'was too tough to pry loose' (S)

headline: Thyssen to Sell 2 Units To Ispat of Britain
abstract: Thyssen AG to sell two steel units, Stahl Ruhrort GmbH and Walzdraht Hochfeld GmbH to Ispat International Ltd (S)

headline: Sporting Goods Retailers Start to Consider New Lineups
abstract: Market Place column on several sporting goods retailers that have started merger talks with other sporting goods retailers; says Sports Authority is talking with Sportmart Inc, chain of 59 stores in Wheeling, Ill, which in turn is also in merger discussion with Jumbosports; holds Sports Authority and Jumbosports may also have been in contact; Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc may want piece of potential action as well (L)

headline: Study Ranks Software as No. 3 Industry
abstract: Computer industry-sponsored study by group of computer executives led by Bill Gates of Microsoft and Andrew Grove of Intel shows computer software business has risen rapidly to become America's third-largest manufacturing industry, paying wages twice that national average; study is partly a lobbying tool; it is intended to emphasize rising importance of software industry at a time when Congress is considering legislation on a number of issues that affect the business, like export curbs on data-scrambling software and new laws to protect intellectual property (L)

headline: Dow Rises 135.64 Points for Fifth Straight Closing High
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 135.64 points, or 1.8 percent, to close at record 7,711.47; Dow has gained 1,263 points this year, rising 19.6 percent in less than six months; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 13.91 points, to 883.48, a closing high; Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks also sets record, gaining 1.92 points, to 389.54; New York Stock Exchange composite index gains 7.14 points, to close at record 460.64; Nasdaq composite index closes up 3.47 points at 1,411.32; graph; table (L)

headline: Will China Choose Power or Wealth?
abstract: Financial markets appear confident that China, set to take over Hong Kong, will allow enough political freedom to keep Hong Kong healthy and wealthy, viewed not shared by most members of United States Congress; graph (M)

headline: VESTA INSURANCE BUYS TWO SUBSIDIARIES FROM ANTHEM
abstract: Vesta Insurance Group Inc agrees to buy main operating subsidiaries of Anthem Casualty Insurance Group Inc--Anthem Casualty Insurance Co and Shelby Insurance Co--for $238.8 million; Anthem Casualty sells insurance through about 1,500 independent agents in Midwest and Middle Atlantic states (S)

headline: Turner to Build Laboratory
abstract: Turner Corp receives $35.7 million contract from University of Connecticut Health Center in Storrs to construct building to house health center's biomedical research, molecular biology programs and 128 laboratory modules (S)

headline: Dear I.R.S.: The Dog Ate My Form 1099. Honest.
abstract: Internal Revenue Service received more than 2.2 million amended individual returns last year, the most common reason being 'overlooking income'; Bob Devlin of IRS notes that most taxpayers who report revised income are elderly, living off interest and dividend income, and facing flurry of 1099 forms from banks and investment houses; only 1 percent of individual returns are audited, but some errors are easier to catch than others, and anything reported on Form 1099 is particularly easy; photo (M)

headline: Aviation Underwriter Sentenced for Fraud
abstract: John V Brennan, former chairman and chief executive of United States Aviation Underwriters Inc, is sentenced to 57 months in prison and fined $100,000, and company itself is fined $20.5 million, in fraud case stemming from 1987 airplane crash; fraud grew out of scheme in which Brennan and United States Aviation manipulated claims litigation arising from crash of Pacific Southwest Airlines flight on Dec 7, 1987; while plane was en route from Los Angeles to San Francisco, disgruntled former employee of USAir, which owned Pacific Southwest, shot his former supervisor and pilot and co-pilot; all 43 passengers and crew died in subsequent crash (S)

headline: TALKS OVER POSSIBLE SALE LIFT BIOWHITTAKER STOCK
abstract: Shares of Biowhittaker Inc. rose nearly 9 percent yesterday after the company said it was in preliminary talks with several parties about a possible takeover. The company, based in Walkersville, Md., makes diagnostic testing products. In October, it hired the investment bank Alex. Brown & Sons to explore ''strategic alternatives to maximize shareholder value.'' Biowhittaker's shares were up 87.5 cents, at $10.75, giving the company a market capitalization of more than $115 million.

headline: Republicans Return Foreign Donation
abstract: WASHINGTON—  The Republican Party returned a campaign contribution of more than $100,000 on Thursday, acknowledging that the money originated from a Hong Kong company and not from a subsidiary incorporated in Florida.

headline: AT&T and SBC Reportedly Talk of Huge Phone Merger
abstract: In a deal that would reunite Ma Bell with the fastest growing of her progeny, the AT&T Corporation is discussing a merger with SBC Communications Inc., people familiar with the talks said yesterday.    The deal, if completed, would be the largest corporate merger in history, with a value of more than $50 billion. And it would create a colossus that dwarfs even the other telecommunications giants created in the wake of deregulation. Together, AT&T and SBC would have 90 million long-distance customers, 30 million local customers and virtual dominion over SBC's two biggest states, California and Texas.

headline: CAPITAL ONE TO BUY DEPOSITS FROM J. C. PENNEY
abstract: Capital One Financial Corp's Capital One FSB unit will assume $425 million in deposits from J C Penney Co's JCPenney National Bank (S)

headline: Baron Firm and 13 Charged With Cheating Thousands
abstract: A R Baron & Co and 13 former employees are indicted on charges that they created and ran criminal enterprise that cheated thousands of investors out of more than $75 million over several years; indictment of Baron is notable for the array of criminal activity that prosecutors say was used to victimize unwitting investors; names of indicted listed (L)

headline: BAY VIEW CAPITAL AGREES TO BUY AMERICA FIRST EUREKA
abstract: Bay View Capital Corp agrees to buy America First Eureka Holdings for $300 million in cash and stock, in combination of two banking organizations in San Francisco Bay area (S)

headline: Swiss Reject As One-Sided Study by U.S. Of Nazi Ties
abstract: Swiss authorities tartly reject US charge that Switzerland prolonged World War II by acting as banker for Nazi Germany; statement read by Foreign Min Flavio Cotti reflects increasingly prickly reaction to damning report chronicling purchases of gold from Nazis, long stalling on bank accounts held by Jews and refusal to honor 1946 agreement on liquidation of German assets for war reparations; statement acknowledges 'questionable' deals and 'fainthearted' refugee policy concerning Jews that was 'inexcusable,' but stresses need to ensure country's survival (S)

headline: Mexican Chief Turns Down U.S. Requests On Drug War
abstract: Mexican Pres Ernesto Zedillo strongly rejects proposals by US law enforcement officials for improving security of US drug agents and detecting police corruption; turns down request for agents in Mexico to carry sidearms, and refuses lie-detector tests for Mexicans applying for sensitive jobs; vehemence suggests Zedillo wants to pre-empt any US arm-twisting during Pres Clinton's upcoming visit; Zedillo, in interview with five American reporters, also boasts of Mexico's economic recovery; says he will tell Clinton that only extended development will slow illegal migration; implies he might stop drug cooperation if Congress tries to impose sanctions, although he emphasizes Clinton's personal friendliness to Mexico (S)

headline: Saudi Handed Over In the '96 Bombing That Left 19 Dead
abstract: Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, Shiite Muslim implicated in June 1996 bombing at US military base in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 American airmen, is deported to US from Canada; will to cooperate with Justice Department in itsinvestigation into attack in exchange for reduced sentence in unrelated case, in which he is charged with conspiring to kill American nationals; is believed by US officials to have driven getaway car used in attack on Khobar Towers military complex in Dhahran but was not part of inner circle that planned bombing; belongs to Hezbollah, Muslim militant group backed by Iran; reportedly struck deal with US because he feared for life if sent back to Saudi Arabia, which had pressed Canada for his return (M)

headline: Agencies Share Best-of-Show Obies
abstract: BBDO Canada in Toronto, Lois/EJL in Los Angeles and J Walter Thompson San Francisco share top honors, winning Best of Show awards, at annual Obie Awards for creative excellence sponsored by Outdoor Advertising Association of America (S)

headline: Japanese Companies Take New Look at Western Management Ideas
abstract: Japanese executives, who once sharply criticized American executives for being overpaid and for focusing too much on short-term results, now seem to be adopting some American management ideas; Sony Corp, in sharp departure for a Japanese company, says it will move toward more Western-style board, with far fewer directors and more of them coming from outside the company; Sony will slash size of its board to 10 directors from 38; Sony says its smaller board will speed decision-making and allow for better discussion; changes represent acknowledgment by some companies that Japanese management, for all its worthwhile focus on long-term investment, sometimes moves too slowly (L)

headline: PEROT SYSTEMS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ASSETS OF NETS INC.
abstract: Perot Systems agrees to acquire most of assets and employees of Nets Inc for $9 million; Nets Inc, which specializes in linking buyers and sellers of industrial goods on the Internet, filed for bankruptcy protection last month (S)

headline: U.S. Reviews A Bid Made By Microsoft
abstract: Justice Department issued formal request to Microsoft Corp last week, seeking internal documents concerning Microsoft's planned $425 million purchase of WebTV Networks Inc; legal analysts note that stepped-up probe--signaled by second request for information--does not necessarily mean Justice Department will challenge planned purchase (L)

headline: Agencies Say U.N. Ignored Pleas on Hutu
abstract: With reports of mass graves adding to evidence that thousands of Rwandan Hutu refugees may have been killed in recent weeks in Congo, relief agencies say they have sought protection for refugees in the region for more than two years, only to be ignored by the Security Council.    ''This is one of those unfortunate situations where you take no pleasure in being right,'' Soren Jessen-Petersen, the representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees here, said today.

headline: Sterling Buys Singer Specs
abstract: Sterling Vision Inc purchases closely held Singer Specs Inc in exchange for unspecified number of Sterling common shares (S)

headline: S.&P. May Cut Tobacco Ratings
abstract: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services says it might cut its ratings on debt issued by tobacco companies or their units amid concern the costs of lawsuits against the industry could hurt companies' ability to pay back bondholders; decision affects bonds at RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp, Philip Morris Companies, Loews Corp and BAT Industries (S)

headline: Silence Ends, and Jewish Ghosts Are Remembered
abstract: Memorial to Holocaust victims, and two museums dedicated to Jewish life and culture, will open in Salonika, Greece, more than 50 years since Nazis wiped out all traces of city's Jewish past; all but one of its 36 synagogues were destroyed, and all but few thousand of pre-war population of 56,000 Jews were killed in death camps; photo; map (M)

headline: Last Dance
abstract: Stories solicited on subject watching a colleague resign with a flourish

headline: Tax Proposal Offers Wall St. Some Relief
abstract: US House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Repr Bill Archer puts forth wide-ranging tax plan, and his proposals contain some relief that would be welcome on Wall Street: phasing out corporate alternative minimum tax, reducing capital gains for middle- and lower-income investors, expanding use of independent contractors instead of employees and continuing tax preferences for both 100-year bonds and for stock options; potentially most painful proposal would require companies to register tax shelters with the Government (M)

headline: Strike Shuts Zaire's Capital for Second Day
abstract: Supporters of ousted Prime Min Etienne Tshisekedi have brought Kinshasa, Zaire, to halt with strike demanding Pres Mobutu Sese Seko's resignation; Government troops roam city, thwarting planned motorcade by strikers, but effectively shutting down city; rebel forces led by Laurent Kabila continue their advance, eroding Government power from another direction; photo (M)

headline: South Korean Leader Apologizes For Election Spending Abuses
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Young Sam, two weeks after his son was arrested on bribery charges, apologizes again for scandal enveloping his administration, but he refuses to disclose details of fund-raising in his 1992 campaign (M)

headline: In a magazine's test, eight laptop computers prove they can take a beating on the road.
abstract: Executives worried about damaging their laptops when they travel will find some comfort in PC Computing magazine's fifth annual 'torture test,' out this month; editors of magazine baked, froze and hurled 16 of latest Pentium laptop computers to see how well they fared; findings noted; Accor's Hotel Sofitel is offering rates of either $125 or $145 a night at nine hotels; special rates expire on May 31; Kuok Group's Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts has introduced range of free services for all guests who pay full, nondiscounted rate; Travelocity, a World Wide Web site created by Sabre Group, is offering new flight-paging service free to travelers; Gulfstream Aerospace's Gulfstream V, a new, $35 million, ultra-long range business jet, embarked on seven-day, round-the-world tour from Los Angeles on April 7 (L)

headline: South African Jet Order
abstract: Bombardier Inc says South African Express of Johannesburg agrees to buy six Canadair regional jet aircraft for about $130 million (S)

headline: Bonds Stage Biggest Rally In a Month
abstract: Treasury prices rebound sharply on June 6 in strongest one-day rally for bonds in month; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 1 7/32, to 98 3/32; bond's yield falls to 6.77 percent, from 6.88 percent (M)

headline: Orthodox Conversion Bill Gains in Israel
abstract: Israeli Parliament, angering Conservative and Reform Jews, gives preliminary approval to bill that would give Orthodox rabbis sole authority to conduct conversions to Judaism in Israel; photo (M)

headline: Power-Broker at Center of Scandal
abstract: Profile of Aryeh Deri, man in middle of influence-peddling scandal threatening Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's Govt; Deri is no stranger to police investigations and criminal indictments; they have punctuated a stormy public career that has swept Deri to top of strictly Orthodox Shas Party, where he has often held fate of Israel's governing coalitions in his hands; at center of scandal are allegations that Deri, who is on trial for bribery and fraud, put pressure on Netanyahu to appoint an Atty Gen who would arrange plea-bargain for him; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: * C. Norman Shaffer, senior vice president and media planning director at Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York, was promoted to executive vice president and media services director, and Jannine Regis, vice president and marketing director, was promoted to senior vice president and business development director. They assume duties from Steven Farella, executive vice president, media services director and director for business development, who left Jordan, McGrath to join D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, New York, a unit of MacManus Group, as senior vice president and regional director for North America media operations.    * Joe Cupani, vice chairman and chief creative officer at the Chapman Agency, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., was promoted to chairman. He succeeds Janet Coombs, who was named president of the New York office of a Chapman sibling, Wunderman Cato Johnson.

headline: Ex-Policeman Who Told of Apartheid Crimes Is Guilty of Killing
abstract: Former South African police captain Dirk Coetzee, first white police officer to expose Government's dirty war against anti-apartheid activists, is convicted with co-defendants David Tshikilange and Almond Nofomela for 1981 murder of well-known civil rights lawyer, Griffiths Mxenge (M)

headline: When Dirty Laundry Shows, Use Tougher Soaps
abstract: Popular Irish television soap operas, Glenroe and Fair City, jostling for top ratings in prime time, are tackling topics considered too touchy 10 years ago; are depicting not only prosperity, but also some troubling, even dismal, aspects of Irish social life; photo (M)

headline: REGISTRY IN STOCK DEAL FOR RENAISSANCE
abstract: Registry Inc agrees to acquire Renaissance Solutions Inc, a management consulting and systems integration company, in deal valued at $430 million based on closing price of May 19 (S)

headline: California Bakeries Sold
abstract: Interstate Bakeries Corp buys Specialty Foods Corp's San Francisco French Bread Co (S)

headline: A.T.M.'s: Who Wins?
abstract: William H Johnson letter notes that ATM's are for banks' convenience, and to save money on tellers

headline: AHMANSON TO BUY BACK $250 MILLION MORE OF ITS STOCK
abstract: H. F. Ahmanson & Company, based in Irwindale, Calif., said yesterday that its board had approved the purchase of an additional $250 million in stock after the completion of its existing buyback program. Ahmanson, parent company of Home Savings of America, said it had bought 19.2 million shares, or 16 percent of all outstanding shares, at $27.11 a share through March. It now has 100.6 million shares outstanding. Since February, the company has been engaged in a hostile bid for the Great Western Financial Corporation.

headline: EMI Plans Return Of Capital to Holders
abstract: EMI Group plans to return up to 499.1 million pounds ($815.7 million) of capital to shareholders (S)

headline: RYDER TO SELL AUTO-TRANSPORT UNIT TO ALLIED HOLDINGS
abstract: Ryder System Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its automobile-transport unit to Allied Holdings Inc. for $114.5 million in cash and the assumption of $60 million of debt. Allied Holdings, a car and truck hauler based in Decatur, Ga., expects its sales to more than double to about $1 billion with the acquisition; it had $392.5 million in sales last year. The unit, Ryder Automotive Carrier Services Inc., is one of North America's largest movers of cars and trucks from auto makers to dealerships. It had revenue of almost $600 million in 1996. Miami-based Ryder had revenue of $5.5 billion last year. It has been selling off units to focus on managing and moving goods for other companies.

headline: Wary of Speeded-Up Mideast Talks, Clinton Wants Israelis to Show Sincerity
abstract: US officials say Pres Clinton emerged from his meeting with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu wary about Netanyahu's idea of dramatic, six-month push toward final settlement between Israel and Palestinians; say Clinton wants Netanyahu to prove that he is sincere about his intentions before Clinton commits himself and US credibility to such bold and risky stroke (M)

headline: States Lead a Crackdown On Telemarketing Brokers
abstract: Securities regulators from 20 states crack down on stockbrokers pushing penny stocks by telephone; led by Attorney General Dennis C Vacco of New York, regulators file lawsuits and other enforcement actions against several individuals and 14 firms, almost all based in New York metropolitan area; brokerage firms listed (L)

headline: In Order to Focus on U.S., Kmart Sells Canadian Unit
abstract: Kmart Corp says it sold its 123-store Kmart Canada unit for $134 million (US) to group of Canadian and American investors as part of strategy to focus on its core business in United States; buyers are York Management Services Inc, Cherokee Ventures Canada Inc and Capital d'Amerique CDPQ Inc, unit of Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec; Kmart will keep 12.5 percent equity interest in Kmart Canada (M)

headline: Firms Slice Big Board Stock Into Yet Smaller Fractions
abstract: Prices of stocks on New York Stock Exchange, which have been traded in increments of 1/8 of dollar--12.5 cents--for Big Board's entire history, begin trading at increments half that large--1/16, or 6.25 cents; move is instituted by a couple of so-called third-market firms, which trade Big Board stocks but do not do so on exchange (S)

headline: Yeltsin to Oust a Foe as Governor in Russia's Far East
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin, setting stage for sharp political and constitutional battle, plans to oust Yevgeny I Nazdratenko as Governor of huge Primorsky region in Russian Far East; Nazdratenko, powerful and independently elected, is openly autocratic critic of Yeltsin; crime and corruption have come to rule strategically important region, which is also rich in natural resources; ouster would be message from Kremlin that it will not accept continuing erosion of federal power; map (M)

headline: EVERGREEN TO SELL 3 RADIO STATIONS FOR $64.1 MILLION
abstract: Evergreen Media Corp sells WEJM-FM in Chicago to Dontron Inc for $14.8 million, WEJM-AM in Chicago to Douglas Broadcasting/Personal Achievement Radio for $7.5 million and WFLN-FM in Philadelphia to Greater Media Radio Inc for $41.8 million (S)

headline: 6 Islands, 7 Days, 48 Monthly Payments
abstract: Princess Cruises has teamed up with MBNA America Bank of Wilmington, Del, to offer lines of credit that people can use to pay not only for cruise tickets but also for expenses incurred on trip or for other expenses altogether; borrowers have two to four years to pay off loans, and interest rates run from 14.99 percent to 26.99 percent, based on customer's payment terms, credit history and credit worthiness; paying for cruise with conventional credit card, whose average rate is now 17.84 percent, may be far cheaper for some people; photo (M)

headline: British Petroleum Posts 19.3% Profit Gain
abstract: British Petroleum Co reports stronger-than-expected 19.3 percent rise in first quarter profit; profit before one-time items rose to record 755 million pounds ($1.22 billion) from 633 million a year ago (S)

headline: Brazilians Sell $3 Billion Of Unsecured 30-Year Debt
abstract: Brazil, seeking to reorganize its foreign debt and reduce its future liabilities for interest by at least $160 million, sells $3 billion of unsecured 30-year bonds, most of which are being exchanged for Brady bonds; landmark transaction is important step on the road that is returning more creditworthy developing countries to international capital markets; 30-year bond slips 5/32, to price of 96 26/32, pushing its yield up to 6.88 percent, from 6.86 percent on June 3; graph (L)

headline: If salmon are going to be turned into low-fat 'bacon,' can salmon belly futures be far behind?
abstract: IF a bacon cheeseburger sounds tasty but unhealthy, how about a burger garnished with fish-based food product that resembles fried bacon pieces? It should taste like bacon, too, under a patent awarded to a Juneau, Alaska, inventor, Duff W. Mitchell.    Food patents are only a small portion of the thousands of patents issued each year. In the last decade, an increasing number have been for inventions that reduce fat, cholesterol or calories in foods that have the worst health images, like chocolate, cheese or meat.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Buying by Military Drives Durable Goods Orders  Orders for durable goods rose 1.4 percent in April, in part because of unexpectedly large orders by the Pentagon.    The rise, which was led by gains in transportation equipment, much of it for the military, erased about two-thirds of a March decline. But orders for electronic equipment slumped for a second month. $(Page D5.$)

headline: Ford Sales Fell 4.3% in April as Big 3 Lost Share to Foreign Makers
abstract: Ford Motor Co says its sales dropped 4.3 percent in April, as Big Three American auto makers lost ground to Japanese auto makers that benefited from favorable exchange rates; Big Three sold 73.3 percent of cars and trucks purchased in US in April, down 2.1 percentage points from April 1996; Japanese auto makers picked up 1.2 percentage points of market share, while German auto makers gained another seven-tenths of a percentage point (L)

headline: Where the Elephants Pay Their Way
abstract: Africans in Muzarambani, Zimbabwe, may be induced by money to consider elephants more than big cranky pests that devour crops and knock over huts; money from tourism and few hunting licenses has built local clinic and beer hall; photo; map; Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia, with growing elephant populations, want to overturn international ban on ivory to sell their big stockpiles of tusks from animals that died naturally or were culled or killed for threatening people; three countries are tired of paying price for other countries where war and corruption decimated herds (Muzarabani Journal) (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Helzberg Diamonds, North Kansas City, Mo., a unit of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., to Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia, to handle the creative and strategic duties for its Jewelry 3 and Helzberg chains of retail stores, which had been handled by Barkley & Evergreen, Kansas City, Mo. The Media Edge, New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc., continues handling media; duties like direct marketing remain in house. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

headline: People
abstract: * Nik Mainthia was named senior vice president and media director at the Fitzgerald Cos., Atlanta, succeeding Rich Simms, who left to join the Media Partnership Corp., Norwalk, Conn., as president. Mr. Mainthia had been vice president and planning director at BBDO South, Atlanta, a unit of Omnicom Group.

headline: VEECO INSTRUMENTS IN $86.3 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR WYKO
abstract: Veeco Instruments Inc agrees to acquire Wyko Corp, privately held supplier of optical measurement systems for semiconductor industry, for about $86.3 million in stock (S)

headline: In Zaire, a Signal That Mobutu May Depart Today
abstract: Pres Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire will make state visit to Gabon, a trip is widely seen as way for him to escape before rebels capture his capital, Kinshasa; diplomats from United States, South Africa and other nations have been working in last few days to ease Mobutu out and avoid violent takeover of crowded city; map; photo (M)

headline: Death, Drugs and Courtroom Drama Trample on a Tranquil Caribbean Isle
abstract: Small and tranquil Caribbean island of St Kitts is at center of drug and murder scandal, in which more than half ton of cocaine, being smuggled from Columbia to US, disappeared on local beach, and was followed by murders of two prominent people believed involved in operation, as well as of police chief who was investigating killings; three trials of David Lawrence for murder of police official has ended in hung jury; map; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Accepts Kabila, but Cautions on Democracy
abstract: Clinton Administration moves quickly to extend ties and recognition to rebel alliance now ruling Zaire, pledging its help in building democratic government and adopting name rebels have given country, Democratic Republic of Congo (M)

headline: A Shaky Year Over, the Yeltsin of Old Flies to the Summit
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin of Russia arrives in Denver for summit meeting of industralized countries; photo (M)

headline: Pro Bono Accounts
abstract: * The Holocaust Memorial-Museum of Jewish Heritage, New York, to DDB Needham New York, a unit of Omnicom Group, as the first agency to handle advertising for the museum, which is expected to open in the fall.

headline: A $1.7 Billion Stake Set By Veba in Degussa
abstract: German utility Veba AG plans to buy 36.4 percent stake in chemical and metal company Degussa AG; Veba will pay 2.9 billion marks ($1.7 billion) stake held by GFC Gesellschaft fuer Chemiewerte (S)

headline: ZAIRIAN SOLDIERS MUTINY AS REBELS NEAR SECOND CITY
abstract: Zairian soldiers in Lubumbashi, country's second largest city, surrrender to rebels without fight in dramatic setback for Government in calamitous six-month civil war; lay down arms and declare common cause with rebels advancing on city; thousands of citizens reportedly turn out in streets to hail rebel leader, Laurent Kabila; army units still loyal to Pres Mobutu Sese Seko fight running battles in capital of Kinshasa with thousands of student protestors calling for his ouster; photo; map (M)

headline: Korean Company Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Yusung Co, one of South Korea's largest textile company's files for bankruptcy (S)

headline: Judge Ends Appeals In Drug-Pricing Suit
abstract: Federal Appeals Court Judge Richard A Posner clears the way for $352 million price-fixing settlement involving 11 major drug companies to take effect in September; group of independent pharmacists filed suit in 1993 against pharmaceutical companies, saying drug makers' two-tier pricing policy discriminated against them and amounted to price fixing (S)

headline: Clamorously, Pacifica Radio Dances Toward Mainstream
abstract: Pacifica Radio, left-oriented network based in Berkeley, Calif, is in midst of rancorous argument over what goes on air and who should decide; argument about programming and control is part of wider debate about purity or popularity of public broadcasting; friction between professional managers and staff volunteers has grown as Federal funds have stagnated and much of Pacifica's old radical audience has moved to mainstream fare (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Possible White House Shift On Internet Decency Law  With a groundbreaking Supreme Court decision imminent concerning a new law regulating children's access to indecent material on the Internet, senior Clinton Administration officials are preparing a new communications policy that sharply undercuts the Administration's argument to the Justices just three months ago in favor of the law.

headline: Algeria Says Rebels Killed 93, Many Women, in Village Raid
abstract: Algerian Government says Islamic radicals killed 93 people, 43 of them women, in raid on village of Haouch Mokfi; map (M)

headline: Restive Indonesians Find Little Hope in Vote
abstract: Often violent monthlong parliamentary campaign in Indonesia, thoroughly engineered to produce Government landslide, has spurred outpouring of disaffection with Pres Suharto's 31-year rule; Suharto says democratic development will be 'long process,' speech; unrest seems to strengthen Government's sense that Indonesia is too volatile to allow openness; map; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CAPSTAR BROADCASTING Austin, Tex., a radio company, said that it had agreed to buy Patterson Broadcasting Inc. for $215 million and that it planned to raise about $90 million through an initial public offering.

headline: New automated system for speeding travelers through immigration will be tested in Bermuda.
abstract: IBM will demonstrate automated system for speeding passengers through immigration checkpoints at airports at World Travel and Tourism Council meeting in Washington, DC; called Fastgate, system will undergo testing beginning next month at Bermuda International Airport; 10-millionth passenger will fly Delta Shuttle on April 22 or 23; lucky passenger will receive two free round-trip tickets to any Delta Air Lines destination; Hanoi Daewood Hotel has become first hotel in Vietnam to join Leading Hotels of the World, reservations and marketing alliance of more than 300 luxury hotels in about 70 countries; Carlson Wagonlit Travel agrees to acquire Travel Agents International, a Florida operator of franchised travel agencies, for undisclosed amount (L)

headline: Mutual Fund Lesson: How It Feels to Lose
abstract: Millions of mutual fund shareholders, many of them neophyte fund investors, lose money in first quarter or 1997, the first quarter that mutual funds that invest in stocks or that buy bonds have lost money in same quarter since fourth quarter of 1994; number of Americans who own shares in mutual funds has grown by third, to 63 million, in last two years; in coming months, mutual fund investors will play big role in determining health and direction of financial markets; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: PAPERBOARD INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC., Montreal, a maker of boxboard and packaging products, will buy Stora Kopparbergs Bergslags A.B.'s paperboard mill in Arnsberg, Germany, for about $43.4 million.      CARBINER INTERNATIONAL INC., New York, a provider of corporate communications, training and promotional services, will acquire Bauer Audio Visual Inc., Dallas, for $13.9 million in cash, $4.6 million in Carbiner common stock and the assumption of about $7.8 million in debt.      COMAIR HOLDINGS INC., Cincinnati, a regional airline carrier, agreed to buy 18 small jetliners valued at $330 million from the Montreal-based Bombardier Inc.

headline: Auditors to Start Work In Switzerland Looking For Holocaust Funds
abstract: Teams from three major U.S. accounting firms will move into 10 Swiss banks this week to begin an independent inquiry into funds that may have belonged to Holocaust victims.

headline: Merrill Investigating Derivatives Accounting
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co is investigating some 'unreconciled balances' in its equity derivatives accounts in Britain after a change in reporting lines for derivatives business last year; Merrill says no clients' funds are affected by inconsistencies in the accounts and that they will not result in any material impact on its business or earnings (S)

headline: Alan Gruber, 69, Retired Insurance Executive
abstract: Alan R Gruber, retired executive of Equity Funding Corp, dies at age 69; photo (M)

headline: Red Lobster USA Sets Account Review
abstract: Red Lobster USA, seafood restaurant chain owned and operated by Darden Restaurants, places in review creative and media planning portions of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $70 million to $90 million; account had been handled by Grey Advertising (S)

headline: TODD-AO TO ACQUIRE HOLLYWOOD DIGITAL FOR $31 MILLION
abstract: Todd-AO Corp to acquire closely-held Hollywood Digital for $31 million in cash and debt (S)

headline: New British Treasury Chief Has Come In With a Bang
abstract: Article on monetary moves of Britain's new Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown; says just days after taking over on May 2, Brown freed Bank of England from Government's control over the power to set short-term interest rates; holds two weeks later he irked central bank by taking away its supervision of banking industry; says now that job is in the hands of a friend who will head beefed-up Securities and Investments Board; holds two moves constitute most sweeping change in British monetary policy and financial regulation in decades and puts end to half-hearted, largely self-regulatory ethic that in recent past failed to detect corruption at Bank of Credit and Commerce International or irregularities that led to collapse of Barings PLC; photo (L)

headline: Payoff Scandal Grows in Japan
abstract: Hideo Sakamaki, former president of Nomura Securities Co, acknowledges that he authorized subordinates to make illegal payoffs to racketeer Ryuichi Koike (S)

headline: Peng Zhen of China, 95, Dies; Was a Leading Hard-Liner
abstract: Peng Zhen, one of China's foremost hard-line leaders, dies at age of 95; photo (M)

headline: EASTMAN KODAK TO BUY MAJORITY STAKE IN CHINON
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co agrees to buy majority stake in Chinon Industries, maker of digital cameras, for 1.9 billion yen ($15 million) (S)

headline: Coffee Prices Soar on Worry About Cold Weather in Brazil
abstract: Coffee prices surged yesterday, posting their biggest one-day gain in almost three years, after a weekend cold snap in Brazil raised concern that the world's largest crop could be damaged by frost at a time when supplies are already tight.    On other markets, platinum and palladium jumped and wheat fell.

headline: Rightly or Not, Tax Writers See Deep Pockets in Airlines
abstract: Market Place column on airline industry as target of increased fees and taxes to help offset tax cuts; says US House Ways and Means Committee chairman Repr Bill Archer this week proposed increased fees and taxes on airlines and their passengers to help offset $135 billion in proposed tax cuts; others also see airlines as convenient source of new Government revenue; Sen William V Roth of Delaware has proposed using fuel taxes to subsidize passenger rail service; Repr Bill Barrett of Nebraska wants to allow states to impose fee of up to $3 a passenger to subsidize air service to smaller communities; state legislator in Texas recently proposed tax of 4 cents a gallon on aviation fuel to help offset cut in property taxes (L)

headline: Fred Meyer Is Acquiring Smith's Food for $700 Million in Stock
abstract: Fred Meyer Inc agrees to acquire Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc for about $700 million in stock, in a deal that would create supermarket and general merchandise chain with 374 stores in 17 Western states (L)

headline: Germany Opts Not to Pursue Iranian Leaders
abstract: Germany backs away from further confrontation with Iran, opting not to pursue high-level investigation of country's top leaders, accused by Berlin court of complicity in 1992 killings of four Kurdish exiles at Berlin restaurant (S)

headline: CADMUS TO CLOSE PLANTS AND DISMISS 225 WORKERS
abstract: Kenneth Cole Productions Inc will enter licensing agreement with Dickson Licensing Ltd of Hong Kong for Kenneth Cole New York and Kenneth Cole Reaction trademarks; financial terms undisclosed; Dickson plans to develop network of Kenneth Cole retail stores in Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan, China, Indonesia and Malaysia; stores are to open by end of 1999 (S)

headline: Low Sales Figures in March Disappoint Many Retailers
abstract: Goldman, Sachs retail composite index, which tracks same-store sales--or sales at stores open at least a year--increased 4 percent in March, after 4.2 percent gain a year earlier and 3.8 percent increase in February; table; graph (L)

headline: Japan Loan Role By Bankers Trust
abstract: Bankers Trust New York Corp is hired to help Nippon Credit Bank sell its bad loans; agreement could lead two banks to take stake in each other (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about William Steiner, a shareholder activist who founded the Investors' Rights Association of America, omitted a byline. The writer was Sana Siwolop.

headline: AHMANSON SAYS GREAT WESTERN INVESTORS FAVOR ITS BID
abstract: H F Ahmanson & Co says 80 percent of shares of Great Western Financial Corp voted so far in a referendum are in favor of its $6.18 billion hostile takeover bid (S)

headline: As Election Nears, More Than Politics Divides Islands
abstract: Nearly 2,400 candidates vie for 109 seats in Papua New Guinea's parliamentary elections, set for late June; vote comes at time of crisis, with civic services breaking down and population convinced of Government's corruption; area, with scattered islands and jumble of over 800 different languages and cultures, has yet to jell as coherent nation; remains mired in poverty; map; photo (M)

headline: Seeking Euro Club Inclusion, Italy Still Faces Hazing
abstract: If Prime Minister Romano Prodi were still in school, he would be the kind of pupil who arrives in the classroom early, gets his homework done on time, puts his hand up in front of the teacher's nose -- and still fails to get straight A's.    In this case, the evaluation is coming not from Italian voters but the country's northern European neighbors -- Germany in particular. Despite the efforts of Mr. Prodi's center-left Government, they continue to give Italy poor marks as a fiscal partner for the planned 1999 introduction of a common European currency known as the euro.

headline: Earnings Climb 6.5% At Rhone-Poulenc
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc SA says first-quarter earnings rose 6.5 percent; net profit was 674 million French francs ($116 million), up from 633 million francs a year earlier; sales rose 2.2 percent, to 21.6 billion francs (S)

headline: Peru Held Hostage: Four Months of Torment Ends Abruptly
abstract: Chronology of events in Peruvian hostage crisis; photo (M)

headline: Testimony in South Africa Ties Ex-Leader to Bombing
abstract: Adriaan Vlok, South Africa's former Minister of Law and Order and highest-ranking official to apply for amnesty, testifies that former Pres P W Botha personally ordered bombing that destroyed South African Council of Churches headquarters in 1988, calling it a 'house of evil'; his testimony is first to be made public that directly links former Pres Botha to acts of terror; revelations represent major step for Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which was set up to uncover country's brutal past; Botha, now 81 and infirm, has said he would not seek amnesty or have anything to do with commission (M)

headline: Oil profits hold up for the first three months, but may slip later on.
abstract: Market Place column on big oil companies that are expected to report strong earnings for first quarter despite decline in crude oil prices; analysts say industry will have tough time keeping up such high level of profitability because crude oil prices are expected to drop to $18 to $19 a barrel; Exxon Corp reports 15.4 percent gain in its net income for the quarter, to $2.18 billion compared with $1.89 billion in 1996 quarter; revenue for quarter total $33.6 billion, up from $31.2 billion in first quarter of 1996; Amoco reports first-quarter net income of $674 million, down 7.4 percent from $728 million in 1996 quarter; revenues in first quarter total $9 billion, up slightly from $8.2 billion in first quarter of 1996; graph; table (M)

headline: Acer Drops Riney For Kahn/Weber
abstract: Acer America Corp has parted ways with Hal Riney & Partners after only 15 months; creative portion of advertising account, with billings estimated at $10 million, has been awarded to Kahn/Weber/Harris (S)

headline: QUALCOMM EXPECTS SALES FROM JOINT VENTURE TO FALL
abstract: Qualcomm Inc expects sales from joint wireless-phone venture with Sony Corp to fall in fiscal second half amid slowing demand in wireless industry during summer; will cut 600 temporary workers (S)

headline: WARY ON ECONOMY, A SULLEN FRANCE GOES TO THE POLLS
abstract: French voters, expressing widespread discontent with nation's economy, go to polls May 25; Pres Jacques Chirac had called elections a year early hoping country would give him conservative majority for remaining five years of his economically troubled term, which began five years ago; polls indicate that as discontent with Prime Min Alain Juppe's policies is widespread, large protest vote of around 15 percent is expected to go to far-right National Front Party; strong showing by National Front could help Socialist-Communists obtain a majority; photo (M)

headline: $532 Million Deal Set In British Electronics
abstract: Siebe PLC agrees to buy APV PLC for about $532 million in stock and debt (S)

headline: Canadian Leader Keeps Majority but Loses Strength
abstract: Canadian voters return Prime Minister Jean Chretien and his party to power, but with slim majority and only 38 percent of popular vote nationally; Chretien narrowly wins own Parliament seat; opposition vote is split among four other parties, creating most fractured Parliament ever; Western-based Reform Party, led by Preston Manning, will be official opposition party, replacing Quebec separatist party, which lost seats; commentators see Chretien having trouble holding Canada together in event of another separatist referendum in Quebec; graphs; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. PENSION FUND SAID TO PONDER MALL PORTFOLIO SALE
abstract: IBM pension fund is considering sale of $1 billion portfolio of shopping malls; IBM is likely to swap the properties for shares in General Growth Properties Inc of Chicago, which manages day-to-day operations of the malls (S)

headline: Zairian Rebels Seize Capital of Rich Region
abstract: Zairian rebels, continuing their advance, march into regional capital, Mbuji-Mayi, in an area rich in minerals after Govt troops flee; with fall of Mbuji-Mayi, main city in area, rebels now control five of country's 11 regional capitals; they are encircling Zaire's second-largest city, Lubumbashi; map (M)

headline: SHARES OF PETSMART POST A DECREASE OF 24%
abstract: Petsmart Inc shares fall 24 percent on concerns about lower sales and higher-than-expected acquisition costs; pet owners are buying more medications for fleas and ticks from veterinarians, while cold spring reduced use and hurt Petsmart's sales of nonprescription powders, soaps and other products (S)

headline: Hong Kong Fears Unraveling of Rule of Law
abstract: Article in series Waiting for China focuses on outlook for rule of law in Hong Kong after Chinese takeover; many fear China's notion of law, based on personal whim and political need, will overwhelm Hong Kong's tradition of written law and impartial justice; foreign investors are concerned about China's cavalier breaching of contracts; optimists hope sanctity of contracts and predictability of conducting business under rule of law that have spurred colony's economic growth will serve as model for China; majority of Hong Kong residents believe corruption they associate with China will become more common under Chinese rule; photos (L)

headline: Companies Flex New Muscle and Labor Feels the Pinch
abstract: Government of Prime Min Costas Simitis is striving to rebuild Greece's flagging economy and lure back foreign businesses that fled nation's earlier pro-labor policies; is investing heavily in infrastructure projects, offering tax breaks for foreign investment and has set up investment agency to help firms deal with bureaucracy; signs of progress cited; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Europe to Study Coke-Carlsberg Deal
abstract: Europe's antitrust regulators will start investigation into proposed joint venture by Coca-Cola Co and Carlsberg A/S to bottle and distribute Coke products (S)

headline: Polaris Faces Inventor's $34 Million Verdict
abstract: Polaris Industries says it will appeal $34 million jury verdict on theft of trade secrets from investor of electronic fuel-injection system for snowmobiles; Raymond Niro, lawyer for inventor Ron Chasteen, and others comments; jury also determines that Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd, a Polaris partner, must pay $15 million on compensatory and $8 million in punitive damages (S)

headline: Giving Savings Bonds a Shot in the Arm
abstract: US Treasury, faced with dwindling sales, moved suddenly last week to rejuvenate its savings bonds; as of May 1, rates are higher, interest accures faster, risk of a big penalty is reduced, and Government has made things simpler; new program detailed; photo (L)

headline: Madison Ave. In Newsroom Once Again
abstract: Continuing debate over whether a newsman should be allowed to be pitchman has flared up because print advertisement for Visa by BBDO New York features CNN correspondent Jonathan Karl; photo (L)

headline: British Aerospace Joins Lockheed in Plane Project
abstract: British Aerospace PLC says it has joined with Lockheed Martin Corp in competition with Boeing Co to build joint strike fighter, United States military's next-generation fighter aircraft; decision, announced at Paris air show, is blow to Boeing, which had been courting British Aerospace for its fighter aircraft expertise (M)

headline: In Japan's Burnt Trash, Dioxin Threat
abstract: Concern about dioxin emissions from trash incineration is growing in Japan, which relies heavily on incineration for waste disposal; issue is part of broader problem about where to dispose of household and industrial waste; map; photo (M)

headline: Kabila Fields A Team Short On Seasoning
abstract: Laurent Kabila, Zaire's new President, remains closeted with with closest advisers as he struggles to transform seven-month-old rebel movement into transitional government; faces enormous obstacles in efforts to fashion Cabinet from relatively inexperienced group of aides; without presenceyof former Pres Mobutu Sese Seko to galvanize rebel alliance, internal divisions that have been simmering for months are likely to surface (M)

headline: AVTEL SAYS IT WILL BUY MATRIX FOR $114.6 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Avtel Communications Inc agrees to buy Matrix Telecommunications Inc for about $114.6 million in stock (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  An earnings report is expected from Atlantic Richfield.

headline: In the latest industry courtship, Omnicom and True North are suitors for Bozell, Jacobs.
abstract: Possible sale of Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt may be near as competitors Omnicom Group and True North Communications pursue separate acquisition bids (L)

headline: Hostile $631 Million Bid for Machine-Tool Maker
abstract: Harnischfeger Industries is making hostile $631 million bid for Giddings & Lewis Inc, big maker of machine tools; offer of $19 a share in cash is nearly 40 percent above $13.625 a share that Giddings stock closes at; Harnischfeger will also assume $116 million of Giddings debt (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: List of rates for key Government bonds

headline: The Money Is in the Stock, Not The Books
abstract: For a print journalist who is tired of hearing that the rise of technology, broadcasting and the Internet will soon make words on paper superfluous, the amazing success of Jeffrey Bezos is indeed satisfying.    The 33-year-old Mr. Bezos is in the business of selling that most old-fashioned of information sources: books. He has sold $32 million of them since entering the business in 1994. That success has made him worth $205 million today.

headline: Boeing and Other Concerns Lobby Congress for China
abstract: Beoing Co, largest US exporter, begins lobbying blitz in Congress, along with host of other American corporations, for vote to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status; says if US makes misstep, China will do more business with Airbus Industrie, European aircraft consortium; says $4 billion order for 100 planes is at stake (M)

headline: SAKHALIN ENERGY STAKE BRINGS MCDERMOTT $122 MILLION
abstract: McDermott International Inc says recent sale of its 20 percent stake in Sakhalin Energy Investment Co will raise its first-quarter profits by $95 million (S)

headline: Italians Vote To Send Force Into Albania
abstract: Italian Prime Min Romano Prodi wins approval from Parliament to send Italian-led multinational force to Albania, but at price that has seriously weakened his center-left coalition; lower house endorses UN-mandated mission after center-right opposition joined Government in patching together compromise intended to avert further damage to Italy's international credibility (M)

headline: The battle of summer blockbusters extends from theaters to fast-food chains to grocery aisles.
abstract: Advertising column on battle shaping up among fast-food restaurants, cereal merchants, confectioners and even auto makers who have tied their fortunes briefly to summer movie releases, cross-promoting their products with that film's insignia or characters, in hope of stealing market share from competitors; for studios, such tie-ins have no disadvantages; but it is difficult to find benefits for every promotional partner in each deal, particularly if movie flops (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Wachovia to Buy Bank In Virginia for $2.3 Billion  Wachovia, a bank company based in Winston-Salem, N.C., and Atlanta, agreed to buy Central Fidelity Banks of Richmond for $2.3 billion in a tax-free exchange of stock.    Two weeks ago, Wachovia agreed to buy Jefferson Bankshares of Charlottesville, Va., for $542 million in stock. The two deals will give Wachovia a leading presence in Virginia, with nearly $10 billion in deposits. $(Page D2.$)

headline: Should You Roll Out the Welcome Mat for HDTV?
abstract: Implications for consumers of planned transition to high-definition television discussed; broadcasters will continue to make programming available for at least nine years on existing channels, while broadcasting new, digital programming on second channel lent them by Government; table; graphs; drawing (M)

headline: Central Americans Feel Sting Of New U.S. Immigration Law
abstract: Many Central Americans who sought refuge in United States during 1980's are being told, as result of new immigration law that went into effect April 1, that hey must return to land of their birth; for poor countries such as El Salvador, still struggling to recover from civil wars, prospect of having to accommodate returnees--have having to do without money they send home--causes consternation; many of those who fled El Salvador, for example, have now lived in United States for up to 15 years, and have children born in US; they include applicants for political asylum, those seeking permanent residency by other means and some who still live clandestinely after entering country illegally or overstaying their visas; photo; map-table shows estimated number of illegal aliens in United States from selected countries (M)

headline: IVACO SELLS 138-ACRE ATLANTA PARCEL FOR $76 MILLION
abstract: Ivaco Inc, Canadian steelmaker, agrees to sell 138-acre property in midtown Atlanta, Ga, to Jacoby Development Inc for $76 million; Jacoby Development wants to use property as resident-commercial establishments (S)

headline: ROCKWELL TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF VIDEO AND DATA CHIPS
abstract: Rockwell International Corp will buy Comstream Corp's Hi-Media semiconductor unit, which develops video and data chips for direct-broadcast satellite and cable television companies, for $50 million (S)

headline: Simon & Schuster Recalls Books, Easing Muslim Anger
abstract: Simon & Shuster moves to recall more than 4,000 copies of children's book that portrays prophet Muhammad, founder of Islam, as man who despised Jews and Christians and took pleasure in beheadings; Council on American-Islamic Relations had complained to publisher about this portrait in its book, Great Lives: World Religions, written by William Jay Jacobs; publisher offers apologies and admits factual errors existed in chapter; photo (M)

headline: PLM STUDIES PROPOSAL FOR BID FROM EQUIS FINANCIAL
abstract: PLM International Inc is considering proposal to be acquired by Equis Financial Group for about $46 million (S)

headline: Bond Prices Little Changed On a Shortened Trading Day
abstract: Treasury prices are little changed in shortened trading session ahead of three-day holiday weekend (S)

headline: Not All Plastic Is Created Equal When It Comes to Renting a Car
abstract: Big Car rental companies, including Hertz and Avis, have stopped letting people rent cars using just Visa Check card or similar Master Money card from Mastercard; card companies, and banks that issue these debit cards are furious; car rental companies have used possession of credit card as crude way to weed out potentially risky renters; this test does not work with debit cards, because banks will now give them to nearly anyone with bank account; Hertz spokeswoman Lisa LoManto says debit cards 'provide no qualification of creditworthiness'; graph; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.00   5.34   5.38        3-MO.
