headline: AMERICAN TOPICS
abstract: An effort to discourage a naked soccer game at Luther College in Decorah, Iowa, led to an arrest and even more nakedness. There were no goals and, at times, no soccer ball as 200 students, many of them unclad, celebrated the end of final exams. Mirsad Zahirovic, a computer science major, was arrested after he tried to stop a police officer from videotaping the game. The arrest angered the crowd, prompting some clothed students to surround the officer, and others to doff their clothes. A wild scene — but, then, the place is called Decorah, not Decorum.

headline: VW Shares Up Again On Earnings Report
abstract: Shares of Volkswagen AG reach record highs as details on 1996 earnings show that company was more profitable than investors had thought; VW's earnings climb to 55 marks ($32) a share in 1996 from 22 marks (S)

headline: BELCO OIL GETS 14.9% STAKE IN HUGOTON ENERGY
abstract: Belco Oil & Gas Corp acquires 14.9 percent stake in Hugoton Energy Corp, for about $31 million (S)

headline: Weak Yen Aids Unexpected Profit for Nissan
abstract: The Nissan Motor Company reported group net income for its latest 12-month period today -- the first time in five years that it has been profitable.    Results for the company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, were lifted by the yen's weakness, cost reductions and stronger sales in Mexico. Still, analysts noted that sales were not growing in Japan, Nissan's biggest market, and that the company was continuing to chip away at a debt  burden that caused significant problems in the early 1990's.

headline: Henry Hyde Is Dead at 82; Wartime Spymaster for O.S.S.
abstract: Henry Baldwin Hyde, lawyer and onetime American spymaster who helped pave way for Allied landings in France, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BORLAND INTERNATIONAL INC., Scotts Valley, Calif., named Kathleen Fisher chief financial officer, succeeding Paul Emery, who left the company.    GLOBAL MARINE INC., Houston, promoted John G. Ryan to president and chief operating officer, replacing C. Russell Luigs, who continues as chairman and chief executive. The company also named Gary L. Kott to succeed Jerry C. Martin, who is retiring as chief financial officer and senior vice president.

headline: Schering-Plough and Lilly Sign Liver Drug Deals
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp and Eli Lilly & Co each sign deals with small biotechnology companies to co-develop drugs for treatment of hepatitis C; Schering's agreement, with Corvas International Inc, and Lilly's with Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc, apply to discovery and production of drugs that could block action of protease, natural enzyme that virus uses to replicate itself (M)

headline: Monetary Union at Risk In Italy's Flat Economy
abstract: Preliminary data show Italy's gross domestic product fell 0.3 percent in first quarter from previous quarter and 0.5 percent from year-earlier period, threatening nation's hopes for entry into European monetary union (S)

headline: Seeking to Jump-Start Leasing, G.M. Cuts Prices on Electric Car
abstract: General Motors Corp, in effort to bolster flagging lease rates of the EV1, limited-range electric car introduced in Southern California and Arizona last December, lowers effective cost 25 percent and agrees to partly finance quick construction of 50 public charging stations (S)

headline: For Hong Hong Pranksters, a Quick Retreat
abstract: Reporter's Notebook vignettes of goings-on in Hong Kong, week before British colony reverts to Chinese rule; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.63   5.23        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.93   4.93   5.07        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.17   5.22   5.20        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.55   3.57   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.61   6.66   6.84        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.86   6.90   7.00        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.90   7.95   8.12        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.72   5.73   6.11          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Electrolux Says Profit Fell 14% in Quarter
abstract: Electrolux AB says pretax profit fell more-than-expected 14 percent in first quarter; pretax profit fell to 777 million kronor ($100 million), from 901 million in year-earlier period; sales rose 4 percent, to 28.715 billion kronor (S)

headline: Russia and West Sign Cooperation Pact
abstract: Opening a new chapter in the post-World War II history of Europe, President Clinton and other NATO leaders joined President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today in signing a ''Founding Act'' of mutual cooperation and security between the alliance and its former principal adversary.    Hammered out in six months of difficult negotiations, the accord is intended by the allies to reassure Russia that it has nothing to fear from NATO's plan to expand eastward at the end of the century to take in new members from Central and Eastern Europe that once were allied with Moscow in the Warsaw Pact.

headline: LEFT WINS STRONG MANDATE AS VOTERS IN FRANCE REJECT AUSTERITY IN FAVOR OF JOBS
abstract: In a stunning rejection of President Jacques Chirac's economic austerity policies, French voters on Sunday  gave the Socialist Party and its Communist allies a mandate to form a Government that would make jobs its absolute priority for the next five years.    Mr. Chirac called the parliamentary elections a year ahead of schedule, appealing to voters to allow his conservative coalition to keep reducing budget deficits and government spending so France could qualify for membership in a new common European currency by the end of the century.

headline: Using the World Wide Web to Enhance Music Compact Disks
abstract: Sony Music and Bertelsmann's BMG Entertainment North American unit are trying to revive idea of multimedia disk, compact disks that can be played in standard audio CD player or placed in personal computer for multimedia features; Sony will retroactively enhance CD's by using World Wide Web sites to link multimedia content to existing disks; BMG will have users log onto America Online to add multimedia enhancement to new CD's; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: OMNICARE INC., Cincinnati, a provider of pharmacy services to long-term- care institutions, agreed to acquire EBA Pharmacy Inc., Chicago, and Sun Health Inc., Hartford, both privately owned institutional pharmacy providers. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  Big retailers that extend credit to customers have something in common with banks: bad debt is on the rise. By Jennifer Steinhauer.    INVESTING IT /Page 5/  If you're looking for stocks that are cheap, you might try some blue chips from Latin America. By Larry Dignan.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 7/  Want to put aside some money for college in, say, 10 years? American Century-Twentieth Century Giftrust and a newer fund, Royce Gift Shares, offer a way. By Juliette Fairley.    SPENDING IT /Page 9/  The I.R.S. is cracking down on trusts that it considers abusive, or that are created solely to avoid taxes. By Jan M. Rosen.

headline: Here it comes, driving down the street, it's the new La Quinta Inns hotel room.
abstract: Advertising column describes campaign for La Quinta Inns that is intended to showcase company's overhaul of almost every room in the chain; campaign was produced by Publicis/Bloom (M)

headline: G.M. Is Trying to Make a Go Of Its Electric Car
abstract: General Motors Corp, which introduced country's first mass-produced electric vehicle in Southern California and Arizona five months ago, says demand is lackluster at best; GM has found just 176 takers for its New Age $34,000 two-seater, known as the EV1; GM is carefully managing initial leasing of EV1's--the cars are not available for purchase--to make sure the first batch of customers like what they get; result has been that many EV1 drivers tend to be electric car enthusiasts who have been wanting for such a vehicle for years; GM's screening process for potential customers discussed; graph; photos (L)

headline: U.S. SURGICAL SHARES SLIDE AFTER PATENT CASE RULING
abstract: Shares of US Surgical Corp fall 7 percent afer jury rules against it in patent case; Applied Medical Resources Corp sued US Surgical over company's trocar products, hollow tubes used for minimally invasive surgery (S)

headline: Either Way, Lineup Is Mostly Set
abstract: When US Supreme Court ruled that cable operators must continue to carry broadcast stations on their systems, broadcasters gloated while their cable counterparts scrambled to rationalize a defeat; ruling is neither as big a victory nor as crushing setback as the years of legal skirmishing would suggest; cable executives had originally pushed for 'must carry' rules to be scrapped because they argued that in a world of proliferating distribution outlets, it was unconstitutional for Government to require that cable companies give broadcasters space on their systems; even if rules had been overturned, several cable executives said it would have made little difference in lineup of channels now available to cable subscribers (L)

headline: A New Generation of Treatments For Cancer Will Soon Reach Market
abstract: Biotechnology industry is poised to deliver a host of cancer drugs in next two to three years; some of drugs promise to extend lives--or at least make treatment more bearable than chemotherapy and radiation; more than 30 such drugs are in third and final phase of clinical trials typically required for Food and Drug Administration approval, more than ever before; by end of 1998, oncologists could have new nontoxic drug for treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system; in 1998, therapeutic vaccine for malignant melanoma that is as effective as chemotherapy but with none of side effects could reach the market; so could safe and effective drugs for metastatic breast cancer and inoperable brain cancers; chart; photos (L)

headline: Cable Deal Creates Not-So-Odd Couple
abstract: At first glance, a deal between Rupert Murdoch and Pat Robertson may appear to be a marriage of the sacred and the profane.    Indeed, Mr. Robertson, known for ''The 700 Club'' Christian talk show, once called for an advertising boycott of a show on Mr. Murdoch's Fox Network. But Mr. Murdoch has agreed to pay $1.9 billion to acquire the Family Channel, home to ''The 700 Club.''

headline: KAYDON TO BUY MAKER OF CYLINDERS FOR $22 MILLION
abstract: Kaydon Corp agrees to buy Great Bend Industries for $22 million (S)

headline: Bond Prices Recover From Early Losses
abstract: US bond prices recover from early losses; 30-year Treasury bond slips 1/32 to price of 96 28/32, to yield 6.88 percent, unchanged from May 2; graph (L)

headline: Digital's Suit Against Intel: Planning for the Next War
abstract: Analysis: Digital Equipment Corp's suit charging that Intel Corp violated Digital's patents is surprising only because Digital did not first try to squeeze some licensing payments out of Intel; this is route most companies go in such disputes, which have become increasingly common as number of computing applications patents has surged (M)

headline: Lazard to Start Investment Fund
abstract: Lazard Freres & Co plans to raise $125 million for private equity fund, becoming latest investment bank to add merchant banking unit; Thomas Lynch will head the fund (S)

headline: READER'S DIGEST STOCK FALLS 12% ON EARNINGS REPORT
abstract: Stock of Reader's Digest Association Inc falls 12 percent after company says its fiscal third-quarter earnings will be below Wall Street's expectations; stock drops $4, to $28.75 a share (S)

headline: U.S. Lawyer for Salinas Scorns Swiss Assertions of Drug Link
abstract: Stanley S Arkin, lawyer for Raul Salinas de Gortari, disputes assertions by Swiss prosecutors that his client accepted millions of dollars to protect shipments of narcotics traffickers; Salinas is brother of former Mexican Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari (M)

headline: Microsoft Poses a Riddle For the Street
abstract: Market Place column on Microsoft Corp; says every quarter, in post-earnings conference call with analysts, Microsoft offers medley of cautions: growth will slow; multiple is too high; comparisons with prior year will be tough; but almost nobody listens; Microsoft's closing share price on June 4 of $119.1875 is a remarkable 45 times estimated fiscal year 1997 earnings of $2.63 a share, giving company market capitalization of $142.8 billion; perhaps main reason that Microsoft shares remain so high is that every quarter, management's warnings notwithstanding, the company blows past analyst estimates; graph (L)

headline: Seagram Sells a Major Part Of Its Stake in Time Warner
abstract: Seagram Co sells 30 million Time Warner Inc shares, or more than half its holding, for $1.39 billion (M)

headline: Spain's Government Joins Soccer-Tinged TV Fight
abstract: Grupo Prisa, Spain's largest private media company, and Spanish Government are at odds over who will control country's pay-television industry; Government has promoted legislation aimed at curbing Grupo Prisa's advantages as it tries to provide more television channels; Government supports Prisa's main rival, consortium consisting of Telefonica, Spain's telephone monopoly, Television Espanola, Government-owned television network, and Televisa, a Mexican broadcasting company; for many Spaniards, dispute comes down to who controls broadcast rights of the professional soccer league; photos (L)

headline: Court Allows Barney's Breakup Fee Plan
abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Judge James L Garrity, in effort to attract higher bids for Barney's, approves deal that will allow retailer to offer $8.5 million breakup fee to potential suitor (M)

headline: LVMH Move May Hamper Guinness Plan
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA plans to buy Guinness PLC's half of jointly owned distribution venture, a step that could complicate $20 billion merger of Guinness with Grand Metropolitan PLC; purchase by LVMH of Guinness's 50 percent stake in the venture would give it distribution rights for most Guinness products in US, France and Asia for at least 10 years; that would deny combined Grand Met-Guinness the profit and marketing muscle that flows from controlling distribution channels by key markets; Guiness and Grand Met assert that LVMH cannot exercise its option because control of Guinness is not changing (L)

headline: The Federal Government will allow a group of companies to unify administration of 27 patents.
abstract: Justice Department will allow consortium of 8 companies and Columbia University to combine 27 patents into single portfolio and license inventions under direction of one administrator; this is first time antitrust division has approved such a patent clearinghouse; patents relate to technology known as MPEG-2 for compressing digital video and audio data; technology squeezes large amounts of data into digital transmissions by limiting information that must be sent contiguously (M)

headline: Barnes & Noble Set to Open Its On-Line Service
abstract: Barnes & Noble Inc, nation's largest bookselling chain, is set to open new electronic bookstore that will offer discounts that are more generous than its superstore bargains; new World Wide Web site will become available for general use on Internet by end of May (S)

headline: EX-S.E.C. Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Stock Fraud
abstract: James W Nearen, former lawyer for Securities and Exchange Commission, pleads guilty to criminal charges of securities fraud and money laundering; US Attorney Zachary W Carter says Nearen conspired with Federal prosecutor Andrew S Pitt in far-reaching scheme to inflate prices of publicly traded stocks; assistant US attorney Mark Ressler says while Nearen was working as legal counsel to Comprehensive Environmental Systems Inc and Alter Sales Co, he prepared false reports about the companies and disclosed nonpublic information about Comprehensive obtained while he worked for SEC (M)

headline: In Vietnam, 'Hanoi Hilton' Brick Links Past and Future
abstract: US State Sec Madeleine K Albright visits Hanoi, Vietnam; Pete Peterson, first American Ambassador to Vietnam since end of Vietnam War in 1965, gives Albright gift of a brick, mounted on wood, from 'Hanoi Hilton,' where he spent more than six years as prisoner of war, and which is now being turned into luxury block of apartments and stores by Singapore company; Albright is trying to solidify political and economic relationship with a Vietnam that has shed its Chinese and Russian allies and now joined Assn of Southeast Asian Nations; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Report Says Swiss Reneged On Accord to Return Nazi Gold
abstract: United States Government report holds Swiss Government deliberately failed to respect 1946 accord to return hundreds of millions of dollars in assets Nazi Germany looted from European banks and Holocaust victims; faults US for 'lack of attention' and lack of will and for giving up leverage by unfreezing Swiss assets in US; holds Swiss bankers' indifference to needs of Holocaust victims and their heirs persisted until international pressure in past year forced Switzerland to offer fraction of nation's profits from war as reparations; says small but significant fraction of monetary gold included jewelry and gold teeth-fillings stolen from Holocaust victims but finds no evidence that Swiss banks knew of gold's gruesome origins; 11 US agencies helped compile report, which makes no policy recommendations; photo (M)

headline: Computers May Soon Use Your Voice to Say Anything
abstract: Researchers are developing electronic impersonators--computer systems that can speak in a particular person's voice; systems start with actual recording of person and break it down into individual sounds; computers can then string sound elements together in new sequences to utter sentences in person's voice that person never actually said; this new technology, being developed by ATR Interpreting Telecommunications Research Laboratories in Japan and elsewhere, are aimed not at impersonation but at improving quality of synthetic speech; but technology could have many nefarious uses, such as framing or blackmailing someone with fake 'recording'; new legal questions are likely to arise over extent to which voices can be protected from exploitation by others; drawings; photos (M)

headline: STATE OF CALIFORNIA SUES BANKAMERICA OVER TRUST FUNDS
abstract: California Attorney General Dan Lungren sues BankAmerica Corp, accusing it of cheating state and local governments out of hundreds of millions of dollars by mishandling their bond fund trust account; suit accuses bank of conspiracy, unfair business practices and breach of contract, among other claims (S)

headline: Buy High, Sell Low, Report Big Profits
abstract: Market Watch column says annual reports for 1997 will calculate earnings per share differently than in past; no longer will they adjust number of shares for options that are outstanding and worth exercising because they allow purchase of stock below market value; result is that companies that issue many options to executives will not have to show any expense for value of options, or have to consider options in calculating earnings per share; but companies are required to estimate impact on earnings if value of options given out to employees had been treated as an expense (M)

headline: Sold on the Simple I.R.A.
abstract: Funds Watch column on T Rowe Price's Simple individual retirement accounts, under new law intended to encourage small businesses to add pensions plans by easing administrative burdens (S)

headline: HACH TO REPURCHASE SHARES FROM LAWTER INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Hach Company is buying back 3.16 million shares, or 28 percent of its shares, from Lawter International Inc for about $60 million (S)

headline: A Kremlin Telltale Expose From the Provinces
abstract: Interview with Boris Nemtsov, popular Governor of Nizhny Novgorod, who was appointed First Deputy Prime Minister in charge of free-market reform, and has become shining star of Kremlin's new economic team headed by Anatoly B Chubais; Russian publishing house will imminently release his book, A Provincial Man, in which he discusses experiences as Governor and makes acid assessments of his new superiors in Moscow; photo (M)

headline: Wheat Prices Surge the Limit As Freeze Hits Sprouting Crop
abstract: Wheat futures prices surge daily trading limit on Chicago Board of Trade, reaching six-month high after reports that weekend freeze in Midwest damaged sprouting winter wheat crop (M)

headline: U.S. Seizes $5.6 Million Hidden in a Truck on Way to Mexico
abstract: US Customs inspectors seize $5.6 million hidden in false ceiling of truck about to cross into Mexico from El Paso in largest cash seizure in memory along Southwest border; believe money was probably proceeds from street sales of drugs, and is part of river of cash flowing south into Mexico from US drug marketplaces (M)

headline: First-Quarter Growth Rate Rose to 5.8%
abstract: Commerce Department reports Gross Domestic Product rose at 5.8 percent annual rate in first quarter, up from earlier estimate of 5.6 percent; reports new home sales fell 7.7 percent in Apr, to annual pace of 772,000; graphs (M)

headline: Yeltsin Signs Peace Treaty With Chechnya
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin, in bid to normalize relations without resolving fundamental dispute, signs peace treaty with Chechen leaders that both sides describe as end of centuries-old conflict between Russia and rebellious region of Caucasus; Yeltsin says agreement is of historic importance; vows never to use force or threaten to use it against Chechnya; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Kraft Foods, White Plains, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, to FCB Direct, New York, a unit of True North Communications, to handle direct marketing for its Gevalia Kaffe business, which had been handled by Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam. Billings estimated at $10 million.

headline: People
abstract: * Martin F. Reidy, chief operating officer at R/GA Digital Studios, New York, part of True North Communications, was named to the additional new position of president.

headline: Thailand's Long-Term Credit Rating Lowered
abstract: Moody's Investors Service lowers its long-term credit rating on Thailand, sharp new confirmation that country has run into tough economic times; Moody's says Thailand's unstable, personality-based coalition governments are poorly suited to address host of current problems; Thailand's export-led economy has slowed sharply, its current-account deficit has swelled, property prices have plummeted and financial institutions have faced embarrassing cash shortage; foreign economists say economic downturn could prompt tighter, sounder management of economy (M)

headline: Philip Morris Earnings Climb 13.3% in First Quarter Report
abstract: Philip Morris Companies reports net income rose 13.3 percent, to $1.77 billion in first quarter from $1.57 billion in year-earlier quarter; says revenue grew 4.2 percent, to $18.2 billion, from $17.5 billion in comparable quarter last year; table (L)

headline: Sisters and Censors
abstract: Comment on film scene in Hong Kong, which has been third only to Hollywood and India's Bollywood in churning out movies; Hollywood blockbusters have taken over top of box-office charts, but current hit is Mabel Cheung's film The Soong Sisters, about three Chinese women who married central figures in China's twentieth-century history; Cheung comments on heavy censorship by authorities in China, where film was shot; her photo (S)

headline: CLINTON MOBILIZES BIPARTISAN EFFORT ON CHEMICAL ARMS
abstract: Pres Clinton, with deadline looming, begins last, late push to win Senate ratification of treaty to ban chemical weapons, orchestrating a public display of bipartisan support while aides work behind the scenes to win over conservative opponents; appearing on South Lawn of White House with such prominent Republican figures as James A Baker 3d and Colin L Powell, Clinton declares that United State would 'go from leading the world to joining the company of pariah nations' if Senate does not ratify treaty; treaty, known as Chemical Weapons Convention, prohibits development, production, stockpiling and use of poison gas; ratified now by 70 nations, it takes effect on April 29--with or without United States' participation, something that Administration insists is crucial to its ultimate success; treaty remains blocked by Sen Jesse Helms, chmn of Senate Committee on Foreign Relations (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BANKAMERICA CORP., San Francisco, named Christine Garvey to head its Commercial Real Estate Services Group. Ms. Garvey, a group executive vice president, will oversee credit and other financial services for real estate developers, investors, pension fund advisers, real estate investment trusts and property managers.     MEAD JOHNSON NUTRITIONALS, Evansville, Ind., a unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb Company that manufactures infant formulas, medical nutritionals and consumer nutritional products, named Ian Stuart president.

headline: Taco Bell Chief Taking Skills At Turnaround To Blockbuster
abstract: Viacom Inc names James F Antioco, chief executive of Pepsico's Taco Bell restaurant chain, as new chief executive of Blockbuster Entertainment; Antioco will replace Bill Fields, who resigned in April; several analysts question whether anyone will be able to restore sizzling growth Blockbuster enjoyed under its founder H Wayne Huizenga (L)

headline: ICI Australia Shares Drop Sharply
abstract: Shares of ICI Australia Ltd plunge after company's parent, Imperial Chemicals Industries PLC, says it will sell its 62.4 percent stake in its Australian subsidiary (S)

headline: Virgin Group to Sell Two Radio Stations
abstract: Capital Radio PLC agrees to buy Virgin Radio Holdings for 86.7 million pounds ($140.5 million) in stock and assumed debt, giving it two more music radio stations and bigger share of London market; adding Virgin's London-based rock music FM license and national AM contemporary music license will allow Capital Radio to reach 38 percent of London market (S)

headline: Why Some Auditors Like the Taste of Leftovers
abstract: BDO Seidman, ninth-largest accounting firm in US, has emerged as national firm that has inherited greatest number of castoff companies; from January 1994 through early June, BDO was hired by companies representing 43 of 546 resignations tracked by Public Accounting Report; table (L)

headline: LAYNE CHRISTENSEN OFFERS TO BUY AUSTRALIAN COMPANY
abstract: Layne Christensen Co offers $52 million to acquire Stanley Mining Services Ltd of Australia (S)

headline: Checking the Flow Of Electronic Ripples
abstract: Building engineers and electrical contractors are concerned about problems caused by renegade electrical frequencies known as harmonics; within electrical systems, addition of more and more electrical equipment, particulary computers, creates amplified electrical ripples called harmonics; these can produce electrical overloads that can burn through wires or cause explosions like one in Nagoya City Science Museum in Japan in 1994; harmonics detection equipment and harmonics filtering devices are selling well as awareness spreads about the problem; diagrams (M)

headline: Clinton and Mexico Chief Pledge Joint Effort on Border and Drugs
abstract: Pres Clinton and Pres Ernesto Zedillo end two days of meetings, Mexico City, with joint statements on managing border and fighting illegal drugs; stress close cooperation and shared goals but propose no novel solutions; Administration aides say accords are aimed at improving ties and reassuring Mexico that it is respected partner; cite rising anti-Americanism; photos (M)

headline: Digital Hints at Antitrust Suit Against Intel
abstract: As a legal battle between the Intel Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation escalates over what Digital contends is a violation of its patents, the next phase could be an antitrust suit filed against Intel by Digital.    At least that is what Thomas C. Siekman, vice president and general counsel for Digital, strongly implied in a previously undisclosed letter to his counterpart at Intel last week.

headline: Nike's Shares Tumble After Profit Forecast
abstract: Shares of Nike Inc fall 13 percent after announcement by the company that its quarterly earnings will be below expectations because of disappointing sales and factory shutdown; shares close at $55.375, down $8.625 (M)

headline: Platinum and Palladium Soar As Russia Delays Shipments
abstract: Futures prices for platinum and palladium jump after Russia delays exports, keeping stockpiles low (S)

headline: Ziff-Davis to Acquire Stake in Herring
abstract: Ziff-Davis and Herring Communications agree on strategic relationship in which Ziff would make minority investment in Herring, privately held publisher of The Red Herring magazine (S)

headline: A Father, a Friend, a Seller of Cyberporn
abstract: Joe Warshowsky runs lucrative live pornography site on World Wide Web called Video Fantasy, where young women disrobe and pose for digital voyeurs who pay service $5.95 a minute; pornography has become one of Internet's main growth engines, with as many as 10,000 Web sites; trade publications see it as $1 billion business; Warshowsky says Video Fantasy verifies age of each of its 20,000 customers, to keep minors away; photo (M)

headline: Want the Fast Lane? Try Russia
abstract: Russia is undisputed leader in worldwide market for stock; newest emerging markets, with all their volatility, are enjoying burst of growth, while established markets, as in Japan, are generally languishing, at least for anyone buying in dollars; photo; charts (M)

headline: Pretax Profits Plunge For Imperial Chemical
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries PLC says first-quarter profit before tax fell to 65 million pounds, about $105.3 million, from 202 million pounds a year ago (S)

headline: Army Renews Pact With Y.& R.
abstract: United States Army renews its advertising and marketing pact with Young & Rubicam Advertising for another five-year term (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $100 million of notes due in 1998 through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. The notes are callable quarterly beginning Aug. 5, 1997, carry an interest rate of 6.21 percent payable at maturity and are priced at par.    * Fannie Mae is selling $1 billion of six-month and three-year debentures in two-parts. The first part is $600 million of debentures due on Oct. 16, 1997, carrying an interest rate of 5.79 percent and priced at par. The second part is $400 million of debentures due in 2000 and priced at 99.988 to yield 6.864 percent.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: Domino's Pizza Inc, which operates 560 stores in 54 countries, says it plans to open 300 stores in 1997, about 250 in international markets and 50 in United States (S)

headline: NETANYAHU FIGHTS REPORT BY POLICE
abstract: Israeli Prime Benjamin Netanyahu goes on counteroffensive against police recommendations that he be indicted for breach of public trust; initial shock of disclosure that Netanyahu has been implicated by police in what has come to be called 'Bar-On Affair' is followed by widespread questioning of gravity of charges, especially after senior police officers confirm that their recommendation is based on testimony of one witness; affair is centered on allegations that Netanyahu appointed lawyer named Roni Bar-On as Attorney General last Jan under pressure from influential member of his coalition, Aryeh Deri, who evidently expected appointment to help him in his corruption trial; Bar-on resigned after one day following complaints that he was unqualified (M)

headline: COLLINS & AIKMAN TO SELL A FABRICS UNIT FOR $310 MILLION
abstract: Collins & Aikman Corp agrees to sell its flat-woven upholstery fabrics unit, Mastercraft Group, to Joan Fabrics Corp for $310 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NESTLE S.A., Vevey, Switzerland, said it did not exercise an option to buy a million newly issued shares in Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream, Oakland, Calif.     ONCOR INC., Gaithersburg, Md., said it had hired Lehman Brothers Inc. to explore strategic alternatives, including the possible sale of the company.

headline: MONTGOMERY WARD TO DISMISS 400 AT HEADQUARTERS
abstract: Montgomery Ward Holding Corp will dismiss 400 workers, or 20 percent of staff, at its Chicago corporate headquarters (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: A chart last Sunday with an article about buying a high-definition television set referred incorrectly to the types of digital televisions that are expected to be priced at $2,500 to more than $10,000. That is the expected range for all digital sets of any size, not those with 31-inch screens.

headline: Clinton Appoints Holbrooke as His Special Envoy for Cyprus
abstract: Pres Clinton names Richard C Holbrooke, key figure in negotiating end to Bosnian civil war, special presidential envoy for Cyprus; appointment is sign or renewed American seriousness in trying to reach political settlement in Cyprus, which has been divided between Greek and Turk Cypriots since 1974 Turkish invasion (M)

headline: Fed Meeting Gives Bonds A Modest Lift
abstract: US Treasury prices rise modestly; price of 30-year bond rises 7/32, to 96 18/32; yield slips to 6.90 percent from 6.92 percent on May 19; graph (L)ï

headline: FILENET TO TAKE $6 MILLION CHARGE TO CLOSE OFFICE
abstract: Filenet Corp will take $6 million pretax charge in second quarter to dismiss 10 percent of its workers and close its office in Burlington, Mass; about 150 people will lose their jobs (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: Hewlett in $1.15 Billion Deal For Maker of Credit Card Devices
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co agrees to acquire Verifone Inc, leading maker of credit card authorization devices, in stock swap valued at $1.15 billion; Hewlett-Packard executives say Verifone is natural addition to company's strategy of seeking to use the Internet to spread organization's reach beyond its own walls (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: Is U.S. Too Poor to Join the New Germany's Fun?
abstract: Architects say plan to build new American Embassy in Berlin on site of Washington's prewar embassy is on hold because of shortage of money; plan is to finance embassy construction from sale of other American-owned properties in Germany, but money from other transactions has been trickling in slowly; photo; map (M)

headline: Autistics, freed from face-to-face encounters, are communicating in cyberspace.
abstract: Many of nation's autistics are on the Internet; they find they are able to communicate when freed from face-to-face encounters; many subscribe to Independent Living, suite of E-mail forums created by and almost exclusively for autistics (M)

headline: Treasury's Schedule of Auctions Is Limited to Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.91 percent and a six-month bill was 5.15 percent.

headline: U.S. Withholds Approval of Utility Merger
abstract: A Federal regulatory agency told two utilities in the upper Midwest yesterday that it would withhold approval of their merger agreement as it is now structured, saying that it would give them too much dominance over the electricity market in their regions.    The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission did not reject outright the merger, between the Wisconsin Energy Corporation and Northern States Power, which was announced in 1995. It said they could draw up a plan over the next three months to sell some of their generating plants and resubmit the merger for consideration.

headline: An Uneasy First Encounter in France's Political 'Cohabitation'
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac presides over first session of France's new Socialist-led Government; says he hopes that power-sharing will be rooted in mutual respect; Prime Ministser Lionel Jospin says he has briefly outlined his Government's plan to stimulate economic growth and create jobs to bring down 12.8 percent unemployment rate (M)

headline: People
abstract: * David Arnold, New York manager for advertising at Town & Country magazine, New York, published by the Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corp., was promoted to the long-vacant position of advertising director.

headline: Ford Plans Zero-Emission Fuel Cell Car
abstract: Energy Department says Ford Motor Co plans to build prototype electric car that gets its power from a fuel cell rather than from batteries; car will carry compressed hydrogen gas, which the fuel cell will mix with oxygen from the air to make water in low-temperature chemical reaction that also gives off electric current; Canadian Government says it will subsidize Ballard Power Systems Inc to build fuel cell that can be used in Ford vehicle (M)

headline: Talks to Buy Dillon, Read Are Ended by Dutch Suitor
abstract: The ING Groep said yesterday that it had withdrawn from talks to buy Dillon, Read & Company because the two companies could not agree on how to combine their businesses.    Now that the discussions with ING have ended, Dillon, Read has begun talking with other parties, including the Swiss Bank Corporation, people close to the firm said late yesterday.

headline: Albright to Go to Hong Kong For Transfer of Rule to China
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright says she will represent United States in ceremonies marking return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule at invitation of Britain and China; discussed invitation with Martin Lee, democratic leader in Hong Kong, who urged her to attend; says US backs preservation of Hong Kong's autonomy, way of life and basic freedoms (M)

headline: New Rapport From India-Pakistan Meeting
abstract: Indian Prime Min I K Gujral and Pakistan Prime Min Nawaz Sharif meet in atmosphere of striking amiability, first such encounter in eight years, at conference of South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation in Maldives; vow to seek ways around deep enmities of past 50 years that have contributed to entrenched poverty of tens of millions of people; reach accord for release of approximately 400 prisoners held for offenses linked to estrangement between both countries, and for re-establishment of hot line between both Governments, which was cut in 1989 (M)

headline: Hot Markets Are Producing Cars For Domestic Buyers and Export
abstract: Auto executives around the world have concluded that Brazil and Argentina, which taken together make up 80 percent of South America's auto sales, represent even more lucrative market than Southeast Asia or Eastern Europe; American, European and Japanese car makers are pouring total of $18 billion into new South American factories, convinced that recent double-digit sales growth will continue; main reason for auto boom has been resurgence of economic growth in Brazil and Argentina; production plans for major automakers, including Ford Motor and Chrysler Corp, discussed; table; graph; photos (L)

headline: Sara Lee Selects Euro RSCG Worldwide
abstract: Sara Lee Corp has named Euro RSCG Worldwide, unit of Havas Advertising, to handle Wonderbra and Playtex products in Europe; billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million (S)

headline: Donaldson Unit's Duane Reade Stake
abstract: DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc unit, has taken $350 million stake in Duane Reade Holding Corp, becoming drugstore chain's largest shareholder (S)

headline: Thompson Chicago Quits Midas Account
abstract: J Walter Thompson Chicago will resign national advertising account of Midas International Corp, effective Aug 15, citing conflict with its important Ford Motor Co account (S)

headline: CBS to Run Its TV Stations Apart From Network
abstract: CBS, hoping to coax higher profits from its company-owned television stations, says that it will run stations separately from network for first time; move is part of management shake-up that gives sweeping new power to Mel Karmazin, executive whose main experience has been in radio; he is named chairman and chief executive of newly created CBS Station Group; Karmazin will oversee 14 television and 77 radio stations owned by CBS's parent, Westinghouse Electric Corp; television stations have been seen as performing below potential; photo of Peter A Lund, who resigned as president of CBS network amid far-reaching shakeup (M)

headline: Mohd al-Jamali, 94, of Iraq; A Founder of the Arab League
abstract: Mohd Fadhel al-Jamali, an Arab statesman who helped establish United Nations and the Arab League and was nearly hanged for his Western leanings after revolution in Iraq in 1958, died on May 24 at age 94 (M)Ø

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.43   5.37        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.92   4.92   5.11        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.06   5.05   5.25        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.63   3.63   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.38   6.38   6.95        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.68   6.68   7.10        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.76   7.76   8.15        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.58   5.59   6.12          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Rebel Army Captured Zaire In T-Shirts and Tennis Shoes
abstract: Triumph by Laurent Kabila's rebel forces in Zaire is a staggering accomplishment; rebels conquered territory as large as US east of Mississippi without mechanized divisions, heavy artillery or air force, and they lacked until late in war the engineering units to build bridges over raging rivers they had to cross; military analysts say Zairian Army of Pres Mobutu Sese Seko lost war as much as rebels won it since it was badly equipped, poorly trained and demoralized; photo; map (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: EQUITABLE COS., New York, named Stanley Tulin chief financial officer. He will remain chief financial officer of Equitable's main insurance unit, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. He succeeds Jerry de St. Paer, who left to join J. P. Morgan & Co.     GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP., Falls Church, Va., named James E. Turner Jr. president and chief operating officer.    LONE STAR INDUSTRIES, Stamford, Conn., named William Troutman, its president, to the additional position of chief executive, succeeding David Wallace, who remains chairman.     SALOMON BROTHERS INC., New York, named Nasser Malik to head its international structured finance group.

headline: Tools to Fix Space Station to Arrive in 2 Weeks
abstract: Russian space officials say that it will take two weeks to transport vital repair equipment to stricken Mir space station, which was seriously damaged when unmanned Progress cargo vessel slammed into it on June 25 (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks Delay of Loan To Croatia
abstract: Clinton Administration, signaling mounting frustration with Pres Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, says that US will try to block World Bank from considering $30 million loan for Croatia (M)

headline: Trying to Resolve Jurisdictional Rules On the Internet
abstract: Legal scholars disagree about how traditional law related to jurisdiction applies to cyberspace; Internet is indifferent to geographical boundaries, while legal systems are built on geographical boundaries; test case for issue is being debated in New York Appeals Court by two jazz clubs with same name: Blue Note in Greenwich Village and Blue Note nightclub in Missouri, both of whom have Internet Web sites; Blue Note in Missouri contends that he cannot control who sees his Web site; photos (M)

headline: EVERGREEN MEDIA TO BUY 5 RADIO STATIONS AND SELL 3
abstract: Evergreen Media Corp buys five radio stations from Gannett Co for $340 million and sells three radio stations to Bonneville International Corp for $205 million; sale is to satisfy antitrust concerns stemming from its planned $2.58 billion acquisition of Chancellor Broadcasting Co; Evergreen acquires WGCI-AM and WGCI-FM in Chicago, KHKS-FM in Dallas and KKBQ-AM and KKBQ-FM in Houston; it is selling WPNT-FM and WLUP-FM in Chicago and KDFC-FM in San Francisco (S)

headline: If It Looks Like HDTV, It Does Not Mean It Is
abstract: Number of major broadcast-television firms, seeking to delay investment in high-definition television equipment, have asked Yves Faroudja and his Faroudja Laboratories to produce equipment to improve resolution of standard broadcast-television signal and convert it to digital form; Faroudja makes line-doublers that improve quality of conventional television picture; diagrams; photos (M)

headline: Bell Atlantic Says Approval Near for Merger With Nynex
abstract: Justice Department has told Bell Atlantic Corp that it is unlikely to block its $22 billion merger with Nynex Corp; Joel Klein, acting chief of department's antitrust division, says department is leaning against suing companies on antitrust grounds (L)

headline: Texaco Picks BBDO For Product Work
abstract: Texaco Inc shifts responsibilities for product and retail advertising to BBDO Worldwide; billings estimated at $30 million to $4 million (S)

headline: GIANT INDUSTRIES TO BUY OR LEASE THRIFTWAY BUSINESSES
abstract: Giant Industries agrees to buy or lease 96 gas stations and convenience stores from Thriftway Marketing Corp, more than tripling number of stations and stores it controls (S)

headline: BUTLER MANUFACTURING TO SELL GRAIN SYSTEMS DIVISION
abstract: Butler Manufacturing Co agrees to sell its Grain Systems division to CTB Inc for $33 million (S)ê

headline: Griffin Bacal Wins 2 Reviews
abstract: Griffin Bacal Inc is awarded two advertising accounts, Feld Entertainment and K'nex Industries, with combined billings estimated at $18 million to $23 million (S)

headline: Time to Play?
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about what happens at work when boss goes on vacation; drawing

headline: In Berlin, Evidence of Private Swiss Banks' Role in Nazi Trade
abstract: German historian Monika Tatzkow, who helped disclose how Nazis moved stolen Jewish assets to Switzerland, has uncovered new evidence in archives of former East Germany that Swiss private banks helped German companies get badly needed convertible currency during World War II (M)

headline: Microsoft to Help Train Computer Workers
abstract: Microsoft Corp introduces program to recruit and train computer and software professionals, saying 190,000 American jobs are unfilled for lack of trained applicants (S)

headline: DAMES & MOORE/BROOKHILL BUYING SITES FOR $72 MILLION
abstract: Dames & Moore says its joint venture with Brookhill Group, Dames & Moore/Brookhill LLC, agrees to acquire 10 properties and mortgages of 14 other properties from failed Canadian insurer Confederation Life Insurance Co for $72 million; Confederation Life was seized by Canadian and US regulators in 1994 after company collapsed under weight of soured real estate loans (S)

headline: Santander to Acquire Argentine Bank Control
abstract: Banco Santander S.A. of Spain said yesterday that it would acquire control of Banco Rio de la Plata of Argentina for $594 million and eventually merge Banco Rio with its Argentine unit to create the country's biggest private bank. Santander will buy 35 percent of Banco Rio, Argentina's second-biggest private bank, from the billionaire businessman Jorge Gregorio Perez Companc, who in turn will get 6 percent of Banco Santander Chile. Santander will have 51 percent of the voting rights and will also assume management control.

headline: Irish Merchant Tells Inquiry Of Cash Gifts to Ex-Premier
abstract: Ben Dunne, former chief executive and part-owner of Dunnes Stores, Ireland's largest department store chain, tells Government tribunal he provided about $1.1 million for use of former Prime Min Charles J Haughey, after intermediary told him Haughey needed cash because he was in financial difficulties; will reportedly testify that he made additional payments for Haughey's use between 1988 and 1991, for total of almost $2 million; Haughey has reportedly denied allegations; scandal has thrown Irish politics into turmoil (M)

headline: Dollar Drops for a Sixth Day; Off 6% in Week Against Yen
abstract: US dollar declines against Japanese yen for sixth consecutive day; dollar is also weaker against German mark and other European currencies (M)

headline: Fidelity Index Funds Hire Outside Manager
abstract: Fidelity Investments hires Bankers Trust to manage its index mutual funds, marking first time company has sought outside group to manage fund assets (S)

headline: Big changes are in the offing for the nation's stock markets.
abstract: Market Place: Securities and Exchange Commission will issue what it calls concept release, setting forth broad ideas for changing the way it regulates stock markets and, possibly, making it easier for foreign stock markets to operate in US; proposals detailed (L)

headline: Israeli Linked To Iran Arms Ordered Jailed
abstract: Nahum Manbar, Israeli businessman living in Switzerland, was jailed after arriving in Israel in March, apparently on suspicion of arms sales to Iran (S)

headline: Clinton and Blair: Baby Boomers Unite
abstract: The ''New Democrat'' (Bill Clinton) met yesterday with the head of ''New Labor'' (Tony Blair) and celebrated the baby-boom generation as perfectly suited to lead a new era. One said the generation ''prefers reason to doctrine,'' and the other that ''yesterday's ideology'' has ended.    Article, page A3.

headline: Camry Teaches Economics 101: Features Are Nice but Price Sells
abstract: Toyota's redesigned 1997 Camry is reshaping US midsize car market, easily moving ahead of both Ford Taurus and Honda Accord to become nation's best-selling car in first five months of 1997; graph; lowered prices of $16,448 to $24,088, because of several manufacturing changes, have substantially narrowed premium that American buyers have had to pay for Japanese imports; whether Camry holds lead will depend on Toyota's ability to keep up production and endure political heat in US; price cut also forced other companies to offer cuts and incentives (M)

headline: Mass Mutual's Real Estate Deal
abstract: Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co says that its real estate unit has formed $330 million partnership to buy and own office buildings (S)

headline: Thanks to Marvel, Toy Biz Faces a Battle of the Boards
abstract: Battle for control of bankrupt Marvel Entertainment Group has spread to Toy Biz Inc, which has right to sell toys based on Marvel characters; Marvel owns Toy Biz stake and has right to appoint 8 of its 11 directors; bondholders who recently took control of Marvel say they have replace directors chosen by Marvel's former board; Toy Biz president Joseph M Ahearn says five directors linked to Ronald O Perelman, who formerly controlled Marvel, have resigned and will be replaced by remaining directors, not by Marvel (M)

headline: Look Who's Stealing Nebuchadnezzar's Thunder
abstract: Across southern Iraq, but especially in the rubbled remains of this city with its magical name, some mud bricks unearthed from the distant past still carry the mark of Nebuchadnezzar, the fabled Babylonian king. It was Nebuchadnezzar who wrested the ancient capital back from the Assyrians, repelled Persian intruders and captured Jerusalem, establishing Babylon in the sixth century B.C. as the largest and most glorious city in the world.    More than 2,500 years later, new bricks placed in Babylon's walls carry the same cuneiform script, but a very different inscription.

headline: Time Warner Stock Price Reaches $50
abstract: Time Warner Inc stock reaches all-time high of $50 a share; share price is what Paramount Communications offered Time Inc shareholders when it tried to break up Time-Warner merger; that bid became angry rallying cry for many shareholders who argued that Time Inc had no right to spurn all-cash offer for their company as opposed to a deal in which Time was to be the acquirer (S)

headline: New Accusation In Investigations Of Bear Stearns
abstract: Employee of Bear Stearns Companies has said executive of the firm told him to destroy documents that were sought by investigators examining relationship between Bear and A R Baron & Co, a defunct brokerage firm which cleared trades through Bear, according to correspondence between lawyers in the case; letters do not identify the executive, or complaining employee, but do indicate that executive holds title of managing director; letters also suggest that the employee may be among the witnesses who have been called to testify before grand jury under direction of Manhattan District Attorney Robert M Morgenthau's office, which is investigating Baron's collapse--and which is now also investigating employee's allegation; Mark E Lehman, executive vice president and chief counsel for Bear Stearns, confirms that the firm knew of employee's accusation; in related matter, Garvey Fox and Matthew Hirsch, former brokers at Baron, plead guilty, State Supreme Court, and indicate they are cooperating with Morgenthau's office; brokers are among 13 former Baron employees indicted on May 13 on state charges (L)

headline: A campaign urges gay men and lesbians to resist tobacco ads.
abstract: California Lavender Smoke-Free Project, coalition of gay men and lesbians from health advocacy organizations, is introducing tough-talking campaign financed by same cigarette tax that has paid since 1988 for aggressive antismoking ads aimed at all Californians; photo (L)

headline: Clinton and Gingrich View Hong Kong as Test for China
abstract: Pres Clinton says he is 'quite satisfied' with assurances on future of Hong Kong he received from Chinese Foreign Min Qian Qichen, but says he is waiting to see if China's words match its actions; House Speaker Newt Gingrich says China's favorable trading status depends upon how it handles British colony's transition to Chinese rule (M)s

headline: Kicking Troubles Down the Road
abstract: Craig R Whitney analysis contends that if any evidence is needed that European Union is near paralysis over how to change to bring its member countries into 21st century, Amsterdam Treaty that European leaders negotiated on June 18 provides it; maintains that treaty is more readable revision of controversial 1991 Maastricht treaty (M)

headline: Pakistani Reportedly Confesses to C.I.A. Killings
abstract: Law enforcement officials say Mir Amal Kansi, Pakistani under arrest for deadly rampage near Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters in 1993, confessed to attack to Federal agents who captured him (M)

headline: Tory Leader, in Election Gamble, Embraces an Anti-Europe Stance
abstract: Prime Min John Major, in move to invigorate his flagging re-election campaign, yields to increasingly vocal anti-European wing of his Conservative Party and declares his opposition to current proposals for Britain's integration into Europe; says his rival, Tony Blair, would sell out British interests to French and Germans if he became Prime Minister; says most of European Union treaties that will be discussed at summit meeting in Netherlands in June are 'unthinkable' for Britain; says Britain should take part in talks about proposed monetary union, even if ultimate decision is against joining (M)

headline: Many Iranians Hope Mandate Brings Change
abstract: Debate is under way throughout Iran about what election of Mohammed Khatami will mean; Iranians have never before so clearly rejected will of ruling Shiite Muslim clerics, in 18 years of Islamic rule; near-final results show that Khatami won 69 percent of vote, while mullahs' favorite, Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, took just 25 percent; Iranian businessmen hope that Khatami's openness will lead him to consider reshaping economic system, which is heavily state-oriented and not encouraging to private or foreign investors; Khatami is faced with intimidating restriction on his power: revolutionary Constitution places ultimate power in supreme leader, Ayatollah Khamenei; photo (M)

headline: The Memorial Day holiday seems to set the pace, with the big airlines expecting a strong summer.
abstract: Air travel over Memorial Day appears to have broken record for that holiday period, as Air Transport Association had forecast, and travel rest of summer seems headed for a record; Hilton Hotels Corp, American Express Co and IBM have teamed up in first test of smart cards in hotel industry and in first public use in US of separate applications performed by same computer chip; for next week or so, passengers bound for Washington on Amtrak Metroliner and Northeast Direct trains will find free guidebook in seat pockets of the trains--Rough Guide to Washington, DC; TWA will award 1,000 miles next month to any member of its frequent-flier program whose flight arrives late or who is booked on flight that is canceled after passengers boarded (L)

headline: Neo-Nazi Leader Gets Jail Term in South Africa
abstract: Eugene TerreBlanche, leader of South Africa's neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, receives six-year prison sentence for 1996 beating of one of his black workers caught eating on job; receives additional one-year sentence for setting dogs on gas station attendant two weeks before beating (S)

headline: Are Big Stocks Really Best?
abstract: Slump in small stocks, which badly underperformed big ones in last year, discussed; investors are taking money out of aggressive-growth mutual funds, most of which invest mainly in small stocks; graph (M)

headline: ENVIRODYNE HOLDERS REJECT ZAPATA NOMINEES TO BOARD
abstract: Shareholders of Envirodyne Industries elect company's slate of directors and reject three nominees from Zapata Corp, which is trying to gain control of Envirodyne (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.38   5.56   5.19        3-MO. headline: Philippine Volcano Still Remaking Land, and Lives
abstract: Mount Pinatubo, powerful Philippine volcano that erupted six years ago after 600 years of dormancy, continues to bury towns and drive people from homes, with yearly flows of sludge during rainy season; scientists say yearly inundations could continue for decade, wiping out more towns and cities; effects on Spanish-era city of Bacolor, 25 miles from mountain, described; photo; map (M)

headline: Thomas Ricketts, 66, Savings and Loan Executive
abstract: Thomas R Ricketts, chairman and chief executive of Standard Federal Bancorporation of Troy, Mich, dies at age 66 (M)

headline: Mazda Shows Improvement Under Ford's Leadership
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp, in sign of partial recovery, says that unconsolidated net profit soared in its first fiscal year under control of Ford Motor Co, although it still had operating loss; net profit comes partly from sale of securities; on consolidated basis, Mazda is expected to announce next week that its net loss widened to about 17 billion yen, or $137 million, from 11.9 billion yen year earlier; net income jumped to 6.11 billion yen, or $49.2 million using exchange rate of March 31 (M)

headline: Clinton Urges an Expanded U.S. Role in International Affairs
abstract: Pres Clinton, in first major foreign policy address of second term, calls for US to play more active role in world; urges Congress to approve treaty banning chemical weapons and give him more authority to negotiate trade agreement with Chile (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Picks Irish President to Be Top Aide on Human Rights
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan names Pres Mary Robinson of Ireland as his new High Commissioner for Human Rights (M)

headline: MGM Owner Said to Offer $300 Million to Buy Orion
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, who reacquired MGM last year, reportedly is in talks to acquire Orion Pictures from John W Kluge for about $300 million; photo; MGM would get small but valuable film libraries of Orion and Samuel Goldwyn Company, which Orion owns; separately, Universal Pictures unit of Seagram Company reportedly is negotiating to acquire October Films; independent New York-based company produced recent successes such as Secrets and Lies and Breaking the Waves (S)

headline: Official Killed In Chechnya As Fighting Flares Anew
abstract: Tenuous peace between Russia and Chechnya dissolves into kind of violence, threats and reciminations that have been common for three centuries; gunman kills local official in republic of Ingushetia; Russian officials say attack was carried out by Chechen rebels, assertion that leaders of republic deny (M)

headline: This Memorial Day, consider turning off the computer and firing up the barbecue.
abstract: TWO apparently unrelated events associated with today's celebrations occurred in the decade after the Civil War.    In 1868, according to General Order No. 11, Headquarters, Grand Army of the Republic (http://suvcw.org/logan.htm), Gen. John A. Logan proclaimed a ''Decoration Day'' during which flowers were to be placed on the graves of both Union and Confederate soldiers.

headline: Fortune Magazine To Change Agencies
abstract: Fortune magazine changes advertising agencies and hires two new aides as part of plans to expand marketing and communications effort; names Fallon McElligott to handle account, which had been at Mullen Advertising; hires Rebecca Weson Darwin as marketing director and Terry McDevitt as communications director, new post (S)

headline: Pricing the Convenience of A.T.M.'s
abstract: Stanley B Winters letter on charges imposed by his bank for returning his own canceled checks each month

headline: U.S. Raises Pressure on Mobutu, A Longtime Ally, to Step Down
abstract: US sharply steps up pressure of Zaire Pres Mobuto Sese Seko to step down as violence sweeps capital of Kinshasa; Clinton Administration says end of his autocratic regime is inevitable; urges Mobutu to help create transitional Government that would hold democratic elections; is wary of intentions of rebel leader Laurent Kabila, who currently controls third of country (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Stocks Fall, Dragging Market Lower  Technology stocks plunged after Seagate Technology and Gateway 2000 again said they expected earnings growth to slow and because of news that Intel planned to cut prices on its Pentium computer chips.    The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 10.68 points, to 1,432.43. The Dow industrials were also pulled lower, losing 42.07 points to close at 7,718.71. $(Page D8.$)

headline: Columbia/HCA Hospital Must Bargain With Union
abstract: Adminstrative law judge John H West has ruled that Audubon Regional Medical Center of Louisville, Ky, a flagship hospital owned by Columbia/HCA Healthcare, violated federal labor laws in efforts to prevent nurses from unionizing; union vote was defeated in 1994 election, which union has long contended was tainted by illegal actions by the hospital; West found David Vandewater, company's president and chief operating officer, had participated personally in unlawful labor practices; Vandewater disputes charges (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.51   5.22        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.14   5.13   4.92        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.39   5.37   5.05        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.67   3.65   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.96   6.90   6.49        30-YR. TREAS.
