headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * Branch Banking and Trust Co., Winston-Salem, N.C., is selling $200 million of floating-rate senior medium-term bank notes through Nationsbanc Capital Markets Inc. in two parts.    The first is $100 million of floating-rate senior medium-term bank notes due in 1999, with a rate equal to the Federal funds rate plus 21-hundredths of a percentage point and priced at par; the second is $100 million of floating-rate senior medium-term bank notes due in 2000 at a rate equal to the London interbank offered rate plus six-hundredths of a percentage point.

headline: Smith Corona Picks Partners & Shevack
abstract: Smith Corona Corp names Partners & Shevack to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: INFORMIX TO WHITTLE GLOBAL WORK FORCE BY 10 PERCENT
abstract: Informix Corp will cut 10 percent of its 4,600 worldwide work force, including 200 jobs in Europe, in bid to return to profitability (S)

headline: Russia-China Theme: Contain the West
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin and Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin pledge to work together to limit US power and influence in world; two leaders hold summit meeting at start of Jiang's five-day state visit; they do not single out US by name, but their message, aimed in part at Russian public that has been bombarded with alarmist reports about NATO expansion and US role as sole remaining superpower, is clear (M)

headline: S.& L.'s Post Solid Earnings
abstract: Office of Thrift Supervision says US savings and loan industry earned $1.7 billion in first quarter of 1997; earnings were up from $1.5 billion in fourth quarter of 1996 and down slightly from $1.8 billion earned in first quarter of 1996; number of problem institutions increased to 30 in first quarter, up from 29 at end of 1996 (S)

headline: 3 Companies Forge Gene Research Link
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co, Millenium Pharmaceuticals Inc, Affymetrix Inc and Whitehead Institute/MIT Center for Genome Research in Cambridge, Mass, say they are forming $40 million research consortium to take information now pouring in from human genome research and use it to identify possible new drugs and treatments; three companies will initially contribute $8 million annually for five years to consortium, as well as make some of their own scientists and resources available to it (M)

headline: Another Side of Arbitration
abstract: Letter by Matthew Farley and Brian F McDonough on June 8 comment by Madelaine and Theodore G Eppenstein on plight of investors who lose money to unscrupulous stockbrokers and are limited to arbitration proceedings conducted by industry tribunals (L)

headline: Zagreb Sends Croat to Trial In The Hague
abstract: Croatian Government, bowing to pressure from Washington, for first time extradites Croat wanted by international war crimes tribunal in The Hague; former Croatian paramilitary commander, Zlatko Aleksovski, is accused of mistreating Muslim prisoners while he was commander of detention camp at Kaonik, Bosnia; extradition follows threat by US to block loan from International Monetary Fund (M)

headline: Mexican Police Protest; 7 Officers Are Injured
abstract: Hundreds of police officers battle with antiriot force in Mexico City in demonstration over rising role of army in policing city (S)

headline: B.A.T. Pretax Profit Hurt by Stronger Pound
abstract: BAT Industries PLC says pretax profit rose 1 million pounds, to 591 million pounds ($963 million) in first quarter (S)

headline: Hotel Investors Win After Big Trade Flops
abstract: Institutional investors who sold large blocks of stock in Renaissance Hotels in 1996 only to see profits vanish shortly after will have shares returned at full value following decision by buyer, identified as Fredreick Liu of Hong Kong, not to proceed with trade because of SEC's move to act on insider-trading complaint (S)

headline: After 15 Years, Dow Jones Lets Futures Trade On Its Average
abstract: Dow Jones & Co has licensed Chicago Board of Trade, Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Chicago Board Options Exchange to begin trading on futures contracts on Dow Jones industrial average; new Dow contracts are aimed at retail investors; contracts will have value of just 10 times the index, or about $72,000, based on current prices; at American Stock Exchange, a similar product will be traded based on the Dow; it is likely to be called Diamonds, with full name designed to abbreviate to that; each one of those will be valued at one-hundredths of the Dow, or about $72 (L)

headline: Office Buildings Have Become the Latest Objects of Desire
abstract: Competition for prime office buildings in Manhattan and elsehere around nation is propelling prices skyward, with real estate investment trusts as prime players; REIT's have been around since 1960's, mostly as mortgage holders; lately they have begun to own property outright, particularly office buildings, and they have become hot properties themselves with investors; so-called equity REIT's have edge, since they can move faster and raise money more cheaply than old-line real estate moguls, hedge funds and investment banks; most aggressive trusts are buying properties less for current return than for hope of spike in rents later; photo; graph (M)

headline: Leftist Poses A Challenge To Top Party In Mexico
abstract: Mexico City to hold its first mayoral election in 70 years in two weeks; Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, leftist candidate, is so far ahead that he is acting--and being treated--not just like mayor-elect but like potential president; surprising dominance of campaign by Cardenas, 62-year-old on of President who nationalized Mexico's oilfields, has already begun to give Pres Ernesto Zedillo a taste of how it could be to govern in face of powerful opposition leader capable of articulating popular grievances (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    ABN Amro Holding N.V., Amsterdam, 14 million  American depository shares each representing one ordinary share. ABN Amro Securities Inc.

headline: Trade Surplus Swells in Japan
abstract: Japan reports its merchandise trade surplus rose 222 percent in May from May 1996 to 738.27 billion yen ($6.4 billion); trade surplus with United States rose 93 percent, to 322.87 billion yen ($2.8 billion) (S)

headline: The New Face at No. 10: Anthony Charles Lynton Blair
abstract: Biographical profile of Labor Party leader Tony Blair in view of his election as Prime Minister of Britain; notes that he was born in Edinburgh on May 6, 1953 (M)

headline: Disney to Buy Controlling Stake In Internet Publisher Starwave
abstract: Walt Disney Co is buying controlling stake in Starwave Corp, an Internet publisher, and says that the two companies will jointly produce a new site on World Wide Web using resources of Disney's ABC News division; terms undisclosed (M)

headline: Nancy Woodhull, 52, Editor Who Fostered News Diversity
abstract: Nancy J Woodhull, first managing editor for news at USA Today, dies at age 52; photo (M)

headline: Monetary Fund Sees World Growth Up 4.4%
abstract: International Monetary Fund reports worldwide economic growth will accelerate this year to its highest level in nearly a decade, but most regions face risks and problems that could cloud their prospects; estimates world output will increase 4.4 percent, up from 4 percent in 1996 and two-tenths of a percentage point higher than fund's last projection, issued in October 1996 (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Growth Soars to 5.6% Rate With Inflation Modest  Powered largely by free-spending consumers, the economy grew at a 5.6 percent annual rate during the first quarter. It was the biggest advance in nearly a decade and came in well ahead of forecasts.    The Clinton Administration claimed credit for the continued robust growth, which has been accompanied by modest inflation, but acknowledged that it was surprised by the strength of the results. $(Page B12.$)

headline: Another Ranking Executive At Apple Decides to Resign
abstract: Apple Computer Inc's executive vice president of operations George Scalise resigns to become president of Semiconductor Industry Association; Scalise will leave Apple at end of May; Apple does not plan to replace Scalise (M)

headline: Egyptian Newspaper Drops Israeli-American Political Cartoonist
abstract: Al Ahram, Egypt's leading newspaper, will suspend publication of work of Israeli-American political cartoonist Ranan Lurie, world's most widely syndicated cartoonist, because of complaints that he once served in Israeli Army and took part in massacres of Egyptian soldiers during Arab-Israeli wars; decision follows fierce campaign by Rose al-Youssef, rival Egyptian publication, and after 19 top Egyptian cartoonists submitted petition to newspaper demanding that it cease publication of Lurie's work (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Grey's GCI Group Names a President
abstract: Grey Advertising says Robert Feldman will join GCI Group, its worldwide public relations agency, as president and chief executive; Feldman succeeds John D Bergen, who resigned; Grey creates holding company for GCI and a sibling, APCO Associates; Margery Kraus, president and chief executive at APCO, will team up with Feldman to head holding company, named GCI-APCO (S)

headline: Another Rise In British Rates
abstract: Britain's newly independent central bank raised the base lending rate yesterday, to 6.5 percent from 6.25 percent. The increase was aimed at fighting inflation; even though the main measure of inflation grew at a 2.5 percent rate in April, meeting the bank's target, the bank is worried that price growth will accelerate.

headline: Sales of New Homes Fell 2.5% In March After Big February
abstract: Commerce Department says sales of new single-family homes fell 2.5 percent in March after having risen to highest level in almost 11 years during February; March decline leaves home sales at seasonally adjusted annual rate of 813,000; that is in contrast to February's sales, which are revised to show increase of 1.1 percent, to rate of 834,000 from decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent reported originally; in the first quarter, 209,000 houses were sold, up from 191,000 in 1996; average price of new house rose to $171,500 in March from $169,900 in February; graph (L)

headline: De Klerk Pulls Party Out of Inquiry Into Apartheid Era
abstract: Former Pres F W de Klerk ends his National Party's cooperation with South African commission that is conducting inquiry into apartheid era; party expects to ask courts to halt inquiry on grounds that officials are violating their own rules by making findings about de Klerk's guilt before hearing evidence; points to remarks by Abp Desmond Tutu and deputy who have questioned truthfulness of de Klerk's recent testimony; commission offers amnesty to those who confess wrongdoing, but de Klerk says he committed no crimes and has no need to seek amnesty (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Mutual Fund Inflows Rise; Dow Average Loses 27.05  With investors bullish, cash flows to mutual funds have gained strength in the last two months -- with inflows to stock funds reported at $15.7 billion in April and estimated at $19 billion in May. But fund managers have been cautious, leaving two-thirds of April's new stock money in cash.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Labor Cost Index Shows Benign Inflation  The Employment Cost Index for the first quarter showed no sign of inflation despite a robust economy and indications that skilled workers have grown increasingly hard to find.    The report sent the stock market rocketing to its greatest gain in more than five years. The data took some of the steam out of the view on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve would feel compelled to raise interest rates repeatedly to slow the economy. $(Page A1.$)    There were other signs that inflation may not be a problem. Orders to factories for durable goods fell in March, a sign that the economy may be losing some of the momentum that caused the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates last month. And the Conference Board said Americans' confidence in the economy fell more than expected this month. $(D4.$)

headline: Sweeping Away A Tax-Rate Mirage
abstract: To the Editor:    ''Around the World in Brackets'' (Spending It, April 13) implies that United States tax rates are among the world's lowest. But it doesn't look that way if one allows for what one receives in return for the taxes.

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of business events of week ending Apr 20; graphs; photos; drawing (l)

headline: Opposition In Mexico Gets To See Clinton
abstract: Pres Clinton becomes first United States president to meet with leaders of Mexico's main opposition parties; gesture spurs mixed reactions (M)

headline: Healthy economy shows up in a vital sign: ad spending.
abstract: Robert J Coen, leading prognosticator of advertising spending, predicts advertising spending in United States will rise 6.2 percent to record $186 billion, up from $175.2 billion in 1996; cites strong economy and growing consumer confidence; graph (M)

headline: The business-class battle among airlines for trans-Atlantic passengers continues to heat up.
abstract: Business-class air war over Atlantic continues to accelerate, exemplified most recently by British Airways' offer of a free ticket for dissatisfied passengers--an offer soon followed by Virgin Atlantic ads urging British Airways passengers to take carrier up on its offer; other airlines that are upgrading services include American Airlines, Alitalia and Delta Air Lines; Pan Am will move from international terminal at Kennedy International Airport in New York into half of TWA domestic terminal, which Trans World Airlines vacated last January; Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan opens 350 renovated rooms; remaining 683 rooms are scheduled to reopen by June 30 (L)

headline: A 13-Year Transition Has Made Hong Kong China's Money Capital
abstract: While most attention focuses on future of political freedom and economic prosperity in Hong Kong under Chinese rule, there are also enormous opportunities for business and billions of dollars in new markets as well; even though July 1 will mark milestone with reversion to Chinese rule, process of transition has been well under way for past 13 years; territory has become China's money capital, and its industrialists have already cultivated China as their manufacturing hinterland, setting up operations that employ about five million Chinese workers; conversely, companies in China are flocking to Hong Kong seeking expertise and services; since China opened up in 1979, foreign investments as of 1996 soared to nearly $100 billion, with two out of every three dollars coming from Hong Kong; financing China's economic development, by helping companies go public by issuing bonds and arranging syndicated loans, is one of Hong Kong's greatest and most lucrative tasks; photos; graphs; chart (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Wearever Health Care Products, Rougemont, N.C., to Howard, Merrell & Partners, Raleigh, N.C., as the first agency for its incontinence-protection products. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $9 million for the first year and $12 million to $15 million in the second.  * Alpha Graphics Inc., Tucson, Ariz., to DDB Needham Dallas, a unit of Omnicom Group, to handle the account of the printing company, which had been at Richards Group, Dallas. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

headline: Pol Pot Reported Seen
abstract: A senior Cambodian Army general said he saw the Khmer Rouge leader yesterday in northern Cambodia, the first reported sighting of Pol Pot by someone outside the Khmer Rouge since 1981. Page A6.

headline: A Great Wall, Alas, of T-Shirts and Baseball Caps
abstract: Great Wall of China, long symbol of China's greatness, succumbs to commercialism and becomes more of a symbol of China's eager entry into international marketplace; entrance at Badaling has become bazaar of souvenirs and kitsch; photo; map (M)

headline: REPUBLIC TO ACQUIRE VALUE RENT-A-CAR FOR $77.5 MILLION
abstract: Republic Industries to buy Value Rent-a-Car from Mitsubishi Motors Corp for $77.5 million in cash or stock; agrees that Mitsubishi will supply it with up to 27,000 vehicles a year for its four car-rental companies (S)

headline: British Bank Weighs Bid For Finance Operation
abstract: Abbey National PLC, British bank, says it may acquire Cater Allen Holdings PLC, an intermediary between Bank of England and big commercial banks; newpaper reports Abbey might pay $327 million (S)

headline: For Moscow's Ambitious Mayor, a New Way to Network
abstract: Center TV, new Russian television network, makes debut with powerful financial and political backing; is owned and operated by City of Moscow, and main goal is to spread image of powerful Mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, who may run for President in 2000 (M)

headline: NEWMONT ACQUISITION OF SANTA FE PACIFIC GOLD APPROVED
abstract: Shareholders of Newmont Mining Corp and its operating unit, Newmont Gold Co, approve acquisition of Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corp for $2.06 billion in stock, creating largest gold producer in North America (S)

headline: G.A.O. Seen Posing Hurdle To British Air-American Tie
abstract: General Accounting Office is expected to testify that it believes American Airlines and British Airways must give up a number of valuable landing rights at Heathrow Airport in London; statement, first formal opinion from a Federal agency on proposed alliance between American and British Airways, was prepared for Senate Commerce Committee hearing; GAO is expected to state that to increase competition, other US airlines should have opportunity to fly at least 23 daily round trips into Heathrow, and that most, but not all, of those landing rights, also known as slots, would come from British Airways and American (M)

headline: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AGREES TO ACQUIRE NHP
abstract: Apartment Investment and Management Co agrees to buy NHP Inc in transaction valued at about $279 million; Apartment Investment would own or have stake in 34,842 apartment units and manage another 176,000 units (S)

headline: German Social Democrats Take Heart in British Labor Victory
abstract: Election of Labor Party leader Tony Blair as Prime Minister of Britain has evoked uneasy resonance in Germany, where Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his Christian Democrats have been in office for over 14 years, and many people sense need for similar change but remain fearful of undertaking it (M)

headline: IMC TO ADD POTASH PRODUCER WESTERN AG-MINERALS
abstract: IMC Global Inc agrees to buy potash producer Western Ag-Minerals, unit of Rayrock Yellowknife Resources Inc of Toronto, for $53 million to expand in the Southwest (S)

headline: Pearle Vision Review Names 4 Finalists
abstract: Pearle Vision Inc names four finalists to compete for its advertising account, with billings estimated at $25 million; account had previously been handled by GSD&M, unit of GGT Group, until that agency declined to participate in review; finalists noted (S)

headline: US WEST SELLING CABLE SYSTEMS IN THREE STATES
abstract: US West Media Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell cable systems in Minnesota to the closely held Charter Communications Inc. of St. Louis and two partners for $600 million. Separately, U S West agreed to sell cable systems in Idaho and Washington to Tele-Communications Inc. for an undisclosed price. U S West is selling the systems in Minnesota and Idaho, which it acquired with Continental Cablevision Inc., to comply with Government regulations barring the company from owning cable networks where U S West Communications, the other division of U S West Inc., provides telephone service. U S West said it was not required to sell the Washington systems.

headline: Short Strike Ends At G.M. Plant
abstract: Hourly employees at an important parts-making complex of the General Motors Corporation in Warren, Ohio, returned to the job today after the auto maker and a union reached a tentative settlement ending a day-old strike.    The agreement, which the union said met its demands for job guarantees, occurred about 12:30 A.M. today, after a 12-hour negotiating session. The strike by 8,200 members of the International Union of Electrical Workers at G.M.'s Delphi Packard Electric Systems unit began just after midnight Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Head of Tainted Japan Bank, Under Inquiry, Commits Suicide
abstract: Former chairman of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Kuniji Miyazaki, commits suicide shortly after being questioned by prosecutors in connection with scandal involving bank and Nomura Securities Co, one of world's largest brokerage companies, and their alleged links to organized crime; Miyazaki was questioned, along with another former chairman of bank, Tadashi Okuda, about loans worth $250 million, much of them uncollectable, to known racketeer, Ryuichi Koike; four former directors of Dai-Ichi Kangyo have been indicted on charges of making illegal payoffs of more than $103 million to Koike (M)

headline: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES (TWA,A)
abstract: Trans World Airlines has loss before charges of $70 million in first quarter, nearly double loss of $37.1 million for comparable period a year earlier; revenue falls 2.6 percent, to $762.3 million from $782.4 million; table (S)

headline: MERFIN ACCEPTS REVISED TAKEOVER BID OF $140 MILLION
abstract: Merfin International Inc accepts sweetened takeover offer of $140 million (US), including assumed debt, from Buckeye Cellulose Corp (S)

headline: The Nation Hopes Subscribers Remember It in Their Wills
abstract: The Nation, self-described lonesome bastion of liberal thinking with perpetual cash-flow problems, mails out fund-raising brochure urging subscribers to leave bequests in their wills to the magazine; five options are described in letter (M)

headline: Mexico Reacts Bitterly to Execution of One of Its Citizens in Texas
abstract: Mexican Government and some international groups criticize execution in Texas of Irineo Tristan Montoya, Mexican citizen convicted of murdering American motorist (M)

headline: 2 Consolidations In Consumer Brands
abstract: Black & Decker Corp names McCann-Erickson New York to handle consolidated domestic responsibilities for its consumer power tools group; billings estimated at $30 million; Twinlab Corp names Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners to handle its consolidated account, with billings estimated at $12 million (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * TBWA International, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group, opened agencies in Sydney, Australia, and Auckland, New Zealand. In Sydney, the new shop, Whybin Lawrence TBWA, is a sibling of Whybin TBWA, Melbourne, headed by Neil Lawrence as chief executive and creative director; he had been vice chairman and national creative director at Young & Rubicam Sydney. And in Auckland, Whybin TBWA New Zealand will be headed by David Walden as managing director; he had been chief executive at Foote, Cone & Belding Auckland, part of True North Communications.    * Eire Partners, Chicago, was renamed the Chicago Creative Partnership.    * Girgenti, Hughes, Butler & McDowell, New York, was renamed GHBM Healthworld.    * Group Bozell France, Paris, owned by the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, acquired Terre Lune, Paris, an agency specializing in promotional and direct marketing. Terms were not disclosed. Terre Lune will be merged with Bozell Marketing Services, Paris, to form Bozell Terre Lune.

headline: Manufacturing and Construction Slow a Bit
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management says its factory index on manufacturing activity declined to 54.2 in April from 55 in March; decline is smaller than expected; Commerce Department report shows spending on construction fell two-tenths of 1 percent in March, to $600.1 billion at annual rate; residential construction spending, which makes up almost half of the total, rose 1 percent from a month earlier; spending on public projects rose nine-tenths of 1 percent; spending on commercial projects fell 2.3 percent; Labor Department reports first-time jobless claims increased by larger-than-expected 28,000 last week, to seasonally adjusted 347,000; graph on construction spending (L)

headline: Conspiracy Charges Filed Against Avant
abstract: Avant Corp, its chief executive John Huyett, president-director Gerry Hsu, vice presidents Steven Wuu and Y Z Liao, director Eric Cho, employees Eric Cheng and Leigh Huang and Mitsuru Igusa, a former engineer, are charged with conspiracy and theft of trade secrets from rival Cadence Design Systems Inc; Cadence president Joe Costello welcomes action; Cadence and Avant are competitors in market for computer-aided design software used to develop new chips (M)

headline: MERISEL ANNOUNCES DEBT CONVERSION AGREEMENTS
abstract: Merisel Inc reaches several agreements in principle to convert debt to equity (S)

headline: Airport Operator Warns Against British Tax
abstract: BAA PLC warns that windfall tax could jeopardize investments in seven British airports it operates; statement comes as company reports that fourth-quarter pretax profit before one-time items rose 43 percent, to 63 million pounds ($103 million) in three months ended March 31; Chancellor of Exchequer Gordon Brown has not yet said which companies will face planned tax of about $8.2 billion, to be aimed at former state-owned concerns (S)

headline: Coffee Prices Plunge as Brazil Escapes Cold
abstract: Coffee prices plunge after cold weather that had been forecast for Brazil fails to appear; platinum and palladium prices, which have soared this year because of tight supplies, fall on speculation that Russia will soon export the metals for first time this year (S)

headline: A Nasdaq Firm Settles Price Suit For $30 Million
abstract: Herzog, Heine & Geduld agrees to pay $30.6 million to investors in largest settlement to date in price-fixing case that encompasses much of Wall Street; settlement is third to stem from May 1994 lawsuit filed after Justice Dept began investigation into price collusion on Nasdaq market; suit received class-action status in Nov 1996 (M)

headline: Cupid's a Korean Computer, Making Wise Matches
abstract: South Koreans seeking appropriate spouse are increasingly using dating services to match birth dates, zodiac signs and elemental characteristics as well as social status; dating services are responsible for some 20 percent of marriages in nation; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Reports Latin America Suffers Fewer 'Disappeared'
abstract: United Nations group of experts conclude that 'disappearances' have almost ended in Western Hemisphere, reflecting changes that democratically elected governments have brought to Latin America and Caribbean (M)

headline: AIRBUS GETS $2 BILLION ORDER FROM NORTHWEST
abstract: Northwest Airlines says it will buy 50 A319 jets, valued at $2 billion, from Airbus Industrie; planes will be delivered from 1999 through 2003 (S)

headline: Across the EU, Amazement At Bonn Plan To Bend Books
abstract: FRANKFURT—  Finance Minister Theo Waigel, undaunted by critics who accuse him of engaging in the sort of budgetary sleight-of-hand that he has long scorned, said Friday that a revaluation of German gold and foreign-currency reserves would help the nation meet both of the most critical budget criteria for a European monetary union.

headline: Bar to Government Bond Work for Dai-Ichi
abstract: Japan says it will bar Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd from underwriting and bidding to buy Government bonds at auction until bank's role in scandal over racketeering payoffs is determined (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BOMBAY CO., Fort Worth, said Carson Thompson, its president and chief executive, had resigned.     HUGHES ELECTRONICS CORP., El Segundo, Calif., a subsidiary of General Motors, named Michael J. Houterman president of its communications and aerospace unit.

headline: When the benefits are mostly modest, what price clean air?
abstract: Economic Scene column on costs of Environmental Protection Agency's proposed air quality standards for ozone and soot; holds criticism from insiders will likely feed Congressional efforts to block the standards, and may yet lead Clinton Administration to compromise; says battle over standards illustrates both escalating stakes on environmental policy and inadequacy of the law as a guide to how much is enough; drawing (L)

headline: General Bearing and G.M.
abstract: General Bearing Corp says it reached $54 million agreement with General Motors Corp to supply wheel and axle bearings to GM over next three years (S)

headline: Coffee Prices Gain as Supplies In U.S. Remain on Low Side
abstract: Coffee futures prices rise on smaller-than-expected growth in United States inventories; coffee for July delivery rises 12.2 cents, to $2.087 a pound (S)

headline: Dow's Rally Ends With a Decline of 21.27
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 21.27 points, to 6,658.60; Nasdaq composite index rises 6.80 points, to 1,217.07 (L)

headline: ECONOMIC UNEASE LOOMS OVER TALKS AT DENVER SUMMIT
abstract: Economic summit opens in Denver; Pres Clinton and leaders of Russia, Japan and Western Europe plunge into messy business of defining their new roles in global economy, with Russia pressing for quick entry into World Trade Orgn and Europe struggling to save is efforts to unify under single currency; Clinton, buoyed by strongest economic performance in world, exudes optimism at opening of summit, which until this hear was called Group of Seven, but with inclusion of Russia is called Summit of Eight (M)

headline: As Markets Shift, a Technology Pioneer Harvests the Fruits of Innovation
abstract: Profile of Xerox Corp focuses on its corporate strategy; last month, company revamped its corporate structure; Xerox on April 15 will introduce four machines that will, for first time, let customers set their own pace for moving from an analog to a digital world; next month, it will flesh the line out, with some products aimed at highest end of copier market and others aimed at small businesses and telecommuters; chief executive Paul A Alaire comments; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Lawmakers to Push Futures Investigation
abstract: Federal lawmakers will ask Justice Dept to investigate possible anti-competitive effects of Chicago Board of Trade proposal to drop Toledo, Ohio, and St Louis as delivery points for exchange's corn and soybean futures contracts (S)+

headline: Profits for these insiders may really be too good to be true.
abstract: Market Place: Insiders at Xircom Inc, technology company whose stock soared then fell sharply earlier this year, showed brilliant timing in selling high then buying low; problem is they may be forced to give up some or all of their profits; sales and purchases of Xircom stock, reported to Securities and Exchange Commission by executives involved, show heavy selling in January and February and even heavier buying in April, when price was far lower; SEC is probing whether executive violated Federal regulations on such trades; graph (L)

headline: EXPANSION INTO VARIOUS AVIATION SERVICES SOUGHT
abstract: Boeing Co creates new unit, Boeing Enterprises, to seek business in airline maintenance and other aviation services (S)

headline: Japan's Ambassador to Peru Resigns Over Hostage Crisis
abstract: Morihisa Aoki, Japanese Ambassador to Peru who was among hostages held in Lima residence by Tupac Amaru rebels, announces resignation; seems to be bowing to public pressure to take responsibility for standoff (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.38   5.45   5.15        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.99   4.94   5.08        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.06   5.05   5.21        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.64   3.64   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.40   6.41   6.93        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.69   6.70   7.08        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.77   7.77   8.16        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.63   5.62   6.11          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Sybase Narrows Account Review
abstract: Sybase Inc narrows review of its account to three advertising agencies from six; account had been handled by Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White (S)

headline: Italian Police Arrest Suspected Mafia Boss
abstract: Police in Sicily arrest Pietro Aglieri, top crime boss who had been on run since 1989 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Industrials Slip, But Technology Stocks Rise  A day after posting its second-largest point gain in history, the Dow Jones industrial average receded a bit, closing down 20.87 points at 6,812.72.    But technology stocks, which had been mired in a slump since January, surged, lifting the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index 14.40 points, or 1.19 percent, to 1,227.14. Microsoft and Intel rose sharply. $(Page D26.$)

headline: Paxson to Buy 4 Stations
abstract: Paxson Communications Corp acquires four radio stations in West Palm Beach, Fla, from American Radio Systems Corp; terms undisclosed; stations are WKGR-FM, WOLL-FM, WBZT-AM and WEAT-AM (S)ï

headline: Israeli Drug Maker Reports Strong Quarter
abstract: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd says its net income rose 68 percent in first quarter, to $31.5 million from $18.7 million a year earlier; sales grew 22 percent, to $267.6 million from $220.1 million (S)

headline: TCI Cable Concern Plans Six Divisions
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc, nation's largest cable-television operator, says it will restructure its domestic operations into six regional divisions; each will be responsible for two million to three million cable customers and will be headed by a vice president (S)

headline: Virgilio Barco, Ex-Colombia Chief, Dies at 75
abstract: Virgilio Barco, American-educated former President of Colombia whose dream of combatting rampant poverty with land reform and other ambitious social measures was sidetracked by American-backed civil war with powerful drug barons, dies at age 75; photo (M)

headline: Top Editor Departing Esquire Magazine
abstract: Edward Kosner is leaving as editor in chief of Esquire magazine, which has been troubled by a decline in advertising and newsstand sales; Hearst Magazines, which owns Esquire, says Randall Rothenberg, magazine's editorial director, will assume duties of acting editor as Hearst searches for replacement for Kosner; photo (L)

headline: Mary D. Gleason, 81, New York Socialite
abstract: Mary Dewart Gleason, whose family owned The New York Sun from 1926 until 1950, dies at age 81 (S)

headline: S.E.C., in Court, Defends Insider Trading Theory
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission goes before US Supreme Court to try to rescue far-reaching definition of insider trading that has been a mainstay of commission's enforcement efforts against misuse of confidential financial information; Federal appeals court, rejecting SEC's approach as unauthorized by Congress, shocked regulators last year by overturning conviction of Minneapolis lawyer James H O'Hagan who made $4.3 million by trading in stock of Pillsbury Co after learning that Grand Metropolitan PLC, a client of his law firm, was planning takeover of Pillsbury; because O'Hagan had no legal relationship to Pillsbury, his behavior would not have met classic definition of illegal insider trading, which entails use of nonpublic information to trade in shares of a company by a corporate insider or one who owes a fiduciary duty to the company; SEC, using more expansive definition known as misappropriation theory, prosecuted O'Hagan (L)

headline: Equity Sales Set For This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Alphanet Solutions Inc., Cedar Knolls, N.J., two million shares. Montgomery Securities.

headline: Four Agencies Are Joining Forces
abstract: Winning Strategies, Paolin & Sweeney, PST Communications Group and Princeton Public Affairs Group merge to form Winning Strategies Communications; Jim McQueeny is chairman, Brad Brewster chief executive, Dale Florio president and Gary Davis chief operating officer (S)

headline: TRIARC EXPANDING WITH ADDITION OF CABLE CAR BEVERAGE
abstract: Triarc Cos to buy Cable Car Beverage Corp for about $31 million in stock (S)

headline: SUPERVALU TO END ITS INVESTMENT IN SHOPKO STORES
abstract: Supervalu Inc, food distributor in Minneapolis, will sell its remaining 46 percent stake in Shopko Stores Inc, ending 26-year investment in discount retailer in deal valued at about $270.3 million (S)

headline: Don't Touch That Dial: Why Should I Hire You?
abstract: Companies are beginning to conduct job interviews via video conferences; they find it saves time and money; but recruiters say video interviewing has its quirks and that candidates who may do well in person may fail on camera; photo (M)

headline: Operating Profit Rises 41% for Spanish Bank
abstract: Spain's Banco Bilbao Vizcaya SA says operating profit rose 41.2 percent in first quarter; net income rose 25 percent, to 24.7 billion pesetas (S)

headline: American Topics
abstract: Fast-Thinking Victim Dept.: When a man drove up next to Myko Kona not long ago in Redondo Beach, California, and exposed himself, she kept her cool. She snapped his picture. He tried to grab her, but she ran behind his van to photograph the license plate. There was none. He tried to back over her. She ran to the front, and snapped a shot of that license plate before diving into bushes and escaping. The police developed the film and within hours arrested Jimmy Jewell, 33. He pleaded guilty.

headline: As Wall Street Groans, A Cable Dynasty Grows
abstract: Profile of Cablevision Systems Corp; Charles F Dolan, founder and chairman, has pushed to build assets at expense of earnings, taking on heavy debt; is under pressure from shareholders to sell some assets instead of seeking new acquisitions and to bring in equity partners; continues to run company like fief, annointing son, James, heir apparent and installing many relatives in management posts; he and family own 45 percent of stock and exercise 90 percent of voting rights; tables; graph; photo (L)

headline: US Airways Chief Warns Of Cutbacks
abstract: US Airways chairman-chief executive Stephen M Wolf says if US Airways is unable to reach cost-cutting agreement with its labor unions, it may start dropping unprofitable routes between East and West coasts, as well as routes in Florida and at its Baltimore hub; United Airlines says that members of its pilots' union approved mid-contract wage agreement reached last month; contract offers two wage increases of 5 percent, the first in July and the second in July 1998 (M)

headline: Lexmark Gives Grey Additional Duties
abstract: Lexmark International has further expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising by selecting it to handle advertising for its personal printers account; account has been handled by Goldberg Moser O'Neill (S)

headline: AURUM SOFTWARE IS ACQUIRED FOR $250 MILLION
abstract: Baan Co, Dutch software concern, agrees to buy Aurum Software Inc in stock deal worth about $250 million (S)

headline: North Korean Boats Fire on South's in Waters Controlled by Seoul
abstract: Group of North Korean boats slips into South Korean-controlled waters and open fire in direction of South Korean military vessels, which return fire; no one is injured, and North Korean boats quickly retreat; incident underscores warnings by some political analysts that secretive Government in North may become even more unpredictable than usual as it suffers from growing famine (M)

headline: Hong Kong Retailer Fined $12 Million
abstract: Giordano International Ltd, retailer based in Hong Kong, is fined 93 million Hong Kong dollars ($12 million) by Chinese authorities for violating customs and commerce rules (S)

headline: Microsoft Joins Netscape on Software Privacy
abstract: Microsoft Corp announces that it will take unusual step of agreeing with its archrival in Internet market, Netscape Communications Corp, on standard for privacy software; Microsoft-Netscape collaboration is pragmatic accommodation in response to growing public concerns about privacy on line--worries that threaten to slow growth of Internet commerce and possibly lead to Government regulation; Federal Trade Commission is holding four-day workshop, begun on June 10, on privacy concerns raised by spread of computer technology (L)

headline: MOORE IN DEAL FOR PEAK TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Moore Corp agrees to acquire Peak Technologies Group Inc for $210 million (S)

headline: Russia Sits with 'Big 8,' Party Crasher No More
abstract: Comment on extraordinary change in circumstances for Russia and Pres Boris N Yeltsin, with Russia being treated as full-fledged member of what is now called Summit of the Eight; Russia several years ago was the troubling focus of Group of Seven meetings, where Western leaders worried about Russia's political chaos, nuclear weapons and inflationary economy; today, Russia sits with the rest, worrying about China (M)

headline: Logitech Selects Young & Rubicam
abstract: Logitech Inc names San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Inc to handle its advertising account, which had been previously handled by Woolward & Partners in San Francisco; billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million (S)

headline: In Israel, Coercing Prisoners Is Becoming Law of the Land
abstract: Special report on Israel's use of force in interrogating suspected terrorists; coercing prisoners is common in region, but Israel is alone among its neighbors, and among Western democracies, in seeking to codify and legally justify practice; human rights groups in Israel and abroad score use of what they call torture; Israel denies 'moderate physical pressure' is torture (L)

headline: Pill for Abortion Ends Production
abstract: Roussel Uclaf, French pharmaceutical company, has stopped production of its unprofitable abortion pill RU 486, ending its battle with anti-abortion campaigners who lobbied against its sale, particularly in US; Roussel Uclaf has signed agreement to transfer 'without remuneration' the patent rights for the drug to newly formed company headed by Edouard Sakiz, who was chief executive of Roussel Uclaf until 1993; Roussel Uclaf says it could not find a buyer for the drug (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * M. J. Wyatt, former general manager of the New York office of Golin/Harris Communications, part of Shandwick P.L.C., opened Wyatt Communications, New York.

headline: Jody Donohue to Sell Marketing Agency
abstract: Jody Donohue, president at Jody Donohue Associates, says she will sell her public relations and marketing agency to executive vice presidents Joan Deignan and Linda Mann; after the sale, Deignan will become chief executive and Mann will become president; Donohue will become a consultant (S)

headline: How Bosnia Policy Set Stage For Albright-Cohen Conflict
abstract: Dispute between State Sec Madeleine K Albright and Defense Sec William S Cohen over Bosnia policy reflects their striking philosophic differences over how aggressively to use United States military force in post-cold-war era; Albright, who wants United States to be more aggressive militarily and diplomatically, has convinced Pres Clinton that US forces in Bosnia should do more to enforce peace accord, stand opposed by Cohen; she seeks to restore her office as pre-eminent voice in foreign policy, role increasingly assumed by Defense Department (M)

headline: Dollar Gains Against Mark And Yen, but Falls vs. Pound
abstract: Currency Markets column; dollar generally rises, after Japanese official says efforts to bolster yen by selling dollars would have little effect and Bank of France council membes raises concern that Europe's proposed single currency would be weaker than the mark (S)

headline: Ford Paying Dealers to Buy Cars Coming Off Lease
abstract: Ford Motor Co, seeking to prevent growing number of cars coming off lease from further depressing used-car prices, has begun to pay dealers to buy these vehicles instead of returning them to auto maker for sale at auction (M)

headline: Snapple's new owners see not a crisis, but an opportunity.
abstract: Market Place column on Nelson Peltz and Peter W May, who control Triarc, company that acquired Snapple Beverages from Quaker Oats Co last week for $300 million; analysts say Triarc has double-barreled advantage over any others for maximizing Snapple's potential: its ownership of Mistic Brands, fruit juice and tea business it bought for $97 million in August 1995, and its decision to hire Michael Weinstein, former president of A&W Brands, to run it; photos (L)

headline: Ex-Chief of Failed Conglomerate Is Acquitted of Forgery in Spain
abstract: Jose Maria Ruiz-Mateos, former president of Rumasa business empire of Spain, is acquitted on two counts of forgery; ruling could put to rest long-running legal battle over once-giant conglomerate, taken over 14 years ago by a Government that said company was on verge of failure (M)

headline: PIONEER AGREES TO BUY CHEMICAL PLANT FROM OCCIDENTAL
abstract: Pioneer Companies agrees to buy chemical plant in Tacoma, Wash, from Occidental Petroleum Corp for $102.5 million in cash and stock; acquisition will add to Pioneer's production of chlorine and caustic soda (S)

headline: BOEING CONSIDERS INCREASE IN PRODUCTION AS ORDERS RISE
abstract: Boeing Co is considering plans to increase aircraft production beyond record levels already announced; production is scheduled to rise to 40 planes a month in fourth quarter, its highest level ever (S)

headline: BANKERS TRUST REPORTEDLY DISCUSSING SALE OF CHILE UNIT
abstract: Bankers Trust New York Corp is in talks to sell its Chilean life insurance unit, Consorcio Nacional de Seguros de Vida, to local investment group led by Said and Massu families (S)

headline: Shareholder Activist, From Basement to Boardroom
abstract: Profile of William Steiner, millionaire who has portfolio of more than 300 stocks and also leads shareholder rights group; interview; photo (S)

headline: No Isle Is an Island, Not With 'That Thing' There
abstract: Prince Edward Island residents are concerned about impact on island way of life of new $750 million bridge linking them to mainland Canada; 9-mile Confederation Bridge crosses Northumberland Strait from New Brunswick; map; photos (M)

headline: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE TO BUY KURZWEIL APPLIED INTELLIGENCE
abstract: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products NV of Belgium agrees to acquire Kurzweil Applied Intelligence Inc for $53 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Omnicom to Acquire Fleishman-Hillard
abstract: Omnicom Group says it agreed to acquire Fleishman-Hillard Inc and merge it with Omnicom's Porter Novelli International; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Unilever uses gentle humor in its national campaign for ovulation predictor kits.
abstract: Article on Unilever's $2.3 million print advertising campaign for Clearplan Easy, an ovulation predictor kit; campaign was created by Ogilvy Adams & Rinehart (L)

headline: Enron to Pay $440 Million to Settle Gas Dispute
abstract: Enron Corp will pay $440 million in cash to settle litigation with Phillips Petroleum Co over agreement to buy high-priced natural gas from North Sea field (M)

headline: Deported Saudi Reports Iranian Link to a Plot
abstract: Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, Saudi deported to United States from Canada, reportedly has told investigators that Iranian intelligence aide Brig Ahmad Sherifi helped direct aborted 1995 plot to attack American installations in Saudi Arabia; investigators say they have no conclusive evidence linking Sherifi to later Dhahran bombing; believe he is liaison to Party of God, Lebanon-based Shiite Muslim terrorist group financed by Iran (S)

headline: In Some States, Lemons Can Take Different Shapes
abstract: Wheelchair lemon laws adopted by 22 states explained; list (S)

headline: 3 Finalists Named In Bauer Review
abstract: Eddie Bauer narrows review on its national brand advertising account to three agencies (S)

headline: Congo Soldiers Break Up Sparse Protest Against New President
abstract: Soldiers break up peaceful demonstration against Pres Laurent Kabila, Kinshasa, Congo, arresting and beating dozens of protesters; sparse turnout raises questions about depth of support for opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi (M)

headline: Alejo Peralta Diaz, 80, Is Dead; One of Mexico's Wealthiest Men
abstract: Alejo Peralta Diaz, pioneering figure in Mexico's industrial development, and one of country's wealthiest entreprenueurs, dies at age of 80; photo (M)

headline: FIRST MONTH BRINGS 100 SATURN SALES IN JAPAN, G.M. SAYS
abstract: General Motors Corp's Saturn division sold about 100 cars in its first month of sales in Japan (S)

headline: Japan Likely to Accelerate Deregulation of Its Markets
abstract: Japanese Government plans to speed up its timetable for changes to its financial markets; originally changes were scheduled for completion by year 2001, but Government advisory panels have recommended that they be made by end of 1999 (M)

headline: Scandal Puts Brazil Leader Under Cloud
abstract: Brazilian Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who built career on reputation for personal honesty, faces charges that his Government paid five congressmen to vote for constitutional amendment to let President and other elected executives run for re-election; measure, approved by lower house in Jan, is set for first of two Senate votes (M)

headline: Texaco Completes Sale of Oilfield Stake
abstract: Texaco Inc completes sale of 15 percent stake in its Captain oil and natural gas field in North Sea to South Korean Petroleum Development Corp (S)

headline: A Lost Investment, And No Answers
abstract: Comment by Rabbi Gerald L Zelizer on how he was swindled out of investment money, by following advice of longtime broker he trusted; describes how SEC and FBI closed down what regulators say was Ponzi scheme (S)

headline: Viacom Reports Loss for the First Quarter
abstract: Viacom Inc posts loss from continuing operations for first quarter of $23.8 million in contrast to earnings from continuing operations a year earlier of $19.4 million; revenue rose 11 percent, to $2.92 billion from $2.62 billion; table (L)

headline: Unit of Grey Buys Stake in Winkler
abstract: Grey Advertising Inc's venture capital arm, Grey Ventures, buys majority interest in Winkler Advertising; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Here's My Car. Please Sell It and Send Me a Check.
abstract: BOB MOSS bought a new vehicle this year, a 1997 Ford Explorer. But to sell his old one, a 1993 Ford Bronco with more than 70,000 miles on it, Mr. Moss took an unconventional and widely overlooked route.     A Ford dealer had offered him a trade-in price of $8,500, ''which was ridiculous,'' he said. Although Mr. Moss, who lives in Lake Hiawatha, N.J., felt he could do much better on his own, he couldn't summon the enthusiasm or time to sell the vehicle himself.  Instead, he took it to a used-car dealer who agreed to take it on consignment.

headline: Anyone for tennis and 'toons? Turner promotes the game to children with its Cartoon Network.
abstract: Turner Broadcasting, Time Warner unit that owns Cartoon Network, and Tennis Industry Association are banding together in advertising and promotional campaign to get children onto the courts; $1 million campaign will run some 25 spots a week for about 24 weeks (L)

headline: Channel Tunnel to Get Better Fire Prevention
abstract: Channel Tunnel operators, hoping to resume full service by June, promise tougher truck inspections and other new safety measures to prevent fire like one that broke out in Nov 1996 (M)

headline: Ex-Texaco Treasurer Indicted In Race Discrimination Case
abstract: Robert Ulrich, former Texaco Inc treasurer, is indicted on charges that he ordered shredding of company documents that were crucial to an employee race discrimination lawsuit that company settled for $176 million; is charged with trying to sabotage case brought by minority workers by conspiring with a subordinate to shred and throw away documents requested by workers' lawyers (S)

headline: Virtual Pitch, but Real Jobs on the Line
abstract: Nine New York area Internet companies pitch their business plans in bid for financing and validation, public forum, New York City, sponsored by International Radio and Television Society Foundation and Silicon Alley Reporter magazine; photo (M)

headline: New Bid for Blender Maker
abstract: CTS Corp says it agreed to buy Dynamics Corp of America for $208.8 million in cash and stock, surpassing hostile bid by WHX Corp, which had offered $167 million (S)

headline: No On-Line 'Pound of Flesh'
abstract: Letter from Michael McCarty, branch manager of Datek Online, on Mar 23 article on on-line stock trading; says $50 his company charges to mail stock certificates is not, as it is characterized in article, a 'pound of flesh' but merely meant as disincentive (S)

headline: Lowell Paxson has a dream: to start yet another television network.
abstract: Lowell Paxson, founder of Paxson Communications, which owns 55 television stations, hopes to sell time on his stations to entertainment and news programmers seeking to reach wider range of viewers; his aim is to start a network, and he feels he already owns enough stations to do that (M)

headline: Pre-K Parties With 10-K Favors
abstract: NOW is the high season for annual meetings. All shareholders are invited, but relatively few show up. They blame the distant locations or the press of other obligations, when, in fact, most people assume that an annual meeting will be pointless and dull.   What is needed here is a fresh perspective. Don't think of an annual meeting as a boring exercise in financial reporting. Recognize it for what it is: a kiddie party in business drag.

headline: Dow Rallies For a 3d Day, Gaining 92.71
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 92.71 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 6,679.87; Nasdaq composite index drops 2.61 points, to 1,210.27; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 8.81 points, or 1.2 percent, to 763.53 (L)

headline: TITAN HOLDINGS HIRES ADVISER TO EVALUATE OFFERS
abstract: Titan Holdings Inc retains Furman Selz Inc, the New York investment firm, to help evaluate 'expressions of interest' it had received about potential sale of some or all of its business (S)

headline: OBITUARY : Patricia High Painton, 67, Former Journalist in Paris
abstract: PARIS (IHT) — Patricia High Painton, 67, a former business journalist and longtime Paris resident, died April 29 of genetic emphysema at Roper Hospital in Charleston, South Carolina.

headline: GERRY BABY PRODUCTS SOLD TO EVENFLO FOR $73 MILLION
abstract: Huffy Corp completes sale of its Gerry Baby Products Co unit to Evenflo Juvenile Furniture Co for $73 million (S)

headline: A Paris Link to Mobutu
abstract: France tried to prop up President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire in January by running a covert military operation against rebels, according to intelligence reports. It could not be determined whether the operation, which involved mercenaries and combat aircraft, has continued.    Article, page A6.

headline: Barney's Expects Agreement With Investor
abstract: Barney's Inc expects to select an investor to rescue it from bankruptcy proceedings by May 28; to meet the timetable, Barney's first needs court approval on April 24 to offer potential investor $10 million in fees if Barney's later withdraws to accept a higher bid (S)

headline: Profits Plunge 92% at Yamaichi Securities
abstract: Yamaichi Securities Co reports that pretax profit plunged 92 percent in latest fiscal year; pretax profit fell to 1.22 billion yen, or $9.2 million, in fiscal year ended March 31 (S)

headline: Dow Jones Reports Earnings Fell 32.5%
abstract: Dow Jones & Co says its first-quarter earnings fell 32.5 percent, to $25.4 million, hurt by steep drop in operating income at its Telerate financial information unit (S)

headline: Minority Voice Fading For Broadcast Owners
abstract: Slim ranks of minority radio and television station owners are growing thinner due to consolidation frenzy in radio industry compounded by elimination of Federal tax credit that favored minority groups; minority ownership slipped by 10 percent last year; minority owners are expectd to continue to sell their broadcasting holdings because their buying power is dwindling without edge that tax credit gave them as station prices escalated; proponents of minority broadcasting ownership say black and Hispanic communities are likely to be more poorly served without local broadcasters and that minority employment is likely to decline because fewer minority owners are making hiring decisions; photo; chart (M)

headline: The Selling of Garage Sales
abstract: Question-and-answer column on whether garage sales are worth the effort (L)

headline: Deeper Losses For Compuserve
abstract: Compuserve Corp posts loss of $17.9 million for fiscal fourth quarter ended Apr 30, compared with year-earlier loss of $1.11 million; H & R Block, which owns 80 percent of Compuserve, reports net income in quarter rose 7.4 percent, to $199.4 million, up from $185.7 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: A Red Heifer, or Not? Rabbi Wonders
abstract: Rabbi Shmaria Shore and other rabbis and sages in Israel seek to determine whether 10-month-old heifer named Melody meets all the scriptural requirements of a red heifer; if so, Melody will become only 10th cow so ordained in all of Jewish history, and first in 2,000 years; Melody would then be turned to ashes; Jewish religious tradition regarding cows described; placement of ashes in Temple Mount could mean that Jewish zealots would seek to evict Moslems from Temple, which for last 1,300 years has been Haram al-Sharif, third-holiest shrine of Islam; case reviewed; photo; map (M)

headline: BANK IS SET TO BUY A BROKERAGE FIRM
abstract: Bankers Trust New York Corp agrees to acquire Alex Brown & Sons Inc, nation's oldest stock brokerage firm, for about $1.7 billion in stock; deal would render virtually meaningless 1933 Glass-Steagall Act, Depression-era law which bans combinations between banks that lend money and brokers who sell corporate securities to public; is expected to set stage for flurry of more such acquisitions by both domestic and foreign banks (M)

headline: All of a Sudden, The New Fund Money Is Going International
abstract: Market Place column on growing number of investors who are putting money into international stock funds; says Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, newsletter that tracks fund flows, estimates that in April, for first time since early 1994, more new cash has flowed into international stock funds than into funds that invest in American stocks; graph (L)

headline: Zaire Rebels Blocking Aid, U.N. Says
abstract: Evacuation efforts are paralyzed for thousands of sick and starving Rwandan Hutu refugees stranded in central Zaire; United Nations officials accuse Zaire's rebel movement of deliberately impeding emergency relief operations aimed at helping them; map; photo (M)

headline: British Safeway Venture In Northern Ireland
abstract: Safeway Food Stores PLC of Britain sets up joint venture with Fitzwilton PLC to run supermarkets in Northern Ireland(S)

headline: 'What? Me Worry?' Mad's Humor Is Racier, Its Readers Elusive
abstract: Mad magazine has spent 45 years poking fun at America; now it is scrambling for fresh identity, because much of parody's power has been leached away in era when television, movies, even real life are self-mocking, leaving little material for Mad; Mad magazine was reintroduced with different look, some new characters and emphasis on humor that is more off-color than before; photo (M)

headline: Is Your A.T.M. Ripping You Off?
abstract: Cost of using bank automated teller machines is rising as banks increasingly levy surcharges for customers of other banks who use their ATMs in addition to fees banks charge own customers for using other banks' machines; Federal and state legislators are introducing bills to ban surcharges; surcharges have made use of ATM often more expensive than using check-cashing service; table; drawing; map; photos (L)

headline: Boston Chicken hits some rough spots in a bond sale.
abstract: Market Place column on Boston Chicken's problems with its bond offering; says company has scaled back the size of the offering and is expected to pay much higher interest rate than it paid on a similar bond sold in 1994 (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Joins Netscape In On-Line Privacy Plan  Microsoft said it would take the unusual step of agreeing with its archrival on the Internet, Netscape, on a standard for privacy software.    The collaboration, which is backed by about 100 companies, is a pragmatic accommodation in response to growing concerns about privacy on line -- worries that threaten to slow the growth of Internet commerce and possibly lead to regulation. $(Page D4.$)

headline: U.F.O. Believers and Debunkers Thrive on the Web
abstract: Internet has many World Wide Web sites dealing with UFO's; conspiracy theorists and true believers have flooded Web; drawing (M)

headline: Colombian Rebels Release 70 Soldiers and Marines
abstract: Colombian rebels free 70 soldiers and marines after Government agrees to ceded temporary control of swath of territory to insurgents; agreement involves military evacuation of area size of Connecticut; it ends ordeal that went on for nearly year (M)

headline: WEYERHAEUSER TO CLOSE PLANT IN NORTH CAROLINA
abstract: Weyerhaeuser Co to close Plymouth, NC, plywood plant, resulting in loss of 200 jobs, and take second-quarter charge to pay for move (S)

headline: Papers Seek More Personal Connection With Readers
abstract: Nation's newspapers seek to reverse their declining circulation and attract younger readership with introduction of color and drama and intimacy; editors and publishers are questioning some basic assumptions of print journalism--that hard news should get more space and staff than soft features, or that it is up to editors and reporters to do the talking while customers just pay attention; some papers are running reader-written stories, one has section written by and for teen-agers, one has no stories at all on its Sunday front page; all the experimentation seems aimed at common objective of more emotional and intimate relationship with readers; market research of Yankelovich Skelly & White found that readers want more 'self-oriented' features and local news; percentage of adults in United States who read weekday paper declined to 64.2 percent in 1995, from 77.6 percent in 1970; photos (M)

headline: In Albanian Countryside, Chaos Yields to Tradition of Civility
abstract: Albanian officials say violence that swept country after collapse of pyramid schemes occurred in urban centers, not in rural areas, where justice is decided by tradition and by elders of each village (M)

headline: Leader of Spain's Socialists Will Not Seek to Retain Post
abstract: Former Prime Min Felipe Gonzalez of Spain stuns his Socialist Workers Party by announcing that he will not seek re-election as its leader, which would seem to preclude his nomination for prime ministership; Gonzalez's withdrawal is interpreted by various aides as effort to remove his longtime deputy secretary general, Alfonso Guerra, from party leadership; scandal over influence peddling in Guerra's family was beginning of series of financial and political scandals that steadily eroded Gonzalez's popularity; photo (M)

headline: Down Under, Tourism As the Growth Industry
abstract: Australia has become one of favorite travel destinations for Japanese, challenging Hawaii; almost one million Japanese visited Australia last year, rejuvenating complex relationship after years of bitterness over mistreatment of Australian prisoners during World War II; travel complements close trade ties, with Australia exporting wheat, coal and other minerals and Japan selling cars, computers and other finished products; Japanese also contribute significantly to tourism revenues, now the leading source of Australia's foreign exchange earnings; photos; map; graphs (M)

headline: PHYSICIAN CORPORATION IS IN TALKS ON 'A TRANSACTION'
abstract: Physician Corp of America is in talks that could lead to capital infusion or sale of the company (S)

headline: Biju Patnaik, 81, Daring Pilot-Patriot of India
abstract: Biju Patnaik, one of most prominent survivors of generation of Indian leaders who took part in independence struggle against Britain, dies at age 81; photo (M)

headline: Mission From Moscow: Find the Money
abstract: Russian companies seeking United States investors are sending aides to US with sophisicated presentations to court money managers; respond to increasing interest of pension funds, mutual funds, other mainstream investors; photos (M)ÿ

headline: New York Bartender to Ireland's Kingmaker
abstract: Deputy Prime Min Dick Spring, who once worked as bartender in New York City, could play kingmaker in Ireland if national election is as close as expected; has not ruled out switching his Labor Party, nation's third largest, from Prime Min John Bruton's coalition to one led by Bertie Ahern's Fianna Fail party; map; photo (M)

headline: For the Young, Hong Kong Is the Home of Opportunity
abstract: Amy Wu article holds rich career opportunities in Hong Kong are luring young Chinese people from Canada and United States despite uncertainties about Chinese rule; photo (M)

headline: 2 Finalists For Big Account
abstract: Ameritech Corp narrows review for its consolidated consumer, brading and business advertising account (S)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES AGREES TO BUY 4 CAR DEALERSHIPS
abstract: Republic Industries agrees to acquire four car dealerships for total of $70 million in stock; Republic is buying Desert Buick-GMC Automotive Group, which owns three dealerships in Las Vegas, Nev, and Gene Evans Ford dealership in Union City, Ga (S)

headline: ALAMCO IN TALKS ABOUT POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
abstract: Alamco Inc says it is in talks about 'a possible business combination' (S)

headline: DIME TO BUY A MORTGAGE LEADER FOR $374 MILLION
abstract: Dime Bancorp Inc to buy North American Mortgage Co for about $374 million in stock (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Charles E. Decker was named senior vice president for management services at the American Association of Advertising Agencies, New York, succeeding Robert Finn, who will retire on April 18. Mr. Decker had been vice president for worldwide marketing at Warner Brothers Consumer Products, New York, a unit of Time Warner Inc.  * Alain Philippe was named to the new position of senior vice president for worldwide business development at MRM World Group, New York, the relationship marketing business sector of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had been vice president at Ogilvy & Mather Direct France, Paris, a unit of WPP Group.

headline: Haiti's Premier Quits, Saying Aristide Forces Undermined Him
abstract: Haitian Prime Min Rosny Smarth resigns, capitulating to months of strikes and violent protests demanding his removal; accuses forces loyal to former Pres Jean Bertrand Aristide of undermining him; move comes less than week before scheduled runoff election for Senate in which his stewardship was only issue; he has been criticized, most recently by Aristide, for economic and social policies that favor reduction in Government spending and privatization of state-owned enterprises (M)

headline: LAIDLAW PLANS TO SELL JTM INDUSTRIES TO LAFARGE
abstract: Lafarge Corp signs letter of intent to acquire JTM Industries from Laidlaw Inc; price and terms undisclosed (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NORWEST CORP., Minneapolis, a financial service company, will acquire International Bancorp., Golden Valley, Minn., a bank holding company with 17 sites. Financial terms were not disclosed.    HENRY SCHEIN INC., Melville, L.I., which markets health-care products and services, acquired Medi-Quick Arzt G.m.b.H. & Co., Germany, a direct marketer of medical and dental products. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Foes' Air Forces to End War Games Over Cyprus
abstract: Greece and Turkey agree, after talks with American diplomats, to stop flying military aircraft in combat exercises over Cyprus (S)

headline: U.N. Says It Has Evidence of Killing of Rwanda Refugees
abstract: UN says it has first direct evidence that Rwandan refugees may have been killed as they fled camps in eastern Zaire that had been under attack by rebels in recent weeks; Sadako Ogata, Commissioner for Refugees, reports discovery of bodies of 20 people near Biaro camp who seem to have been attacked with machetes; says armed troops besieged pediatric hospital at Bukavu, and abducted sick and malnourished children (M)

headline: Where's the latest trend? At the intersection of Madison Avenue and the paths of righteousness.
abstract: Article on growing use of religion, especially Christianity, in advertising; while everyone from scholars to consumers may have noticed the trend, there appears to be a range of possible explanations, from increasing pluralism of American society to approach of the third millennium; some examples cited (L)

headline: A Toy Maker in Search of a New Blockbuster
abstract: Bandai Company hopes that its electronic game/key chain Tamagotchi, in which goal is to properly care for and feed a 'virtual chicken,' is as successful in United States as it has been in Japan, where five million have been sold since last November; photos (M)

headline: As Vote Nears, Mexican Party Muzzles Foes
abstract: Pres Ernesto Zedillo and lawmakers in Mexico's governing party, who face one of most competitive nationwide elections in decades, move to suppress activities and influence of several foreign critics and watchdog groups; Human Rights Watch Americas issues report concluding that Institutional Revolutionary Party is using violence 'to retain or win political or economic power' (M)

headline: U S WEST GETS $220 MILLION FOR TIME WARNER SHARES
abstract: US West Media Group Inc sells about 4.4 million Time Warner Inc shares for $220 million; US West Media says sale is part of plan to sell $1 billion of assets the company does not consider strategic and is unrelated to its partnerships with Time Warner (S)

headline: New World's Spanish Speakers Declare Independence
abstract: Writers and linguists have gathered at invitation of Mexican Pres Ernesto Zedillo in Zacatecas for conference on Spanish language; Spain's Royal Academy of Language continues to battle what it sees as debasing Latin American influence on language, while Mexican academics hail Mexican contributions; photo (M)

headline: Coke Earnings Climb 38.4% in Quarter
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says net income grew to $987 million in first quarter, up 38.4 percent from $713 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue declined 2 percent, to $4.14 billion from $4.22 billion in the quarter; table (L)

headline: PREMIER BANCSHARES IS PURCHASING GEORGIA BANK
abstract: Premier Bancshares Inc to acquire Citizens Gwinnett Bankshares Inc for about $35 million in stock (S)

headline: French Oil Company Buys Back Shares
abstract: Elf Aquitaine SA buys back shares from another of its original core shareholders, UAP SA (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Consumer Spending Soars, But Other Gauges Slow  Exuberant spending by consumers was the main reason for the economy's recent surge in growth. Spending grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent from September through March, the biggest six-month increase in this decade.    The rise in spending was capped by an increase of one-half of 1 percent in March, helped by a gain of six-tenths of 1 percent in personal income during the month. But economists, attempting to explain the surprising gains, suggest that they may not be sustainable. News analysis. $(Page D3.$)    Several other reports provided signs that the economy may be cooling from its recent torrid pace. Manufacturing activity grew at a slower rate in April, construction spending slowed in March and initial claims for unemployment benefits rose last week. $(D3.$)    Bond Yields Decline Again   Treasury prices rose for a fourth day, as the economic reports suggested that growth might be cooling enough to allow the Fed to keep interest rates on hold. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.91 percent from 6.95. $(D13.$)     Blue-chip stocks retreated after the market's recent strong advance, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 32.51 points, to 6,976.48. But computer stocks led the Nasdaq higher; it rose 9.74 points, to 1,270.50. $(D6.$)    Outdoor Systems in $1 Billion Deal   Outdoor Systems, the nation's biggest outdoor ad company, agreed to acquire the billboard unit of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing for $1 billion. $(D2.$)    ING in Talks for More of Dillon, Read   ING Group, the Dutch financial services giant, is in talks to acquire, for as much as $450 million, the 75 percent of the investment bank Dillon, Read that it does not already own. $(D6.$)    F.D.A. Cautious on Tobacco   In the wake of last week's court ruling that the F.D.A. could regulate nicotine as a drug, the agency is charting a delicate course. As scientists collect data that might bolster the case for reducing or eliminating nicotine from cigarettes, officials are studying the political minefield of regulation. $(A1.$)    On-Line Services in Settlement   Three on-line services -- America Online, Compuserve and Prodigy -- have agreed to an F.T.C. settlement over complaints about their billing and marketing practices. $(D3.$)    Movie Ads Abound on 'Ellen'   Because it was well known that Ellen DeGeneres's character would ''come out'' on ABC's ''Ellen'' sitcom, perhaps the only real surprise was the lineup of advertisers during the show. Most notable was the abundance of spots plugging motion pictures and the dearth of fast-food, beverage and car ads. $(D2.$)     The Leo Burnett agency is charged with wooing buyers of imported cars to Oldsmobile, best known for building stodgy sedans driven by grandparents. Advertising. $(D2.$)     Interactive TV Project to End   Time Warner said that it would shut an interactive TV network in Orlando, Fla., that it had introduced with great fanfare. $(D2.$)    Soros Foundation Fined in Belarus   Belarus has fined a foundation supported by the financier George Soros for what the Government said were currency exchange violations. The move is apparently an effort to shut down the foundation, the country's largest independent nongovernmental organization, spokesmen for the foundation said. $(A3.$)

headline: In London, 2 Young Guys Sit Talking About Democracy
abstract: Pres Clinton meets with British Prime Tony Blair in London; Blair says this is new era that calls for 'new-generation leadership'; Clinton attends Cabinet meeting of Britain's new Labor Government; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Is Accused of Being Part of a Cover-Up in Guatemala
abstract: Guatemalan human rights groups say United Nations mission there may have helped rebels and Government cover up political killing that was part of crisis that nearly scuttled peace plan; accusations stem from disappearance last October of Juan Jose Cabrera Rodas, guerrilla leader involved in kidnapping of elderly Guatemalan woman (M)

headline: In Congo, the Great Guys Have Much to Talk Over
abstract: Comment on Great Guys Club, which meets every Sunday morning in Kinshasa, Congo, to discuss books, culture, science, moral issues or, especially now, politics and dramatic change of scene, with new President in power after three decades of Mobutu Sese Seko's dictatorship; photo (M)

headline: Package Bomb Kills Daughter of a Top Leader of the Burmese Junta
abstract: Parcel bomb kills 34-year-old daughter of Lieut Gen Tin Oo, Myanmar Army's Chief Of Staff; democracy movement and members of ethnic Karen insurgency deny involvement (M)

headline: A Machine to Call Your Own
abstract: As automatic teller machine fees have risen, so has number of promoters peddling the machines to individual entrepreneurs as route to quick fortune; consumer advocates say few of these deals work out as promised; it makes little sense for most individuals to own ATM's because of enormous price per machine, usually $35,000 and up, and continuing expenses that can put an additional $35,000 a year on the tab; photo (L)

headline: Chairman Leaving Cole Henderson
abstract: Cole Henderson Drake says Dick Henderson, chairman and executive creative director, will leave agency (S)

headline: African Currency Funds
abstract: J P Morgan & Co and Standard New York, subsidiary of Standard Bank Investment Corp of South Africa, may introduce funds dedicated to investing in African currencies and sovereign debt (S)

headline: Pennzoil Adds to Benefits in Face of Bid
abstract: Pennzoil Co increases employee severance and stock option benefits in face of hostile $6.4 billion takeover bid from Union Pacific Resources Group Inc (S)

headline: TENET AND MEDPARTNERS TO FORM HEALTH CARE NETWORK
abstract: Tenet Healthcare Corp and Medpartners Inc agree to form health care network serving more than million people in Southern California (S)

headline: Trade Storm Imperils Caribbean Banana Crops
abstract: Clinton Administration, at urging of Chiquita Brands, seeks to overturn agreement that guarantees Caribbean banana farmers special access to European Union market; move alarms small banana farmers in St Lucia and other Caribbean islands; map; photo (M)

headline: NETANYAHU HOLDS WHITE HOUSE TALK
abstract: Pres Clinton and Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu meet at White House in effort to shore up Middle East peace effort, but reportedly make little progress; Netanyahu suggests at news conference that he will build housing for Arabs in Jerusalem, but does not otherwise soften public stance toward Palestinians; accuses them of violating numerous provisions of Oslo agreements; accuses journalists of playing into Palestinian hands by accusing Israel of violating accords and crediting Palestinians with keeping it (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Nestle Coffee Specialties, New York, to Renegade Marketing Group, New York, as the first agency to handle integrated marketing for the Nespresso System espresso maker. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: A Stylish REIT Offering Could Stand a Little Trim
abstract: Profile of Boston Properties, real estate company run by Mortimer Zuckerman and Edward Linde, considered one of best development teams in nation; Zuckerman photo; public offering, in which two plan to raise $785 million by selling 31.4 million shares, assessed (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American General Corp names Robert M Devlin, chief executive, to additional post of chairman; Devlin will give up post of president, which will be assumed by James D D'Agostino Jr (S)

headline: Germany's Free Democrats Watch Their Popularity Plunge
