abstract: FRANKFURT—  - With Germany groaning under the weight of record unemployment, staggering taxes to rebuild eastern Germany, waning industrial competitiveness and a welfare system it can no longer afford, the economic reform zealots in the nation's Free Democratic Party thought their moment had arrived.

headline: Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Is to Acquire a Unit of Total
abstract: Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corp, in continuing consolidation of oil refining and marketing industry, is acquiring Total Petroleum (North America) Ltd for about $400 million in stock and assumption of $414 million in debt (M)

headline: Three Goldman Managers Start a Firm
abstract: Money managers Michael E Horowitz, Mark S Fife and Gregg S Hymowitz have left Goldman, Sach & Co to set up Entrust Capital Inc, an investment firm that manages money for wealthy clients; Entrust begins with about 125 clients and $750 million in assets (S)

headline: Bundesbank Leaves Rates Unchanged
abstract: Germany's Bundesbank leaves interest rates unchanged at historic lows; West Germany's annual inflation rate was 1.4 percent in April (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Apple Is Said to Seek Friendly Merger Candidate  Apple Computer is actively looking for a friendly merger candidate, several executives close to the company said. The disclosure came after Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, who has a history of making investments in successful turnaround efforts, announced that he had acquired more than 5 percent of Apple's stock.    The investment deepened the mystery surrounding comments made last week by Oracle's chairman, Larry Ellison, who said that he was considering making a bid for Apple with the aid of an unidentified group of investors. $(Page D3.$)    Compuserve in Takeover Talks  Compuserve acknowledged that it was in talks to be acquired, though it would not name the suitor. News reports have said that the rival America Online is preparing a bid, and securities analysts saw advantages for both sides in such a deal. $(D3.$)

headline: Saudi Case Casting a Light on How Militants Infiltrate and Exploit Canada
abstract: Recent of arrest in Canada of Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, Saudi man linked to bombing of US military barracks in Dhahran last June that killed 19 Americans, provides glimpse of how largely hidden network of militant groups uses Canada to raise money, recruit members, provide refuge and plan attacks; transcripts of interviews with Mohammed Hussein al-Husseini, another man accused of terrorism and deported three years ago, reveal surprising degree to which officials believe Iranian-backed militant group Hezbollah, has established presence in Canada (M)

headline: Official Says Pol Pot's Foes, Fearing Trial, May Kill Him
abstract: Cambodia's First Prime Min Norodom Ranariddh says enemies of Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot are likely to kill him rather than let him testify at trial where he could implicate them; says some Cambodians and some countries may not be interested in having him brought to justice; map (M)

headline: Stocks Regain Steam as Dow Jumps 58.35
abstract: Stock market sends all major indexes back into record territory afer suffering technology selloff day earlier; Dow Jones industrial average gains 58.35 points to close at 7,777.06 (M)

headline: Senate Vote Is Now Likely On Chemical Arms Treaty
abstract: Senate majority leader Trent Lott indicates that Senate will vote on whether to approve treaty to ban chemical weapons; former Defense Secs Caspar W Weinberger, James R Schlesinger and Donald M Rumsfeld tell Senate Committee on Foreign Relations that they oppose treaty, known as Chemical Weapons Convention (M)

headline: Nippon Credit Bank to Sell a U.S. Unit
abstract: Nippon Credit Bank Ltd, financially troubled Japanese bank, decides to sell all or part of Eastbridge Holdings, its United States primary dealership (S)

headline: At the Pawnshop, Lessons in Creativity
abstract: Commentary by Jack E Rossin, who claims that everything he knows about marketing he learned as a teenager, working in a pawnshop; says lessons include knowing the customer, offering him options, and the power of magic; drawing (M)

headline: Japanese Lawmakers Vote to Allow Heart and Lung Transplants
abstract: Japanese Parliament, after three decades of bitter national debate, approves bill that would allow heart or lung transplants, but only under strict conditions; issue has been whether patient whose brain has ceased to function can be legally defined as dead so organs can be used to save others; unlike in US and other Western countries, Japan regards person as legally dead only after heart has stopped; some Japanese doctors say strict conditions in bill will make it difficult to overcome longstanding taboos against such operations (M)

headline: U.S. and Russia Still Mired in Talks on Links to NATO
abstract: Just weeks away from a target of May 27 for completing a NATO-Russia charter, the United States and Russia remain far apart over fundamental military issues.    After a round of difficult talks today, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov put the best face on their meeting. But American and Russian officials said the negotiations were slow and the differences between the two sides considerable.

headline: N.A.S.D. Fines Prudential on Disclosure
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers arbitration panel orders Prudential Securities and former broker, Gerald Kissner, to pay Robert L Huff, Houston, Tex, customer, $813,000 including $500,000 in punitive damages, for failing to disclose that a company recommended by Kissner, WRT Energy Corp, had given him free stock; Huff lost $218,000 from a decline in WRT Energy stock (S)

headline: Producers' Group Presents Awards
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy and 'at' radical.media win most awards in their classes at annual Association of Independent Commercial Producers Show (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SOUTHERN NATIONAL CORP., Winston-Salem, N.C., agreed to acquire the investment banking firm Craigie Inc., Richmond, for an undisclosed amount.     AUTOIMMUNE INC., Lexington, Mass., a biotechnology company, said it would take a charge of about $300,000 in the second quarter and lay off 24 employees, or 31 percent of its work force, because of the disappointing performance of a trial drug.    DAVID WHITE INC., Germantown, Wis., a maker of optical and laser surveying instruments, agreed to be acquired by Choucroute Partners, a company formed by the Milwaukee businessman Robert Foote Jr., for $6 million, or $12 a share, in cash.     MGIC INVESTMENT CORP., Milwaukee, a mortgage insurance company, said its board approved a 2-for-1 stock split along with a 25 percent increase in the company's quarterly dividend.

headline: BLACKSTONE TO BUY COMMNET IN $718 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Commnet Cellular Inc plans to take company private by selling majority stake to Blackstone Group LP fund for $718 million including assumption of $200 million in debt (S)

headline: Too Little of Dow's Good Thing?
abstract: Lawsuit has been filed by 38 employees of Dow Environmental Inc, claiming that company reneged on its offer to reward them if company did well, in deferred-compensation plan begun in 1990; of 38 employees, only one benefited from plan; he is former president of unit, and he has joined suit, seeking rest of money he says he is owed; suit contends that company canceled plan because it had grown so much in value that it would have been too costly to pay employees (M)

headline: Coffee Prices Continue to Rise; Pork Bellies Hit 4-Week High
abstract: Coffee prices resume their ascent after world's largest producers decide to maintain export quotas for another year, dashing hopes for relief from lean inventories and high prices; pork bellies also rise (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BOSTON CO. ASSET MANAGEMENT, Boston, a unit of Mellon Bank Corp., named Francis Antin chief executive. Mr. Antin, formerly vice chairman and chief operating officer, joined the company in November 1995 from State Street Bank and Trust.    GILLETTE CO., Boston, named Gian Camuzzi vice president and treasurer effective July 1, succeeding Lloyd Swaim, who is retiring.

headline: A Wider Road, With New Curves, for Robertson, Stephens
abstract: Robertson Stephens & Co says it expects significant growth from planned acquisition by BankAmerica Corp, hoping to double its assets under management from $4.3 billion to $10 billion within two years; the brokerage firm sees two avenues to growth: new fund offerings that will attact more assets and sales of existing funds to the many thousands of customers of Bank America, the country's third-largest bank (M)

headline: CHS ELECTRONICS TO BUY SWISS CONCERN FOR $160 MILLION
abstract: CHS Electronics Inc to buy Karma International SA for $160 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Chip Maker to Sell Unit
abstract: DSC Communications Corp agrees to buy telecommunications division of Texas Instruments Inc for undisclosed amount of cash (S)

headline: Kin of Peru Guerrillas Held After Trip to Leader's Grave
abstract: Rosa Cardenas and Susan Roque, relatives of jailed Marxist guerrillas, are arrested by Peruvian law enforcement officials after paying respects to Tupac Amaru rebels killed in hostage rescue at Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima; arrests raise fears of renewed repressive crackdown on people with any ties to leftist rebels (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Climb Sharply To 6th Record Close in Row  The stock market extended its record-breaking run, as the Dow Jones industrial average soared another 70.57 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent. It was the sixth straight record close; for the week, the Dow gained 346 points, or about 4.7 percent.

headline: None of Their Business
abstract: Letter by Felicia Ackerman on April 20 article about use of personality tests to screen prospective National Football League draft choices (S)

headline: Health Care Investment
abstract: Transworld Home Healthcare Inc says Hyperion Partners II LP and its affiliate Hyperion TW Fund LP agreed to invest additional $52.8 million in the company (S)

headline: Japan's Prime Minister Offers Heartfelt Thanks for Rescue
abstract: Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto addresses Japan to express his heartfelt thanks that hostages in Lima, Peru, have been freed; acknowledges that he received no warning of raid, but he refuses to voice any criticism of Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru (M)

headline: West Warns Croatia on Serbs With Threat to Retain Enclave
abstract: Washington and its European allies have warned Zagreb that they will postpone transfer to Croatian control of a United Nations-administered enclave unless Croatia lives up to its commitments under the 1995 peace accords.    Western diplomats said today that the allies have been angered by Croatia's repeated refusal to allow exiled ethnic Serbs to return to their homes in Croatia. If Croatia continues to flout the Dayton peace accords, Western diplomats said they would press to extend the stay of the 5,000-member peacekeeping force in Eastern Slavonia, a swath of land that was seized by rebel Serbs six years ago.

headline: An Operating Chief to Calm The Ferment At Fidelity
abstract: Market Place column on Fidelity Investments' appointment of James C Curvey as chief operating officer and chairman of company's operating committee; says appointment puts Curvey in charge of day-to-day business, making him second in command to Fidelity's chairman Edward C Johnson 3d; holds industry analysts say move makes clear that Johnson has grown weary of lingering questions about company's ability to continue dominating mutual fund business (L)

headline: British Airways Halts A Planned Spinoff
abstract: British Airways PLC will not spin off its aircraft maintenance division until at least 2000, shelving plan it had hoped would cut costs (S)

headline: CABLETRON SHARES PLUMMET ON WARNING OF WEAK PROFIT
abstract: Stock of Cabletron Systems Inc falls by a third after company, a network equipment maker, says slowing sales will hurt profit for at least two quarters; Cabletron shares plunged $15.50, to $30.25 (S)

headline: CAPSTAR TO BUY 8 STATIONS AND SWAP 3 OTHERS WITH SFX
abstract: Capstar Broadcasting Partners Inc will buy eight radio stations in Mississippi for $60 million in cash and swap three others with SFX Broadcasting Inc; Capstar says it will pay $70 million to buy closely held Knight Quality Stations, which operates eight radio stations in New England (S)

headline: Image Retrieval System Wins M.I.T. Entrepreneurship Prize
abstract: Massachusetts Institute of Technology awards grand prize in its yearly $50K Entrepreneurship Competition to team called Imagen for its image retrieval technologies; two runner-up prizes go to one team for its plan to create wireless pen mouse and another for its plan to create computer monitor that allows users to see objects in three dimensions (S)

headline: How Tight Is the Knot In Partnership Pacts?
abstract: Legal issues in Wall Street partnerships discussed; Mimi Willard, partner at Cowen & Co, discusses her fight with firm over her move to rival Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette; photo (S)

headline: Court Won't Reconsider Tax Ruling in Favor Of Texaco
abstract: Supreme Court lets stand lower court ruling that Texaco Inc does not owe about $1 billion in Federal taxes; Texaco expects to get refund of $700 million from Internal Revenue Service this year and says its first-quarter earnings would benefit by $488 million as a result of Court's decision; high court's position could also benefit Exxon Corp, which has been involved in similar dispute with IRS and has similar case pending in lower court; tax dispute goes back to events that occurred from 1979 to 1981, when Saudi Arabia broke from OPEC and Texaco and Exxon, part of Aramco, consortium of American oil companies that marketed cheaper Saudi crude, made a commercial windfall when prices soared during Iran-Iraq war; IRS maintained that Texaco could shift about $1.8 billion of income from foreign subsidiaries to parent company and be subject to US taxation (L)

headline: INGRAM MICRO BUYING UNIT OF INTELLIGENT ELECTRONICS
abstract: Ingram Micro Inc is buying Intelligent Electronics Inc's computer distribution business for $78 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: Whisky Kills Cow in Spain, Setting Off a Furor
abstract: Death of young cow, forced to drink four bottles of whisky during fiesta in farming village in northern Spain, prompts police investigation and demands by animal rights advocates for crackdown on cruelty to animals (M)

headline: Zaire's Fall Jolts Neighboring Angola's Frail Peace
abstract: Angolan Government troops, in spillover of effect of war in Congo, formerly Zaire, attack territory controlled by longtime rebel enemies, who lost their most important backer when Mobutu Sese Seko, Zairian dictator, was ousted; military officials and diplomats say Angolan Government, which signed peace treaty with rebels in 1994, has launched offensives deep in country's diamond mining territory--source of income for UNITA rebels; photo; map (M)

headline: Straining Toward an Agreement on Global Bribery Curb
abstract: US and its major trading partners remain sharply divided over how to enact and enforce long-sought global ban on commercial bribery; Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development hopes to announce agreement at its annual meeting of finance ministers that opens in France on May 26 that would subject companies in all member countries to same restaints that US business has faced since Congress passed Foreign Corrupt Practices Act two decades ago; while most OECD members acknowledge need for ban on kickbacks, which in some countries are not only tolerated but remain tax deductible as business expenses, rift has developed between Clinton Administration and some of its key allies on form the ban should take (L)

headline: A Heath Care Giant Has a Taste of Defeat
abstract: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has become the world's largest health care company by aggressively competing in an industry dominated by institutions named for saints and samaritans. But now its practices have inspired a backlash.     Money and Business, Section 3.

headline: BAXTER TO BACK VIMRX DEVELOPMENTAL VENTURE
abstract: Vimrx Pharmaceuticals Inc and Baxter International Inc form joint venture to development treatments for cancer, AIDS and other diseases

headline: Maya Dress Tells a New Story, and It's Not Pretty
abstract: Ancient weaving tradition of Maya women of Guatemala is in peril in San Pedro Sacatepequez and other towns, result of three decades of civil war and economic, social and religious changes that war brought; map; photo (M)

headline: Ben Raeburn, 86, Publisher Of the Known and the Aspiring
abstract: Ben Raeburn, who published complete works of Frank Lloyd Wright and a pantheon of authors, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Europe Rivals Set TV Venture
abstract: Kirch Group and CLT-UFA plan to form German pay-TV joint venture and agree to use single digital decoder box to decode transmissions, ending long-running dispute; will use pay-TV broadcaster Premiere as vehicle for venture, each increasing stake to 50 percent by buying Canal Plus SA's 37.5 percent stake (S)

headline: China Defeats U.N. Resolution Critical of Its Record on Rights
abstract: United Nations Human Rights Commissions, after aggressive Chinese lobbying drive that divided its European members, rejects resolution condemning China's human rights record, 27-17; Chinese delegate Wu Jianmin, who earlier scored Western effort to dominate China's fate, hails vote; State Sec Madeleine K Albright says United States, resolution co-sponsor, regrets vote (M)

headline: Coke Campaign to Challenge Pepsi's 'Stuff'
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's new promotional and advertising campaign will not be named 'Coke Stuff,' despite fact that there are similarities to 'Pepsi Stuff' campaign of company's archrival; promotion will be called 'Coca-Cola Incredible Summer,' and it will start in late May; ad campaign, developed by Edge Creative and Leo Burnett Inc, detailed; photo (L)

headline: MacManus Forms Media Company
abstract: MacManus Group forms worldwide media company called Mediavest; Mediavest will be headed by Michael D Moore as president and chief executive; Adrian Birchall is named president of Mediavest Europe, Middle East and Africa; Kevin Malloy is named global client media director; J C Penney Co names MacManus Group's Televest to handle its national television and syndication buys, account with estimated billings of $125 million; account had been at Bozell Worldwide (S)

headline: Airline Seeks Value Of Shuttle Concern
abstract: US Airways Group Inc is trying to establish value of Shuttle Inc and will consider its option to purchase the company; Shuttle Inc operates US Airwyas shuttle (S)

headline: Dow Up 37.50 to Reach Record 7,383.41
abstract: Stocks advanced to new highs yesterday in a rally led by computer issues.    The Dow Jones industrial average rose 37.50 points, to a record 7,383.41, led by I.B.M., which jumped 5 7/8, to 179 1/4, an all-time high. AT&T, the most widely held stock, contributed to the rally, rising 1 3/8, to 37 1/2. The stock rose after The Wall Street Journal reported that the company was in merger talks with SBC Communications Inc. SBC gained  3/4, to 57 5/8.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pepsico to Sell Unit That Supplies Restaurants   Pepsico has agreed to sell its PFS restaurant-supply unit to Ameriserve Food Distribution for a price believed to be in the half-billion-dollar range.

headline: The Question of Succession
abstract: AT&T faces acute management problem; John R Walter, who was recruited by Robert E Allen, chairman, as his heir-designate last November, has been living under dark cloud since reports arose two months ago that he might not get top job; one board member says that Walter might be edged out by John D Zeglis, general counsel of AT&T who has been promoted to vice chairman; photo of Allen and Walter (M)

headline: Smith Barney's Chief of Funds Quits for Post At Small Firm
abstract: Jessica M Bibliowicz resigns as head of Smith Barney's $78 billion mutual fund business; she will join John A Levin & Co, investment advisory firm, as president, chief operating officer and director; photo (M)

headline: Late Selloff Blunts Sharp Rise as the Dow Ends Up 50.97
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average is up 50.97 points, or 0.72 percent, at 7,136.62; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks finishes at 820.26, up 4.64 points, or 0.57 percent; Nasdaq composite index closes up 10.06 points, or 1.1 percent, to 919.35; table (L)

headline: Albanian Village Finds Boom in Gun-Running
abstract: Albanian Justice Min Spartak Ngjela says rioters ransacked Government storehouses of weapons and took hundreds of thousands of AK-47 assault rifles last month; says substantial number of weapons are being smuggled into Macedonia (M)

headline: German Company In Deal for Floor Unit
abstract: Tarkett AG, German hardwood-floor maker, will acquire floor-covering business of French plastics maker Sommer Allibert SA for 705 million marks ($416.2 million) in cash and assumption of 250 million marks in debt; Sommer Allibert plans to acquire 50 percent stake in Tarkett by paying 32.75 marks a share for 20.1 million Tarkett shares; once transaction is completed, Sommer Allibert will own 50 percent of Tarkett's shares (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Gil Bashe, executive managing director at Hill & Knowlton, New York, and worldwide director for health and pharmaceutical accounts, was named to the additional new position of vice chairman for strategic planning at Common Health, a health care communications agency that like Hill & Knowlton is owned by WPP Group.

headline: EGGHEAD TO BUY SURPLUS SOFTWARE FOR $25.9 MILLION
abstract: Computer retailer Egghead Inc agrees to buy Surplus Software Inc for about $25.9 million; Egghead will also assume about $5.6 million of Surplus Software's debt in the transaction (S)

headline: Clinton Meets a Thorn in China's Side
abstract: Pres Clinton meets with Martin Lee, prominent Hong Kong democratic politician, and warns Chinese leaders that they should 'live up to their agreement' to protect Hong Kong's economic, political and civil liberties after British colony returns to Beijing's sovereignty on July 1; photo (M)

headline: Refugees in Zaire at End of a Death Trek
abstract: Rwandan Hutu refugees in Zaire find their desperate five-month flight from Tutsi pursuers coming to deadly end deep in Zairian rain forest, hundreds of miles from their homeland; near Biaro, Zaire, thousands of Rwandan refugees, driven there by war and now stranded by diplomatic impasse, have built shelters of bamboo, palm fronds, plastic sheeting; inside some of shelters, skeletal figures beckon for water and wait for death; sick and exhausted people are littered about the ground, sleeping on bundles of rags; United Nations officials estimate that 120 refugees are dying each day among 80,000 Hutus in camps along a slender dirt road running south through forest from Kisangani, regional capital, to Ubundu, 72 miles away; most of refugees are gathered in two groups in villages 15 miles and 26 miles south of city; they are succumbing to malaria, dysentery and other diseases; photos (M)

headline: 2 Building Companies In Spain Consider Merger
abstract: Securities regulators in Spain suspend trading in shares of builders OCP Constructiones SA and Gines Navarro SA because of possibility companies will merge (S)

headline: Industry Group to Offer Standards for Privacy on Internet
abstract: Group of about 40 companies, in face of growing concerns about privacy in cyberspace, will propose standards this week intended to enable computer users to control what personal identification is obtained when they visit Internet sites and how that information is used, as well as avoid unwanted junk mail; industry initiative is led by Netscape Communications Corp, Internet software maker (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Pall

headline: Consumer Price Index Rises Only Slightly for 3d Straight Month
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.1 percent, May, as combination of global and domestic forces held inflation unusually low for third straight month; Federal Reserve reports industrial output rose in May by strong 0.4 percentage points and capacity utilization rose to 83.7 percent from 83.6 percent in Apr; Commerce Department reports housing starts fell by 4.8 percent, May, to Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.1 percent, May, as combination of global and domestic forces held inflation unusually low for third straight month; Federal Reserve reports industrial output rose in May by strong 0.4 percentage points and capacity utilization rose to 83.7 percent from 83.6 percent in Apr; Commerce Department reports housing starts fell by 4.8 percent, May, to annual rate of 1.397 million units; graphs; table (M)

headline: Can Bond Trading Stay This Dull?
abstract: Market Watch column on seeming certainty of investors and speculators that nothing major will happen in bond market, as evidenced by extraordinarily low prices investors are paying for bond options, lowest premiums since 1993; problem is that bond market has bet heavily on continuation of low volatility; risk for investors lies in what will happen if that expectation proves to be wrong; graph (M)

headline: Rhone-Poulenc May Buy Rest of Drug Subsidiary
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc SA may acquire 31.7 percent of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc that it does not already own as part of possible plan to shed nonpharmaceutical operations; weighs offer of $4.3 billion (S)

headline: Dow Declines 43.34 Points In Dull Session
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 43.34 points, to 6,660.21; Nasdaq composite index drops 18.62 points, or 1.52 percent, at 1,203.95; table (M)

headline: There's a New Mix of Fundamentals in Baking
abstract: Fast-changing baking industry is attracting investor interest as companies consolidate, cut costs and try to strengthen value of their national brands; industry has become much more apparent and accountable to investors with splitoffs of major bakers from larger conglomerates; table; photo (M)

headline: Panamerican Beverages and Venezuelan Bottler to Merge
abstract: Panamerican Beverages Inc, Latin America's largest soft drink bottling company and one of world's largest Coca-Cola bottlers, agrees to merge with Coca-Cola y Hit de Venzuela, Venezuela's leading soft drink bottler, in cash and and stock transaction valued at about $1.2 billion; Panamerican exchanges 30.6 million shares and about $100.3 million in cash for all of stock in Coca-Cola y Hit (L)

headline: Europe Battery Job Is Awarded to Bates
abstract: Ralston Energy Systems, part of Ralston Purina Co, names Bates Worldwide to handle its Energizer battery account in Europe, with billings at $20 million; account had been handled by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO (S)

headline: Safeco Is Said to Buy A Unit From Lincoln
abstract: Safeco Corp agrees to buy American States Financial Corp, Lincoln National Corp's property and casualty insurance unit, for about $2.7 billion (S)

headline: American Topics
abstract: They're big and getting bigger; they're headed for huge; they're nuns! Americans, it seems, are buying nun puppets, nun greeting cards, even nun snow globes in droves. Squeak Toy Nun, "pious but not uptight," is a favorite; so are the 13 superhero nuns of the Warrior Nun comic book series.

headline: Foster's Shares Being Bought Back and Sold
abstract: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd will pay $468 million to buy back 13 percent of its shares held by Asahi Breweries Ltd of Japan; Foster's major shareholder, Broken Hill Proprietary Co says it is selling its 36.5 percent stake (S)

headline: In a Violent and Fearful Mood, Albania Goes to the Polls
abstract: Disillusioned and anxious Albanians are set to vote in Parliamentary election expected to be marked by violence and fraud; at stake in voting is future of Pres Sali Berisha, who is widely blamed for nation's collapse into lawlessness; Western officials say it is impossible to hold fair elections; map; photo (M)a

headline: The Clintons' Caribbean: TV, a Pool and Time Off
abstract: Vignettes from Pres Clinton's Latin American and Caribbean trip; photo (M)

headline: Zairian Insurgents Keep U.N. From Suspected Massacre Sites
abstract: Facing two soldiers on the other side of a stick across a jungle road, a high-level United Nations delegation today tried to get into an area where a team of Rwandan soldiers is rumored to be massacring refugees, burning their bodies and scattering the ashes in the forest.    Although a United Nations official said that the rebel leader Laurent Kabila had told them just that morning that the delegation's members would be allowed anywhere refugees were, the two soldiers at the checkpoint turned them back, saying they had received no orders.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL MOTORS CORP., -- Detroit, revised its second-quarter production estimate, cutting output by about 46,000 units, to 1,477,000.    AMERICAN GENERAL FINANCE CORP., -- Evansville, Ind., a unit of American General Corp., agreed to sell to a Ford Motor Co. subsidiary its portfolio of outstanding loans to consumers who used the money to buy home satellite dishes. The book value of receivables in the sale was placed at $253 million.

headline: 13 Years After Invasion, Grenada Agonizes Anew
abstract: Proposal to name Grenada's airport for Maurice Bishop, Marxist Prime Minister whose execution provided pretext for 1983 United States invasion, stirs passions; comes at time when Grenada still grapples with question of clemency for leaders of radical faction of Bishop's own party that ousted and killed him; most are serving life term; Grenadians seem as disinclined as ever to confront past; map; photos (M)

headline: Nike's Asian Factories Pass Young's Muster
abstract: Andrew Young says his probe for Nike Inc of labor practices at its Asian plants found no evidence of widespread or systematic abuses, news conference; holds Nike should do more to insure that foreign subcontractors comply with its code of conduct; findings anger some critics of Nike (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford to Build Vehicles Using Ethanol or Gasoline  Ford Motor announced that it would build 250,000 cars, pickup trucks and mini-vans to run on either ethanol or gasoline. The effort, beginning late next year and to last over a period of years, is the largest alternative fuel vehicle program ever in the United States.    Chrysler is expected to announce a similar program, and General Motors is considering the idea. Environmentalists were critical. Under a loophole in Federal law, building dual-fuel vehicles will help Detroit sell more big profit, big-engine, gas-guzzling trucks and sport utility vehicles. Their strong sales are putting Ford and Chrysler at risk of violating Federal fuel-economy standards. $(Page A1.$)

headline: Swiss Army Brands uses astronauts, Navy Seals and name recognition to sell its new sunglasses.
abstract: Swiss Army Brands Inc is entering the market with new line of sunglasses backed by $3.5 milion advertising campaign created by Hill, Holiday, Connors, Cosmopulos (M)

headline: CYRK INTERNATIONAL AGREES TO BUY SIMON MARKETING
abstract: Cyrk International will buy closely held promoter Simon Marketing for as much as $63 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: In Lush Tropics, a Flowering of Murderous Gangs
abstract: Tough young criminals have taken over streets of Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, terrorizing local and foreign residents; over last decade, influx of unemployed people, faltering economy and breakdown of many Government services have contributed to epidemic of assaults, burglaries, carjackings and gang rapes; map; photo (M)/

headline: NCR Expects Net to Disappoint Analysts
abstract: NCR Corp warns that second-quarter earnings will fall below analysts' estimates (S)

headline: Evidence for a modest impact from abolishing rent controls.
abstract: Economic Scene column on impact of abolishing rent controls in New York; says economists point out that averge rents could not possibly reach level of rents on free market units because they simply are not enough people with both the income and the desire to live in Manhattan for $1,500 a month; William Tucker, specialist in housing and author of new report on rent regulation, offers solid evidence that abolishing controls would have only modest impact on most rents; drawing (L)

headline: This Dehydrated Isle, Demi-Desert, This England
abstract: English fret that their famously wet country may be drying up; there is intensifying drought in southern and western England; last 24 months have been driest two-year period in England and Wales since reliable record-keeping began 230 years ago; this is third consecutive year of alarmingly dry weather, and Environment Agency warns that this may become long-term phenomenon because of global warming; water crisis reviewed (M)

headline: Short Positions on Nasdaq Rose 6.3% in Latest Month
abstract: Nasdaq reports overall short position in Nasdaq stocks rose 6.3 percent in month through April 10, to record 1.53 billion shares; tables (M)

headline: Serb Is Held In the Killing Of 261 Croats
abstract: Slavko Dokmanovic, Serb charged in 1991 massacre of 261 patients in Croatian hospital, is arrested by investigators for international tribunal for war crimes in former Yugoslavia; arrest is the first by tribunal's own investigators; case reviewed; map (M)

headline: Microsoft to Buy WebTV, Blending PC's, TV's and the Internet
abstract: Microsoft Corp will acquire WebTV Networks Inc, start-up company that delivers Internet information directly to television sets, for $425 million; this is latest in series of maneuvers by Microsoft to extend its reach from personal computer, which is in 40 percent of American homes, to television, which is in 98 percent of all homes in America; Microsoft plans to add software to permit its Windows operating system to be used in new hybrid computer-TV, called a PC-Theater, which computer makers plan to produce within next few months; Microsoft also will announce with Intel Corp and Compaq Computer Corp their technical plans for digital interactive computer-TV's, plans they hope will become standard adopted by broadcasters (M)

headline: Lois/EJL to Handle Rio Casino Account
abstract: Rio All-Suite Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev, names Lois/EJL to handle its advertising account (S)

headline: Suspect in Japan Beheading Is Linked to 2 Other Attacks
abstract: News reports link unidentified 14-year-old boy, arrested in slaying and beheading of 11-year old Jun Hase, to two previous attacks against children in Kobe, Japan (S)

headline: One Sky, Many Owners
abstract: Comment by Peter Barnes on prospect of setting up system of marketable permits for carbon dioxide emissions to combat global warming and deciding who would own the permits; suggests way that revenue from permits would benefit all current and future citizens (L)

headline: Sex and the Argentines: The Anatomy of a Scandal
abstract: Federico Andahazi's first novel The Anatomist, about scientist's interest in function of clitoris, causes literary uproar in Argentina; Fortabat Foundation's prize for book is canceled by Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat, wealthy businesswoman who sponsors prestigious award; Fortabat, outraged by subject, grudgingly agrees to give $15,000 prize money, but not the prize, to 33-year-old psychologist-author; his photo; incident propels book to top of best-seller list and leads to discussion of both freedom of expression and issues of female sexuality (Buenos Aires Journal) (S)

headline: Hong Kong Paper Cuts Newsstand Price
abstract: Oriental Press Group, publisher of Hong Kong's biggest-selling newspaper Oriental Daily News, says it will cut its newsstand price, causing concern that price war might force smaller competitors to close; Oriental Daily will cut its price to $2 from $5 (Hong Kong), or 26 cents from 65 cents (US) (S)

headline: Another Nursing Home Deal Is Set, for $1.8 Billion
abstract: Living Centers of America announces it will merge with Grancare Inc in two-step, $1.8 billion transaction; complex deal will give Apollo Management LP, firm headed by Leon Black, former Drexel Burnham Lambert deal maker, controlling stake in the company; new company, which has yet to be named, will be one of largest providers of long-term care in the country, with 330 nursing homes (L)

headline: How U.N. Keeps Pace, With Fewer Troops to Keep the Peace
abstract: United Nations in 1994 was running 18 peacekeeping operations, fielding total force of some 80,000 peacekeepers from 82 countries at annual cost of almost $3.3 billion; today, UN is running 17 peackeeping operations, but it has only 23,000 soldiers in field and its peacekeeping budget has shrunk to $1.3 billion (M)

headline: POLYMER GROUP IN BID FOR MERFIN INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Polymer Group Inc offers to buy Merfin International Inc for more than $130 million, topping Buckeye Cellulose Corporation's bid to buy Canadian property; Polymer is offering $7.15 (Canadian) for each share of Merfin (S)

headline: Norwegian Bank Seeks Acquisition
abstract: Sparebankgruppen, a regional savings bank, wants to take over Fokus Bank, Norway's third-largest commercial lender; Sparebankgruppen says its bid is valued at about $689 million (S)

headline: Uncertainty Undercuts Case Against Saudi Bomb Suspect
abstract: United States aides say they are unsure whether Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, Saudi held in Canada, can provide enough evidence about June bombing of American military barracks, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, to make it worthwhile to bring him to US; say they do not have enough evidence to prove he played role in attack; Canada rebuffs Federal Bureau of Investigation bid to interview him while it decides whether to deport him as national security threat (M)

headline: HarperCollins Cancels Books In Unusual Step for Industry
abstract: HarperCollins publishing house begins rare push to downsize its book lists, canceling at least 100 titles and finished manuscripts in cost-cutting move that is indicative of publishing industry's doldrums; chief exececutive Anthea Disney says company canceled 36 titles in last two weeks (M)

headline: Time to Play?
abstract: Stories solicited about life in the office when the boss is on vacation

headline: Zaire's President and Rebel Agree to Shipboard Meeting
abstract: Pres Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire and rebel leader Laurent Kabila agree to meet aboard South African ship off Atlantic coast on May 2; agreement comes after two days of shuttle diplomacy by Pres Clinton's special envoy Bill Richardson; he says there are no conditions and established agenda for talks; Mobutu resists Kabila's demand that he step down immediately, but military reality of situation, with rebel forces nearing Kinshasa, is forcing President to negotiate terms of his departure; map; photo (M)

headline: Oil and Gasoline Prices Surge On Concern About Refineries
abstract: Crude oil and gasoline prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange, hurt by worries over refinery shutdowns and a strike in Nigeria (M)

headline: American Topics : Word at the NOW Meeting:'Polygamy Is Empowering'
abstract: The Utah members of the National Organization of Women heard from an unlikely speaker at their recent conference in Salt Lake City, Utah: a polygamist wife who says she has the ultimate feminist lifestyle.

headline: Swiss Join NATO Plan, Easing a Long Isolation
abstract: Switzerland, in a first step away from its traditional isolationism, joins NATO's security cooperation pact, called Partnership for Peace; but Swiss officials emphasize that their country's participation will be limited (S)

headline: Fear of Coming Data Weighs on Treasuries
abstract: Traders bid down prices of Treasury securities; 30-year bond falls 16/32, to price of 94 12/32 to yield 7.08 percent, up from 7.04 percent on April 22; graph (L)

headline: Correction: Stock Performance
abstract: A chart in Business Day yester-day comparing stock perform-ance of four designer clothing companies was mislabelled in a way that greatly understated movements in the stocks' value. Here is a corrected chart.     Graph tracks changes in Liz Claiborne, Gucci, Tommy Hilfiger, and Donna Karan stock prices, since Donna Karan's initial public offering June 28, 1996. (Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

headline: Pope Lands In Beirut Issuing Call For Healing
abstract: Pope John Paul II begins two-day visit to Lebanon with appeal for reconciliation in countries where Christians and Muslims live together; photo of Pope in Beirut (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Stone & Webster  Eastern Utils Assoc  Goodrich B F  Noble Affil  Southern

headline: Resignations In Turkey Imperiling Islamic Chief
abstract: Two Cabinet ministers from Turkey's secular True Path Party resign, shaking coalition Government led by Islamic party head Necmettin Erbakan; score his reluctance to honor Feb pledge to reverse some Islamist policies; he is also under increasing pressure from military; senior military and civilian leaders, including Erbakan, gather in Ankara for key meeting of National Security Council (M)

headline: Grenfell Hires Merrill Banker
abstract: Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Inc, continuing its drive to establish a major Wall Street firm, hires C Edward Carter to head its American investment banking division; Carter spent 16 years at Merrill Lynch & Co (S)

headline: Industry Index In Unexpected May Rebound
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management says its overall index jumped 57.1 in May, nearly 3 points above its April reading and highest since November 1994; Commerce Department reports personal income and spending each edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in April, although savings rate remained at 5.1 percent despite unusually heavy mid-April income tax payments; new construction dropped 1 percent in April to annual pace of $596.9 billion; construction in private sector fell 1 percent, to $450.2 billion, while spending on public works fell 2 percent, to $146.7 billion; graphs (L)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             June 6   May 30   June 7          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   8.0   8.2   7.7       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.7   3.4       Gasoline stocks   202.4   199.7   205.8       Distillate stocks   109.3   107.3   96.8       Crude imports, daily   8.4   8.4   8.0       Product imports, daily   1.9   2.3   1.7       Crude stocks   324.0   323.6   310.4       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.3       Refinery utilization (%)   98.3   98.4   94.5          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: British Fund Manager Says Profits Rose 22%
abstract: Mercury Asset Management, Britain's largest fund manager, says pretax profit for year ended March 30 rose 22 percent, to 171.3 million pounds ($277.5 million), from 140.4 million pounds last year (S)

headline: MAGELLAN AEROSPACE TO ACQUIRE ROLLS-ROYCE SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Magellan Aerospace Corp agrees to acquire Bristol Aerospace Ltd from Rolls-Royce Industries Canada Inc for $44.9 million (S)

headline: Helping the Young, At Whose Expense?
abstract: Eric Laursen letter on Alexei Bayer's May 4 article proposing extending vote indirectly to children to counter increasing influence of elderly by giving parents extra votes (S)

headline: Amstrad to Sell Unit To Bosch of Germany
abstract: Amstrad PLC, British consumer electronics maker, is selling mobile telephone unit Dancall Telecom to Robert Bosch GmbH of Germany for 92 million pounds ($150 million) (S)

headline: USA WASTE SERVICES IN $312 MILLION EXPANSION
abstract: USA Waste Services Inc agrees to acquire certain assets from Browning-Ferris Industries and Allied Waste Industries as well as assets of two closely held waste companies for $312 million in stock and cash; USA Waste is third largest trash hauler (S)

headline: COMSAT FILES LAWSUIT AGAINST FORMER CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Comsat Corp sues Bruce Crockett, former chief executive, contending he leaked inside information to shareholders who have threatened to take over company; lawsuit, which seeks $20 million in damages, comes two weeks after Providence Capital Inc and Wyser-Pratte Inc said they would wage proxy fight to replace Comsat's directors because stock has fallen 27 percent the past year (S)

headline: Are Nordstrom's Efforts Eroding Profits?
abstract: Article on financial problems plaguing Nordstrom Inc; says that as Nordstrom has grown into national department store chain, its vendors have become increasingly critical of chain's decentralized management structure--a system that puts basic decisions about fashion mix and merchandising in the hands of local managers; Nordstrom acknowledges that its unique culture resulted in some mistakes; some of retailer's mistakes detailed; graphs; photos (L)

headline: NEW CONGO LEADER MEETS U.S. ENVOY ON REFUGEE ISSUE
abstract: The new leader of Congo, Laurent Kabila, promised today to allow the United Nations to investigate accusations that his forces killed thousands of refugees during the rebellion that brought him to power, an American envoy said.    ''This is a major breakthrough,'' said the envoy, Bill Richardson, who is the United States chief delegate to the United Nations. Mr. Richardson led a high-level delegation that met with Mr. Kabila for two hours today in this mining capital in the southeastern corner of Congo.

headline: DU PONT TO SELL GRAPHICS AND PRINTING-PLATE BUSINESSES
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co agrees to sell its graphics film and offset-printing plates businesses to Bayer AG's Agfa-Gevaert; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Profit Is Flat At I.B.M., but Revenue Rises
abstract: IBM reports first-quarter earnings of $1.195 billion, up 54 percent from $774 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue increased 4.5 percent, to $17.3 billion; table (L)

headline: Profit Sharing at Hewlett
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co distributes more than $176 million to almost 112,000 employees as part of profit-sharing plan (S)

headline: SUIZA FOODS IN $400 MILLION DAIRIES AND FACTORIES DEAL
abstract: Suiza Foods Corp agrees to buy four dairies and other businesses for about $400 million in cash and stock; dairies are Dairy Fresh LP, Garelick Farms, Fairdale Farms and Grant's Dairy (S)

headline: A proposal to overhaul patent law has one Congressman hopping mad about the changes.
abstract: Proponents and opponents of 21st Century Patent System Improvement Act are poised to start last-minute lobbying blitz as House of Representatives schedules full vote on measure; bill would transform Patent Office into quasi-private corporation; most controversial part of bill is provision that would publish patents 18 months after they are filed, rather than keeping patents secret until they are issued; Douglas Engelbart receives $500,000 award from MIT-Lemelson Prize Program for his role in personal computer revolution; he received patent for computer mouse in 1969 (M)

headline: To Aid Banks, Japan Plans To Buy $3.1 Billion of Land
abstract: Japanese Government will buy 380 billion yen, or $3.1 billion, of land held as collateral for loans as part of measures to help real estate prices and aid nation's banks; analysts say Government is not doing enough, a view that investors in financial markets seem to share (L)

headline: For Cover Subject Of Time Magazine, A Time Warner Deal
abstract: Time Inc executives say it is just coincidence that its Time magazine named Dr Andrew Weil as one of 25 most influential people in country just month before its New Media unit acquired the 'Ask Dr Weil' Web site; visitors to Dr Weil's site look at two million pages a month, making it lucrative source of ad revenue (S)

headline: Raids Are Reported At Japanese Firms
abstract: Japanese news organizations are reporting that regulators have searched offices of three big Japanese securities houses; reports are latest sign the scandal at Nomura Securities could affect rest of brokerage industry; investigators are looking for evidence that Daiwa Securities, Yamaichi Securities and Nikko Securities funneled profits to Ryuichi Koike, corporate racketeer named in Nomura scandal (S)

headline: Gehe Reports Sales Rose 13% in Quarter
abstract: Gehe AG says sales rose 13 percent in first quarter; sales rose to 6.107 billion marks ($3.6 billion), from 5.407 billion marks in first quarter last year; excluding purchase of Lloyds Chemists PLC, pretax profit rose 5.4 percent, to 104.2 million marks from 98.9 million (S)

headline: Taking Office, Congo's Ruler Promises Vote
abstract: Laurent Kabila, rebel leader whose army swept Mobutu Sese Seko out of power, is sworn in as President of Democratic Republic of Congo; Kabila, in his inaugural address, promises transition to democracy with elections in April 1999; says Constitution will be drafted and put to referendum by Dec 1998; photo (M)

headline: After 27,000 Guests, the Great Gabfest Winds Up
abstract: Radio host Peter Gzowski, whose voice has become one of best known and most comforting in Canada, is giving up 3-hour daily show after 15 years; photo (M)

headline: Unlike EU, It Moves Slowly on Integration : ASEAN:Less Is More
abstract: SINGAPORE—  When asked recently what he had found unique about ASEAN, Vu Khoan, the deputy foreign minister of Vietnam, thought for a moment then replied with a smile: "Having to try to play golf and sing karaoke, because it leads to quiet diplomacy."

headline: Unspoken Dissent
abstract: Letter by Bert Ely on April 20 article on Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae (S)r

headline: INTEGRATED REVISES ITS ACQUISITION OF CORAM HEALTHCARE
abstract: Integrated Health Services Inc reduces stock part of its planned acquisition of Coram Healthcare Corp to about $186 million (S)

headline: NETANYAHU AVOIDS CRIMINAL CHARGES IN SCANDAL INQUIRY
abstract: Israel's state prosecutors, citing lack of sufficient evidence, will not indict Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu on charges related to scandal over appointment of attorney general, but say there is tangible suspicion over propriety of his role in affair; Netanyahu claims exoneration; admits he made mistakes, but says he did not commit any crime; bitterly assails news media and opposition; political opposition immediately revives calls for resignation; left-wing will sue to reverse ruling; decision follows investigation into allegations that Netanyahu appointed Roni Bar-On, lawyer with close ties to his Likud Party, Attorney General to secure plea bargain for Aryeh Deri, political ally who was facing corruption charges; photo (M)

headline: Two Chip Makers Surprise Wall Street With Earnings
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc says company earned $13 million in first quarter of 1997, more than half the $25.3 million it reported in comparable period a year ago; sales grew slightly, to $552 million, from $544.2 million in first quarter of 1996; Motorola Inc earned $325 million in quarter, down 15 percent from $384 million in year-earlier quarter; sales fell 4.5 percent, to $6.64 billion, from $6.96 billion in first quarter of 1996 (L)

headline: BOSC Technologies Picks Carmichael Lynch
abstract: BOSC Technologies, marketer and retailer of personal computers, names Carmichael Lynch as first agency to handle its advertising account (S)

headline: Saks and Isetan Offer $290 Million for Barney's
abstract: Saks Holdings Inc and Isetan Co of Japan make long-awaited bid for Barney's Inc, offering $290 million in cash and Saks stock; unsecured Barney's creditors immediately reject the offer, declaring that it would unfairly favor Isetan, Barney's largest creditor, over them; Isetan resigns from official committee of creditors, seeking independent route to recoup its money (M)

headline: SALLIE MAE TO OFFER DISSIDENTS SEATS ON A NEW BOARD
abstract: Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, is planning to offer board seats to a dissident shareholder group in bid to retain control of the company (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * McCann-Erickson Washington, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was awarded an account and becomes the first agency to handle advertising for The Newseum, an interactive museum devoted to news, Rosslyn, Va. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: Nationalists In Croatia Turn Away From West
abstract: Western diplomats say Croatia's ruling nationalist party, spurred by sweeping election victory, is scuttling American-led initiatives to rebuild region and defying Western pressure to allow return of Serb refugees and prosecute indicted war criminals; say US will block pending $486 million international loan to Croatia if it does not extradite Zlatko Aleksovski, charged with atrocities against Muslim civilians in Bosnia (S)

headline: Sports Authority Goes to Lord Group
abstract: Sports Authority Inc names Lord Group to handle its advertising and marketing account, with billings estimated at more than $20 million (S)

headline: Kidder to Pay $14.1 Million To Settle Suit By Investors
abstract: Kidder, Peabody & Co, which has not operated as a brokerage firm for two years, agrees to pay $14.1 million to settle class-action lawsuit that accused 35 firms of fixing prices on Nasdaq stock market; Kidder is second firm to settle investors' suit, which was filed in 1994; Sherwood Securities Corp agreed earlier this month to pay $9.2 million; Kidder, Peabody, which is winding down operations and completing its legal obligations, denies any wrongdoing (M)

headline: Bausch & Lomb Will Trim 1,900 Jobs in Revamping
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc will eliminate 1,900 jobs, or about 14 percent of its work force, as part of revamping that company says will result in more than $100 million in annual savings by 1999; company earned $3.3 million in first quarter, down 85 percent from $2.5 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $451.2 million, compared with $454.4 million in first quarter of 1996 (M)

headline: Publisher of Vibe Buys Spin Magazine
abstract: Spin magazine, chronicler of alternative-music scene, is sold to Miller Publishing Group, a partnership that publishes Vibe, a magazine focusing on urban sounds like hip hop; sale price is $43.3 million; Spin was owned by Robert Guccione Jr (S)

headline: Congo's Neighbors Played Crucial Role in Civil War
abstract: When Laurent Kabila's rebels captured this country's capital over the weekend and catapulted him into the presidency, they did not do it alone.    From the onset of the war last autumn until the fall of Kinshasa on Saturday, Mr. Kabila's forces received heavy support from several neighboring countries with an interest in toppling the longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, diplomats and United States officials said.

headline: Clairol Hair Product To Reassign Duties
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co says it will reassign creative and strategic duties on account of its Clairol Herbal Essence hair care brand after incumbent, Wells Rich Greene BDDP, resigned because of conflict (S)

headline: Iraqis Still Defying Arms Ban, Departing U.N. Official Says
abstract: Rolf Ekeus, United Nations arms control expert who has directed disarming of Iraq since 1991, says Iraqi scientists are still under orders to keep nation ready to make lethal chemical weapons at short notice, even if existing stocks are destroyed; says Iraqis have refused to cooperate in good faith, and have turned to Eastern Europe and Asia in search of prohibited equipment; Ekeus, who is leaving UN to become Sweden's Ambassador to US, will be succeeded as executive chairman of UN Special Commission by Richard Butler, Australian arms control expert (M)

headline: With a Deal Like This, Who Needs a Salary?
abstract: YOU may have heard a lot about the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga and the kudos he received when he refused both salary and bonus upon taking over Republic Industries in 1995.    But don't worry about him. In 1995 Mr. Huizenga received options on Republic stock worth $17.6 million, and in 1996 he got more options, worth $3.9 million. By giving him the right, but not the obligation, to scoop up a lot of Republic stock at pre-set prices, both years' options together would have yielded a profit of $64.3 million at the end of 1996, had he exercised them.

headline: Narciso Yepes, Spanish Guitarist And an Innovative Musician, 69
abstract: Narciso Yepes, Spanish guitarist, dies at age 69; photo (M)

headline: Amstrad to Become Part of Viglen Unit
abstract: Amstrad PLC, a British maker of consumer electronics and computers, says it will fold itself into Viglen, its personal computer unit, and return at least $327 million to shareholders (S)

headline: Novell to Cut 50 Positions
abstract: Novell Inc says it will cut about 50 jobs, or 15 percent of its 400-member work force in Europe; does not confirm report posted on the Internet that it will cut staff at its US operations (S)

headline: Summit First. Then Books. Then Movies. Then . . .
abstract: Commercialization of Mount Everest includes best-selling book and four more books on the way, television movie, IMAX large-format film and live cybercast that will allow computer users to hear panting of climbers; common wisdom is that fascination with Everest endures because it is roof of world, at 29,028 feet; its size and deadly power has loomed even larger since deadly storm last year that left eight climbers dead; David Breashears, three-time Everest climber, speculates that books and film projects are proliferating because people involved are more ordinary; notes that efforts to reach Everest's summit are no longer limited to elite experienced climbers; photos (M)

headline: MARRIOTT SELLS 5 NURSING HOMES FOR $79 MILLION
abstract: Marriott International Inc sells five Brighton Gardens nursing homes to Prime Care One LLC, private investment company, for $79 million; Marriott will continue to manage the homes (S)

headline: Affiliate of Big Japanese Securities Firm Fails
abstract: Yamaichi Securities Co says it will close debt-ridden affiliated securities firm, Ogawa Securities Company, first Japanese brokerage house to fail in 17 years (M)

headline: Motorola Kuwaiti Pact
abstract: Motorola Inc signs contract worth $24 million to expand digital cellular network in Kuwait; Motorola says expansion will allow Kuwaiti network operated by Mobile Telecommunications Co to service more than 155,000 subscribers nationwide (S)

headline: B C SUGAR BACKS COMPETING OFFER FROM GREAT PACIFIC
abstract: B C Sugar Refinery Ltd receives offer to be acquired by Canada's Great Pacific Capital Corp for $115 million (Canadian), or $83.8 million (US); BC Sugar's board will urge shareholders to support offer, despite higher, unsolicited bid by Balaclava Enterprises Inc (S)

headline: 11.2% Profit Gain for Lilly, Though Sales of Prozac Slip
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co reports earnings rose 11.2 percent in first quarter as new products helped offset first-ever drop in sales of company's best-selling antidepressant Prozac; net income rose to $432.6 million from $389.2 million a year earlier; revenue rose 9.5 percent, to $1.95 billion from $1.78 billion; table (M)

headline: INTEL REQUESTS SUMMARY JUDGMENT IN SUIT AGAINST DIGITAL
abstract: Intel Corp seeks summary judgment in its breach-of-contract suit against Digital Equipment Corp involving computer chips, Federal court (S)

headline: Computers Are the Future But Remain Unready for It
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of computerized operations worldwide face looming global quagmire after December 31, 1999 unless software is developed to change date fields to reflect arrival of new century, special report, The Milennium Bug; current software used by many computers is programmed with two-digit shorthand for date so that year is represented by last two digits; computers would interpret year 2000 as 00, or 1900, with potentially frightening results; experts concede unanticipated troubles could arise, but that major problems will be dealt with beforehand; most say milennium will probably not end in calamitous computer crash, but with many expensive and disruptive headaches; photo; drawings (L)

headline: Where, Oh Where?
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about misplacing important work; drawing

headline: Mr. Europe's Daughter Is a Voice for France's Left
abstract: Martine Aubry, Socialist and former Labor Minister who is running for French Parliament, is daughter of Jacques Delors, former president of European Union's executive commission; she says Pres Jacques Chirac's austerity policies are main issue in coming elections; map; photo (M)

headline: Trinity I Fund Makes Offer To Acquire Fisher Scientific
abstract: Fisher Scientific International Inc receives unsolicited takeover proposal from Trinity I Fund LP, group affiliated with members of the Bass family, the Texas investors; precise terms ae not disclosed (M)

headline: Seagate Plans Irish Plant
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc to invest over 148 million Irish pounds ($223 million) to set up factory, Ringskiddy, Ireland, to make data storage magnetic disks (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Former Andersen Director To Head Accounting Board  Edmund L. Jenkins, 62, a former managing director at Arthur Andersen, has been chosen as the new chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, according to people who were briefed on the decision. The choice came after months of struggle over the direction of the board, which determines the nation's accounting rules.     It appears that Mr. Jenkins, who has pushed for companies to issue more forward-looking information, will be acceptable to Arthur Levitt Jr., the S.E.C. chairman. $(Page D8.$)

headline: Summer's near, and the time is right for Dixie vs. Chinet in the battle of the paper plates.
abstract: Dixie, James River Corp brand, and Chinet, Van Leer Group unit, are using different media approaches to promote paper plates; Dixie's television drive depicts family dining situations, while Chinet's radio campaign features well-known chefs (M)

headline: Three Companies Join ABC Promotion
abstract: ABC television network announces plans to team up with American Airlines, McDonald's Corp and Toys 'R' Us to promote network and its programming for 1997-98 season (S)

headline: Germany Will Place Scientology Under Nationwide Surveillance
abstract: German authorities decide to place Scientology movement under nationwide surveillance for one year, their sharpest action yet in long battle against group they say is bent on undermining their democratic society; decision, which critics call authoritarian and impractical, means that Scientologists' mail may be intercepted, their phones tapped and their offices infiltrated by undercover agents posing as adherents; orgn says it will contest decision in court (M)

headline: Cult Guru Accused in Tokyo Subway Attack Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Shoko Asahara, guru of Aum Shinrikyo cult, pleads not guilty in Japanese court to masterminding 1995 nerve gas attack on Tokyo subway system; he offers meandering, often unintelligible, account in court, blaming two aides and claiming he ordered them to stop plot (S)

headline: New Cabinet Is Announced In France
abstract: New French Prime Min Lionel Jospin forms 14-member Cabinet that includes 2 Communists and member of environmentalist Greens party; names five women to Cabinet; names Hubert Vedrine Foreign Minister (M)

headline: Platinum Prices Rise Sharply As Talks on Exports Continue
abstract: Platinum futures surge on New York Mercantile Exchange as a halt in Russian platinum and palladium exports continue to leave supplies scarce; platinum for delivery in July rises $25, to $436.60 an ounce; September palladium rises 35 cents, to $173.15 an ounce (M)

headline: British Airport Plan Results in BAA Charge
abstract: BAA PLC, British airport operator, will take $65 million charge in fiscal year 1997 because of accumulated interest from costs of developing fifth terminal at Heathrow Airport (S)

headline: Coffee and Cotton Exchanges May Merge
abstract: Boards of Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and New York Cotton Exchange agree to explore possible merger (S)

headline: Nationsbank Talks Seen for Montgomery
abstract: Nationsbank may acquire Montgomery Securities for as much as $1.2 billion, joining stampede by commercial banks into investment banking as stock market rises to ever-higher levels giving analysts new reasons for optimism over prospects for growth and prosperity; other recent acquisitions noted (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.63   5.50   5.25        3-MO.
