headline: Russell G. Cleary, 63, Dies; Ex-Head of Heileman Brewing
abstract: Russell G Cleary, who built G Heileman Brewing Co into one of largest breweries in country, dies at 63; photo (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: FILENE'S BASEMENT CORP., Wellesley, Mass., named W. Jay Carothers president, chief operating officer and director. Mr. Carothers previously was president of the Federated Merchandising Group. He succeeds Mone Anathan 3d, who is seeking early retirement. The appointment takes effect on June 20.

headline: Brazil's Chief Wins Vote Despite Scandal
abstract: Diplomats say Rwanda, Uganda, Zambia and Angola covertly gave Laurent Kabila's rebels heavy support in their successful drive to overthrow longtime Zairian dictator Mobutu Sese Seko; say aid ranged from military advisers and training to air transport, supplies and even some troops; thousands of Tutsi volunteers from Uganda and Rwanda joined rebellion in sympathy with Tutsi kinsmen; foreign support is likely to complicate Kabila's efforts to govern nation, now called Congo, since it has brought to power Tutsi, minor ethnic group in Congo with strong ties to Rwanda; map; photo (L)

headline: Philippines Weighing New Access to Counter China's Ambitions : U.S. Sets Sail for Subic Bay Again
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Five years after it returned the giant Subic Bay base to the Philippines, the United States military is negotiating with Manila to use the port and its facilities more frequently to maintain a stronger naval presence in the South China Sea.

headline: BankAmerica Selling Unit To Travelers
abstract: BankAmerica Corp is selling its consumer finance unit, Security Pacific Financial Services, to Travelers Group for $1.6 billion; sale is announced same day that BankAmerica confirms that that it is paying $540 million to buy Robertson, Stephens & Co, a San Francisco investment bank; profit from sale of Security Pacific and pending sale of BankAmerica's Hawaiian banking operations to American Savings Bank, a unit of Hawaiian Electric Industries, will be used to help finance Robertson, Stephens purchase (L

headline: Men Once Led By Pol Pot Say They Have Him
abstract: Clandestine rebel broadcast says that fugitive Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot has surrendered to his former comrades; development suddenly opens prospect that Pol Pot can be handed over to Cambodian Government or international community and put on trial for killings of over million people during his reign of terror from 1975 to 1979; broadcast is greeted with astonishment, joy and skepticism by Cambodian officials and foreign analysts; map; photos (M)

headline: Staples and Office Depot to Fight F.T.C. Merger Challenge
abstract: Staples Inc and Office Depot Inc, asserting Federal antitrust officials do not understand office supply business, vow to 'vigorously contest' the Federal Trade Commission's decision to challenge their proposed merger (M)

headline: BANKRUPTCY JUDGE ALLOWS MARVEL TO SUSPEND PAYMENTS
abstract: US Bankruptcy Court Judge Helen Balick says Marvel Entertainment Group Inc can temporarily stop making $4 million monthly interest payments while it tries to pull itself out of bankruptcy; Balick agrees to let Marvel suspend payments to banks until mid-July (S)

headline: Granada to Acquire All of Yorkshire-Tyne
abstract: Granada Group PLC will acquire 73 percent of Yorkshire-Tyne Tees Holdings Group PLC that it does not already own, valuing British commercial TV broadcaster at $1.2 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clinton Calls for Scrutiny Of Tobacco Settlement  President Clinton encouraged critics of the tobacco settlement agreement to regard it only as a starting point, and said he feared that it might hobble the Government's regulation of nicotine.

headline: Honors
abstract: * Advertising New York, the annual benefit event sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York, Advertising Women of New York and the American Advertising Federation, named three recipients of the 1997 Good Egg Awards to honor corporate citizenship. They are: Lotas Minard Patton McIver, Pfizer Inc. and WPIX-TV, owned by the Tribune Co. They will receive the awards at the event, scheduled for June 18 in Rockefeller Center.

headline: Nikkei Down, the Yen Up
abstract: Stocks trade lower in Tokyo on June 9; benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues closes down 261.93 points, at 20,223.82 (S)

headline: Now, the well-packed carry-on for a Club Med vacation contains jeans, cologne and cigars.
abstract: Club Mediterranee SA is counting on new marketing alliances with Levi's, Calvin Klein Cosmetics and Davidoff of Geneva, the cigar company, to lift it out of financial doldrums in which it has floundered since 1990; company says sales in US have been flat, at $200 million, over last five years, while company has posted losses in three of last six years; company's US marketing arm has refocused strategy on selling Americans three separate brands of vacation resorts--villages for couples, for singles and for families (L)

headline: Kohl Finds His Pet Project May Prove His Undoing
abstract: German public lacks enthusiasm for Chancellor Helmut Kohl's drive to create single European currency; Germany, which has not restructured economy to meet costly strains of reunification and of global economic change, is unable to meet criteria for new currency; photo (M)

headline: HAYES WHEELS IN TAKEOVER OF LEMMERZ OF GERMANY
abstract: Hayes Wheels International Inc agrees to acquire Lemmerz Holding GmbH for $200 million cash and $110 million in Hayes preferred stock (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ITI TECHNOLOGIES INC., North St. Paul, Minn., a maker of wireless security systems, agreed to buy Caddx-Caddi Controls Inc., Gladewater, Tex., from four individual shareholders for $19 million.

headline: Data Point to More Growth, But With Inflation in Check
abstract: Evidence mounts that economy accelerated markedly in recent weeks, though inflation appeares to remain in check; report by National Association of Purchasing Management shows index of factory activity climbed in March to match its highest reading in more than two years; report also shows easing of group's prices-paid component, a gauge of inflation; employment component of index rose after 24 consecutive months of contraction in number of factory jobs, and suppliers needed more to time to deliver goods; Conference Board reports that index of leading economic indicators rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, after gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in January; Commerce Department's tally of new construction shows activity rose 2.3 percent in February from January, to annual rate of $603.8 billion; table; graphs (L)

headline: FIRST REPUBLIC SHARES FALL AS SEARCH FOR BUYER HALTS
abstract: Stock of First Republic Bancorp falls 10 percent after company says it is no longer exploring possible sale or merger (S)

headline: CATALYTICA TO PAY $247 MILLION FOR GLAXO DRUG PLANT
abstract: Catalytica Inc says it will pay $247 million in cash plus shares, share options and business contracts for Glaxo Wellcome PLC's drug manufacturing plant in Greenville, NC, and its inventory (S)

headline: Kenneth Mott, 58, Tropical Disease Expert
abstract: Dr Kenneth Eugene Mott, who led World Health Organization drive against tropical diseases, dies atage 58 (S)

headline: Secrets and Lines: Legacy of a Reporter Who Was a Hanoi Spy
abstract: Correspondents, veterans and diplomats involved in Vietnam War will meet in New York to discuss its legacy, but without presence of Pham Xuan An, Time Magazine correspondent who was secret agent for Hanoi during war; organizers of meeting say he was denied exit visa by Vietnamese Government; his colleagues in press corps recall him as knowledgeable reporter; photo (M)

headline: A Good Quarter for Short-Sellers, but Risks Remain
abstract: Strong first-quarter gains by short-sellers, money managers who bet stocks will decline in value, follow years of losses that have trimmed ranks of hedge funds; short-sellers see conditions ripe for continuing gains in second quarter; graph (M)

headline: S.& P. 500 Gives Cardinal Health a Lift
abstract: Stock of Cardinal Health rises more than 8 percent after company is moved into Standard & Poor's 500 index (S)

headline: TEXAS PLANNED COMMUNITY TO BE SOLD FOR $543 MILLION
abstract: Mitchell Energy and Development Corp agrees to sell Woodlands property unit, which owns and operates office and residential development north of Houston, Tex, for $543 million in cash; partnership formed by affiliate of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co and Crescent Real Estate Equities Co is buying the Woodlands (S)

headline: As Digital TV Arrives, Cable's Picture May Not Be So Clear
abstract: Broadcast television networks are aiming for digital high-definition programs, while nation's cable operators are willing to forgo picture clarity to offer customers more channels; cable companies want to use digital compression to make themselves more competitive, quantitatively rather than qualitatively; are stung by competition from direct-broadcast satellite companies that are stealing millions of customers by offering nearly four times the channels; broadcast television executives think high-definition will give them competitive advantage over rivals in cable industry; television manufacturers worry that cable industry's plans may undercut their drive to sell expensive, new high-definition sets next year; photo (M)

headline: Laura Ashley Stock Falls After Resignations
abstract: Shares of Laura Ashley Holdings PLC fall after company says that two senior execs had resigned; they are Julie Ramshaw, merchandise director, and Dominic Lavelle, Europe finance director (S)

headline: Simmons Says He Declined Offer to Settle Lawsuit
abstract: Dallas investor Harold C Simmons says he has refused $50 million settlement proposed by two of his daughters, Scheryle S Patigian and Andrea Swanson, who have sued for control of his billion-dollar corporate empire; Simmons has put most of his fortune into trusts for his four daughters; two daughters are seeking to remove the trusts from his control; Simmons says settlement and resulting taxes would have forced him to liquidate $80 million in investments (M)

headline: Bayer Plans to Invest $6 Billion in U.S. Unit
abstract: Bayer AG will invest more than $6 billion in its US unit by year 2000 for research development and capital improvements (S)

headline: Joana Mendes, 77, Champion Of Father's Effort to Save Jews
abstract: Joana Mendes, daughter of disgraced Portuguese diplomat who devoted her life to winning recognition of his role in rescuing Jews from Holocaust, dies at age of 77 (M)

headline: BOMBARDIER OF MONTREAL SELLS 4 PLANES TO BRAZIL
abstract: Bombardier Inc of Montreal says it sold four de Havilland Dash 8Q aircraft to Brazil's Transportes Aereos Regulares SA for $48 million in United States currency (S)

headline: Howard Sloane, 76, A Trade Appointee In 4 Administrations
abstract: Howard G Sloane, a New York real estate executive who advised four administrations on trade issues, dies at age 76 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Soft Sheen Products Inc., Chicago, to Spike/DDB, Chicago and New York, to handle the strategic development and production of advertising and marketing programs. Billings were not disclosed. Soft Sheen will continue a relationship with its agency of 16 years, Brainstorm Communications, Chicago. Spike/DDB is a joint venture between the director Spike Lee and the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group.    * Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester, to Gyro Worldwide, Philadelphia, to handle worldwide advertising for its Killer Loop eyewear brand, which had been handled by various agencies. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

headline: Auto Researcher Bought by K-III
abstract: K-III Communications Corp acquires Intellichoice Inc, a research concern that publishes information about automotive market; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Petroleum Prices Move Higher As Snows Shut Down Pipeline
abstract: Crude oil and gasoline futures rise after large pipeline from Canada to US is closed over weekend because of heavy snow; IPL Energy Inc shut most of the lines by its Interprovincial Pipe Line Inc subsidiary in Canada because of power failures caused by storms (M)

headline: Success May Be Bad for Jews As Old Russian Bias Surfaces
abstract: Presence of many Jews in high political office in new Russia has reawakened old prejudices, and is something some Russians depict as sinister; many people, frustrated by wrenching economic and social upheaval that followed collapse of Communism in 1991, have returned to traditional scapegoat; overt anti-Semitism, nevertheless, remains mostly at fringes of society, where it has flourished ever since mid-1980's when Pres Mikhail Gorbachev's program of glasnost unleashed various brands of grass roots chauvinism; Jewish population, estimated to number more than half million, has re-established Judaism as religion and culture; photo (M)

headline: Circulation Auditors Agree to Merge
abstract: BPA International in New York, which provides circulation audits for print and interactive media, will merge with Canadian Circulations and Audit Board in Toronto, which provides circulation audits for newspapers and periodicals in Canada (S)

headline: Officials Say China Illegally Sent U.S. Equipment to Military Plant
abstract: Intelligence officials say Federal criminal inquiry has uncovered new evidence suggesting that state-owned Chinese company, Catic, had intended all along to divert American machine equipment to military plant that builds missiles and fighter aircraft; equipment was supposed to be used solely for civilian purposes; Clinton Administration is faced with question of how to proceed if it is proved that Catic knowingly misled US officials; Administration approved Catic's purchase of machine equipment from McDonnell Douglas Corp in Aug 1994; officials say some equipment sent from US wound up at military complex in Nanchang (M)

headline: Miller Settles Suit With Spin Doctors
abstract: Band the Spin Doctors has received settlement in connection with suit filed against Miller Brewing Co and former Miller agency, the Leap Partnership, which accused Miller and Leap of plagiarizing band's hit single Two Princes in commercial for Lite Ice beer that ran nationally throughout 1995; terms undisclosed (S)/

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt   * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, is selling $100 million of notes due 2004 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 6.95 percent and are priced at par.    * Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, is selling $150 million of medium-term notes due in 2000 through Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 6.56 percent and are priced at par.

headline: Canada, No Longer Riding High, Votes Today, Resigned to Austerity
abstract: At one point during a nationally televised debate last month, Prime Minister Jean Chretien made an apology that seemed surprisingly frank for a politician in the thick of his 11th election campaign.     ''In some areas I'm sorry we could not do as well as we wanted,'' said Mr. Chretien, who is trying to lead his Liberal Party to victory in Canada's parliamentary election on Monday.

headline: Bristol-Myers Adds To Wells Rich Jobs
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co assigns Wells Rich Greene BDDP to handle responsibilities for new Vagistat-1 yeast infection remedy, with billings estimated at $35 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., said its Raytheon E-Systems unit had won a five-year Department of Defense contract worth up to $1.12 billion. The contract calls for the company to provide logistics support to the Special Operations Command in at least seven sites in California, Florida, Kentucky and North Carolina.

headline: Small-Cap Stocks Are At It Again
abstract: Left behind by the bull market in the first quarter, stocks of smaller companies have raced forward in recent weeks, easily outpacing giant stocks. Market Place, page 10.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Are Down; Investors Don't Seem to Be  The bull market may be trembling, but in chats on the Internet or at home this weekend, investors were not talking about getting out.

headline: Zaire Talks Collapse
abstract: Talks on Zaire's crisis collapsed yesterday when the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, refused to meet with President Mobutu Sese Seko. That set the stage for an armed takeover of the capital, Kinshasa.    Article, page A6.

headline: Auto Makers Draw a Yawn On Wall Street
abstract: Market Place: Big Three auto makers have been showing signs of renewed strength this month, but to Wall Street the industry seems to have reached a plateau; even two bullish announcements from Chrysler Corp and Ford Motor Co leave analysts talking about auto stocks mostly as safe bet if stock market nose dives; Chrysler Corp says it earned $1.03 billion during first quarter, up 2.4 percent from $1.01 billion in same quarter last year; revenues were $16.1 billion, increase of 7.8 percent; Ford says it will raise its dividend to 42 cents a share during second quarter, up 3.5 cents; about 1,800 workers go on strike at Chrysler's main engine factory in Detroit, Mich, forcing company to plan a shutdown of four assembly plants by early April 11; table (L)

headline: Sears, Roebuck Profits Up
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co reports net income in first quarter rose 21 percent, to $182 million from $151 million a year earlier; sales rose 9.4 percent, to $7.56 billion from $6.91 billion (S)

headline: Gyro Is Awarded On-Line Assignment
abstract: Gyro Advertising Worldwide is named by The Hub, content site on America Online aimed at computer users in 20's, as its first agency of record (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Mexico Accused of Diverting U.S. Anti-Drug Aid to Fight Rebels
abstract: Mexican Sen Felix Salgado Macedonio stirs controversy with demand that Mexican military respond to suspicions that it misused helicopters supplied by United States for anti-drug missions for recent anti-guerrilla missions in southern Guerrero State; Government denies using US helicopters in state; Salgado comments, interview (M)

headline: Asia Times Stops Printing
abstract: Sondhi Limthongkul, Thai entrepreneur, says he will halt publication of Asia Times because of cash-flow crisis at his flagship daily newspaper (S)

headline: Big Boeing Order From British Air
abstract: British Airways exercises option to buy five Boeing 777 jetliners and orders three 767 models, in deal valued at $1-billion (S)

headline: Kabila Bans Party Activity In Kinshasa
abstract: Pres Laurent Kabila of Congo bans political party activity and public demonstrations in capital of Kinshasa, settting week-old Government on collision course with main opposition leader, Etienne Tshisekedi; orders measures as disillusion and dissent increase in city known for turbulent politics; troops break up protest march and arrest 70 people; many opposition politicians complain that Kabila's transitional Cabinet does not include them; photo (M)

headline: Higher Rates and Bad Weather Hurt Housing Resales in March
abstract: National Association of Realtors reports that home resales fell 2.8 percent in March as higher borrowing costs began to bite; economists say poor weather also hurt sales but that they expect a rebound in April (S)

headline: 2 Phone Companies Deny Report on 10,000 Job Cuts
abstract: Merger of Bell Atlantic Corp and Nynex Corp may produce $200 million more in cost savings than two phone companies predicted when they announced $22 billion deal last year; but companies deny report that they plan to lay off 10,000 employees within five years (L)

headline: Compaq Plans to Show First Home PC Theater
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp to offer first so-called PC theater, device that combines fully featured computer with large-screen television; Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc, whose parent Thomson SA owns RCA brand name, built system's picture tube and product will carry both Compaq and RCA brand names; computer industry views PC theaters as key weapon in its drive to take part of television market away from consumer electronics industry and plans to build digital-television receivers into every PC starting in 1998; photo (M)

headline: A good omen? Chief executives are holding on to their options.
abstract: Market Place column on chief executives who are holding on to their stock options; says most chief executives, loaded with stock options granted in last several years, decided to exercise few, if any, during 1996; holds they passed up sure gains from market's stunning 1996 rise, and took their chances on the ride in 1997 and beyond; list of chief executives who exercised some of their stock options in 1996 (L)

headline: Honors
abstract: * Hector and Norma Orci, founders of La Agencia de Orci & Asociados, Los Angeles, will receive the Industry Career Achiever Award from District 2 of the American Advertising Federation, co-sponsored by Essence Communications and the Leo Burnett Co.

headline: Hunger in North Korea: A Relief Aide's Stark Report
abstract: Relief expert Andrew S Natsios, World Vision aide, discusses witnessing impact of famine in North Korea, interview; holds only about 15 percent of food deficit results from flooding in 1995 and 1996; cites signs of malnutrition; notes elderly have vanished from provincial city streets, apparently because they have stopped eating to keep grandchildren alive; map; photo (M)

headline: Internet Song Use Spurs Recording Industry Suits
abstract: Recording Industry Association of America sues operators of Web sites reportedly pirating and distributing copyrighted songs free over Internet; is forced to sue Internet addresses in hopes of discovering names of operators (S)

headline: At This Site, Russian Nerds Get Together, Virtually
abstract: Consumer electronic chain Partya sponsors Moscow's first Internet cafe; major denizens are children, attracted by free access to World Wide Web; photo (M)

headline: COMPUTER DATA TO BUY ANALYTICAL SYSTEMS
abstract: Computer Data Systems Inc to buy Analytical Systems Engineering Corp for about $51 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Lagardere Stock Rises; Bid for Thomson Is Cited
abstract: Shares of Lagardere Groupe rise on expectations that it will win battle with Alcatel Alsthom SA to buy French Govt's majority stake in Thomson-CSF unit of Thomson SA (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: General Electric Co agrees to buy Tridom satellite communications unit from AT&T (S)

headline: GTE Discloses 3 Big Deals In Growth Bid
abstract: GTE Corp, bidding to become major operator of corporate data networks, agrees to pay $616 million in cash to acquire BBN Corp, one of nation's biggest Internet service companies; if takeover is approved by shareholders of both companies, GTE will be set to open new round of fierce competition against big long-distance companies, including AT&T Corp; GTE on May 5 announced $485 million agreement to buy 25 percent of new national fiber optic network being built by Qwest Communications Corp, a unit of Anschutz Corp; GTE has also formed alliance with Cisco Systems Inc, leading maker of data networking equipment, to develop new products and services and buy as much as $1 billion in products from Cisco over next five years (L)

headline: BMC, EXERCISING OPTION, PAYS $60 MILLION FOR DATATOOLS
abstract: BMC Software Inc acquires privately held Datatools Inc for $60 million (S)

headline: Northern Exposure
abstract: Chart on some dubious stock promotions from Canada that have made their way to US since early 1950's; focuses on fraud cases involving Great Sweet Grass Oils Ltd, St Stephen Nickel Mines Ltd, New Cinch Uranium Ltd, Chopp Computer Corp and MTC Electronics (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Rise
abstract: Stocks moved higher here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 207.22 points -- slightly more than 1 percent -- to stand at 20,276.03. On Friday, the Nikkei index lost 243.42 points.

headline: TRANSCRYPT TO PAY $34 MILLION FOR E F JOHNSON
abstract: Transcrypt International Inc agrees to acquire E F Johnson Co, closely held wireless telecommunications company, for $34 million (S)

headline: Albright Lays Cornerstone for Diplomacy With Vietnam
abstract: Madeleine K Albright, first United States State Secretary to visit Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, since Vietnam War, lays first stone for new American Consulate; calls for economic and political reform and talks up American investment; stresses for accounting for 1,584 Americans missing in action; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Soldiers March Into Hong Kong
abstract: First elements of Chinese Army crosses border into Hong Kong; initial contingent of 40 officers and soldiers, first Chinese troops to take up positions in Hong Kong in 150 years, will prepare for China's resumption of sovereignty on July 1; photo (M)

headline: Defector Stirs North Korea Nuclear Scare
abstract: South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo says Hwang Jang Yop, high-ranking North Korean defector who arrived in Seoul on April 20, has implied that North Korea has nuclear weapons and ability to use them to annihilate South Korea (M)

headline: Report Says Barclays May Bid For NatWest
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC shares rise on report that Barclays PLC weighs takeover bid (S)

headline: Zairian Rebels' New Allies: Men Armed With Briefcases
abstract: Mining company aides flock to Zaire's Shaba Province, signing lucrative deals with rebels led by Laurent Kabila within days after rebels seized mineral-rich region; deals give rebels way to finance war and boost devastated economy; American Mineral Fields signs pact to take over two mining operations in return for investing $885 million in zinc and cobalt projects; rebel Finance Min Mwana Mawampanga says rebels, in general, will honor Zaire's pacts with mining companies, but possibly renegotiate details; map (M)

headline: Ignoring U.S., France Signs Accord Protecting Cuba Ties
abstract: France signs agreement protecting interests of French companies that invest in Cuba, brushing off US criticism (S)

headline: FISHER SCIENTIFIC SHARES RETREAT BY ABOUT 16%
abstract: Stock of Fisher Scientific International Inc drops as much as 16 percent after company posts first-quarter profits that are below Wall Street's expectations; company says it earned $11 million, or 53 cents a share, for quarter ended March 31 (S)

headline: The Costly Other Life Of an A.T.M. Card
abstract: Richard E Anderson article on discovering after bank 'debit' card was stolen that thief was able to make purchases that drained checking account and backup credit line without identification number needed to use card at automatic teller machine; drawing (M)

headline: Bond Prices Off as Traders Warily Await Fed Meeting
abstract: Bond market participants, with Federal Reserve's meeting on interest rates drawing near, become more sensitive to economic data and sell off after reports show strength in housing and a rise in consmer sentiment (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Anthony Wainwright was named to the new position of vice chairman and business development director at McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C. He was previously chairman at Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.    * Alan Reighard, senior vice president at Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White, Salt Lake City, a unit of Havas Advertising, was named to the new position of managing director of the San Francisco office.    * Harry Cocciolo and Sean Ehringer were named to the new positions of creative director and head of art, respectively, at Leagus Delaney, San Francisco. They were previously associate creative directors at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, a unit of the Omnicom Group.    * Preston Bealle was named to the new position of on-line advertising director at Poppe Tyson New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. He was most recently vice president and management supervisor at Saatchi & Saatchi/DFS, San Franciso, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. And Marlin Collingwood was named to the new position of public relations director for Poppe Tyson's Pittsburgh office. He was previously senior vice president at Howard J. Rubenstein Associates, New York.

headline: 2 to Be Nominated For Seats on F.C.C.
abstract: Pres Clinton will nominate Harold Furchtgott-Roth, economist for House Commerce Committee, and William Kennard, top lawyer at FCC, to seats on FCC (S)

headline: Kodak Account Gets Media Chief
abstract: J Walter Thompson Co and its sibling agency, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, name Bob Zach to new position of worldwide media director for two agencies' shared Eastman Kodak Co account (S)

headline: $12 Billion Market by 2004 Is Expected : The Scramble to Set Up Satellite Phone Services
abstract: NEW YORK—  For an industry with only one functioning company, the global satellite telecommunications business has some pretty fierce competition. Dozens of companies are spending billions of dollars to launch hundreds of satellites in an often confusing race to provide telecommunications services to people all around the world.

headline: What would Lazard be like without Felix Rohatyn?
abstract: Market Place column on outlook for Lazard Freres & Co if Felix G Rohatyn, star at firm for nearly 40 years, is confirmed as US Ambassador to France, replacing Pamela Harriman; says Rohatyn's departure would clearly be a significant loss for the firm (L)

headline: Albright Sees an Ambitious World Mission for U.S.
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright, in commencement address at Harvard University, lays out activist agenda for American responsibility and leadership in less coherent, post-Soviet world; warns of dangers of American isolationism and global indifference; it is also 50th anniversary of George C Marshall's offer at Harvard to rebuild Europe with American aid, and Albright praises Marshall; photo (M)

headline: Dow Jones Braces for a Shareholder Showdown on Telerate
abstract: Senior managers of Dow Jones & Co will face some angry shareholders at annual meeting Apr 16; Institutional Shareholder Services, which advises large investors, is urging stockholders to pass resolution opposed by management that would require independent directors to review compensation of Peter R Kann, company's chief executive; it is also asking shareholders not to re-elect David K P Li to board because he attended only half of its meetings last year; major issue will be management's decision to spend up to $650 million to overhaul ailing Telerate financial data business; vocal group of shareholders wants Dow to dump Telerate (M)

headline: TRANSITIONAL HOSPITALS WITHDRAWS FROM DEAL
abstract: Transitional Hospitals Corp withdraws from $565 million agreement to be bought by Select Medical Corp in favor of higher bid from Vencor Inc (S)

headline: PENNEY (J.C.) CO. (JCP,N)
abstract: J C Penney Co says earnings fell 2.1 percent in its fiscal quarter ended April 26; reports net income fell to $139 million from $142 million in year-earlier period; sales rose 44 percent, to $6.70 billion from $4.64 billion; table (S)

headline: 18 Charged in Stock Fraud That Cost Investors Millions
abstract: Eighteen residents of five states are charged with operating a scheme that bilked investors out of millions of dollars by persuading them to put their money into cyberspace company, Globus Group Inc, with no business, little value and fraudulently inflated stock price; two of the defendants, Alik Stolyar and his son, Igor, are charged with murder-solicitation plot that was said to have been related to fraud scheme; murder plot was to have involved recruiting a hit man in Canada to kill people who were extorting a cut of proceeds from investment fraud; some of those indicted called from office of licensed brokerage firm in Manhattan, the Hillcrest Financial Corp, which is not charged in the case; ring was made up largely of Russian emigres (L)

headline: At the Moment of Truth, Rebels' Resolve Failed
abstract: Peru's Agriculture Min Rodolfo Munante Sanguinetti says moments after explosion signaled beginning of military raid to rescue 72 hostages in Japanese Ambassador's residence, young guerrilla appeared ready to carry out plan to kill hostages if government troops attacked; Munante says guerrilla changed his mind; says soon after, he and 13 other Tupac Amaru guerrillas were dead; raid that freed 71 hostages was triumph of military planning and preparation; several hostages say that its success also stemmed from weakening of rebels' determination and unity over four months of siege; photos (M)

headline: What's Cute and Cuddly, but Pays Just 2.33% Interest?
abstract: Oxford Bank in Illinois takes advantage of craze for Beanie Baby stuffed toys by offering them as incentive for new accounts; photo; catch is that savings account pays only 2.33 percent interest (S)

headline: Swiss Find Only $3.4 Million In Bank Accounts for Mobutu
abstract: Switzerland's commercial banks find only $3.4 million belonging to Mobutu Sese Seko, ousted President of Congo, reputed to be one of world's richest men; Congo holds Mobutu deposited over $8 billion in Switzerland during his 32 years in power (M)

headline: With This Ring, I Thee Hyphenate
abstract: Letter from Ricki Fulman comments on Mar 16 article on changing name at time of marriage (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Existing-Home Sales April  Consumer Confidence May

headline: Japan Airlines' Debt Rating Is Cut
abstract: Debt rating of Japan Airlines is cut by Moody's Investors Service, a move that will make it more expensive for company to borrow (S)

headline: Unpersecuted, an Old Faith Withers in Japan
abstract: Hidden Christians, who passed their faith down to descendants for four centuries in face of fierce persecution in Japan, are dwindling in numbers amid religious freedom; young people are uninterested in living faith many of their ancestors died to preserve; map; photo (M)

headline: It's Young vs. Old in Germany As the Welfare State Fades
abstract: Interviews with Germans on looming split between young and old over social welfare benefits; young are questioning system in which they face higher contributions and reduced benefits; retirees hold they are entitled to current generous benefits because their hard work produced nation's economic miracle of 1950's and 1960's; photos (L)

headline: Replacing steel wheels with rubber tires may be the road to making high-speed railways a reality.
abstract: Developer Abe Hirschfeld patents two designs for rubber tires to replace steel wheels now used on trains; holds rubber tires would enable trains to travel at high speeds on existing tracks; Dr Robert Ledley patents method to separate fetal hemoglobin cells from mother's blood, move that would make genetic testing for defects possible without risks involved in inserting needle into mother's abdomen; National Inventors Hall of Fame names eight inductees, including five from computer field (M)

headline: AMERICAN GENERAL COMPLETES $665 MILLION ACQUISITION
abstract: American General Corp completes its $665 million acquisition of Home Beneficial Corp (S)

headline: Thai Airways Orders 9 Planes From Airbus
abstract: Airbus Industrie receives $1 billion order for nine planes from Thai Airways International (S)

headline: BBDO West Wins An MGM Account
abstract: MGM Distribution Co, which handles marketing, publicity and distribution of films for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, names BBDO West to handle media planning and buying portions of its advertising account; account had been handled by Saatchi & Saatchi Pacific (S)

headline: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS April 6
abstract: This   Last     Month   Month   Hard Cover                 1   1   TOTAL CONTROL by David Baldacci (Warner, $25). A woman's effort to find her husband, who has disappeared, discloses many of big business's ways.                 2   2   THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko (Longstreet Press, $22). How to become wealthy in America.                 +3   -   SUCCESS IS A CHOICE by Rick Pitino with Bill Reynolds (Broadway Books, $25). The basketball coach offers a 10-step program for achieving goals.                 +4   3   THE SEVEN SPIRITUAL LAWS OF SUCCESS by Deepak Chopra (Amber-Allen/New World Library, $14). How to generate wealth in all its forms.                 +5   4   THE DILBERT PRINCIPLE by Scott Adams (Harper Business, $22). The foibles of the business world.                 +6   5   DOGBERT'S TOP SECRET MANAGEMENT HANDBOOK by Scott Adams (Harper Business, $16). Dilbert's creator satirizes management manuals.                 +7   7   WALL STREET MONEY MACHINE by Wade Cook (United Support Association, $24.95). Strategies for enhancing cash flow and wealth.                 +8   -   IF IT'S GOING TO BE, IT'S UP TO ME by Robert H. Schuller (HarperCollins, $22). A TV evangelist sets forth his program for achieving success.                 9   6   THE EDUCATION OF A SPECULATOR by Victor Niederhoffer (Wiley, $29.95). Principles for success.                 3   3   THE ERNST & YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1997 edited by Peter W. Bernstein (Wiley, $14.95). The numbers are statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide.    * indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.    + Some bookstores report receiving bulk orders on these titles.

headline: Palestinians Detain Reporter Who Is Said to Have Irked Arafat
abstract: Palestinian police are holding without charges Palestinian journalist Daoud Kuttab, who irked Yasir Arafat with live television broadcasts of Palestinian Legislative Council meetings; council members have scored Palestinian Authority and Arafat over alleged corruption and misuse of official funds (M)

headline: For Hutu Refugees, Safety and Heartbreak
abstract: Tens of thousands of Hutu refugees traverse some of nastiest terrain on earth--malaria-infested swamps and jungles of central Congo, formerly Zaire--to arrive at safety of refugee camp in Bilolo, Congo Republic; refugees who arrive in former French colony are barefoot, weak and clothed in rags after fleeing Tutsi and civil war in eastern Zaire, and having trekked over 1,000 miles; now, having found safety, they may be sent back, against their will, to Rwanda, place they originally fled; refugees fear retribution for genocidal campaign that Hutu hard-liners waged against Tutsi; photos; map (M)

headline: Reynolds to Resume Ads for Winston
abstract: R J Reynolds Tobacco Co to resume national advertising for its flagging Winston line as part of comprehensive revamping of that cigarette's formula, packaging and marketing (S)

headline: Stocks Resume Their Slide; Dow Drops Another 94.04
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 94.04 points, or 1.42 percent, to close at 6,517.01; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 9.53 points, or 1.25 percent, to 750.11; Nasdaq composite index declines 15.93 points, to 1,201; graph (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bankers Trust Is Expected To Buy Alex. Brown & Sons  Bankers Trust New York has agreed to buy Alex. Brown & Sons, the nation's oldest stock brokerage firm, for about $1.7 billion in stock, according to people close with the transaction. The move would shatter the wall long dividing banks from brokers.

headline: Along a Jungle Road in Zaire, Three Wars Mesh
abstract: Young rebel soldiers in Zaire say openly that they are capturing and killing Rwandan refugees, Hutus who were responsible for massacres in their own country;' these Rwandans are not the 80,000 on outskirts of Kisangani who wanted to go home but who, in recent days, have been driven from camps by attacks; region east of Kisangani is center of three wars: hunt for Hutus, civil war between Mobutu Government's soldiers and Laurent Kabila's rebels, and quixotic on-and-off conflict waged by Mai-Mai guerrillas who hide in jungle and smoke large quantities of marijuana; photos (M)

headline: A Market of Mood Swings
abstract: Chart lists most bearish and bullish 22-day periods for Dow Jones industrial average, Jan 10, 1992 to May 13, 1997

headline: Unicef Says U.N. Reforms Could Harm the World's Children
abstract: Carol Bellamy, executive director of UNICEF, warns agency risks losing independent voice for children around world as UN prepares to undertake broadest restructuring in its history (M)

headline: Ahmanson Starts Exchange Offer
abstract: H F Ahmanson & Co begins exchange offer for stock of Great Western Financial Corp, but deal is contingent on repeal of Great Western's poison pill shareholder rights plan (S)

headline: On the Information Highway, E-Mail Litter Problem Grows
abstract: Junk E-mail, called spam, is jamming electronic mailboxes of companies that provide gateways to cyberspace; some Internet providers are trying to sue junk E-mailers for electronic trespassing; legal system is scrambling to catch up to problem; two anti-spam bills have been introduced in Congress, and Federal Trade Commission will conduct hearing on problem next month; wildcat entrepreneurs selling everything from software to sex find it so cheap to automatically crank out millions of messages that just a few sales can easily cover the cost; irritation the mass mailings cause is considered worth the price, especially with loads of new software making it easy for junk E-mailers to cover their tracks; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Accuses a Fund of Illegal Fee Use
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission acuses Jerome L Dodson, portfolio manager of Parnassus Fund, one of largest mutual funds that practice 'socially responsible' investing, of illegal ue of brokerage commissions generated by the fund and of overvaluing a security in fund's portfolio (L)

headline: Ward, Down And Struggling, Plans to Follow Revived Rivals
abstract: Comment on plans of Roger Goddu, who took over as chief executive of embattled Montgomery Ward Holding Corp, to turn around struggling retailer (M)

headline: Dollar Gains as Traders Bet Euro Will Be Weakened
abstract: Currency traders head for safe harbors, buying American dollars and British pounds in light of Socialist victory in France and an unusual domestic spat between German Government and the central bank involving nation's gold reserves and budget; analysts say activity reflects sentiment that Europe's two biggest economies are moving away from strict fiscal and monetary austerity and that proposed single European currency, the euro, will be weaker than rock-hard currency akin to German mark that European leaders have promised; table (L)

headline: New York Agencies Form Buying Unit
abstract: J Walter Thompson Co and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, units of WPP Group, team up to open national television buying subsidiary, to be called JWT/O&M (S)

headline: Toyota Plans to Offer Compact Car in Europe
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp is planning to introduce entry-level compact car in European market as part of its strategy to expand local operations and sales in Europe (S)

headline: Latest Offer to Buy Coram Is Called Off
abstract: Integrated Health Services Inc calls off its latest offer to buy Coram Healthcare Corp; Integrated reduced its offer to about $186 million in stock plus assumed debt early last week; last October, Integrated offered about $280 million in stock plus debt (L)

headline: Clinton Selects Rohatyn to Be the Next Ambassador to France
abstract: Pres Clinton reportedly selects financier, Felix G Rohatyn, to be new Ambassador to France, replacing late Pamela Harriman; 68-year-old Rohatyn was born in Vienna; moved to France in 1934, where he lived until family fled Nazi occupation in 1942; is fluent in French; received Legion of Honor from French Government in 1983 (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Janet Coombs was named president of the New York office of Wunderman Cato Johnson, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Barbara Jack, now the agency's worldwide chief executive. Ms. Coombs had been chairwoman and chief executive at the Chapman Agency, New York, also part of Y.& R.    * Joanne Burke was named to the new position of research director at Carat North America, New York, a unit of Aegis Group P.L.C. She had been senior vice president and worldwide media research director at TN Media, New York, part of True North Communications.    * Ruth Ayres was named to the new position of executive vice president and marketing director at N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, a unit of MacManus Group. She had been business development director at DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group.    * Robert Largen, president at Tracy-Locke Consulting, Dallas, was named to the new post of executive vice president and partner at Bustin & Co., Dallas, after Mr. Largen's company merged with Bustin.    * Dane Solomon was named to the new post of director and senior vice president at Arnell Group, New York. He had been director for marketing and advertising for Sony labels at Sony Music Entertainment, New York.    * Tom Evans, president and publisher of U.S. News & World Report and Fast Company magazines, New York, was named to the added post of president and publisher at a sibling magazine, The Atlantic Monthly, succeeding Jayne Young, who resigned after 10 years. All three magazines are properties of Mortimer B. Zuckerman.    * Alison Tocci was named to the new position of advertising director at Time Out New York magazine, owned by Time Out New York Partners L.P. She had been publisher at Brooklyn Bridge magazine, Brooklyn, published by Brooklyn Bridge Inc.

headline: People
abstract: * Edward Tobin was named to the new position of technology director at Poppe Tyson Interactive West, Mountain View, Calif., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. He was previously senior technology director at Eagle River Interactive, Mountain View.

headline: Terror Suspect Freed by U.S.; Flies to Jordan
abstract: Mouse Mohammed Abu Marzook, political leader of Hamas movement jailed in Manhattan for 22 months on suspicion of terrorism, is deported to Jordan; release ends embarrassment for US and Israel, which had sought to prosecute him but failed to provide persuasive evidence of his complicity in series of violent Hamas attacks; Abu Marzook will relinquish permanent residence status in US and will not contest terrorism accusations that prompted incarceration; detention at Kennedy International Airport in July 1995 and series of complicated negotiations between his attorneys and US Immigration and Naturalization Service that led to release discussed (M)

headline: Manuel Elizalde, 60, Dies; Defender of Primitive Tribe
abstract: Manuel Elizalde Jr, weathly Filipino official who caused sensation in 1971 when he announced that he discovered tiny tribe isolated since the Stone Age, died on May 3 at age 60; photo (L)

headline: Nothing Worth Mining Found on Bre-X Site
abstract: Independent consulting company finds no evidence to support claim of Bre-X Minerals Ltd of Canada that it found gold strike of century in Indonesia; independent audit concludes that initial drilling results were deliberately doctored in elaborate scheme to make finds at Busang jungle site appear far richer than they actually were; consulting company, Strathcona Mineral Services, was hired by Bre-X to clear up confusion about drilling results after prospective American partner for Bre-X, Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold, said its preliminary tests indicated that claims of vast gold deposit seemed false; several shareholder groups have already filed lawsuits against Bre-X, and Strathcona's damaging report is likely to prompt more suits from infuriated stockholders who have seen value of their shares plummet since first doubts were raised (M)

headline: I.R.A. Wing And British Hold Meeting
abstract: Sinn Fein, Irish Republican Army's political wing, holds talks with Britain on new cease-fire to clear way to reopen stalled peace talks; Mo Mowlam, Britain's new Northern Ireland Secretary, says she will brief Pres Clinton on new Prime Min Tony Blair's peace initiative (M)

headline: EARNINGS REPORT LIFTS MICRON TECHNOLOGY STOCK
abstract: Micron Technology Inc and Micron Electronics Inc, which is majority-owned by Micron Technology, report quarterly earnings that were stronger than expected; Micron Technology earned $98.6 million, up 66 percent from year earlier, and Micron Electronics earned $19.7 million, up 40 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: 2 Exchanges Set Records In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports overall short interest through May 12 rose to record 3.28 billion shares, up 4.2 percent from month earlier; short interest at American Stock Exchange rose to record 158.9 million shares, up 1.5 percent from month earlier; tables (L)

headline: CNS Assigns Martin/Williams
abstract: CNS Inc, which markets Breathe Right nasal strips, names Martin/Williams to handle its advertising account, which had been handled by Sietsema, Engel & Partners; billings estimated at $10 million to $20 million (S)

headline: Israeli Accuses Palestinian Aide in Killing of Land-Selling Arabs
abstract: The head of a Palestinian security agency and his men were directly involved in two recent killings of Arabs suspected of selling land to Jews, the Jerusalem police chief said today.    The chief, Gen. Yair Yitzhaki, said four of the agency's members and two other men were caught on Saturday night as they tried to kidnap another Arab real estate dealer from East Jerusalem and take him to the Palestinian-ruled town of Ramallah in the West Bank.

headline: U.S.-Latin War on Drugs Replacing Blame With Cooperation
abstract: Top law enforcement and military officials from Western Hemisphere countries who attended three-day conference in in Key West, Fla, focused on less ambitious goal of cooperating with each other, rather than working at odds, on drug policy; claimed increased success in interdicting shipments of drugs and reducing areas of production; new focus comes after years of mutual sniping about who is really at fault for US drug problems--Americans for consuming so many drugs, or other countries for supplying them (M)

headline: HUNTSMAN TO ACQUIRE REXENE FOR $304 MILLION IN CASH
abstract: Rexene Corp agrees to be bought by closely held Huntsman Corp for $304 million in cash; Huntsman will also assume about $300 million of debt (S)

headline: McWatters to Buy Mines
abstract: McWatters Mining Inc. has agreed to buy mining operations in Val d'Or, Quebec, from Placer Dome Inc. for $70 million. McWatters, based in Montreal, said that the Val d'Or operations include two gold mines and a package of exploration properties. The two mines produced 150,000 ounces of gold last year.

headline: Germany Arrests Suspect Linked to Basque Group
abstract: Fritz Gary Siemund, German suspected of having links to Basque terrorists, surrenders to German police, ending manhunt that began after bomb exploded accidentally in his Madrid apartment; second man is sought; arrest points to wider international support for Basque separatists (S)

headline: Congress Must Define Insider Trading
abstract: Comment by David M Brodsky and Daniel J Kramer, litigation lawyers, says Congress needs to define clearly what constitutes illegal insider trading (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MCN ENERGY GROUP INC., Detroit, said its MCN Investment Corp. subsidiary would buy Panenergy Corp.'s 18.1 percent stake in the Midland Cogeneration Venture L.P., for undisclosed terms.     KENNAMETAL INC., Latrobe, Pa., a maker of metal cutting tools and supplies, will sell as much as 20 percent of the common shares of its newly formed JLK Direct Distribution Inc. unit in an initial public offering.     REVENUE PROPERTIES CO., Toronto, a real estate developer and manager, agreed to buy two California shopping malls for $20.8 million.     KENSEY NASH CORP., Exton, Pa., a medical device company, said its marketing partner Sherwood-Davis & Geck would resume selling its Angio-Seal artery puncture closure devices in the United States.

headline: Shell Shareholders Reject A Human Rights Initiative
abstract: Filing past some 150 noisy demonstrators, shareholders of Shell Transport and Trading P.L.C. rejected a resolution today calling for greater attention to environmental and human rights policies. Operations of the giant oil company in places like Nigeria have been criticized on those grounds.    But Shell said it had taken steps to lessen the criticism by establishing regular contacts with representatives of several groups, including Greenpeace, Amnesty International and the World Wide Fund for Nature.

headline: Out of Spotlight, Violence Tears at Mexican State
abstract: Tensions and violence in Chiapas Indian hamlet of San Pedro Nixtalucum is linked, at least in part, to edgy, undeclared truce between Mexican Government and Zapatista rebels; rebels are penned up in jungle strongholds by troops and have lost nearly all their political momentum, while Government has poured money into non-Zapatista communities to win their allegiance; photo; map (San Pedro Nixtalucum Journal) (S)

headline: Compaq Plans A Big Change In Its PC Sales
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp will overhaul way it makes and distributes its personal computers in a campaign that could mean lower prices and shakeout of weaker competitors; intends to begin building made-to-order PC's and is even exploring buying direct-sales PC maker like Gateway 2000 Inc or Micron Electronics Inc to improve its efficiency further; hopes to slow momentum of smaller but faster-growing PC makers that enjoy cost advantage because they ship directly to customers while Compaq sells through dealers, with attendant price mark-ups; Compaq's moves are risky because they will threaten company's relations with tens of thousands of large and small dealers around world that distribute its computers and were largely responsible for helping it overtake IBM in 1994 to become world's No. 1 PC vendor (M)

headline: Hotel Chain Shares Rise on Vote to Split
abstract: Shares of Choice Hotels International Inc gain nearly 11 percent on news that its directors voted to split the company, creating hotel owner and operator and separate company that only franchises hotels; stock rises $1.375, to $14.125 a share (S)

headline: AETNA TO ACQUIRE FINANCIAL NETWORK INVESTMENT
abstract: Aetna Inc agrees to acquire Financial Network Investment Corp, closely held company that provides financial planning; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Earnings Increase 12% at Lehman Brothers
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc reports 2d-quarter 1997 net rose 12 percent to $121 million, compared with $108 million in year-earlier period (M)

headline: A Report on Jobless Claims Aids a Rally in Bond Prices
abstract: US Treasury bond prices recover, helped by report that shows initial claims for unemployment benefits remain at five-month high; price of 30-year Treasury bond is up 11/32 at 96 6/32; yield falls to 6.93 percent, from 6.96 percent on May 7; Labor Department says number of workers applying for state jobless benefits for first time held steady last week at seasonally adjusted 347,000; analysts had expected decline of 13,000, to 334,000; graph (L)

headline: Kiosks in Florida Widen Offerings
abstract: Universal Studios Florida and Shell Oil are installing automated kiosks in Orlando that dispense tickets for theme parks and 20 other central Florida attractions; kiosks will be placed in gas stations, supermarkets and drugstores throughout central Florida (S)

headline: Is China Coveting 'Lost' Lands?A Wary Asia Looks On
abstract: HONG KONG—  While the handover of Hong Kong to China next month will have no direct impact on the military balance of power in Asia and the Pacific, some officials and analysts worry that it may embolden Beijing to intensify its quest to recover other "lost" territory in the region.

headline: Japanese Bank Discusses Forming Ties to Barclays
abstract: Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd, one of weakest of Japan's big banks, may form links with Barclays Bank PLC in broad range of areas, including asset securitization (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Down 68 Points In Day of Wild Gyrations  After a day of big swings attributed to heavy program trading, the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 68.08 points at 7,689.98 -- perhaps with investors' psyches more battered than stock prices.    Much of the slump was tied to falling bond prices and rising oil prices, although some analysts cited technical factors. Big Board volume was heavy, with more than 607 million shares traded. The Nasdaq composite index lost 6.19 points to close at 1,446.24. $(Page D10.$)

headline: Novice Newscasters Get Voice Therapy
abstract: Business is booming for voice consultants who work with novice television newscasters as veteran print reporters are increasingly being tapped to fill air time; table; photo (M)

headline: Columbia/HCA Hospital Deal Is Delayed
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp's plan to buy nonprofit Roger Williams Medical Center in Providence, RI, has been delayed, after state health department decides to postpone its review of the transaction (S)

headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF RALSTON PURINA TO STEP DOWN
abstract: Ralston Purina Co says that William Stiritz will step down as chief executive and names Patrick McGinnis and Patrick Mulcahy as co-chief executives to replace him (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.34   5.46        3-MO. headline: Bond Prices Drop; 30-Year Yield 6.73%
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities declined on credit markets on June 25; benchmark 30-year bond dropped 18/32, to 98 19/32, yielding 6.73 percent; graphs (M)

headline: U.N. Names Italian Expert on the Mafia to Its Top Anti-Crime Post
abstract: Pino Arlacchi, one of Italy's top experts on Mafia who is also member of Italian Senate, will become UN's Under Secretary General and will head its office on international crime (M)

headline: Price Decrease For Used Autos Reverses Trend
abstract: Prices for used automobiles fall 2 percent in last 12 months, after rising briskly for four years; weaker prices may reflect fading popularity of used cars, after several years in which they were increasingly seen as alternative to new models; lower used-car prices will have ripple effect throughout automobile industry; graphs (M)

headline: Sharing Ganges Waters, India and Bangladesh Test the Depth of Cooperation
abstract: Article discusses status of shaky treaty between India and Bangladesh over use of water from Ganges River; under treaty, India and Bangladesh alternate from March to May in taking water; charges and countercharges involving cheating and improper use noted; photo; map (M)

headline: Heberto Castillo Martinez, 68, Leftist Political Leader in Mexico
abstract: Heberto Castillo Martinez, civil engineer, advocate of workers' rights and opposition politician who helped pioneer movement to make Mexico modern democracy, dies at age 68 (M)

headline: Bondholders Propose $365 Million Investment in Bankrupt Marvel
abstract: Bondholders led by Carl C Icahn propose plan for $365 million to be invested in bankrupt Marvel Entertainment Group Inc by shareholders and bondholders; Marvel spokesman calls bondholders' plan inadequate and says company's plan will be filed soon (L)

headline: U.N. Extends Plan for Iraq to Sell Oil to Buy Food
abstract: United Nations Security Council agrees to again let Iraq sell $2 billion in oil over six months to pay for food, medicine, other civilian needs; United States votes for extension; Amb Bill Richardson scores Iraqis and UN aides for what he calls serious technical problems that have delayed food distribution (M)

headline: MATERIAL SCIENCES STOCK SLIDES ON FALSE DATA
abstract: Stock of Material Sciences Corp skids 16 percent after company says fake bookkeeping entries forced it to restate profits for last three years; stock drops $2.875, to $14.50 (S)

headline: In These Ratings, Paradise Is in the Eye of the Beholder
abstract: Comment on Worth magazine's July issue on 'richest' towns in America, and Money magazine's list of 'best' places to life; different criteria noted; cover photos (S)

headline: WAINOCO TO SELL NUMAC CANADIAN ASSETS FOR $96 MILLION
abstract: Wainoco Oil Corp says it will sell its Canadian oil and gas interests to Numac Energy Inc for about $96 million (S)

headline: Corporations Schedule Offerings Of Equity and Convertible Debt
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    3DFX Interactive Inc., San Jose, Calif., an initial public offering of three million shares. Robertson, Stephens & Co.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stock Market Ends Higher, But Early Gains Are Pared  After a big drop the day before, the stock market roared back, only to give up much of its gains late in the session. The Dow industrials, up nearly 130 points during the day, closed up 50.97 points at 7,136.62.    The Nasdaq composite closed up 7.92 points  at 1,330.83. Technology stocks did particularly well, with I.B.M., Intel and Microsoft all gaining. $(Page D6.$)     Mutual fund investors, apparently unfazed by the stock market's rampant volatility, added some $13.5 billion to equity funds last month. And in recent days, it appears that investors have further stepped up their fund purchases. Market Place. $(D6.$)    Treasury prices rallied, with the 30-year bond yield falling to 6.93 percent from 6.96. $(D13.$)    Retailers Report Sluggish Sales   Running counter to recent buoyant economic statistics, retail sales have been sluggish. The Goldman, Sachs Retail Composite Index rose 3 percent in April from a year earlier. Companies operating low-priced stores, like Ross and TJX, did better than owners of expensive stores, like Saks Holdings and Neiman Marcus. $(D4.$)    China May Buy Hong Kong Stake   China's two state-owned telecommunications providers are interested in acquiring 15 percent of Hong Kong's largest telephone company, investment bankers said: 7 percent from Cable and Wireless, the company's majority owner, and 8 percent from Citic Pacific. $(D2.$)  Possible U.S. Trade Victory   The European Union's ban on hormone-treated beef is illegal, a World Trade Organization panel has decided in a preliminary ruling, potentially giving the American cattle industry a victory but turning over new ground on issues of national sovereignty. $(A1.$)    Thousands of banana farmers in the Caribbean find themselves at the center of another trade dispute between the United States and the European Union. The World Trade Organization has issued a preliminary ruling that a policy of guaranteeing Caribbean banana farmers special access to the European market is an unfair restriction on American companies like Chiquita that produce bananas in Central and South America. $(A6.$)    Sony Reports Tenfold Profit Surge   Sony's quarterly earnings surged more than tenfold, helped by the weak yen and sales of its Playstation video game. $(D2.$)    A Recommendation Against Drug   An F.D.A. advisory panel recommended against approval of Cephalon's drug, Myotrophin, for the treatment of Lou Gehrig's disease. $(D2.$)     Bre-X Gets Court Protection   Bre-X Minerals was granted protection from creditors as it prepares for liquidation after being accused of perpetrating the biggest mining fraud in history. $(D2.$)     Simmons Rejects Settlement   Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, said that he had refused a $50 million settlement proposed by two of his daughters, who have sued for control of his corporate empire. $(D6.$)    I.B.M. to Buy Out Sears in Venture   I.B.M. said that it would buy the 30 percent stake in Advantis -- a networking services joint venture with Sears, Roebuck -- that it does not already own, for $450 million. $(D13.$)    United Paramount Chief to Leave   Lucie Salhaney, the chief executive of United Paramount Network, a fledgling television network, said that she had decided not to renew her contract this fall. $(D3.$)    Small Retreat on Privacy Policy   Giving ground on the Clinton Administration's computer-data privacy policy, the Commerce Department said that it would begin in some cases to allow export of the most powerful data-scrambling technologies when used for securing transactions. $(A17.$)

headline: Better Late Than Never? Dow Does Derivatives
abstract: Market Watch column on Dow Jones plans for index of derivatives (S)

headline: Harvard Loses A.I.D. Grant For Russians
abstract: United States Agency for International Development suspends $14 million in grants to Harvard University's International Development Institute, charging two of its advisers on project promoting fiscal and legal reforms in Russia used their posts for personal gain; charges Prof Andrei Shleifer and Jonathan Hay used program resources and staff to help Shleifer's wife, Nancy Zimmerman, invest in Russia and charges Hay invested in Russian Government bonds; two deny charges (M)

headline: Warner-Lambert Deal
abstract: Warner-Lambert Co purchases 66 percent of Jouveinal Group of France that it does not already own, partly to market its cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor better; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: MTV to Transmit Internet Videos
abstract: Viacom Inc's MTV unit will broadcast music videos to consumers' personal computers using technology developed by Intel Corp (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jury Rejects Suit Against R. J. Reynolds  A jury ruled in favor of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco in a closely watched wrongful death lawsuit in Florida, rejecting arguments that the company's cigarettes were defective products that caused the death of a woman whose family sued the company.    The verdict represented a show of strength by the industry, which has suffered a series of legal setbacks and which has been seeking to settle multibillion-dollar health claims by state governments. $(Page A16.$)    Deal to Form Paper Giant  James River said that it would acquire Fort Howard for $3.6 billion, creating the largest maker of tissues, napkins and paper towels in the United States. $(D4.$)

headline: Israeli Quits Cabinet, Saying Netanyahu Wanted to Oust Him
abstract: Israeli Finance Min Dan Meridor resigns in dispute over exchange rates; asserts that Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu deliberately raised issue to force him out (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Oracle Seen Investing In Netscape Affiliate  Oracle is expected to announce a majority investment in Navio Communications Inc., a company established by Netscape Communications to develop Internet software for the so-called network computer and for other consumer electronics.

headline: BOSTON CHICKEN TO CUT HEADQUARTERS STAFF BY 25%
abstract: Boston Chicken Inc will dismiss 115 employees, or one-fourth of its headquarters staff, and have franchises combine their administrative duties to cut annual costs by as much as $40 million (S)

headline: Reed Deal With Microsoft
abstract: Reed Elsevier PLC signs five-year publishing agreement worth $30 million with Microsoft Corp; deal allows Reed Elsevier to use Microsoft's commercial Internet system applications for future electronic offerings in scientific, legal, business and travel information markets (S)

headline: Australian to Head U.N. Effort To Monitor Curbs on Iraqi Arms
abstract: Richard Butler, Australia's representative at United Nations, is named chairman of UN Special Commission in charge of locating and destroying Iraq's offensive weapons; he succeeds Rolf Ekeus, who is leaving UN to become Sweden's Ambassador to US on July 1 (M)û

headline: German President's Lament Rejected : Much Distress in Europe Over Talk, Talk, Talk
abstract: FRANKFURT—  - Germany's political establishment has rejected a scathing speech by President Roman Herzog that portrayed the nation as dangerously delaying social and economic changes.

headline: Donaldson, Lufkin Posts 32.7% Gain In Earnings
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc says earnings rose 32.7 percent in first quarter; earnings rose to $86.4 million from $65.1 million in 1996 first quarter; revenue after interest expenses rose 27 percent, to $760 million from $600.9 million a year earlier; table (M)

headline: Panel to Call Former Wife Of Mandela
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, established to investigate atrocities in country's past, will subpoena Winnie Mandela, Pres Nelson Mandela's former wife, to closed session of panel; commission has been investigating activities of her former bodyguards (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the passenger flights begun by the United Parcel Service omitted the attribution of a comment. It was Paul J. Harjes, a mechanic, who noted differences between cargo and passenger flights but the importance of avoiding delays on both. ''When I take a delay on a cargo flight, I don't see the people involved,'' Mr. Harjes said. ''But there's people behind the boxes,'' who rely on the packages' timely arrival.

headline: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS PLANS TO ADD CRAIN-DRUMMOND
abstract: Reynolds & Reynolds Co agrees to buy Crain-Drummond Inc for $44.3 million in cash (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   6.22   5.27        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.90   4.88   5.06        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.08   5.10   5.23        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.64   3.57   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.42   6.39   6.93        30-YR. TREAS.
