headline: Interactive Services Venture in Britain
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC and British Sky Broadcasting Group PLC form joint venture to provide digital satellite-television, home banking and other interactive services in Britain; British Telecom and B Sky B will each own 32.5 percent of venture, called British Interactive Broadcasting Ltd; HSBC Midland Bank will own 20 percent and Mitsubishi Electric Industrial will own 15 percent (S)

headline: Long-distance truck drivers get the royal treatment from the Knights Inn hotel chain.
abstract: Knights Inn, fast-growing chain with 200 hotels in 34 states and Canada, has staked out a turf as unofficial hotel of long-distance truck drivers; advertising campaign created by Musselman Advertising Inc discussed (L)

headline: Weak Sale of Inflation Notes Hurts Bonds
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities sag under weight of more data showing strength in economy and disappointment over latest auction of Government's new inflation-indexed securities; benchmark 30-year Treasury bond drops 13/32, to price of 94 6/32; yield rises to 7.10 percent, from 7.06 percent on April 7; graph (L)

headline: Congolese Troops Detain Top Opposition Leader
abstract: Congolese soldiers, in move that appears to signal new hard line against dissent, arrest opposition politician Etienne Tshisekedi and his wife and take them to undisclosed destination; Tshisekedi's arrest comes only hours after he held rally at University of Kinshasa in defiance of ban on political meetings (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Uromed Corp buys rights to incontinence device from Johnson & Johnson Medical Inc for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: With This Ring, I Thee Hyphenate
abstract: Letter from Robin Beckhard James on Mar 16 article on keeping or changing name when marrying (S)

headline: Mexican Leaders Honor a Union Giant, and an Era
abstract: Mexican Government officials and labor leaders pay final respects to Fidel Velazquez Sanchez, 97-year-old labor patriarch who died on June 21, at funeral in Mexico City; he is hailed by Pres Ernesto Zedillo; rank-and-file union members display little grief; criticize his legacy of low wages; predict death will unleash power struggle to produce more decentralized and aggressive labor movement, and to break decades-old bond between unions and Government; photo (M)

headline: CV REIT TO PAY $110 MILLION FOR 22 SHOPPING CENTERS
abstract: CV Reit Inc agrees to acquire 22 strip shopping centers in eastern Pennsylvania and southern New Jersey for about $110 million; sellers are several private owners and companies (S)

headline: German Growth Is Seen Above 0.5% in Quarter
abstract: Germany's gross domestic product could grow a real 0.5 percent to 1 percent in the second quarter, exceeding that of the comparable period a year ago by 2.5 percent, DIW, one of Germany's main economic research institutes, said yesterday.

headline: Early '97 Growth Is Lifted a Bit, to 5.9%
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that economy grew in first quarter at slightly faster pace than previously estimated and that inflation remained in check; growth in corporate profits is revised downward; gross domestic product rose at 5.9 percent annual rate; chart (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CITGO PETROLEUM CORP., Tulsa, Okla., a unit of Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., said its president and chief executive, Ralph S. Cunningham, was resigning, effective May 31. Roberto V. Mandini, executive vice president and deputy chief executive, will assume the duties of chief executive until a successor is named.

headline: Dow Adds 130, Putting 1997 Gain Near 1,000 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average soars 130.49 points, or 1.8 percent, to close at record 7,435.78 on June 6; graph (M)ÿ

headline: U.S. DIAGNOSTIC REJECTS MEDICAL RESOURCES BID
abstract: US Diagnostic rejects Medical Resources Inc's stock takeover offer of $6.25 a share (S)

headline: By Hook or by Crook, a Fishing Village Gets By
abstract: Article profiles fishing village of Wagenia, Congo, which sits on the famous Stanley Falls and next to Kisangani, third-largest city of the former Zaire; map; photo (M)

headline: The Sun Over Hong Kong Sets on the British Navy
abstract: Ensign of British Royal Navy is lowered on HMS Tamar in Hong Kong, ending Britain's naval presence in Asia after 156 years; Gov Chris Patten presides at ceremony (S)

headline: HONDA SUES TO THWART REPUBLIC DEALERSHIP PLANS
abstract: Honda Motor Co sues Republic Industries to block Republic's acquisition of Honda and Acura dealerships in major markets; American Honda Motor Co believes Republic wants to buy more than 60 Honda and Acura franchises in major markets in next 18 months, which would give it as much as 20 percent of American Honda's total sales volume (S)

headline: Lobbyists for TV Angle to Elude Rules to Return Free Channels
abstract: Article, in occasional series on lobbying, notes that lobbyists for television broadcasting industry have managed to work two provisions into Senate and House budget bills that would allow broadcasters to evade most significant commitments they made for coming transition to digital broadcasting; Federal regulators lent each of nation's 1,600 TV stations second channel for transition; Federal Communications Commission, at urging of White House, passed rule calling for return of channels in 2006; one provision in budget bills would enable broadcasters to keep channels for indefinite period; other could delay introduction of digital high-definition television broadcasts far beyond Government-set deadlines (M)

headline: Smith Barney Dismisses Official Linked to Fund-Raising Inquiry
abstract: Smith Barney Inc has dismissed Robert B Maloney, its New England regional director, whose role in raising campaign contributions for his brother, Repr James H Maloney, Democrat of Connecticut, is under investigation by Federal authorities (M)

headline: DUTCH COMPANY BUYS PUBLISHING CONCERN FROM DISNEY
abstract: Wolters Kluwer NV, Dutch publishing company, acquires NILS Publishing from Walt Disney Co; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Group of 7 Officials Issue Currency Warning  Finance ministers and central bankers from the world's seven largest industrial nations, including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, strongly hinted that they would intervene in the currency markets, if necessary, to prevent Japan's trade surplus from growing.    The warning was the first since the officials called for a halt to the dollar's rise against the yen in February. But in Asian trading, the dollar still rose early against the yen, though it receded later. $(Page D2.$)    PC Sales Grew in First Quarter  The PC industry continues to show strong growth, despite Wall Street anxieties about the market for home computers. Two reports indicate that the market grew by about 16 percent worldwide in this year's first quarter, compared with a year earlier. $(D6.$)

headline: Coffee Prices Fall as Supplies In the U.S. Show an Increase
abstract: Futures Markets column; coffee prices retreat on market in New York as rise in inventories in United States gives temporary relief to concern about shortages in months ahead (S)

headline: A Cleric's Tolerant Orthodoxy Wins
abstract: Profile of Iranian President-elect, Mohammed Khatami, who is known as gentle, soft-spoken, tolerant and worldly, who nonetheless wears a black turban; under often complex rules of Shiite Islam, only clerics who can prove that they are direct descendants of prophet Mohammed may wear black turbans; at several polling places, voters say that Khatami's black turban was enough to resolve any doubts that he was not sufficiently orthodox Muslim; Khatami believes in what one friend describes as 'a very peaceful interpretation of Islam' that rejects 'any form of oppression or coercion' (M)

headline: On the Left Bank, Moveable Feast Is Harder to Find
abstract: Some Parisians complain that stores are beginning to eclipse cafe scene on Left Bank; they are waging fight to save character of Left Bank, which for centuries has harbored writers and other intellectuals; map; photo (M)

headline: When the Cat's Away
abstract: New York Times is looking for stories on how one's office is run when the boss takes an extended vacation; drawing (S)

headline: U.S. Giving North Korea More Food
abstract: State Department, on eve of new meetings with North Korea, says United States will prove $15 million worth of corn in response to United Nations appeal for aid to avert growing famine; State Sec Madeleine K Albright holds famine relief is humanitarian, not political (M)

headline: McDonald's Reinvents a Promotion in Fast-Food Frenzy
abstract: McDonald's Corp's Campaign 55 that will let consumers buy breakfast sandwiches for 55 cents beginning April 4 and Big Mac sandwiches on April 25, seems to have come up with latest promotion twist in fast food industry: creating the veneer of value pricing, and all its attendant marketing ballyhoo, without undergoing deep markdown that would erode its profitability; in most of the country, 55-cent breakfast sandwich will be packaged with hash browns and small coffee for $1.79, down from $1.99 regular price; McDonald's competitors, including Burger King, Wendy's International, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut, are not rising to challenge posed by Campaign 55; graph; photos (L)

headline: The SBC Deal Shelved, What Tack For AT&T?
abstract: Analysis of AT&T's future following breakdown of merger talks with SBC Communications Inc; fact that talks were held at all seen as AT&T's acknowledgment that it is wary of competing on its own in deregulated market; company's peculiar handling of negotiations may have tarnished both its credibility and morale; financial logic of a merger is so compelling that many experts expect AT&T to try to resuscitate talks with SBC; failing that, AT&T could try to forge deal with another regional Bell company, like BellSouth, or with GTE; photo (M)

headline: Legal Situation Is Confused On Web Content Protections
abstract: On-line businesses look to courts to impose law and order and to help protect their content; in one case, Ticketmaster Corp has sued Microsoft Corp, seeking to prevent links to its site from Microsoft content provider; Microsoft contends that essence of Web is that it permits largely unrestricted linking and roaming of content; emergence of such intellectual property questions coincides with increasingly profitable nature of Internet content (M)

headline: Delivering a Big Blow to the Death Tax
abstract: Formidable small-business lobby, led by National Federation of Independent Business, has taken issue of cutting estate taxes that touches relatively few--and relatively wealthly--people and pushed it to the top of nation's economic agenda; in just a few years, issue has gone from quixotic quest by few die-hard tax cutters in Congress to one that enjoys almost unanimous support from Republicans and backing from considerable number of Democrats; Repr Bill Archer has agreed to increase size of estate-tax reduction by $10 billion, allowing increase to $1 million exemption to be phased in by 2007; in sign of how influence of small businesses can be greater than that of corporate America, most of money to pay for bigger cut will come from scaling back Archer's proposal to eliminate alternative minimum tax on corporations; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Companies Go on Line To Trim Costs and Find Ways to Make Money, Too
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc's successful use of Internet to sell computer networking gear could portend how businesses may eventually turn Internet into money-making medium; sales on Cisco's World Wide Web site have reached over $1 billion a year and are expected to double that pace by July; Cisco, in addition to order-taking, also handles credit checking, production scheduling, basic technical support and routine customer-support queries on line; benefits include faster service, quicker production cycles and savings; Cisco aide Peter Solvik says companies in any field can soon do same; graph; photos (L)

headline: Bosnian Refugees as Political Pawns
abstract: Western diplomats say Bosnian Government is packing border town of Sanski Most, with tens of thousands of returning Bosnian Muslim refugees in preparation for a political--and perhaps military--offensive to seize Bosnian Serb territory; map; photo (M)

headline: Smaller Investors Keeping Faith, Despite Stock Market's Troubles
abstract: Sharp drop in stock prices apparently has not shaken investors' faith in market's long-term potential, partly because many do not see alternative to investing in stocks; stock mutual fund managers say they have not yet seen signs of investor retreat; sampling of individual investors indicates they are planning to sit tight during downturn (M)

headline: Rules Tightened At Occidental
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp adopts policies to strengthen its internal controls in its dealing with foreign governments and businessmen; oil company is responding to article in Wall Street Journal, which reported that lawyers for the company are investigating whether it had overpaid some foreign middlemen or whether any funds might have been used for payoffs overseas (S)

headline: A New Market For First Union
abstract: First Union Corp says its investment banking unit has received approval from Federal Reserve to begin equity underwriting; regulatory approval is first step in bank's plan to begin providing stock underwriting (S)

headline: Turning Rough Takes Into Summer's Big Hits
abstract: Movie industry is in midst of frenzied period before release of summer blockbusters, when armies of workers perform post-production technical tasks of editing, scoring, sound mixing and digital effects; laborious post-production process has traditionally taken 20 weeks or longer; in recent years, incentive to crunch post-production schedules has increased as major studios compete furiously to release their films first; studios also need to recoup high costs of production as quickly as possible; this has led to 80-hour weeks for post-production workers; petitions to limit days to 14 hours have been signed by many post-production workers, but that campaign is controversial in industry where most workers are freelancers who welcome chance to earn overtime; photos (M)

headline: Clinton In Caribbean: No Bananas Today
abstract: Pres Clinton meets with leaders of 15 Caribbean countries in Barbados; he pledges freer trade to Caribbean nations and receives assurances of more help in fighting illegal drugs; Caribbean leaders sign joint statement to continue negotiations with US on dispute over bananas; say they will resist US effort to eliminate trade preference that Caribbean bananas have in Europe; photo (M)

headline: Clinton, at Costa Rica Talks, Gives Pledge on Immigrants
abstract: Pres Clinton, after meeting in San Jose, Costa Rica, with leaders of seven Central American and Caribbean nations, says he will seek to blunt new law to restrict illegal immigration and compel deportations (M)

headline: The Hard Times of a Coal Town, Ignored in Booming Britain's Vote
abstract: Ghettos of reinvigorated urban centers and downtrodden rural villages near affluent towns all over Britain are all but forgotten by both Tories and Labor in current general election campaign; residents of rural areas such as Grimethorpe, South Yorkshire mining town, find themselves neglected and invisible, and left behind in recovering economy; are resentful of Tories for shutting down coal pits, but are no longer enamored of Labor Party, to which they have long been loyal, since party has refashioned itself to appeal to voters of prosperous Middle England, none of whom exist in Grimethorpe, which remains poor with abundance of drugs and crime; photo; map (M)

headline: Greenspan Defends Fed's Rate Policy
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, clearly stung by widespread criticism that Federal Reserve was too quick to raise interest rates six weeks ago, aggressively defends action, saying that failure to act would have constituted 'a threat to the job security and standards of living of too many Americans,' speech at awards dinner of New York University Stern School of Business; Greenspan does not say whether he will push for another rate increase when Fed meets to consider monetary policy on May 20, although he warns that further rate increase might be necessary if economy does not slow (L)

headline: Eurotunnel Reports Loss of $1.1 Billion
abstract: Eurotunnel, debt-burdened operator of Channel Tunnel, says it lost 685 million pounds, or $1.1 billion, last year as costs of servicing its debt overwhelmed 71 percent rise in revenue (S)

headline: A Slowdown In the Works Whatever The Fed Does
abstract: Analysis: American economy appears to be heading into period of slower economic growth whatever the Federal Reserve does over next few months; virtually no economist is predicting a recession, only slowdown to perhaps half booming annual growth rate of more than 4 percent that prevailed from October through March; many analysts consider such rapid growth to be inflationary, if it lasts long enough; graphs (L)

headline: Stock Sale by Top WMX Shareholder
abstract: WMX Technologies Inc says Peter Huizenga, its largest individual shareholder, will sell part of his 1.7 percent stake; Huizenga, who owns about eight million shares and has said that he plans to resign as a board member next month, is tendering 'a minority position' under WMX's plan to buy back as much as $1 billion in stock (S)a

headline: China Buying U.S. Computers, Raising Arms Fears
abstract: US officials say China has purchased more than 46 American-made supercomputers since Pres Clinton deregulated exports in 1995, and that they suspect equipment is being used to design more efficient or lighter nuclear warheads that could be placed on missiles capable of reaching US; Clinton Administration officials defend 1995 decision, which rebuffed request by House National Security Committee to refrain from deregulation and to reassess national security risks of allowing exporters to decide who may purchase equipment; say they believe China's civilian purchasers are insuring that equipment is not diverted to military uses; argue it would nearly impossible for US to effectively prevent Chinese from obtaining computers from other sources (M)

headline: Supreme Court Upholds S.E.C.'s Theory of Insider Trading
abstract: US Supreme Court rules, 6-3, that insider trading laws apply to people with confidential information even if they have no connection with company whose shares are being bought; ruling reinstates conviction of James H O'Hagan, Minneapolis attorney who made $4.3 million in Grand Metropolitan PLC's hostile takeover of Pillsbury Co, and is major victory for Federal prosecutors and securities regulators; majority opinion by Assoc Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg upholds misappropriation theory US Appeals Court had ruled invalid; establishes standard that anyone who gains inside information under conditions in which persons knows it is supposed to remain confidential may not use it for trading; covers anyone, from financial printer to law firm secretary, but not someone who obtained information by chance (M)

headline: Technology and Small Stocks Join Surge
abstract: Stock market finishes stunning weeklong rally that sends Dow Jones industrial average within 14 points of its record high and sees first sharp recovery in smaller stocks and technology issues since selloff in March and April; Dow jumps 94.72 points, or 1.36 percent, to 7,071.20, finishing with gain of 4.9 per cent for week--its best in more than five years; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fares even better, rising 14.44 points to 812.97, and its best weekly gain--6.2 percent--in almost 13 years; graphs (M)

headline: Drops in Circulation Continue for Most Big Newspapers
abstract: Figures released by Audit Bureau of Circulations show broad decline in newspaper circulation sales that began early in the decade continued for most big metropolitan dailies during winter months; of country's 10 biggest papers, 4--USA Today, San Francisco Chronicle, Los Angeles Times and Newsday--registered increases; The New York Times and Daily News of New York reported circulation declines of about 4 percent; Sunday circulation also suffered at most papers; other statistics; table (L)

headline: Israel Defends Use of Force in Interrogation
abstract: Israeli aides defend use of physical coercion in questioning detainees who might have information about terrorism, United Nations Committee Against Torture, Geneva; reveal for first time case in which bombing was averted through 'moderate physical pressure;' hold methods are not designed to inflict severe pain and suffering (M)

headline: Storebrand Makes Bid For Norwegian Bank
abstract: Storebrand ASA makes $1.84 billion stock offer to acquire Christiana Bank ASA (S)

headline: Brutal End for an Architect of Cambodian Brutality
abstract: Profile of Son Sen, Khmer Rouge official who is reported to have been executed by his leader, Pol Pot; Son Sen was one of earliest members of radical Maoist movement, and one of its most brutal; Son Sen's reported killing by his close comrades, following accusations of spying and treason, seem to close circle on his role as executioner during purges at Tuol Sleng, in which Khmer Rouge Govt devoured itself; chronology of Khmer Rouge's role in Cambodia; photo of Pol Pot (M)

headline: POLYGRAM OF THE NETHERLANDS IN U.S. EXPANSION
abstract: Polygram NV of Netherlands says tht it had set up new United States distribution company, Polygram Films, in Hollywood to market 10 to 12 major movies each year (S)

headline: CHS ELECTRONICS TO BUY COMPUTER PRODUCTS COMPANIES
abstract: CHS Electronics Inc agrees to buy four closely held computer-related companies; acquisitions of Ameritech Argentina SA and Compexpress Informatica Ltda are expected to make CHS Electronics leading computer products distributor in Argentina and Brazil; also agrees to buy Ameritech Exports Inc, concern in Miami, Fla, that distributes Compaq Computer products throughout South America, and Atlantis Skupina, which distributes computer products in Slovenia (S)

headline: Italy Seeking Refugee Boat From Albania That Sank
abstract: Italian authorities order search for remains of sunken Albanian boat, struck on March 28 by Italian Navy warship enforcing blockade along Italy's southern shoreline, in probe of events that led to accident; Prime Min Romano Prodi says Italy will not stop naval patrol of its southern shores, despite accident; says patrols are intended not to deter refugees, but to stop illegal organizations that are profiting by transporting them; Albania accuses Italian Navy of causing deaths of dozens aboard boat (M)

headline: The London-Paris train under the channel adds a premium service with its own special cars.
abstract: Eurostar, train that connects London and Paris via Channel Tunnel, recently began premium service for business travelers in first and second class; new 337-room Hotel Adlon, managed by Kempinksi chain and built on site of original Adlon Hotel in Berlin, Germany, will open June 1; services for business travelers noted; Traveler's Weather Guide, published by Ten Speed Press, has tables that list weather conditions in more than 200 cities in US and overseas; travelers tired of wasting time in transit might find Landjet, an office housed in converted GMC Savannah van, appealing; van is priced at $74,300; Tokyo-Q, colorfully illustrated Web site, created by non-Japanese residents of Tokyo, provides rundown of latest doings, including information on the arts, dining, night life and politics (L)

headline: Russia's Premier to Slash Budget, Trimming Military and Subsidies
abstract: Russian Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin tells Parliament that effort to raise more money by cracking down on tax evaders has failed and that Government must cut 1997 budget by about 20%; calls for cuts in spending on military and state-subsidized industries; plan, which Government has already begun to impose by decree, sets aside money for wages and pensions that have gone unpaid for months; reflects influence of reformers; table; photo (M)

headline: Burmese Crack Down as U.S. Investment Ban Goes Into Effect
abstract: United States ban on new investments in Myanmar takes effect; is designed to punish military Government for human rights abuses; Government reportedly arrests more members of pro-democracy movement led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi (M)

headline: Southeast Asia Bloc Admits Burmese and Two Others
abstract: Asian trading bloc Asean says it will admit Myanmar, formerly Burma, despite concerns of US over human rights abuses; seven-member group, formally Association of Southeast Asian Nations, also agrees to admit Laos and Cambodia (M)

headline: Zurich Insurance Sells $1 Billion in Debt
abstract: Zurich Insurance Group, Swiss insurer that is negotiating to buy Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc, has sold $1 billion in debt to finance expansion of the company (S)

headline: RUMORED PURCHASES BY BUFFETT LIFT NIKE SHARES
abstract: Shares of Nike Inc rise 6 percent on speculation that Warren E Buffett, head of Berkshire Hathaway Inc, might be purchasing shares (S)

headline: Wheat Price Soars as Estimate Of World Supplies Is Reduced
abstract: Futures Markets column; wheat prices surge to their highest-level in four and half months after Government predicts that American and worldwide stockpiles would be even leaner than expected because of strong demand; tables (M)

headline: John Landry, 73, Marlboro Marketing Expert
abstract: John Thomas Landry, whose knack for marketing helped turn Marlboro into world's largest-selling cigarette and whose love of horse racing inspired Marlboro Cup, dies at age 73 (M)

headline: Clinton, at West Point, Says Bigger NATO Lessens Chance of War
abstract: Pres Clinton, in his commencement address at US Military Academy, tells graduating cadets that mere prospect of NATO's expansion into former Soviet bloc has increased stability in Europe and decreased chances that they 'will ever be called to fight in another war across the Atlantic' (M)

headline: Blockbuster Chairman Out; Viacom to Issue Shares in Unit
abstract: Viacom Inc says that Bill Fields, chairman of its Blockbuster unit, has resigned and that it plans to issue new class of shares to track performance of troubled home-video chain; also warns that Blockbuster's first-quarter cash flow will fall 15 percent to 20 percent from comparable quarter a year earlier because of a weak lineup of movie titles; executives at Viacom have been weighing plans to spin off Blockbuster for several months; financial and managerial turmoil drives down Viacom's class B shares by 12 percent, to $27.25 each; Viacom chairman, Sumner M Redstone, comments; graphs (L)

headline: POLO RALPH LAUREN PLANS TO OFFER 30% STAKE TO PUBLIC
abstract: Polo Ralph Lauren Corp, its founder and other shareholders plan to sell 29.5 million shares at $22 to $25 each in initial public offering that values company at as much as $2.46 billion (S)

headline: Donna Karan Announces Plan to Cut Costs
abstract: Donna Karan International Inc will cut its work force in US by 4 percent and reduce its annual number of runway fashion shows in effort to cut costs and bolster profits; company will take second-quarter pretax restructuring charge of about $1.6 million and other pretax charges of about $3.6 million, related to costs of job cuts and write-down of inventories of unsold products from its Donna Karan New York Accessories line (S)

headline: B Sky B Chief to Resign At End of the Year
abstract: Sam Chisholm plans to leave as British Sky Broadcasting Group chief executive and managing director at end of year for health reasons; will become nonexecutive director; Mark Booth will succeed him (S)

headline: U.S. Airline Executives Are Hot in a Deregulated Europe
abstract: Many European carriers are recruiting battle-tested American executives for top jobs as Europe's airline industry goes through overhaul reminiscent of wrenching changes at America's airlines in 1980's; article focuses on Frederick W Reid, president and chief operating officer of Lufthansa, Jeffrey G Katz, who will become chief executive of Swissair, and Jonathan Ornstein, chief executive of Virgin Express; photos (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.63   5.95   5.18        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.15   5.18   4.95        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.36   5.35   5.02        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.64   3.64   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.92   6.87   6.52        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Compass of Britain Buying Food Concern
abstract: Compass Group PLC to acquire 93 percent stake in the French food company SHRM for 227.1 million pounds ($376 million); says it will also acquire remaining shares, which are held by SHRM management; agrees to sell its 11 percent stake in Generale de Restauration to Compagnie Generale des Eaux (S)

headline: Cold Shoulder To Insurance Customers
abstract: Major life insurance companies, in little-noticed nationwide lobbying campaign, have gotten several states to adopt legislation allowing them to sell stock to investors without longstanding requirement to pay policyholders share of profits; 70 million policyholders are considered formal 'owners' of mutual insurers, including giants like Metropolitan Life, New York Life and John Hancock; critics say changes effectively end hallmark cooperative nature of mutual insurers; former Texas insurance commissioner J Robert Hunter charges companies would 'rob money' from policyholders; new laws permit mutuals to transform themselves into holding companies; map; chart explaining insurers' organization (M)

headline: NEC to Spend Heavily On Production of Chips
abstract: NEC Corp will spend $3.17 billion on production of semiconductors over next three years (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Personal Income April  Construction Spending April

headline: U.S. NOW AT ODDS WITH NATO ALLIES ON NEW MEMBERS
abstract: US is at odds with many of its allies over how many nations from Central and Eastern Europe should be invited to join North Atlantic Treaty Organization; although Hungary, Poland and Czech Republic have been leading candidates, majority of NATO foreign ministers at meeting in Portugal on May 29 favor including Romania and Slovenia; Iceland is only country to declare its support for limiting first group of new members to three; US, Germany and Britain, while supporting three, leave open their options, laying groundwork for compromise (M)

headline: Mitsubishi to Write Off American Auto Losses
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors Corp will write off 43.1 billion yen ($342 million) in losses from its American sales subsidiary, latest blow to company's troubled United States operations (S)

headline: Monsanto recruits the horticulturist of the San Diego Zoo to pitch its popular herbicide.
abstract: Roundup, world's most popular brand of weed killer, begam campaign last month with gardener of country's most popular zoo, San Diego Zoo and Wild Animal Park, as its spokesman; in the commercials, Cary Sharp, zoo's horticulturalist, describes his use of Roundup, product of Monsanto Co, at work and at home (M)

headline: BARNETT AND REPUBLIC BANKING END TAKEOVER TALKS
abstract: Barnett Banks and Republic Banking Corp end discussions without completing definitive acquisition agreement (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.72   5.50        3-MO. headline: Brouillard Gets Supermarket Work
abstract: Penn Traffic Co, which operates 265 supermarkets in four states, names Brouillard Communications to handle its advertising; billings estimated at $20 million; previous agency was Ron Foth Advertising (S)

headline: European Union Strengthens Resolve to Merge Currencies
abstract: Members of European Union attending Amsterdam summit agree to stability pact that preserves tight government spending as alliance's top priority and renews its determination to create common currency; rebuff demand by France's new Socialist Government for huge public-works investments to create jobs; preserve dedication to common currency, while pledging to coordinate economic policies to try to create high job growth without throwing more government money at problem; call for special summit on jobs in Luxembourg later in year; unemployment averages more than 10 percent in Europe, where last period of rapid growth was in 1960's; photo (M)

headline: Charger Promises To Extend Life Of Batteries
abstract: Advanced Charger Technology Inc is marketing device that it says speeds recharging of batteries and also preserves battery's ability to hold a charge; charger works on lead-acid, nickel-cadmium and nickel metal-hydride cells (S)

headline: Added Budget Value Is Goal of Program
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies has teamed up with Advertising Research Foundation and Marketing Science Institute to help marketers spend advertising dollars more effectively and efficiently (S)

headline: The Euro Creates European Turmoil
abstract: Dream of common currency in Europe is giving way to inescapable practical imperatives and forcing political leaders to address contradictions they have ignored for years; in France, center-right Government of Pres Jacques Chirac is fighting for survival after voters issued stunning rebuke in last Sunday's first round of national elections, which was seen as referendum on the euro; in Germany, Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to take extraordinary step of using obvious accounting gimmick--booking a quick profit by revaluing gold reserves--to reduce a ballooning deficit (L)

headline: Pounding and Protests for Hong Kong's Big Day
abstract: Waiting for China, Reporter's Notebook on preparations for Hong Kong's handover to China; says Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright and British Prime Min Tony Blair will witness handover, but will boycott subsequent swearing in of Hong Kong's new government, to protest China's abolition of territory's elected legislature and its installation of appointed assembly; notes China is moving main force of army garrison into Hong Kong, reflecting Chinese military's conviction that United States and Birtain are conspiring to undermine Hong Kong; photo (M)

headline: Europe Focuses on Future and the Impact of New Members
abstract: Leaders of European Union meeting at summit in Amsterdam set aside differences over how to achieve common currency by 1999 to tangle thorny issue of power-sharing; fail to reach agreement on how power should be apportioned once new members from central Europe are admitted; officials say 15-nation Union is unlikely to be in position to admit new countries until middle of next decade--putting group far behind US-led NATO alliance, which plans to admit three formerly Communist Central European countries by 1999; photo (M

headline: Credit Card Debt Hits a Record
abstract: Bad credit card debt reported in April rose $62 million, to $821 million, among banks and other lenders tracked by Fitch Investment Service; Fitch says its Credit Card Performance Index hit 6.71 percent, a record, up 0.35 of percentage point from previous month (S)

headline: Tradition on Trial As New Yorker Rethinks Cartoons
abstract: Robert Mankoff is named The New Yorker's first new cartoon editor since 1973; definition of New Yorker cartoon has changed over last decade, with its principal humor, long tailored to Manhattan sensibilities, transformed into something a little more generally accessible; critics say New Yorker cartoons of late are so dependent on the moment that they may not last; Mankoff is 53-year-old cartoonist whose work first appeared in The New Yorker in 1977; Mankoff says New Yorker cartoons should be intelligent and accessible, rather than pose as obscure intelligence test; cartoons (M)

headline: France Signals Its Flexibility To Avoid a Crisis on the Euro
abstract: France's new Socialist Government signals that it is willing to be flexible to avoid major crisis at a European summit meeting scheduled for Amsterdam next week; with financial markets and European governments reacting nervously to France's decision on June 9 to put off consideration of agreement that is prelude to planned European currency, Pres Jacques Chirac and Lionel Jospin, new Socialist Prime Minister, discuss with European Union leaders how plans for single currency can get back on track (L)

headline: Montague Selects A Chief Executive
abstract: Brian Martin will join Montague & as chief executive (S)

headline: Salomon Trader Was Paid $31.45 Million
abstract: Salomon Inc paid Shigeru Myojin, head of its trading unit, $31.45 million in 1996, and Deryck C Maughan, chairman of its securities business, received $11.52 million (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Joseph M. Kessler, a principal at Sawyer Miller Consulting, New York, part of the Bozell Sawyer Miller Group division of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, was named to the new post of president for Southern California, based in Los Angeles. Also, Dan Pittman was named to head a new Orange County, Calif., office of Bozell Sawyer Miller, in Costa Mesa, as senior managing partner. He had been a partner for public relations at the Costa Mesa office of Bozell Worldwide. Mr. Pittman will report to Mr. Kessler.    * Louise Coolick was named advertising director at Mademoiselle magazine, New York, owned by the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications, succeeding Erica Bartman, who joined a sibling magazine, Vogue, in a similar post. Ms. Coolick had been senior vice president and advertising director at Ivillage, New York, a venture of America Online Inc., the Tribune Co., the TCI Interactive unit of Tele-Communications Inc. and Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers. Also, Elizabeth Nann, national sales manager at Mademoiselle, was named to the new post of advertising manager.

headline: Turkey's Prime Minister, About to Step Down, Defends Record
abstract: Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan of Turkey says he will soon resign, but predicts he will be returned to office with stronger mandate; first Islamist politician to lead modern Turkey has been under intense pressure from military, which feels he is undermining secular basis of Turkish state and leading country toward fundamentalism (M)

headline: Lucent and Philips to Create $2.5 Billion Phone Venture
abstract: Lucent Technologies and Philips Electronics will combine their existing phone-making operations in new joint venture, Philips Consumer Communications, in bid to create wireless phone powerhouse; Philips aide Michael McTighe will be chief executive of new firm, which will be 60 percent owned by Philips; he expects minimal layoffs (M)

headline: QUAKER SAYS QUARTERLY PROFITS WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
abstract: Quaker Oats Co says its first-quarter earnings will beat Wall Street's expectations, excluding $1.4 billion pretax charge from sale of its Snapple beverages unit (S)

headline: Hands Off Our Babies, a Georgian Tells America
abstract: Fifteen American couples set to adopt infants in Georgia are stuck in deeply politicized bureaucratic struggle that pits them against wife of Pres Eduard Shevardnadze, who leads drive to end foreign adoptions; she charges foreign adoption agencies use bribery and deceit, including exaggerated diagnoses of medical needs, to take healthy babies Georgians would be happy to adopt; painful controversy has been echoed throughout former Soviet Union, where foreign adoptions soared after Communism collapsed; photos (L)

headline: Strong Demand for Regional Jets Helps Fuel a Booming Civilian Market
abstract: PARIS—  The 42d Paris Air Show reflects an upturn in markets for civilian jetliners and intense competition for the embattled military sector as defense budgets are trimmed in many countries.

headline: President Resigns At Chrysler's Japan Unit
abstract: Hideo Hohgi, president of Chrysler Corp's Japanese unit, resigns; Keisuke Egashira, chairman and director of Japanese subsidiary, will temporarily run the unit (S)

headline: New Amoco Canada Plant
abstract: Amoco Canada Petroleum Co to build $178.9 million olefins plant on NOVA Chemicals Ltd Joffre site near Red Deer, Alberta (S)

headline: Lucent in New Identification Joint Venture
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc and US Venture Partners say they formed a company that will make products to help people prove their identities through electronic fingerprinting technology; first product of that company, Veridicom Inc, will be postage-size fingerprint sensor used to retrieve information, authorize purchases or allow entry into restricted areas (S)

headline: GATEWAY 2000 ANNOUNCES 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
abstract: Gateway 2000 Inc will split its stock 2 for 1 and move its listing to New York Stock Exchange from Nasdaq stock market (S)

headline: Fascists Reborn as Croatia's Founding Fathers
abstract: Supporters of Croatia's Party of Rights give fascist salute at rally marking 57th anniversary of founding of Nazi-allied wartime state, which murdered hundreds of thousands of Jews, Serbs and Croatian resistance fighters; photo; map; shouts of black-shirted young men in Split mark final day of campaigning in local elections; Pres Franjo Tudjman's Government has rehabilitated Ustashe fascists as precursors of modern state, and veterans are honored while partisans are ignored; Catholic Church, which strongly collaborated with Ustashe, has now re-emerged as powerful force (S)

headline: As tourism stagnates, Hawaii fights back with a campaign to invigorate its image.
abstract: Advertising column on state-sponsored advertising campaign to lure more tourists to Hawaii, where one in three jobs is directly tied to tourism; state has suffered decline in annual tourist spending in years following its peak of $10.63 billion in 1991; advertising campaign is produced by Ogilvy & Mather, and has tag line, 'The Islands of Aloha' (M)

headline: Mairs & Power Growth Fund
abstract: Article on investing in Mairs & Power Growth Fund, managed by George A Mairs 3d; stocks of Minnesota companies dominate fund; photo (L)

headline: From the Chief Accountant, a Farewell Ledger
abstract: Interview with Dennis R Beresford, retiring chairman of Financial Accounting Standards Board; photo; board's role in compelling companies to recognize cost of retiree benefits noted, as well as Congressional pressure that thwarted proposal to make companies treat value of stock options as expense; Beresford's successor, yet unnamed, will have to be approved by Financial Accounting Foundation, which includes many business executives who are concerned about too-strict standards; appointment must also be approved by SEC chairman Arthur Levitt, who is determined that board remain independent of corporations it regulates (L)

headline: Arafat and Israeli President Hold Talks on Security Cooperation
abstract: Pres Ezer Weizman of Israel meets with Yasir Arafat and says Arafat agreed to revive security cooperation with Israel; says meeting was intended as ice breaker and stresses that he does not seek to supplant Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu; Palestinians say nothing was resolved at meeting and that Arafat agreed to security meetings only if American aides attend (M)

headline: WESTERN MICRO AGREES TO BUY COMPUTER DISTRIBUTOR
abstract: Western Micro Technology Inc agrees to buy Star Management Services Inc for $52 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Will the Wicked Witch someday receive top billing? Did Ford grab an idea from coffee beans?
abstract: Advertising column by Stuart Elliott questions some recent events in advertising, marketing and media (L)

headline: Five 'Forgotten Funds' on a Remember List
abstract: Morningstar Mutual Funds newsletter has come up with its eighth annual list of 'forgotten funds,' five appealing funds that investors have overlooked; funds described (M)

headline: Coffin Company Acquired
abstract: Service Corp International acquires Marsellus Casket Co (S)

headline: General's Words Shed a New Light on the Golan
abstract: Late Defense Min Moshe Dayan, in 1976 conversation with reporter Rami Tal, suggested that during 1967 Middle East war, Israel took Golan Heights for farmland, not for security purposes; Tal kept his notes secret for 21 years, but they were recently published in newspaper Yediot Ahronot; map; photos (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: TOBACCO WARS  Cigarette Taxes: Not Yet  How can society tackle the public-health disaster of teen-age smoking? Well, raising taxes and banning cigarette advertising are two options. But so far, at least, this nation has not moved strongly on either front. In Britain, the new Government said last week that it would ban all cigarette ads and bar tobacco sponsorship of sports events. The White House, meanwhile, grasping for a budget deal, ditched a plan to raise tobacco taxes to pay for children's health care. Yes, this is the White House of Bill Clinton, sworn enemy of smoking, and Al Gore, who delivered that emotional anti-smoking speech at last year's Democratic convention. Mr. Clinton backed down after Senator Trent Lott called the tax a ''deal buster'' in the budget wrangle. But Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a key backer of the cigarette tax, said Mr. Lott was bluffing. ''We would have won this,'' he said.     NATURAL ECONOMICS  Planet for Sale (Not Cheap)  A price tag for nature? A dollar value for our planet? Absurd. If a nuclear disaster makes the earth uninhabitable, we can't exactly stroll into Earth Depot and order a new one. But we live, alas, in a society that simply loves doing studies, loves hunching over calculators and spewing out numbers. So, inevitably, the journal Nature just put the value of 17 ''ecosystem services'' (sounds like Roto-Rooter: ''Here to clean your ecosystem, ma'am'') at, conservatively, $33 trillion. But wait. Beyond the absurdity, there's something to this. We constantly make economic choices about nature -- we just don't focus on the cost. An example: New York City water. It's still good, but getting worse because society made a bunch of economic choices not to protect the watershed. Now the city must spend $660 million to protect the watershed -- unless it wants to spend $4 billion for a water-treatment plant. Another example: a growing region builds malls on a flood plain, and the flooding simply moves elsewhere, with more devastating force. Economic choices everywhere. The point of issuing that obviously debatable number is to remind people that those choices, often nearly invisible, are made constantly.    ENVIRONMENT  Welcome Mat for Polluters?  ''Pollution credits'' have seemed like odd creations ever since they were born in 1990. A company that's less filthy than the law allows need not wait for heavenly recompense -- it can sell its virtuous deed right here on earth, a license for filth that can be snapped up by some less fastidious outfit. Or some benevolent soul can buy credits and simply retire them. But in a new twist at this sooty bazaar, Gov. George E. Pataki is offering pollution credits as little Welcome-to-New-York door prizes for companies that relocate to the state. Environmentalists are not amused.    MARKETING DEALS  Tiger Woods, Blazing  Tiger Woods is having one heck of a run in his 15 minutes of fame. He's young, he's a superstar, and he has stormed the white citadel of golf. Outlandish as it may seem, he may even be bigger than Michael Jordan. (''He's fading,'' one observer decreed.) And is he cashing in! No superstar could get by on a trifling $2 million in golf earnings, but weren't those Nike and Titleist contracts, together worth $60 million, enough? Apparently not. Last week, Tiger Woods signed a five-year contract -- reportedly worth $13 million -- to become a spokesman for American Express. And what does being a golf whiz have to do with credit cards? Oh, you just don't understand marketing.    MANAGED CARE  Reforming Health Reform  The word ''reform'' normally brings to mind something battered with age; welfare, to its critics, fit that description perfectly. But last week a Connecticut legislator used the word in a startling context, talking of ''reforming managed care.'' Huh? Managed health care is still in its infancy -- well, early adolescence, maybe -- and was itself created to ''reform'' a health system in dire need of repair. To many people, though, it, too, already needs repair, and last week Connecticut tried to do just that as legislators passed a bill to let the state overturn managed-care companies' rulings on what treatments they will cover. The industry fought the proposal, saying external review was unnecessary because of in-house appeals processes. But lawmakers were swayed more by testimony from hundreds of customers outraged at being denied what they considered reasonable care.    PRISON HEALTH CARE  Economics Behind Bars  Politicians have this thing about being tough on prisoners. It's not enough to deprive someone of sweet, irreplaceable liberty -- they are determined not to appear to ''coddle'' inmates. New York City's jailers are convinced that many prisoners go to clinics as a social occasion, as a break in the grim routine -- and no doubt some do. But when the Giuliani administration last week proposed charging inmates fees for medical care, it outraged prisoner-rights advocates. True, the fee would just be $3, and would be waived for those deemed indigent. But critics say that's a substantial sum for an inmate with limited resources, and they argue that it would lead to delays in seeking care -- and possibly to far more costly treatment later. With contagious diseases lurking in jails, ''it is pretty stupid'' to make it harder to get care, a Legal Aid official said.    MEDICAL RESEARCH  Progress vs. Progress  Medical research keeps bestowing priceless gifts on humankind -- gifts like the discovery, a decade ago, of a way to screen pregnant women for Down syndrome. But our world takes on a bizarre symmetry sometimes -- even as progress gives, progress can take away. No one can deny that lawsuits have evolved into a high art, but it is an art that is not, well, always used to improve the human condition. Take that Down syndrome test: Dr. Mark Bogart discovered the hormonal link that the test is based on, then patented it, then demanded that laboratories pay him a $9 royalty every time they used it (a fee sometimes higher than a lab's reimbursement), then threatened lawsuits against labs that refused. And even though legal experts don't think the patent will survive court scrutiny -- it's ''a little like patenting Newton's law of gravity,'' one said -- some labs are settling, while others are dropping the test. Progress, full circle.    WAGES AT THE BOTTOM  Catching a Rising Tide  If a civilization is judged by wage inequality, the United States gets dismal marks for its record of the last two decades. For even as executive pay has gone through the roof, the wages of workers in the bottom 10 percent of the wage heap have slid 20 percent, adjusted for inflation. Suddenly, though, in recent months those wages have picked up, now rising faster than inflation -- and faster than middle-income pay. And this, in turn, is luring more people on the fringes into the working world. Why the change? Partly it's the ripple effect of the rise in the minimum wage, but mainly it's just a strong economy creating demand for low-skill workers. Temper your rejoicing, though, for the low-wage worker's lot in life, because the recent upturn makes only a tiny dent in that two-decade loss. And when this economy hits a bump, it won't always be top executives tightening belts.    GRADUATING TO JOBS  Downsizing's Children  Remember downsizing? Remember how some nonbelievers said meekly that corporate America was perhaps overdoing it and might one day, its ranks threadbare, repent of its ruthlessness? To judge by the rosy job picture for college graduates, the nonbelievers were right. Schools everywhere have seen a record number of recruiters this year, and the job offers are descending like desperate confetti. The explanation, to some: companies blew it, and desperately need to replace those workers they laid off a few years ago.

headline: Budget Deficit Narrowed in May
abstract: Federal budget deficit totaled $48.494 billion in May, down from $53.051 billion in May 1996 (S)

headline: For Bosnia, Peace Is Coming Up Empty-Handed
abstract: Civilian administrators in Bosnia have been unable to cajole Bosnian Serbs, Croats and Muslims to cooperate in rebuilding multi-ethnic society destroyed by more than four years of civil war; many acknowledge failures, but say refusal of NATO leaders to arrest people indicted for war crimes or to protect refugees who wish to return, has left them without coercive power to make parties respect peace agreement; also fault international-aid donors for refusing to find adequate money and help to build viable economy; situation in Brcko, where accord has not yet brought peace, described; map; photo (M)

headline: Mini-Vans Facing a Midlife Crisis at Age 14
abstract: * Sales of minivans, archetype of suburban family transportation, are declining after rising steadily for more than decade as increasing numbers of buyers are rejecting soccer-mom image of 1980's that they project; even though mini-vans are roomy, practical and cheaper, buyers are defining themselves more with rugged sport utility vehicles that project image of freedom and individuality; sales of mini-vans, which reached high of 1.3 million units in 1994, declined by 4 percent in 1996; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Burmese Sanctions Get Little Backing in Asia
abstract: US fails to persuade Myanmar's neighbors to join in sanctions against military regime; Asean seems intent on welcoming Myanmar as member this year, although US action has resonated in region (S)

headline: Magellan, a Year Later
abstract: Robert E Stansky, in annual report to Fidelity Magellan fund shareholders, says he has transformed fund into relatively aggressive growth fund, with 96 percent of assets in stock; he has sold off cyclical stocks and bonds acquired by former manager, Jeffrey N Vinik, and cut portfolio turnover rate by more than half; graphs (S)

headline: U.S. Judge Rules Against Marvel
abstract: Bondholders fighting Marvel Entertainment Group's plan to merge with Toy Biz Inc. and emerge from bankruptcy won a round in court yesterday when a Federal judge ruled that the bondholders could take control of the 80 percent stake in Marvel stock that secured the bonds.    The ruling will not take effect until May 23, however, giving Marvel time to appeal.

headline: Geico Chief May Be Heir to an Legend
abstract: Article on financial strategy of Louis A Simpson, head of investments for Geico Corp, auto insurance company that Berkshire Hawthaway Inc owns; says Simpson, whose financial philosophy is similar to Berkshire Hathaway head Warren E Buffett, may be heir to Buffett; tables; photos (L)

headline: An Accord With Total News Is Reached
abstract: Web site, operated by Total News Inc, agrees to stop putting borders--known as frames--around content provided by news organizations, including CNN and Washington Post; Total News site links 1,350 news sites worldwide, but keeps a frame of its own advertising wrapped around the other sites; Total News can continue to link to more than 100 Web sites managed by six companies that sued, but must do so directly; six news companies sued Total News in Federal District Court in Feb (S)

headline: Entering Zaire's 2d City, Top Rebel Puts Off Elections
abstract: Rebel leader Laurent Kabila makes triumphant entry into Lumbumbashi, Zaire's second-largest city, hours after arousing controversy by decision to put off elections there indefinitely and to name relative Governor of Shaba Province, breaking with policy in other areas of moving quickly to hold elections and to put local officials in charge; decision and opposition it has aroused underscores political and ethnic divisions in area that could cause him trouble in future; map (M)

headline: The Ralph Lauren name does its magic, but some analysts say the price could be too rich to last.
abstract: Shares in Polo Ralph Lauren Corp, in an initial public offering, close at $31.50, 21 percent higher than offering price of $26, which itself is higher than range of $22 to $25 that had been expected; some analysts says price is too high to last (L)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None

headline: Hong Kong's Inner Circle: Rich and Autocratic
abstract: Pro-China business tycoons have emerged as power elite in Hong Kong; with Chinese rule to return there on June 30, new elite has emerged to run Hong Kong, one dominated by local tycoons with often anti-democratic instincts, strong financial or ideological ties to Beijing, and skeptical attitude toward accountability to Hong Kong's citizens; Beijing's selection of shipping magnate Tung Chee-hwa as first Chinese to run Hong Kong is clearest signal what Hong Kong's new elite will look like; Paul Yip Kwok-wah, head of new Hong Kong Policy Research Institute, has emerged as central figure in Tung's government-in-waiting (M)

headline: Private Colleges Juggle Aid Formulas To Fill Seats With the Top Freshmen
abstract: Private colleges like Tulane University are offering smaller merit scholarships to larger numbers of applicants to increase enrollment and tuition income without lowering academic quality of entering freshmen; structuring scholarships is apparently the way of the future, as parents seek better value from their five- or six-figure investments in four-year colleges and as all but most selective colleges are forced to focus on problem of attracting good students without losing revenue; Richard Whiteside, dean of admissions at Tulane, comments; photos (L)

headline: MCDONALD'S TO DROP PRICE OF BREAKFAST SANDWICHES
abstract: McDonald's Corp will begin to sell breakfast sandwiches for 55 cents on April 4, kicking off price-cutting campaign the company is counting on to increase its sluggish US sales (S)

headline: New Wireless Shares Inspire Heavy Trading
abstract: Cable and Wireless Communications PLC surges on its first day of trading on London Stock Exchange; shares rise to 306.5 pence a share, up from listing price of 294.5 pence; more than 10.6 million shares change hands (S)

headline: How the F.B.I. Got Its Man, Half the World Away
abstract: Mir Amal Kansi, who was captured by FBI agents in hotel in Afghanistan on June 15, appears in Fairfax, Va, court and is charged with 1993 murders of CIA employees Lansing H Bennett and Frank Darling in Langley, Va; Kansi fled US four years ago, but with strange coalition of CIA operatives, FBI detectives, Pakistani spies and Afghan warriors on his trail, it was only matter of time before US captured him; photo (M)

headline: Bozell and WPP Make Acquisitions
abstract: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt acquires Fair Riley Call Communications; terms undisclosed; Fair Riley is being merged with Bozell Health Care West, to form Fair Riley Call/Bozell; Jackie Reed is named to head Fair Riley Call/Bozell as president and chief executive; Sher Call and Rich Fair, managing partners and creative directors at Fair Riley, and Tim Riley, managing partner and account services director at Fair Riley, will continue in those roles; WPP Group acquires minority stake in Hyper Parallel Inc; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Cambodia Tribunal Is Opposed by China
abstract: As attempts to curtail China's trading privileges failed in the American Congress, Beijing indicated that it would not support a United Nations effort to bring Khmer Rouge leaders to justice.     A Cambodian Government request for help in prosecuting Pol Pot and his associates formally reached the United Nations yesterday. But China  said the issue was an internal Cambodian matter and should be decided by Cambodians.

headline: Q&A/Andrew Lippman / Media Consultant : Internet's Innovative Role
abstract: Andrew Lippman is associate director of Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and director of Digital Life, a Media Laboratory consortium that looks at the online interconnections between objects and people. He is an electrical and computer engineer by training and holds seven patents. He recently spoke with Ken Shulman in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

headline: Trying to Zap the Games That Workers Play
abstract: Workers play computer games on the job, many using Microsoft Windows software, which is pre-installed on most computers and contains various game options; now Antigame program automatically erases game software from computers and their networks; photo; drawing (M)

headline: China Appears To Crack Down On CD Pirating
abstract: After years of ignoring demands from US and elsewhere, China's copyright police are pursuing and arresting pirates of compact disks, even well-hidden ones; began concerted effort in December 1996, notably in Guangdong Province, ackowledged center of copyright piracy, where more than 100 offenders have been arrested and 28 underground factories shut down; is being aided in efforts by paid informers; industry experts say Beijing seems serious about current crackdown, in part because of recognition of dangers piracy poses for China's own legitimate industries; maps (M)

headline: SIMON DEBARTOLO IN DEAL WITH CHELSEA REALTY
abstract: Simon DeBartolo Group and Chelsea GCA Realty Inc say they formed joint venture to buy and develop factory outlet centers (S)È

headline: AMERICAN EAGLE ORDERS 12 ATR PLANES FOR $200 MILLION
abstract: AMR Corp's American Eagle subsidiary orders 12 ATR-210A turbo-propeller aircraft from Aero International Regional, which says order is worth more than $200 million (S)

headline: KMART INTRODUCES PROTOTYPE FOR NEW STORE LAYOUT
abstract: Kmart Corp discloses new store layout that places highly sought items near front of the store and expands selection of food and household goods (S)

headline: France's Premier Says Shaky Finances Put a Brake on Jobs Plan
abstract: Prime Min Lionel Jospin tells Parliament that France's precarious finances will force him to move cautiously on job-creation programs he promised during election campaign (M)

headline: Egyptian Court Overturns Ban On Cutting of Girls' Genitals
abstract: Egyptian court overturns year-old ban on ritual cutting of female genitals in all state and private clinics; maintains ban on cutting as practiced by untrained people in rural villages; Islamic leaders hail ruling; human rights advocates score it (M)

headline: Treasury's Scheduled Auctions Include 3- and 10-Year Notes
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and auctions of 3-year and 10-year notes Tuesday and Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.08 percent and that on the six-month bill was 5.31 percent. In when-issued trading, the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.40 percent, and the 10-year note, 6.67 percent.

headline: Trading of Supercuts Ex-Chief Is Cited
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission charges Supercuts Inc former chairman-chief executive David Lipson with saving $621,000 by trading on insider information; SEC complaint says Lipson sold 365,000 shares in hair-cutting chain in March and April 1995 before disappointing results were made public in May 1995 (S)

headline: Japanese Regulators Order S.& L.'s to Merge
abstract: Regional authorities in Japan have ordered the merger of five savings and loans to rescue the Chogin Osaka Credit Cooperative, the government of Osaka Prefecture said yesterday.

headline: Clinton to Tweak China Over Hong Kong
abstract: Pres Clinton, in move that will undoubtedly irritate China, will meet with Hong Kong democracy leader, Martin Lee, in Washington; meeting follows widespread criticism of Vice Pres Al Gore's decision not to visit Hong Kong during recent Far East trip, and after Lee was warmly received on Capitol Hill (M)

headline: Foreign Troops Protect Albania, but From What?
abstract: Approximately half of 6,000 foreign troops being sent to Albania with UN backing are setting up camps and beginning patrols, amid confusion about reason behind mission; while official reason is to provide humanitarian, relief agencies delivering food report few are hungry and are having little difficulty getting food to those who need it; deployment has made Albanians, already mistrustful of own Government, suspicious; many say real reason may be that Italian and Greek Governments wish to stop outpouring of refugees to their countries; map; photo (M)

headline: CITIBANK BUYING BALANCE OF ARGENTINA PENSION MANAGER
abstract: Citibank NA says it will pay $230 million to $250 million to acquire 51 percent of Argentine pension fund and insurance group, Siembra, that it does not already own (S)

headline: New Records Show the Swiss Sold Arms Worth Millions to Nazis
abstract: Switzerland, still reeling from charges that it helped prolong World War II through financial dealings with Nazi Germany, faces newly documented charges that its arms industry profited from and favored Germany in arms trade worth millions of dollars; is increasingly seen as power that collaborated broadly with Nazi Germany under cloak of neutrality; historian Mauro Cerutti says arms trade has long been widely known, but that detailed accounting, discovered in Swiss archives, is new (M)

headline: I.R.A., Killing 2 Policemen, Cripples the Irish Peace Talks
abstract: Irish Republican Army kills two police constables in Northern Ireland, crippling Irish peace talks; British Government calls off all further contact with Sinn Fein, IRA's political wing; Prime Min Tony Blair says killings signal that IRA and Sinn Fein are not interested in peace and democracy; officers, John Graham and David Andrew Johnston, are shot at point-blank range while on foot patrol in town center of Lurgan (M)

headline: CMS-LED GROUP IN AUSTRALIAN POWER PLANT DEAL
abstract: Group led by CMS Energy Corp will pay $3.81 billion for 75 percent interest in Australian Loy Yang A power station in state of Victoria; NRG Energy Inc will take 25 percent; Victoria is first Australian state to privatize its utilities and to introduce competition into its electricity market (S)

headline: With big publishers absent, can the booksellers' convention remain viable?
abstract: Publishing industry's annual bookselling convention, newly renamed Bookexpo America, faces its 50th anniversary in Chicago as an anxious industry struggles with flat sales and high return rates and continuing decline in number of independent booksellers; most major publishers are not attending; their absence is reminder of residue of ill feeling from legal dispute in 1994, when American Booksellers' Assn went to court accusing some publishers of violating antitrust law by establishing discounting and pricing policies that varied according to size and type of bookseller (M)

headline: NO. 1 STEELMAKER IS CONSIDERING ITS GROWTH OPTIONS
abstract: USX-US Steel Group, largest United States steelmaker, is considering growth options, including acquisitions, joint ventures or alliances (S)

headline: Fidelity Adds Duties For Hill, Holliday
abstract: Fidelity Investments has consolidated corporate and retail advertising at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston; those duties had been divided between that agency and Houston Herstek Favat in Boston; billings estimated at $50 million and $60 million (S)

headline: Wealth Whets Chinese Taste for Freedom
abstract: Patrick E Tyler article examines state of freedom in China today; contends that never in their history have Chinese been as free to flourish, earn and move about their country building networks of commerce and opening markets at home and abroad; notes that Chinese officials, eager to end long political isolation that followed 1989 Tiananmen massacre, argue that Chinese are running their own affairs as never before; says part of great complexity of China today is that even as Chinese are more and more unleashed, they are far from free and far from satisfied about state of their liberties; photos (M)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Consumer Borrowing Feb.    TUESDAY  None

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   Ronald O. Perelman's problems at Marvel comics are well-known. Not so his woes at the Coleman Company, the camping equipment maker. By James Sterngold.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 7/   The issue of soft dollars is raising hard questions in the fund industry, as regulators ask whether brokers should be giving managers free research for trades. By Edward Wyatt.    EARNING IT /Page 12/   Now where did we put those story summaries? They were here just a moment ago. On the Job, by Lawrence Van Gelder.    VOICES /Page 13/   Why should private interests reap the benefits of selling rights to the skies? By Peter Barnes.

headline: $45,000 a Share, $1,500 a Share or $264 a Share
abstract: Profile of Wesco Financial Corp, which is 80% owned by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, and may be of great appeal to investors who like Buffett's approach of taking large long-term positions in few blue-chip comppanies; Westco chairman is Charles Munger, Buffett's 'alter ego'; photo; charts comparing two companies; Wesco's actual operations, which include reinsurance business and steel and metal fabricator, provided just $30 million in net income last year, on revenue of $108 million, tiny sum for company with market capitalization of $1.9 billion; Wesco makes its money from investing, and stock price in the hundreds is far more accessible than Berkshire Hathaway's $45,000 per share (M)

headline: Daimler-Benz to Exhibit An Early-Stage Internet Car
abstract: Engineers at Daimler-Benz research center in Silicon Valley, Calif, on April 30 will roll out Mercedes E420 equipped to give driver and passengers full access to World Wide Web; engineers and programmers note that their 'Web Car' is only technology demonstration and that commercial applications are probably five years or more in the future (L)

headline: Cordiant executives are setting goals for life after 'demerger.'
abstract: As Cordiant PLC proceeds with plans to divide its worldwide agencies into stand-alone companies, some top executives who will direct destinies of separated units are sharing their plans for life after the 'demerger'; one is Michael Bungey, chairman and chief executive of one of the agencies, Bates Worldwide in New York, who will head spinoff that may be named Bates Group of Companies; the other is Kevin Roberts, who last month joined the other agency, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York, as its chief executive; that agency will be principal holding of a company that may be named Saatchi & Saatchi Group of Companies; Roberts and Bungey comment; photo (Advertising column) (L)

headline: Russia Is True to West, in Its Fashion
abstract: Michael R Gordon analysis contends that Russia's talk of new strategic partnership with East is more theater than substance; maintains that Russia looks mostly to West and its financial institutions, like International Monetary Fund and World Bank for money, technology and acceptance (M)

headline: European Nations Are Told They Need Tough Budget Cuts
abstract: European Monetary Institute says efforts by European countries to narrow budget deficits have been unsatisfactory, and governments must be prepared to make painful spending cuts (M)

headline: Host Marriott Services will test tabletop computers at eight restaurants it operates.
abstract: Roundup of business travel news; Host Marriott Services will test rental of tabletop personal computer units hooked up to Internet at some of its airport and highway restaurants; American Airlines devises promotion plan for relatively infrequent fliers; Rand McNally offers package of trip-planning software for business travelers (M)

headline: New Intel Chip Set for Games
abstract: Intel Corp introduces hardware specification for coin-operated video games based on its coming Pentium II chip, hoping to set standard for game creation in both arcade and home consoles; it is chip maker's first foray into coin-operated arcade game technology (S)

headline: Report Links Iran to Suspect In Saudi Attack
abstract: Washington Post reports American and Arab officials have linked high-ranking Iranian intelligence official, Brig Ahmad Sherifi, to bombing in 1996 of US military base in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, in which 19 airmen died (S)

headline: Amasa S. Bishop, 76, Scientist Who Worked in Fusion Physics
abstract: Amasa Stone Bishop, American nuclear scientist specializing in fusion physics who took up environmental causes under United Nations auspices, dies at age 76 (M)

headline: NATO Pact Clouds Fate of Arms Cuts, A Yeltsin Aide Says
abstract: Interview with Ivan P Rybkin, Russian national security chief, who says NATO's decision to expand eastward has hurt chances for Government's approval of latest strategic arms reduction treaty with US; calls parliamentary ratification almost impossible, citing extreme antagonism of many parliamentary deputies; says Washington must probably wait years until new, younger generation wins election to assembly; Russia's failure to ratify accord, which would slash each side's nuclear warheads to between 3,000 and 3,500, would be major setback for Clinton Administration (M)

headline: To Mend Broken Minds: Herbs, Faith and Chains
abstract: Papa Kitoko, traditional healer and leader of Christian-based sect, cares for mentally ill under appalling conditions in Luanda, Angola, city where even basic services have all but collapsed after 20 years of civil war; he comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Kmart-Hudson's Talks
abstract: Hudson's Bay Co, Canada's largest department store chain, is negotiating to buy 36 of Kmart Corp's 123 Canadian outlets (S)

headline: British Company Reports Big Pakistani Gas Find
abstract: British oil exploration company Lasmo PLC says it tapped substantial new natural gas discovery in Pakistan, on the Kirthar field about 60 miles north of Karachi; Lasmo says one of wells at the site could produce more than 60 million cubic feet of gas a day (S)

headline: Ukraine Decides Not to Supply Key Parts for Iranian Reactor
abstract: Ukraine, responding to American and Israeli appeals, decdies against providing turbines for nuclear reactor Russia is selling to Iran; decision is victory for Western efforts to curtail nuclear cooperation with Iran; US officials hope decision will delay Russian project, but do not expect it to prevent sale of reactor (M)

headline: Merger Plan to Form an Italian Apparel Giant Is Called Off
abstract: Marzotto SpA is pulling out of merger with Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali SpA, or HPI, deal that would have united some holings of two of Italy's most prominent families (S)

headline: In a Land of Plenty, Good Health Still Eludes the Aborigines
abstract: Gov Gen William Deane report on precarious state of health of Aborigines is causing growing alarm in Australia; report finds that life expectancy of Aborigines is 15 to 20 years lower than for white population; officials say alcohol abuse is major cause of Aborigines' health problems (M)

headline: After 66 Years, Kodak Dismisses Thompson
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co dismisses J Walter Thompson Co as its advertising agency, ending one of oldest relationships in advertising; Thompson has handled Kodak account for 66 years, and was responsible for creating 'Open me first' and 'Kodak moment' campaigns; Kodak will consolidate all consumer photography accounts at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide; annual spending is estimated at $300 million; photo (M)

headline: Along Rutted Streets, Few Mourn Departure
abstract: Many residents of impoverished Kinshasa hope Pres Mobutu Sese Seko will not return to Zaire; see his exile preventing battle with rebels; life appears nearly normal in city, as it awaits rebels without apparent security precautions; photos (M)

headline: 'Irrational Exuberance'
abstract: News analysis; Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan is providing own answer to rhetorical question posed in December 1996 over whether irrational exuberance had unduly escalated stock prices; is suggesting that run-up in prices may be justified since corporate profits are expected to continue growing sufficiently (M)

headline: Toy Biz Ends Deal to Join With Marvel
abstract: Toy Biz Inc cancels its agreement to combine with some units of Marvel Entertainment Group Inc as part of Marvel's bankruptcy reorganization (M)

headline: Meditrust to Buy Santa Anita Companies
abstract: Meditrust will merge with Santa Anna Companies in order to broaden its scope from owning real estate to operating businesses; stock swap will be tax-free transaction valued at $383 million (M)

headline: A Bad Week Finishes With A Good Day
abstract: Stock market, battered all week, shows new signs of life, rallying to put temporary cap on worst downturn in two years; Dow Jones ends 48.72 points higher, closing at 6,526.07; tables (M)

headline: Ralph Lauren Hopes to Raise $600 Million by Going Public
abstract: Polo Ralph Lauren Corp plans an initial public offering of stock that would raise as much as $600 million (M)

headline: The question is: What is the role of the Ad Council? The answer is: It is under debate.
abstract: Advertising Council in New York is adding longtime agency executive to its top management ranks; S Murray Gaylord, who has worked at such shops as Scali, McCabe, Sloves and Young & Rubicam Advertising, has become executive vice president and general manager of the council, nonprofit organization that coordiates public service campaigns for agency and media industries; role of Ad Council in advertising industry is under debate (L)

headline: Timing the Market, and Proud of the Results
abstract: Investment adviser Gerald Appel, who runs Signalert Corp, discuses his strategy of market timing, interview; photo (M)

headline: Legislators Devise Non-Trade Steps to Press China on Rights
abstract: Informal Republican task force appointed by House Speaker Newt Gingrich reportedly agrees on legislation intended to push China toward democracy and human rights without resorting to economic or trade sanctions; proposals include increased financing of broadcasts to China and pro-democracy projects there, as well as publication of lists of companies doing business in US that are owned by China's military (M)

headline: MCCORMICK SAYS IT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY F.T.C.
abstract: McCormick & Co says it is under investigation by Federal Trade Commission over how it sells its spices to retailers; McCormick says commission is looking into whether its use of exclusivity clauses in certain contracts with retailers violates antitrust laws by stifling competition (S)

headline: Mexican Bank Deal
