abstract: GE Capital Services Mexico SA agrees to pay $26.7 million for Banco Alianza, a two-year-old commercial bank (S)

headline: April Sales Show Retailers Still Lag Behind Economy
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co Retail Composite Index rose 3 percent in April over year earlier; lower-priced stores outperformed other retailers, as they have all year; chart (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SEITEL INC., Houston, plans to sell all but 19 percent of its Eagle Geophysical Inc. unit, which provides seismic services for oil exploration.

headline: Safeco to Pay $2.8 Billion for American States Financial
abstract: Safeco Corp, big West Coast insurer of homes and automobiles, will pay $2.83 billion for American States Financial Corp in transaction that exemplifies insurance industry's shift toward specialization; Safeco will increase its main property and casualty business by nearly 50 percent; American States' parent, Lincoln National Corp, will abandon property and casualty insurance to devote itself to selling life insurance and annuities and to investment management; graphs (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN BRANDS INC.,  Old Greenwich, Conn., said the Internal Revenue Service had approved the company's planned spinoff of its Gallaher Tobacco business as tax free, clearing the way for the transaction.     BOX ENERGY CORP.,  Dallas, an independent oil and natural gas company, has hired Smith Barney Inc. to act as a financial adviser to the company as it reviews its strategic alternatives.     NORTHLAND CRANBERRIES INC.,  Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., agreed to buy Atoka Cranberries Inc. for $28.5 million in cash and debt.

headline: Xerox Is Buying Out a Partner
abstract: Xerox Corp will pay Rank Group about $1.5 billion for 20 percent of Rank Xerox that it does not already own and will change venture's name to Xerox Ltd (S)

headline: SUPPLIER OF AVIATION PARTS AGREES TO BUY A RIVAL
abstract: AAR Corp agrees to buy closely held Cooper Aviation Industries for undisclosed amount of stock (S)

headline: Internet Commerce Pioneer Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Nets Inc, pioneering company in field of Internet commerce, files for bankruptcy protection; Nets is led by Jim P Manzi, former chmn of Lotus Development Corp; Nets ran on-line shopping mall for manufacturers selling basic industrial goods from ball bearings to glue guns (M)

headline: A War-Crimes Trial, but of Muslims, Not Serbs
abstract: United Nations war-crimes tribunal, Hague, hears case against three Bosnia Muslims and one Croat charged with 1992 murder, torture, rape and abuse of Serbs at prison camp, Celebici, Bosnia; charges mirror stories told by survivors of dozens of Serbian-run camps where Bosnian Muslims were held and persecuted; photo (M)

headline: Bonn's Blank Check Buys Hollow Economy
abstract: Special report, The Money Pit, on eastern German economy, which remains fundamentally bankrupt despite over $600 billion in subsidies, tax breaks and support payments for individuals Germany has poured into area since 1990 and $500 billion more in corporate investments; wages have skyrocketed but there are not nearly enough real jobs; unemployment is at 25 percent, growth has almost ground to halt, productivity is low and exports miniscule; economy remains heavily dependent on subsidies, threatening plans for single European currency; western Germans are becoming increasingly angry about paying for subsidies at time when Chancellor Helmut Kohl seeks to cut social benefits to reduce deficit; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Passports to Adventure?
abstract: Funds Watch column warns that typical foreign funds fail to deliver the promised diversification benefits; some funds recommended (M)

headline: Chrysler Seeks to Spur Neon Sales in Japan
abstract: Chrysler Corp will start cash-back program in Japan that will cut sticker price of its Neon model by as much as 15 percent to bolster sales (S)

headline: Security Is Tight for Denver Meeting of Industrial Nations
abstract: Chain link fences and concrete barriers have been built around site in downtown Denver where Group of Seven will hold its three-day summit conference (M)

headline: SMARTALK TELESERVICES PAYS $70 MILLION FOR GTI TELECOM
abstract: Smartalk Teleservices Inc acquires GTI Telecom Inc for $70 million in combination of two makers of prepaid phone cards (S)

headline: DYNATECH SHEDS UNITS FOR $61 MILLION IN CASH AND STOCK
abstract: Dynatech Corp sells three units for $50 million in cash and $11 million in securities; Dynatech sells Computerized Medical Systems Inc, Dynatech Video Group Inc and products and international distribution business of Dynatech Communications Inc; units are sold to three different buyers (S)

headline: More Complex Superchips Put Premium On Designs
abstract: Development of new superchips is spurring broad changes through $130 billion semiconductor industry, with proliferation of companies that do not sell chips but rather their designs; 'chipless' chip companies are springing up like wildflowers in Silicon Valley; Iready Corp, start-up company from San Jose, is seen typical of new breed of Silicon Valley semiconductor company; Iready does not sell chips, but is licensing design of its 'Internet tuner' integrated circuit to others to incorporate into their chips (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: Mastercard Sets Review Lineup
abstract: Mastercard International invites six advertising agencies to compete in review for creative part of its domestic account, with billings estimated at $90 million; account has been handled for five years by Ammirati Puris Lintas, which declined to participate in review (S)

headline: China Trade: Gingrich Asks Shorter Rein
abstract: House Speaker Newt Gingrich says he favors extending China's 'most favored nation' trading status for just six months, instead of usual year, in bid to protect political rights in Hong Kong after Chinese takeover, television interview; says even six-month extension faces opposition in Congress; Rep Dick Armey, House majority leader, predicts close vote on extension, television interview (S)

headline: Clinton Expects Delay on Nafta
abstract: President Clinton does not expect Congress to grant him the negotiating authority to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to Chile and other Latin American countries until next year, his press secretary said today.    ''We are frying a lot of fish right now and the kettle is only so big,'' the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, replied when asked why efforts to renew the President's fast-track trade negotiating authority, which limits Congress to accepting or rejecting broad trade agreeents, appeared to be stalled.

headline: Shucking Oysters: At 5 Cents a Pound, It's a Living
abstract: Fourteen-year-old Fu Chun shucks oysters for a living with her mother in Beihai, small port on China's southern coast, and she illustrates effects of far-reaching economic and social changes sweeping China; rapid economic growth and fresh opportunities to earn modest amounts of money has presented many people with tough choices, like forcing children to work instead of going to school; maps; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Rise in Japan
abstract: Stocks trade higher in Tokyo on May 12; Nikkei index of 225 issues closes up 340.73 points, at 20,143.51 (S)

headline: A Hospital Chain's Brass Knuckles, and the Backlash
abstract: Article on Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, world's largest health care company; says chief executive Richard L Scott has built company with policy of aggressively acquiring hospitals, strictly controlling costs and fiercely competing with established rivals, many of which are not-for-profit operations; holds company's formula has helped it grow in a decade from nothing to $20 billion in revenues, with roughly 350 hospitals, 550 home-health-care offices and scores of other medical businesses in 38 states; opposition to Columbia's bare-knuckled competitive tactics and several Federal inquiries into its financial practices detailed; tables; photos (L)

headline: Little Caesars Wins Four A's Award
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies names Little Caesars Enterprises Inc as recipient of its John O'Toole Advertiser Award, honoring outstanding advertising campaigns over a period of time (S)

headline: Sallie Mae Head to Resign; Hopes to Break Stalemate
abstract: Lawrence A Hough, chief executive of Student Loan Marketing Association, says he will resign from company as soon as successor can be found; Hough is seeking to break what has been bitter, protracted fight for control of the company; announcement comes as organization, known as Sallie Mae, is facing proxy challenge from group of dissident board members (L)

headline: Pharmacia and Upjohn Names Its New Chief and President
abstract: Pharmacia and Upjohn Inc names Fred Hassan as its president and chief executive officer; Hassan takes over from Jan Ekberg, who temporarily filled chief executive's spot after John L Zabriskie's abrupt departure in January; Ekberg will be nonexecutive chairman (M)

headline: Ford and Mazda To Share Underbodies
abstract: Ford Motor Co and its Japanese affiliate, Mazda Motor Corp, agree to make at least two car models using common underbodies (S)

headline: Akzo Deal With Du Pont
abstract: Dutch chemical company Akzo Nobel NV agrees to sell industrial nylon fibers business of its Brazilian subsidiary, Cobafi, to Du Pont Co (S)

headline: Triarc to Cut 50 Jobs
abstract: Triarc Cos Inc will eliminate 50 jobs in sale of all 355-company owned Arby's Restaurants to RTM Restaurant Group; Triarc sells restaurants for $71 million (S)

headline: Reports of Bug in New Pentium Chip Appear on Internet
abstract: Intel Corp will not formally introduce its Pentium II microprocessor until May 7, but World Wide Web is already buzzing with reports of a bug that causes new chip to make errors in some complex mathematical calculations (L)

headline: Independents Have a Weapon Against the 'Big Boxes'
abstract: In fast-growing hardware business, retailing cooperatives like Ace Hardware and Servistar are locked in battle for market share with retail giants like Home Depot; co-op structure has let local hardware stores compete, though their growth has lagged behind big chains; big co-ops include Ace; Cotter & Co, whose members operate under True Value name; Servistar Coast to Coast Corp, and Hardware Wholesalers Inc; hardware dealer Kyle Buikema, who runs five Ace Hardware stores in Chicago area, comments; charts; tables; photos (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said its shareholders approved a 2-for-1 stock split at the company's annual meeting.

headline: WATKINS-JOHNSON TO SELL ITS MILITARY ELECTRONICS UNITS
abstract: Watkins-Johnson Co plans to sell its military electronics units; it has hired Bentley Hall Von Gehr, a California investment bank, to identify potential buyers and coordinate the sale (S)

headline: Punt, Pass and Ponder the Questions
abstract: National Football League teams are increasingly assessing mental makeup of athletes before investing in them; givve prospective draft choices behavioral or psychological tests to see how they might fit in; table; photos (L)

headline: HOLLINGER TO SEEK FULL CONTROL OF NEWSPAPER CHAIN
abstract: Hollinger Inc will offer $660 million (US) to take full control of Southam Inc, Canada's largest chain of daily newspapers (S)

headline: Zurich Group Said to Offer $867 Million For Scudder
abstract: Zurich Group, big Swiss insurer, will announce acquisition of majority control of Scudder Stevens & Clark Inc, money management giant, for about $867 million in cash and significant minority stake in combined company; reportedly plans to include Scudder with its existing money management business to form Scudder Kemper Investments; new entity would be one of world's largest investment companies, with more than $200 billion of assets under management (M)

headline: Dow Surges To End One Of Best Weeks
abstract: Stock prices rise, boosting Dow Jones industrial average to best week in more than five years; Dow gains 44.95 points, closing at 5,703.55, on trading volume of about 469 million shares (S)

headline: An Anatomy Of Autocracy: Mobutu's Era
abstract: Special report, Master of Ruin, chronicles Mobutu Sese Seko's long brutal reign over Zaire, his inveterate meddling in Africa, colossal ego and amassing of enormous wealth, all of which has ended with stealthy departure from Kinshasa in face of rebel conquest; Mobutu's canny courtship of West during cold war, destabilization of neighbors, rapacious corruption and grandiose economic schemes have brought country to ruin; former Belgian Congo, vast in size and potentially rich, has lost roads, health and education systems, electicity and telephones, and reverted to brutishness; Mobutu in early years did forge sense of nationhood among 450 ethnic groups that have French as official language but no commonly-spoken tongue; former army sergeant first seized power in 1960, just after independence, as rivals quarreled, and may have organized 1961 execution of Patrice Lumumba at CIA urging; three decades of autocracy reviewed; photos; chronology (M)

headline: German Software Maker Posts 54% Jump in Profit
abstract: Shares of SAP AG, a German software maker, rise to record after company says first-quarter pretax profit was up better-than-expected 54 percent (S)

headline: Wheat Prices Up as Estimates Of Freeze Damage Are Raised
abstract: Wheat prices surge on reports of freeze damage in Midwest (S)

headline: A Surprise Climb in Inventories Pushes Crude Oil Prices Down
abstract: Crude oil prices tumble on New York Mercantile Exchange after report shows unexpected rise in US inventories, indicating that supplies are outpacing demand from refineries (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Antivirals Inc., Portland, Ore., an initial public offering of 2 million units consisting of one share of common and one redeemable warrant. Paulson Investment Company Inc.

headline: Accounts
abstract: White Lily Foods Co., Knoxville, Tenn., a unit of Pioneer Flour Mills,  to Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., to handle advertising for the maker of flour and baking mixes, which had been handled by West Wayne, Atlanta. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

headline: Back in Time With America's Time-and-Motion Man
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews The One Best Way, by Robert Kanigel, a book about Frederick Winslow Taylor, engineer who introduced stopwatches and 'scientific management' to American factory floor beginning in 19th century; Taylor was not first to study how fast workers could work, but he was first to pose question: how quickly should workers work? and he based answer on his 'scientific' calculations about time, motion and materials; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CAPSTAR BROADCASTING PARTNERS -- Austin, Tex., a radio investment group, said it had signed an agreement to acquire three radio stations in Birmingham, Ala., from Ameron Broadcasting Inc., for $31 million.    COMPAQ COMPUTER CORP., Houston, said its board had approved a plan to repurchase up to 25 million shares. The company has about 274.5 million shares outstanding.

headline: Western Pacific Airlines to Serve Denver
abstract: Western Pacific Airlines Inc will begin service to Denver International Airport on June 29, offering 45 departures daily along with 24 departures by its commuter carrier, Mountain Air Express (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about the high cost of real estate in Hong Kong misstated the price, in United States dollars, of one expensive product there. The product, a box of delicate swallow's nests used in fancy soups, sells for about $2,300, not $17,500.    A chart with the article misstated the recent selling price of a home on Victoria Peak in Hong Kong. As stated in the article, it sold for $70 million, not $170 million.

headline: Veteran Governor to Have Freer Invisible Hand on Rate Policy
abstract: Edward A J George, governor of Bank of England, should have more leeway in adjusting interest rates to try to achieve greater price stability without Government interference thanks to Gordon Brown, new Labor Government's Chancellor of the Exchequer; Brown is giving George and Bank of England full operational independence, something the bank has quietly but unofficially wanted for many years; George has reputation for reliability and toughness; photo (L)

headline: Swiss Eye U.S. Report on Nazi Gold With a Yawn
abstract: Many Swiss are reacting with indifference to Under Sec of Commerce Stuart E Eizenstat's report chronicling Switzerland's wartime dealings as trading center for gold looted by Nazis (M)

headline: New Netscape Web Browser To Offer Push Technology
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp plans to incorporate so-called push technology, which automates the delivery of content, into latest version of its Internet browser; Netscape Communicator, successor to Netscape Navigator browser, will offer push technology through feature called Netcaster; Netscape Communicator will be available commercially by end of June for $59.95 (M)

headline: Zaire Negotiations Collapse as Rebel Balks on Security
abstract: Diplomatic efforts to bring together Zaire Pres Mobutuo Sese Seko and rebel leader Laurent Kabila for talks fall through after day of relentless confusion, after Kabila refuses to fly to offshore vessel for security reasons; Mobutu, who has advanced cancer and cannot walk unassisted, is driven up cargo plank in armored Cadillac to join US envoy Bill Richardson and Pres Nelson Mandela aboard South African ship; photo; map; tensions are high in Kinshasha, as wealthy Zairians flock to hotels in case of panic at rebel assault; rebel units are said to be within 100 miles (M)

headline: German Group to Investigate Claims of Nazi Victims
abstract: Allianz AG, one of Europe's largest insurance companies, promises to investigate claims from families of thousands of European Jews whose insurance policies were confiscated by Nazis in World War II; announcement suggests that German insurance companies are taking more conciliatory stance than Switzerland's banks; lawsuit recently filed in US on behalf of nine people accuses Allianz and six other European insurers of refusing to make good on policies taken out by people who died in Holocaust (M)

headline: Marketers from Ford to La-Z-Boy are hit by a computer-aided outbreak of anthropomorphism.
abstract: Growing number of companies are featuring animals whose bodies and mouths move in convincingly human-like ways in their advertisements; primary reason for boom in babbling creatures is rising sophistication of computer animation; some companies that are using animation include Ford Motor, Nissan, La-Z-Boy and Texaco (M)

headline: Barney's Indicates Other Bids Are Near
abstract: Barney's Inc is close to receiving more takeover offers; asks Bankruptcy Court to let it pay certain breakup fees to potential investor if Barney's rejects its offer for higher one (S)

headline: Shopping for Groceries on Line
abstract: Convenience of ordering groceries by computer is not new; industry pioneer, Peapod, has been in on-line grocery business since 1989 and now has 44,000 customers around country; new generation of companies like Shoplink Inc contend that turning this consumer convenience into money maker will require totally bypassing supermarkets--and their high manual labor costs--by automating ordering, warehousing, distribution and delivery of food to American households; diagram; photo (M)

headline: Metro Pacific Controls Big Philippine Project
abstract: Metro Pacific Corp will pay $203 million for Filinvest Group's 16 percent stake in Bonifacio Land Corp, gaining control of Filinvest Sky City project outside Manila (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICATIONS INC., San Antonio, a broadcasting concern, agreed to acquire 30 percent of American Tower Corp., of Webster, Tex., an owner of domestic wireless communications towers, for $32.5 million.

headline: HERTZ STOCK RISES 15% ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
abstract: Shares of Hertz Corp, car rental unit of Ford Motor Co, rise 15 percent above their offering price in their first day of trading on New York Stock Exchange; more than $480 million is raised on sale of 20.01 million shares at $24 apiece; stock closes at $27.625 (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BROOKS BROTHERS, New York, a subsidiary of Marks & Spencer P.L.C., named Paul Andrew Gitter to the newly created position of director of advertising and loyalty marketing.    CABLEVISION SYSTEMS CORP., Woodbury, N.Y., named Marc Lustgarten chairman of Madison Square Garden. He had been the vice chairman of Cablevision.

headline: Today's Bill Sale Is Only Item On Treasury's Auction Calendar
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.82 percent and a six-month bill was 5.10 percent.

headline: Controversy Diminishes Italy's Clout In Albania
abstract: Recent criticisms of Albania by Italian diplomats heightens tensions in already sensitive relationship betwen both countries; statements have fueled controversy three weeks before Albanian elections, in which outcome could be test of Italy's credibility as international crisis manager; Italy has commanded 6,500-troop multinational peacekeeping force in Albania since country teetered on edge of anarchy earlier in year (M)

headline: South Africa Shedding Ban on Foreign Assets
abstract: South Africans, for first time in more than three decades, will have legal right to own assets overseas; Government, under current budget, is legally obligated after July 1, 1997, to begin lifting strict exchange controls imposed during apartheid era, especially after 1960 Sharpeville massacre and subsequent protests, when confidence in economy tumbled for fear of black revolution; citizens will be allowed to transfer $44,000 abroad at current exchange rates (M)

headline: Unrest in Afghanistan Is Disrupting Plans for Pipelines
abstract: Setback for militant movement known as Taliban in northern Afghanistan is clouding prospects for $2 billion natural gas pipeline from Turkmenistan through Afghanistan to Pakistan; Unocal Corp of US and Bridas Energy Corp of Argentina have been in unusually bitter competition over proposals to build 870-mile pipeline; Taliban has suffered sudden setack, and industry experts again see the chance of persuading institutions like World Bank to finance such a pipeline as elusive as ever; map (L)

headline: In Best Tally Ever, Sinn Fein Wins 2 Seats in Westminster
abstract: Sinn Fein, political wing of IRA, wins two seats in British Parliament in its strongest showing ever in a British election; Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness are elected as Sinn Fein takes seats away from both mainstream Catholic-dominated Social Democrats and hard-line Protestant Democratic Unionists (S)

headline: Iraq Defies U.N. Ban With Pilgrimage Flight to Arabia
abstract: Iraq, for first time, openly defies UN air embargo, enforced against it since Persian Gulf war in 1991, to fly Muslim pilgrims to holy sites of Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia; even though Saudi Arabia remains unabashed foe of Iraqi Government and Pres Saddam Hussein, it is deeply reluctant to deny Muslims to perform haj as custodian of Islam's two holiest sites; Iraqi Government apparently concluded that, like Libya which has defied embargo three times to fly pilgrims to Saudi Arabia, it is not likely to pay any real price for defiance; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.61   5.17        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.13   5.13   4.81        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.38   5.39   5.02        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.63   3.62   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.88   6.86   6.52        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   7.09   7.09   6.81        TELEPHONE BONDS   8.15   8.12   7.92        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.99   5.97   6.03          *Estimated daily average, Telerate  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Paulo Freire, 75, Is Dead; Educator of the Poor in Brazil
abstract: Paulo Freire, radical Brazilian educator, died on May 2 at age 75; photo (L)

headline: Nippon Credit Stock Off Amid Doubt on Overhaul
abstract: Shares of Nippon Credit Bank Ltd fall more than 3 percent, a sign that investors are worried that expected revamping plan will not solve bank's bad-loan problems; revamping plan includes cutting salaries as much as 50 percent and eliminating jobs of one-third of 3,000 workers (S)

headline: News Corporation Says Profits Soared Fourfold in 3d Quarter
abstract: News Corp says earnings rose roughly fourfold in its third fiscal quarter; net income was $330 million (Australian), or $257 million (US), up from $77 million (Australian); sales rose 23 percent, to $3.7 billion (Australian) (M)

headline: U.S. Is Wary of Ban on Land Mines
abstract: Clinton Administration remains wary about international campaign against land mines, reluctant to create breach with Joint Chiefs of Staff, who are not eager to endorse ban on mines; upcoming Washington, DC, gala to raise funds for land mine victims will be hosted by Elizabeth Dole, president of American Red Cross and a potential Presidential candidate (M)

headline: France Suspends Sale Of Film Company
abstract: French Government has decided to suspend sale of Societe Francaise de Production after Havas SA and Compagnie Generale des Eaux withdraw their bid for state-owned film production company (S)

headline: Netscape Chief To Forgo Salary
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp says its chief executive, James L Barksdale, has chosen not to receive any salary or cash bonuses for 1997 because company's stock price has fallen by two-thirds in last year (S)

headline: Penguin Sues Ex-Credit Aide As Embezzler
abstract: Pearson PLC's publishing arm, Penguin Group, has filed civil complaint against its former credit director, Christina Galatro, her husband, Stanley, and collection agency owner, Jerome Bedell, accusing them of embezzling $1.4 million from company; Penguin is blaming Galatro for international bookkeeping scandal that shook Pearson in February, forcing company to take $163 million pretax charge against its 1996 earnings and leading initially to wild fluctuations in Pearson's stock price; American Booksellers Assn sees Galatro as convenient 'corporate scapegoat' for company; ABA is pursuing separate legal inquiry into Penguin discounts offered to bookselling chains; analysts in Britain and rival publishing executives in US cannot understand how junior executive such as Galatro could have concealed such large losses from her superiors and from Penguin's auditors, Arthur Andersen & Co (M)

headline: Winning Friends for Foreign Policy: Albright's First 100 Days
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright's first 100 days in office reviewed; she says public view of her as more accessible because she is woman helps to demystify foreign policy, interview; says she seeks to build popular, bipartisan base for foreign policy, and its costs; photo (L)

headline: ASCEND SHARES SLIDE ON A DELAY IN PRODUCT SHIPMENTS
abstract: Ascend Communications stock falls $6.25, to $41.375, on concern that software problem in chip in its Max networking products line might cause it to miss second-quarter revenue targets; shares of Cascade Communications Corp, which Ascend is acquiring, fall $4.3125, to $28.5625 (S)

headline: XEROX TO BUY REMAINING STAKE IN DELPHAX SYSTEMS
abstract: Xerox Corp agrees to buy rest of Delphax Systems to gain access to its high-speed electronic printing technology (S)

headline: Telefonica de Espana Ends AT&T Alliance
abstract: Telefonica de Espana chooses MCI and British Telecommunications to join its lucrative Latin American operations; pulls out of alliance with AT&T (S)

headline: China, Wary on Mood of Congress, Balks at Opening Markets
abstract: World Trade Organization director, Renato Ruggiero, says China's top leaders want assurances that Congress will not block Beijing's long-sought entry into organization because of allegations of Chinese involvement in campaign finance scandal and growing anti-China mood on Capitol Hill (M)

headline: CBS President Resigns Over Revamping
abstract: Peter Lund, president of CBS television network, resigns after being informed that he will no longer oversee CBS's television stations division; executives say Michael H Jordan, chief executive of CBS and its parent company, Westinghouse Electric, has told Lund that he is reorganizing the company to put 14 CBS stations under direction of Mel Karmazin, chief executive of corporation's radio division (L)

headline: A Boy Is Killed, and All Japan Is Stunned
abstract: Funeral is held for 11-year-old Jun Hase of Kobe, Japan; police believe boy was victim of serial killer; murder has spawned a spate of soul-searching editorials in the national press, wondering whether the fault lies not in one deranged killer, but in society itself; photos (M)

headline: Nokia Says Profits More Than Tripled
abstract: Nokia's profit rose to higher-than-expected 1.452 billion markkaa ($282 million) in first quarter from 399 million markkaa in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 58 percent, to 6.151 billion markkaa (S)

headline: Say No to 'Socialist Ideas,' Chirac Urges
abstract: President Jacques Chirac took charge of his battered conservative coalition's election campaign tonight, appealing on national television to voters in Sunday's elections not to impose a Socialist and Communist Government on him while he was trying to get France ready for the 21st century.    ''Do you want to put yesterday's Socialist ideas back in the saddle?'' he asked earnestly, in a six-minute speech that was the most directly partisan appeal he has yet made in the legislative election campaign.

headline: Toyota Plans Another Buyback
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp will buy back another 100 billion yen, or $793 million, of its shares and raise its dividend (S)

headline: 6 Grand Winners In Ad Competition
abstract: New York Festivals names six grand Best of Show winners at 39th annual international print and radio advertising competition; Jupiter Drawing Room, South African agency, wins most awards (S)

headline: Gallagher Buys an Insurer
abstract: Arthur J Gallagher & Co acquires Tinder & Norwood Inc for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: VF PLANS TO ACQUIRE BRITTANIA BRAND FROM LEVI STRAUSS
abstract: VF Corp signs letter of intent to buy trademarks and existing inventory of Brittania Sportswear Ltd from Levi Strauss & Co; specific terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Yeltsin Basks at Summit; Some Europeans Are Cool to U.S.
abstract: Expanded 'Summit of Eight' opens in Denver, Colo, with Pres Clinton meeting Pres Yeltsin of Russia and trying to soothe European anger over what they see as America's arrogance in NATO and UN; fit-looking Yeltsin seems thrilled just to be at conference of world's most important nations; Yeltsin was invited to summit by Pres Clinton to make NATO expansion easier for Russians to accept; Japanese were annoyed that Clinton decided on his own to invite Russia; photo (M)

headline: David Johnston, 76, Commodities Trader
abstract: David T Johnston, commodities trader and executive who served two terms as chairman of Commodity Exchange in New York, dies at age 76 (S)

headline: PHYSICIAN CORPORATION DISCLOSES NEW MERGER TALKS
abstract: Physician Corp of America is in talks with unnamed partner to be bought for $7 a share, or $266 million (S)

headline: Images of Pain And Despair From a Region Raked by War
abstract: Photos of hungry and exhausted refugees in camps near Kisangani, Zaire

headline: LVMH Reports a Surge In Luxury Goods Sales
abstract: LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton, French retailer of luxury goods, says its first-quarter sales rose 68 percent, to 10.87 billion francs ($1.86 billion) (S)

headline: Safeskin to Expand
abstract: Safeskin Corp, maker of latex gloves, will spend $40 million to expand its manufacturing operations in Thailand; company will spend $20 million this year and another $20 million in 1998 to increase annual production by more than a billion gloves (S)

headline: Panel Urges Deep Cuts in U.S. and Russian Nuclear Arsenals
abstract: National Academy of Sciences says US and Russia should reduce nuclear arsenals to few hundred weapons to lower risk of war and keep other nations from producing huge stockpiles; says nuclear warheads should be seen as fundamentally useless except to deter enemy nuclear attack (M)

headline: U.N. Panel Rules Israel Uses Torture
abstract: UN committee condemns Israeli technques for questioning suspected terrorists, such as violent shaking, painful restraints and sleep deprivation; Israel Amb Yosef Lamdan rejects charge that methods constitute torture; committee acknowledges Israel's 'terrible dilemma' in dealing with terrorist threats to security (S)

headline: When Saving for Retirement Comes With the Job
abstract: COMPANIES have tried almost everything to get employees to sign up for 401(k) plans. They have held seminars, they have cajoled, they have offered matching contributions. Toys ''R'' Us even recruited Geoffrey Giraffe, its mascot, to spur worker interest in the subject.    But what if employers just dispense with the formalities and automatically enroll new workers in 401(k)'s? Unless employees opt out of the plan, they stay in. That is what a small but growing number of companies, like J. C. Penney and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, are doing.

headline: One Jet in Crash Over India Ruled Off Course
abstract: Investigators studying causes of 1996 midair collision between Saudi Arabian Airlines Boeing 747 and Kazak Airlines Ilyushin-76 near New Delhi, India, establish crash occurred after Ilyushin-76 descended nearly 1,000 feet below 15,000-foot altitude assigned to it by Indian air traffic controllers; says deviation put it in direct path of Boeing 747 that took off from New Delhi minutes earlier; accident claimed 349 lives (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * PSINet, Herndon, Va., to Arnold Communications, McLean, Va., for the commercial Internet service provider, whose account had been at Woolward & Partners, San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $3.5 million.

headline: Another Rally In Hong Kong
abstract: Hong Kong stocks rise for second day in across-the-board rally as new index of China shares gives investors fresh reason to buy market's hottest companies; new index rose 7 percent, to 2,865.17 (S)

headline: TV Stars Appear In Anti-Fur Ad
abstract: Ellen DeGeneres and Bill Maher, stars of two television shows on ABC-TV, are appearing together in print advertising for advocacy organization People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals; advertisement supports anti-fur cause (S)

headline: Limited Operating Net Dips, as Expected
abstract: Limited Inc says operating earnings fell 11 percent in fiscal first quarter; net income was $24.9 million in quarter ended May 3; sales rose 2.3 percent, to $1.83 billion from $1.79 billion, but same-store sales or sales in stores open at least a year, fell 4 percent; Toys 'R' Us Inc posts 57 percent gain in its first-quarter, to $29.4 million, from $18.7 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 17 percent, to $1.92 bilion from $1.65 billion; tables (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Parent Time, New York, a joint venture World Wide Web site of the Procter & Gamble Co. and Time Warner Inc., to Multimedia Resources L.L.C., Larchmont, N.Y., to handle its interactive marketing account, which had been handled on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: As It Seeks New Status, Island Helps A U.N. Panel
abstract: Gibraltar Chief Min Peter Caruana supports continue existence of United Nations General Assembly decolonization committee, holding British colony may need international support in its bid for new relationship with Britain and new constitution, interview; colony's residents have rejected independence and oppose reversion to Spanish rule (M).

headline: Carlton of Britain Buys Rank's Film Library
abstract: Carlton Communications PLC acquires film distribution business of Rank Group PLC for $107 million in cash (S)

headline: Argentine Oil Company To Allow Sale of Shares
abstract: YPF SA, Argentine oil company, will allow workers to sell $1 billion worth of shares they received when national Government sold company to private investors four years ago; plan will allow workers to sell shares that they were originally restricted from selling 20 years ago; employees received 35.3 million shares worth $19 apiece; shares are worth $29 apiece (S)

headline: Bonds Rally on Report That Retail Sales Slipped in May
abstract: US Treasury prices are sharply higher; price of 30-year bond rises 26/32, to 98 5/32; yield falls to 6.77 percent, from 6.83 percent on June 11 (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Levitz Furniture, Boca Raton, Fla., to Bozell Retail, New York, a division of the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, as agency of record, succeeding David Cravit & Associates, Chicago, which closed. Bozell Retail will focus on creative, production and media duties for the broadcast portion of Levitz's account, with billings estimated at $25 million.

headline: Family of Pakistani In Killings at C.I.A. Also Seeks a Motive
abstract: Family of Mir Amal Kansi discuss his capture by American agents in Pakistan for 1993 shooting rampage near Central Intelligence headquarters at Langley, Va; say they have no idea of what may have prompted Kansi to have carried out attack that killed two CIA employees and wounded three others; deny published reports that Kansi family may have worked with CIA in 1980's when their home town of Quetta was staging area for American-led effort to channel weapons to anti-Soviet guerrillas in Afghanistan; map (M)

headline: SYBRON INTERNATIONAL ACQUIRES MICROBIOLOGY CONCERN
abstract: Sybron International Corp says its Erie Scientific Co subsidiary has acquired Remel LP for $155 million in cash and assumed debt, expanding Sybron's position in microbiology industry (S)

headline: PANAVISION IN $61 MILLION DEAL FOR FILM SERVICES UNIT
abstract: Panavision Inc agrees to buy film services unit of Visual Action Holdings PLC of Britain for 37.5 million pounds ($61 million) in cash (S)

headline: Company Draws Rich Eco-Tourists to Africa
abstract: Profile of Conservation Corp of Africa, which runs 22 small, isolated and expensive lodges scattered over Africa aimed at European and American tourists visiting to see animals in wild; company, in forefront of eco-tourism, strives to build ties with local residents and aid local economies; Africa, while promoting eco-tourism, is still struggling to build tourism into major economic force; map; photos (M)

headline: Partner Re to Buy a Reinsurer for $950 Million
abstract: Partner Re, a large reinsurance company based in Bermuda, says it is buying French reinsurer Societe Anonyme Francaise de Reassurances for $950 million in deal that would diversify Partner Re from its specialty in coverage of catastrophes (L)

headline: To Asians, Softer 'Karaoke Diplomacy' Plays Better in Beijing
abstract: HONG KONG—  Call it karaoke diplomacy. The lights are dimmed. A bottle of Scotch is passed around the table. The karaoke machine whirls into action and Chinese and other Asian diplomats settle in for an evening of diplomacy away from the glare of the world's news media.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: TODAY  The Newspaper Association of America convention opens in Chicago. Speakers include Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, and Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor.  The finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations meet in Washington.    MONDAY  The Commerce Department reports new-home sales for March.  Earnings reports are expected from Boeing, Safeco and Tyson Foods.    TUESDAY  The Commerce Department reports on durable-goods orders for March.  The Labor Department releases the employment cost index for the first quarter.  The Conference Board releases its consumer confidence index for April.  Earnings reports are expected from Newmont Mining, Pepsico, Tenneco and Textron.    WEDNESDAY  The Purchasing Management Association releases its manufacturing index for April.  The Commerce Department releases its initial estimate of first-quarter growth.  Earnings reports are expected from Cigna and Columbia/HCA.    THURSDAY  The Commerce Department reports on construction spending for March.  The Commerce Department reports on personal income and spending for March.    FRIDAY  The University of Michigan releases its April index of consumer sentiment.  The Labor Department reports on April unemployment.  The Conference Board releases the leading economic indicators for March.

headline: East German Ex-Master of Infiltration Now Can't Even Get Visa
abstract: US State Department, for second time in two years, rejects visa application of former East German sypmaster Markus Wolf, who is seeking to visit US to promote his memoirs; accuses him of ordering or abetting acts of international terrorism (M)

headline: Inflation Rate Down In Western Germany
abstract: Germany's Bundesbank reports that western German consumer prices rose at annual rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent in six months through April, down from 1.2 percent in March (S)

headline: Grace & Rothschild Quits Omnipoint
abstract: Grace & Rothschild Advertising resigns advertising account of Omnipoint Communications, wireless communications services company (S)

headline: Moving the Little House 8 Miles Across the Prairie
abstract: Economics of moving house discussed; moving house can cost from $5,000 to over $100,000, depending on its size and how far it is moved; experience of Dave and Joanne Meeuswen, who spent $18,500 moving house eight miles in Michigan, described; photos (M)

headline: Time Warner's Performance Is Strong Over All in Quarter
abstract: Time Warner Inc says earnings rose 32 percent in first quarter, to $499 million, as revenues climbed more than 46 percent, to $3 billion; company says Carol Wallace has been promoted to managing editor of People magazine, replacing Landon Y Jones Jr, who will become vice president for strategic planning at Time Inc; table (L)

headline: Plan Is Offered To Reorganize Finance Sector
abstract: Clinton Administration introduces long-awaited plan to revamp nation's financial services industry; Administration retreats from its idea of allowing banks to own manufacturers or other nonfinancial companies; analysts say Administration has provided framework for a bill with solid prospects of enactment; plan, outlined by Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin, is attempt to reflect deregulatory changes that have already swept through marketplace, paced by efforts of Federal regulators that have allowed banks and Wall Street to move onto each other's turf; Rubin predicts increased competition in securities, banking and insurance industries will produce savings of as much as $15 billion for consumers (L)

headline: Cordiant Names Outsider to Lead Saatchi Unit
abstract: Cordiant PLC names Kevin Roberts to take over reins of its Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit from Edward L Wax, who will continue as chairman of agency until end of year, when his contact expires (M)

headline: PRICE COMMUNICATIONS IN $168 MILLION DEAL ON PHONE LIST
abstract: Price Communications Corp says it agreed to sell part of its Fort Myers, Fla, customer list that it will soon acquire from Palmer Wireless Inc to Wireless Network LP for $168 million; Fort Myers area has about 382,000 potential customers (S)

headline: ENCORE TO SELL DATA STORAGE UNIT TO SUN MICROSYSTEMS
abstract: Encore Computer Corp agrees to sell its data storage products unit to Sun Microsystems Inc for $185 million (S)

headline: A Scoundrel or a Scapegoat?
abstract: Joseph Jett, former superstar bond trader at Kidder, Peabody & Co, has been fighting for three years charges that he engineered $339 million in phony profits; he and his lawyers cite cryptic recorded conversations as evidence that top officials at Kidder, Peabody urged him to help deceive General Electric, Kidder's parent at the time; arbitration hearing and trial last summer on SEC charges against Jett produced mass of intriguing documents and sworn testimony; at the least, the evidence adds up to extraordinary chronicle of negligence by Kidder officials who were supposed to supervise Jett; dozens of people were aware of central component of his strategy, and no one objected to it as being based on an outright fiction; administrative law judge's ruling is expected in next few months; photos (L)

headline: Why U.P.S. Is Flying A New Package Deal
abstract: United Parcel Service is using three of its cargo jets during idle hours to test passenger market; is working to speed up time it takes to transform planes back and forth from cargo to pasenger use; all flights so far have been charters, but UPS weighs starting scheduled service; UPS Airlines president Thomas Weidemeyer comments, interview; photos (L)

headline: Rare Look Uncovers Wartime Anguish of Many Part-Jewish Germans
abstract: Bryan Mark Rigg, American researcher at Cambridge University, probes Nazi era fate of Christian Germans who had Jewish forbears, unexplored and confounding chapter in history of Holocaust; finds Hitler personally declared larger-than-expected number of such part-Jews 'of German blood' to retain valuable military officers; former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who hid existence of Jewish grandfather to remain in air force, lauds Rigg's effort; photo (M)d

headline: U.N. Refugee Chief Warns Zaire Crisis a 'Nightmare'
abstract: Sadako Ogata, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, says she is pleased that US is finally asserting leadership in Zairian crisis (M)

headline: Zaire's Absent President Keeps the World Guessing
abstract: Zairian Pres Mobuto Sese Seko remains in Gabon after talks with French-speaking African leaders, touching off new speculation that he will give up trying to stay in power in face of Laurent Kabila's advancing forces; UN officials in Geneva accuse rebels of blocking investigation of reported massacres of Rwandan Hutus in eastern Zaire; photo of evaucation train; map; more than 40,000 Hutus are reported trapped along Congo River border with Congo (S)

headline: Excel Agrees To Buy Telco For $1 Billion
abstract: Excel Communications Inc agrees to acquire Telco Communications Group Inc for $1 billion in cash and stock (M)j

headline: Dropping a Sure Path to the Top To Follow a Technological Dream
abstract: Profile of Alex J Mandl, who resigned as AT&T Corp president and chief operating officer to head firm now renamed Teligent Inc; he is model for growing number of executives who have abandoned AT&T's cozy clutches for lucrative but risky life of entrepreneur; hopes to offer wireless phone and Internet access to small and medium-size businesses using fixed-wireless technology; photo; tables; drawing (M)

headline: GREAT WESTERN HOLDERS SAID TO BACK MEETING DEADLINE
abstract: H F Ahmanson & Co says that holders of required majority of shares of Great Western Financial Corp voted in favor of requiring Great Western to hold its annual shareholders meeting by May 6; on April 24, Great Western said Ahmanson double-counted more than five million votes in its referendum of shareholders; Ahmanson has made hostile $6.01 takeover bid for Great Western (S)

headline: EDISON INTERNATIONAL PLANS TO BUY BACK MORE SHARES
abstract: Edison International plans to buy back up to $1.5 billion of its common shares; move is in addition to program to buy back $800 million of stock (S)

headline: PHOENIX NETWORK TO MERGE WITH US ONE COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Phoenix Network Inc, reseller of long-distance telephone service, will merge with closely held US ONE Communications Corp in $94 million deal; Phoenix Network will be surviving entity (S)

headline: Washington National Set For Its New Terminal
abstract: Article on new $400 million terminal at Washington, DC's National Airport, which opens on July 27 (M)

headline: Pope Returns Today to His Changed Polish Home
abstract: Pope John Paul II is set to visit his Polish homeland for his longest and what may be his valedictory pilgrimage; there is widespread hope that Pope's 11-day visit will help heal old wounds and prepare Poles to live as part of a united Europe; photo (M)

headline: A History Lesson for the S.E.C.
abstract: Comment by Edward H Fleischman on Securities and Exchange Commission's consent order, labeling as illegal a market mechanism--hedging--that has become essential to small- and big-business financings; says this will likely put a chokehold on ability of many businesses to obtain financing and will certainly make capital more costly (L)

headline: In Congo's Restive Capital, New Government Sows Resentment
abstract: In the week since he seized power and declared himself President of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Laurent Kabila has stirred resentment in Kinshasa against his nascent Government; the former rebel leader has not addressed the nation since ousting long-time dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, and has remained virtually invisible; also being weighed against Kabila are the eviction of hundreds of former military officers from their homes to house his own troops, crackdown on public demonstrations, ban on 'immodest' dress by women, and looting by rebel soldiers; also problematic is that rebel soldiers are ethnic Tutsi from eastern Zaire, who speak Swahili rather than Lingala, and belief that among them are thousands of Rwandan and other foreign Tutsis (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MARINE DRILLING COS., Sugar Land, Tex., an oil and natural gas drilling contractor, acquired approximately 90 percent of the outstanding shares of Deep Sea ASA of Norway for $49 million.

headline: The Economy and Markets Frail, Thais Breed Skeptics
abstract: New Thai finance minister, Thanong Bidya, moves to repair country's troubled financial system, but analysts remain unconvinced that Government has found resolve to rejuvenate faltering economy; analysts say Government has yet to overcome political infighting that has held up meaningful economic change; express skepticism over Cabinet approval of plan that would allow property loans to be repackaged and sold as securities, and to promote mergers among ailing financial companies; photo (M)

headline: PART-OWNER OF PRICE COMMUNICATIONS QUESTIONS DEAL
abstract: Franklin Resources Inc says Price Communications Corp's purchase of Palmer Wireless Inc might not be in shareholders' best interests; Price Communications offered in May to acquire Palmer for $880 million, including several hundred million of debt; Franklin has 31.5 percent stake in Price (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Today  I.B.M. sponsors its Financial Services Industry Conference, with speakers including Mickey Kantor and Alvin Toffler.    Monday  Earnings reports are expected from Toys ''R'' Us and Limited.    Tuesday  The Federal Open Market Committee meets to set interest-rate policy.  Earnings reports are expected from Dayton Hudson, Talbots and Ann Taylor.    Wednesday  The Commerce Department reports the trade deficit for March.  The Treasury Department reports the April budget statement.  Earnings reports are expected from Computer Associates and Harnischfeger.    Thursday  The Labor Department reports initial claims for unemployment insurance.

headline: ANHEUSER-BUSCH TO INCREASE STAKE IN MEXICAN BREWER
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Companies agrees to pay $605 million to increase its stake in Grupo Modelo SA, brewer that makes Corona beer, ending disagreement about the price and paving the way for it to gain control of the company (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Data Show Strong Growth But Little Inflation  Evidence mounted that the economy accelerated markedly in recent weeks, though inflation appeared to remain in check.

headline: Slap at Yeltsin as Legislators Veto Return of Art Booty
abstract: Russian Parliament, in extraordinary step, overrides Pres Boris N Yeltsin's veto and votes to retain art treasures and government archives taken by Russian troops during World War II; vote by upper house, deferred earlier to avoid embarassing Yeltsin during visit to Germany, follows earlier vote to overturn veto by more populist lower house (M)

headline: CHATTEM TO BUY ASSETS OF SUNSOURCE INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Chattem Inc agrees to buy assets of Sunsource International Inc for shares and cash, moving maker of health care products into expanding market for dietary supplements (S)

headline: Big Coke Bottler Expanding In New York and Canada
abstract: The world's largest soft-drink bottling company, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., grew even larger yesterday, agreeing to acquire from the Coca-Cola Company its Canadian and metropolitan New York bottling companies for $1.01 billion in cash plus $650 million in assumed debt.     The acquisition will allow Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is 44 percent owned by the Coca-Cola Company, to cut costs, control its distribution and market its products more efficiently in New York and Canada after the acquisitions, analysts said.

headline: Irish Vote Seems to Give Top Post to Opposition Chief
abstract: Final results from Irish parliamentary elections favor opposition leader Bertie Ahern, who is expected to be new Prime Minister; his coalition wins 81 seats, short of 84 needed for outright parliamentary majority, but it is expected to win over handful of independent members to form new Government; coalition led by incumbent Prime Min John Bruton wins 75 seats; photo (M)

headline: Spanish Judge Tries New Tactic to Fight Pollution: A Jail Term
abstract: Factory owner Jose Puignero begins serving four-year jail term for illegally dumping chemicals into river Teg, first such punishment in Spain; repeatedly ignored Government warnings, contaminating river and local groundwater and wells; broad movement to press for his release is under way in Barcelona area, one of Spain's most industrialized and polluted areas, where factories have violated pollution rules for decades (M)

headline: Lawmaker Questions Plans Of Mortgage Enterprises
abstract: Repr Jim Leach, chairman of House Banking Committee, calls on Clinton Administration to review investments and expansion plans of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp, Federal National Mortgage Assn (Fannie Mae) and Federal Home Loan Bank System; Leach's request comes several days after Banking Committee learns that Fannie Mae is weighing plan to give insurance to homeowners that would pay off their mortgages if they died or became disabled (M)

headline: Anheuser-Kirin Venture
abstract: Anheuser-Busch enters joint venture with Kirin Brewery Co market Kirin Lager, Kirin Ichiban and Kirin Light in US; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: In a Bahrain Port, No More Sailors on the Town
abstract: US orders sailors on its vessels docking in Manama, Bahrain, to be denied liberty after US Embassy receives information that terrorist attack might be planned against US forces in Bahrain; map (M)

headline: WALDEN RESIDENTIAL IS ADDING DREVER PARTNERS
abstract: Walden Residential Properties Inc says that it agreed to buy closely held Drever Partners Inc for $380 million in securities and assume $290 million in debt, forming one of largest public owners of apartment properties in United States (S)

headline: Prices for Crude Oil Tumble On Report of Rise in Inventory
abstract: Crude oil prices tumble on New York Mercantile Exchange after American Petroleum Institute report shows that inventories in US are rising even as refiners operate close to maximum rates; coffee prices fall (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.59   5.24        3-MO. headline: Publishers Hire Marketing Executive
abstract: Magazine Publishers of America hires Christine Miller as executive vice president for marketing (S)

headline: KIA GROUP HOPES TO RAISE $893 MILLION IN LAND SALES
abstract: Kia Group, citing cash flow problems, hopes to raise some $893 million through real estate sales; says nonbanking institutions have called on its units to make debt payments in response to unsubstantiated reports that Kia has financial problems; asks South Korea to minimize damage from such speculation (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CARIBBEAN CIGAR CO., Miami, the maker of the Havana Classico and Signature Collection brand cigars, acquired most of the assets of American Western Cigar Co. Terms were not disclosed.     ECHLIN INC., Branford, Conn., an auto parts manufacturer, bought Industria e Comercio Brosol Ltda., a Brazilian maker of automotive fuel systems, for $20 million.

headline: Surprise Favorite Emerges in Race to Be the Tories' Next Leader
abstract: William Hague emerges in increasingly divisive selection progress as surprise favorite to lead Britain's Conservative Party; wins backing of Peter Lilley and Michael Howard, who had been committed to back John Redwood to deny post to Kenneth Clarke; Redwood defies calls to drop out of race (M)

headline: American Topics
abstract: Hospitals that once routinely performed autopsies have been cutting back to save money. But if anything, family members are quicker now than in the past to insist on answers about how their relatives died. They may suspect malpractice, or want to learn whether a genetic defect was involved.

headline: $640 Million Acquisition Of Hotel Group Is Expected
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc is expected to announce plans to buy Wyndham Hotel Corp for about $640 million (S)

headline: France Telecom Value Is Put at $31 Billion
abstract: France Telecom SA's initial public offering, France's biggest ever, will value company at 180 billion French francs ($31 billion) (S)

headline: DAMARK'S EARNINGS FORECAST SENDS STOCK UP 24%
abstract: Shares of Damark International rise 24 percent after company says it expects earnings to beat analysts' second-quarter estimates by about 30 percent to 34 percent; stock rises $2.86, to $14.98 (S)

headline: Rising Outcry in Argentina as Economic Reform Pinches
abstract: Violent demonstrations over economic conditions and policies are increasing in Argentina; Government of Pres Carlos Saul Menem is being pressured to loosen its economic policies, which have brought fiscal stability and tremendous growth but have failed to produce new jobs and better social conditions for many people; photo (M)

headline: A China Share Frenzy Blooms In Hong Kong's Tulip Mania
abstract: Market Place: Hong Kong's latest fast-buck scheme reaches market and climbs like a rocket as shares of one of China's celebrated red chip companies, Beijing Enterprises Ltd, goes public and more than triples in price; just a few weeks before Hong Kong is to revert to Chinese control on July 1, phenomenon known as tulip mania is sweeping British crown colony; tulip mania occurred in Holland 350 years ago when tulip bulbs assumed staggering value, but when it became clear that tulips were just tulips, realization wrecked havoc across much of Dutch economy; early stages of tulip mania are spreading over Hong Kong; last week, frenzied investors emptied bank accounts and lined up for hours for a chance to by stock in Beijing Enterprises, which is owned by Beijing city government; red chips, as Chinese companies are known, are Hong Kong's latest tulip; red chips have recorded staggering gains for a year; index of 41 such mainland companies is up 127 percent since June 1996, the overall market 30 percent; graph; photo (L)

headline: Pollution Politics: Clinton's Choice
abstract: John H Cushman Jr analysis contends that Pres Clinton has confronted two most important environmental questions of year: how to slow global warming and how to tighten Clean Air Act; maintains that he satisfied environmentalists in his constituency on issue of smog and soot, but deeply disappointed many of them on question of climate change; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: * John McNamara was named to the new post of vice president for client services and managing director of the New York office at Western Direct, the direct response media-buying group of Western International Media, owned by the Interpublic Group. He had been senior vice president and group media director at Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam.

headline: Germany Finds Its Soil Still Sprouts Neo-Nazis
abstract: 24-year-old Kay Diesner, once unassuming teenager, has transformed himself into violent German neo-Nazi who is charged with murder following what police call rampage of politically inspired violence in February 1997; case reflects suspicion among investigators that after Government crackdowns in early 1990's, Germany's far-rightists went underground, either as loners like Diesner or in small ananonymous cells; photo (M)

headline: Fiat's Earnings Increased 10.4% Last Year
abstract: Fiat SpA says profits rose 10.4 percent in 1996, which is higher than expected; for 1996, company earned 2.37 trillion lire ($1.39 billion), up from 2.15 trillion lire in 1995; for first quarter of 1997, pretax profit rose nearly 7 percent, to 495 billion lire, from 464 billion lire in period a year ago; operating profit fell 11 percent, to 450 billion lire; sales in first quarter gained 5.3 percent, to 20.84 trillion lire (S)

headline: They're Off and Running, but With Whose Money?
abstract: Gwen Bennett's fight for control of Vernon Downs race track in upstate New York outrages victims of pyramid scheme allegedly run by her husband, Patrick Bennett, through his Bennett Funding Group; it owed $1 billion to banks and to 12,000 investors when it collapsed last year; bankruptcy trustee says $600 million is missing, including $4 million that Patrick Bennett used to buy stake in small company that owns race track; Bennett situation shows how widespread and unexpected the consequences of hugh financial collapse can be, and how they can seem to overwhelm system supposed to deal with them; photos (L)

headline: YELTSIN DISMISSES 2 MILITARY CHIEFS FOR RESISTING CUTS
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin abruptly dismisses Defense Min Igor N Rodionov and Chief of General Staff Gen Viktor N Samsonov, lambasting them for resisting spending cuts and restructuring of armed forces; invites television cameras to meeting of defense advisers to capture his scathing criticism; Yeltsin also reaffirms his goal of cutting military spending to about 3 percent of GNP by year 2000, from about 5 percent now; move is part of broader shift on economic policy, as reformers push for budget cuts, lower tax burden on industry and tighter controls over energy and transportation monopolies; Boris Y Nemtsov and Anatoly B Chubais, leading reformers, are named to Security Council; hard-liners in Parliament denounce military dismissals; photos; Gen Igor D Sergeyev is named acting Defense Min (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Continues Its Surge, But Technology Stocks Fall  Stock prices generally continued to climb, allowing the Dow Jones industrial average to again rewrite the record books.    Despite some weakness in the broader market, particularly in technology stocks, investors' appetite for blue-chip issues was unabated. The Dow industrials gained 60.77 points to close at a record 7,539.27. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 10.35 points, to 1,401.69. $(Page D8.$)

headline: 4 at Syracuse Finance Firm Indicted in Pyramid Scheme
abstract: Federal Government files 43-count indictment against Patrick R Bennett, former chief financial officer of Bennett Funding Group, and three other men for allegedly engaging what it says is one of biggest securities fraud cases in American history and large-scale attempt to cover it up; says scheme cost more than 12,000 investors and 200 banks nearly $750 million dollars; says many elderly lost life savings in scam that extended to 46 states; says Bennet and co-defendants sold investments in office equipment leasing contracts that were, in some cases fictitious, already pledged to other investors or as collateral to institutions; others charged identified as brother Michael Bennett, Charles T Genovese and Gary Peiffer (M)

headline: OUTBOARD MARINE OMITS DIVIDEND AFTER $7.3 MILLION LOSS
abstract: Outboard Marine Corp omits its dividend for current quarter and hires Salomon Brothers for assistance after loss of $7.3 million, or 36 cents a share, for its fiscal second quarter ended March 31 (S)

headline: U.S. Could Bar Mexico Official Over Narcotics
abstract: Clinton Administration weighs revoking visa of Manilo Fabio Beltrones, Governor of Sonora, Mexico, identified in American intelligence reports as associate of powerful drug traffickers (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * MRM World Group, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., agreed to acquire Scherer Team, Starnberg, Germany. Terms were not disclosed. Monika Scherer, 46, who founded Scherer in 1981, will continue to head the agency as general manager. MRM is devoted to direct and relationship marketing.

headline: FOUNDATION HEALTH SYSTEMS TO REPURCHASE STOCK
abstract: Foundation Health Systems Inc to repurchase 4.55 million of its shares from California Wellness Foundation, charitable entity created in 1992 to allow company to convert its Health Net unit to for-profit status (S)

headline: Global Central Bank Says It Held Gold Looted by Nazis
abstract: Swiss-based Bank for International Settlements confirms its gold transactions with Germans after World War II included looted gold and ingots re-smelted in Nazi Germany to disguise their origins; is organization of central banks formed in 1930 to organize reparations payments by Germany for its actions during World War I; was run in 1940's by American, Thomas McKittrick, who Treasury Department suspected was helping Axis powers escape US efforts to freeze funds that were helping Germany to conduct war (M)

headline: ENRON FORMING VENTURE WITH ENEL OF ITALY
abstract: Enron Corp and Enel SpA, Italy's state electricity utility, say they will form $2.9 billion power-generating venture to take advantage of opportunities in Europe's electricity market (S)

headline: Israel's Central Bank Lowers Interest Rate
abstract: Bank of Israel cuts rate at which it lends to bank 1.2 percentage points, to 12.7 percent; acts after Israeli Cabinet votes to widen shekel's trading band (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COS., St. Louis, agreed to take an undisclosed minority stake in the closely held Widmer Brothers Brewing Co., Portland, Ore., and distribute its beer, gaining a bigger piece of the growing United States specialty beer market.    EXAR CORP., Fremont, Calif., the integrated circuit maker, said it would take a $9 million pretax reserve in its fourth quarter to end a 1995 wafer-production agreement with a metal-parts supplier and write off equipment it provided.

headline: Islamic Scholar Seeks to Oust Cairo Professor Over Writings
abstract: In a new sign of tension beneath the surface of Egyptian society, a prominent Islamic scholar has begun a campaign to oust a leading professor at Cairo University from his post on grounds that his writings have insulted Islam and ''contradicted the clear teachings of the Koran.''    The accusations against the professor, Hassan Hanafi, are the most serious against an Egyptian intellectual since a case involving Nasr Abu Zeid, a fellow Cairo University professor who was ordered by an Egyptian court in 1995 to divorce his Muslim wife. That action came in response to a complaint filed by a group of religious leaders who asserted that his teachings showed that he had renounced Islam.

headline: Disney Second-Quarter Profit Exceeds Analyst Expectations
abstract: Walt Disney Co posts earnings for its second quarter that are stronger than expected; net income was $333 million in contrast to loss a year earlier of $25 million; revenue grew nearly 21 percent, to $5.48 billion from $4.54 billion; table (M)

headline: Home-Services Alliance Forms
abstract: Utilicorp United Inc, Peco Energy Corp, AT&T Corp and ADT Ltd form Energyone LLC to sell electricity, natural gas, Internet access and home security services in single package to customers; Utilicorp and Peco will sell package in own areas and venture will sell it as franchises to other utilities (S)

headline: U.S. Restrictions on Exports Aid German Software Maker
abstract: German software company's rapid growth stems from United States Government's restrictions on exports of encryption technology; encryption technology is big battleground in evolution of electronic commerce and Internet, but American companies are blocked from exporting advanced encryption programs because American security agencies, including FBI, fear they will lose their ability to monitor communications of suspected terrorists or criminals; this has allowed Brokat Informationssysteme GmbH and handful of other European companies to carve out booming business, selling powerful encyption technology around the world with no competition from American companies; American computer industry has complained about situation and US Government has relaxed some restrictions, but not enough to allow US companies to compete fully with European companies; photo (M)

headline: In Texas, Labor Is Feeling Trade Accord's Pinch
abstract: Texas border economy by many measures is depressed, and officials in border towns blame North American Free Trade Agreement; in Mexican border states, hundreds of factories have opened since NAFTA took effect; job losses to Mexico are accelerating, especially among workers already at bottom in pay and skills; since treaty took effect at beginning of 1994, losses, mostly to Mexico but some to Canada, have grown by more than a third each year; Labor Department total of 124,000 includes record 7,600 jobs lost in April alone; Clinton Administration officials say that lower trade barriers with Mexico and higher American exports still leave Americans with far more new jobs than they are losing; they say layoffs are more the result of peso's crash in late 1994 and lowered cost of Mexican labor than trade agreement; tables; photos (L)

headline: Coca-Cola is introducing a pithy new campaign for its fast-growing Sprite soft drink.
abstract: Coca-Cola Co is introducing series of pithy ads for its Sprite soft drink brand, and is increasing its campaign budget, to capitalize on popularity of the drink, which is fastest-growing brand in the country; ads were created by Lowe & Partners/SMS (L)

headline: Treasury Schedules Bill Sales
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    Bond traders said that by the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the interest rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.02 percent and a six-month bill was 5.23 percent.

headline: TV Makeover in Romania: It's Not Just Cosmetic
abstract: Interview with Andreea Gheorghita, well-known Romanian news anchorwoman who returned to job at TV Romania after absence of three years; had quit job because of Government manipulation of media; photo (M)

headline: Metromedia to Sell Film Units To MGM for $573 Million
abstract: Metromedia International Group agrees to sell its film and television units to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc for $573 million in cash; Metromedia will sell its 2,200-title film and television library, along with Orion Pictures Corp, Goldwyn Entertainment Co and Motion Picture Corp of America studios; MGM agrees to sell pay-TV rights in Germany, for as many as 600 films, to Kirch Group for estimated $300 million to $500 million; MGM says agreement with Kirch does not include Metromedia library (M)

headline: Washington Post Co.'s On-Line Venture
abstract: Washington Post Co will team with Citysearch Inc to develop new site on World Wide Web for Washington, DC, area news and information; new site will be owned and administered by the Post company's electronic media subsidiary, Digital Ink Co, while Citysearch will contribute technological expertise (S)

headline: 17 Indicted in Computer Chip Theft Case
abstract: Seventeen people, linked by Federal prosecutors to Asian organized-crime syndicates, have been indicted in Los Angeles for participating in what is described as country's largest robbery of computer chips; defendants were named in sealed indictment handed up on May 29 and disclosed on June 2; armed robbery of Pentium chips, made by Intel Corp, and of motherboards took place on May 16, 1995, at Centon Electronics; stolen components are valued at $10 million; eleven of defendants are also charged with robbery on May 3, 1995, of $400,000 worth of chips from Multi-industry Technology Inc; authorities say organizer of robberies is John That Luong (S)

headline: Chaim Herzog, Former Israeli President, Dies at 78
abstract: Chaim Herzog, Israel's outspoken President from 1983 to 1993, dies at age 78; photo (M)

headline: For Now, U.S. Insists on Limiting New NATO Members to 3
abstract: US defies most NATO allies and announces its determination to limit first wave of alliance's expansion to Hungary, Poland and Czech Republic; 9 of 16 NATO members have favored including Romania and Slovenia (M)Ø

headline: As Iran Votes for a President, Choice Is Tradition or Change
abstract: Iranians go to polls to choose new President, with much clearer choice than they have had in 18 years since Islamic revolution began; one candidate, Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, Speaker of Parliament, is viewed as favorite of mullahs; his principal opponent, Mohammed Khatami, has broken with revolutionary tradition by suggesting that he favors loosening social control and opening country to outside cultural currents; although ultimate power in Iran is held by councils of clergymen, prospect that high official would even advocate reforms has energized millions of voters; photos (M)

headline: Cloning of Humans? Unethical, EU Panel Decides
abstract: BRUSSELS—  The cloning of human beings is "ethically unacceptable" and should be prohibited by law, but genetic research on human embryos as well as research into animal cloning should be permitted under strict conditions, a European ethics panel said Thursday.

headline: A diverse political group backs choice for auto insurance.
abstract: Peter Passell column on diverse political group that is co-sponsoring Auto Choice Reform Act, a bill introduced this week that would allow motorists to give up their right to collect legal damages for pain and suffering in auto acciddents; says Joint Economnic Committee of Congress estimates motorists could save $45 billion each year under the bill if they agreed to waive their rights to sue for pain and suffering; holds vote on bill is unlikely this year; drawing (M)
